1242

ARMS ACT, 1878 AND ARMS RULES, 1924

Citation: 40 DLR (AD) 170,40 DLR 251, 40 (AD) 170,44 DLR 110,41 DLR 524, 4I DLR 524, 40 DLR 493,44 DLR 159,43 DLR 150

Case Year: 1878

Subject: ARMS

Delivery Date: 2018-01-08

Arms Act, 1878
 
Sections 16 & 18—
Appellant was neither given any notice of enquiry nor was he given any hearing before cancellation of arms—Enquiry undertaken on a sprawling private complaint made by the local upazila Chairman.
No emergency or any other compelling situation  preventing  giving of notice of enquiry lo the appellant—Nothing on record to show that any specific case was started against the appellant involving alleged misuse of revolver —Inquisitorial nature of enquiry aggravating the degree of unfairness—Principles of natural justice to be observed in proceedings affecting "the person or property or other right of parties concerned "—court adds a rider to the observance of the principle of natural justice that so far as exercise of power under section 18 of the Arms Act is concerned, the absence of a prior notice or hearing may not always invalidate the order passed thereunder if the security of the public peace is involved.
Sk. Ali Ahmed Vs. Secretary, Home Affairs 40 DLR (AD) 170.
 
Sections 16(1) and 19(1)—
The  Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Shariatpur had no jurisdiction whatsoever to cancel the license s of the guns in question under section 18(a) of the Arms Act or under any provision of the Arms Rules of 1924. As the license s of the guns in question were not cancelled by any legally competent authority such as the District Magistrate or by any authorised officer to whom he is subordinate as required under the provisions of Arms Act or the Arms rules, cancellation thereof by the SDO is illegal. Conviction under sections 16(1) and 19(1) of the Arms Act read with section 26 of the Special Powers Act is not sustainable in law.
Anawar  Hossains. Vs State  40 DLR 251.
 
Section 18—
Cancellation and suspension of license for arms—The necessity of recording reasons by the appropriate authority in writing for the cancellation of the license to be emphasized as a general rule—If the appropriate authority chooses not to make its order a speaking one and merely relies on the materials on record, its order stands a greater risk of being struck down. 
Sk. Ali Ahmed Vs. Secretary Home Affairs 40 (AD) 170.
 
Section 18—
Orders passed by the District Magistrate cancelling license s of guns of the petitioners without giving them any notice and opportunity of being heard and giving no reason for cancellation are illegal being violative of the principal of natural justice.
Rezaul Karim (Md) Vs. Ministry of Home Affairs 44 DLR 110.
 
Section 19A—
Uncorroborated testimony of an accomplice cannot be basis of conviction of an accused.
Kazi ibrahim Vs State 41 DLR 524.
 
Section 19A—
A person cannot be convicted on surmises and conjectures and from any analogical deduction.
Kazi Ibrahim VS. State 4I DLR 524.
 
Section 19(f)—
Appellants leading the police to place of occurrence and recovery of arms—Appellants cannot be held guilty of the charge of unauthorised possession of arms under section 19(f) of the Arms Act.
Abdul Khaleque Vs. State 40 DLR 493.
 
Section 19(f)—
Recovery of arms—culpability—mere knowledge of the accused that the arms were lying at the spot pointed out by him in the absence of evidence that he himself kept the same there or that he had exclusive possession over it, he cannot be made liable under section 19(f).
Abul Hashem Master Vs. State 44 DLR 159.
 
Arms Rules, 1924
 
Column 2 of the Table Schedule I as amended by notification No 896—Section II dated Dhaka the l9th November l973—The decision in this case having depended on findings of facts as to whether the seized arm were recovered from the possession of the petitioner, whether the same came within the exception provided for and covered by amnesty, if any, declared by the government, the extraordinary power to prevent the abuse of process of the court is not required to be exercised.
Hossain Mohammad Ershad Vs. State 43 DLR 150
1243

BURDEN OF PROOF

Citation: 6 BLD (AD) 174, 7BLD (AD) 1.Ref. Safdar Ali Vs. Crown 5 DLR (FC) 107, 9 BLD (AD) 110, 9 BLD (HCD)502, 11 BLD (HCD) 423, 12 BLD (HCD) 429

Subject: BURDEN OF PROOF

Delivery Date: 2018-07-08

BURDEN OF PROOF

 

Onus of proof — Special knowledge — If the maid-servant had died in any other circumstances other than by kicking it was within the special knowledge of accused Mokles Mridha on whom lay the onus to prove the circumstances — The conduct of the accused is highly in­criminating in that it is he who was the master of the maid-servant and it is in his house that she suddenly died, although she got no ailment prior to her death and it is he who hurriedly buried her — Evi­dence Act (1 of 1872) S 106 Abdul Hakim Vs. Mokles Mridha and others 6 BLD (AD) 174. 

Presumption of innocence of the ac­cused — Fundamental principle of a criminal trial — The accused shall be premused to be innocent and he is not re­quired to adduce any evidence to prove his innocence and the entire burden of proof of his guilt lies on the prosecution alone — Although law does not require a particular number of witnesses to prove a case, the rule of prudence requires cor­roboration of a solitary witness — Evi­dence Act (1 of 1872) Ss. 101 and 102 Muslimuddin and others Vs. The State. 7BLD (AD) 1.Ref. Safdar Ali Vs. Crown 5 DLR (FC) 107.

Burden of proving exceptions — The defence suggestions that the occurrence of murder took place in their land — The suggestion, if established, would entitle them to the right of private defence of person and property — The onus to establish this plea is upon the accused and the court shall presume the absence of any circumstances which bring their action within the exceptions of the offence of murder — To discharge this onus they did nothing except making a suggestion and led no evidence to show that the incident took place in their land — It was the duty of the defence to file as exibit the complaint petition of their counter-case or at least submit it as a part of their state­ment before the court — They simply re­lied upon the omission of the 1.0. to seize any alamat from the place of the occur­rence — In view of this position the Courts below rightly rejected the plea of the right of private defence — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 105 — Penal Code (XLV of 1860) S 300 — Code of Crimi­nal Procedure (V of 1898) S 342 Tayeb AH and others Vs. The State 9 BLD (AD) 110.

 

Burden of proof — Criminal Trial — The burden of establishing the guilt of the accused is always on the prosecution and it must prove every link in a chain of evi­dence as well as every ingredient of the offence beyond reasonable doubts — Evidence Act, (1 of 1872) S 101. Md Nasir alias Nasir Vs. The State 9 BLD (HCD)502.

 

Burden of proof — Defence has no duty to prove anything — It is the duty of the prosecution to prove its case beyond all reasonable doubts — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) Ss. 101 and 102 Kazi Ibrahim alias Ibrahim Kazi Vs. The State 11 BLD (HCD) 423

Burden of proof — It is always the burden of the prosecution to prove its case beyond reasonable doubts and this burden never shifts — The failure on the part of the defence to prove the defence p\ea does not react on the defence case and the prosecution must stand on its own legs — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) Ss. 101 and 102 Dabir Talukder Vs. The State 12 BLD (HCD) 429

1244

MUSLIM FAMILY LAWS ORDINANCE, 1961

Citation: I BLD (HCD) 163, 8 BLD (HCD) 189 Ref. ll)83 BCR (HCD) 239

Case Year: 1961

Subject: MUSLIM FAMILY LAW

Delivery Date: 2018-08-27

MUSLIM FAMILY LAWS ORDINANCE, 1961 (VIII OF 1961)

 

Muslim Family Laws Ordinance, 1961— Accused contracted a second marriage on 17 .8. 75 during the subsistence of an existing marriage — After the dissolution of Local Bodies by P.O.7 of 1972 no amendment in the definition of "Arbitra­tion Council", "Chairman" and "Union Council" having been made and no person having been appointed to discharge the function of the Chairman under the Ordinance, Sections 6 and 7 of the Ordinance have been rendered nugatory — There was no competent authority from whom the accused was required to take permission for the second marriage and as such he cannot be convicted of an offence U/S 6( 5) of the Ordinance — The Muslim Family Laws Ordinance (VIII of 1961) Ss. 2, 6 and 7 - The Bangladesh Local Councils and Municipal Commi­ttees (Dissolution and Administration) Order (P.0.7 of 1972), Arts .3 and 6 Farooque Mia Vs. Tahera liegum I BLD (HCD) 163.

 

Punishment for polygamy — When to be awarded — For awarding punishment for polygamy a finding as to the absence of the previous permission of the Arbitration Council is necessary — Muslim Family Laws Ordinance 1961, (VIII of 1961) S 6  Abul Basher Vs Nurul Nabi others 8 BLD (HCD) 189 Ref. ll)83 BCR (HCD) 239.

1245

ABATEMENT

Citation: 3 BLD (AD) 10, 10 BLD (HCD) 270, 6 BLD(AD)62.

Subject: ABATEMENT

Delivery Date: 2018-07-02

ABATEMENT

Abatement — Judgments pronounced by the High Court Division from which no appeal preferred and judgments by the Appellate Division before the Proclama­tion of March 24, 1982 have not abated and will remain effective and enforceable ___ Appeals being continuation of Writ Petitions, judgment of the High Court Di­vision will abate to the pending appeals ___ Proclamation of Martial Law dated March 24, 1982 Clause (g) Bangliulesh and another Vs. Md Salimullah and Bangladesh Vs. Hamidul Huq Chowdhury and others 3 BLD (AD) 10.

Abatement — It is well settled that there is no finality to a judgment or decree when it is under appeal, an appeal being a continuation of the suit — The whole suit becomes subjudice and consequently the suit abates with the abatement of the appeal Government of Bangladesh Vs. A. Wahed Sikder and others 10 BLD (HCD) 270.

 

Abatement — Attia Forest (Protection) Ordinance (XXXIII of 1982) and Ss 3, 4 and 20 of the Forest Act (XVI of 1927)___ Abatement of a legal proceeding challenging the validity of the notifica­tions constituting reserved forest known as Attia Forest — There is no scope for challenging the validity of the notifications of 1927 under the Forest Act (XVI of 1927) constituting reserved forest after the Promulgation of the Attia Forest (Protection) Ordinance (XXXIII of 1982) — All judgments, decrees or orders in respect of Attia Forest shall have no force and all suits, appeals and other legal proceedings challenging con­stitution of Attia Reserved Forest shall abate — Independently of the Attia Forest (Protection) Ordinance, the Noti­fication of 1927 constituting a reserved forest known as Atia Forest was a valid one Bangladesh Vs. Abdul Baset Mia, 6 BLD(AD)62.

1246

ACCOMPLICE

Citation: 11 BLD (HCD) 432 Ref. 21 DLR 684, 12 BLD (HCD) 495 (503) Ref. AIR 1948 (Lahore) 27; AIR 1954 (SC) 322; 37 DLR 278, 1 BLD (AD) 296, 12 BLD (HCD) 3 45

Subject: ACCOMPLICE

Delivery Date: 2018-07-02

ACCOMPLICE

Accomplice — The uncorroborated testimony of an accomplice cannot be the basis of conviction of an accused though those statements could be considered for finding out whether there existed inde­pendent witnesses to corroborate the same Kazi Ibrahim alias Ibrahim Ka:.i Vs. The State 11 BLD (HCD) 432 Ref. 21 DLR 684

 

Accomplice — Decoy witness — It is well settled that to establish a case of bribery against an accused for having ac­cepted marked currency notes from a de­coy witness employed by the police in furtherence of a trap, it is not a sufficient proof that the marked notes passed from the decoy witness — In a case of this kind it is of utmost importance that there should be independent corroboration of the statements of the decoy witness that the money was received by the accused person for an illegal purpose. A. K. M. Moklesur Rahman Vs. The State 12 BLD (HCD) 495 (503) Ref. AIR 1948 (Lahore) 27; AIR 1954 (SC) 322; 37 DLR 278

ACCUSED

Right of Accused — Right given to the accused for getting copies of statements U/S.161 Cr.P.C. is a valuable right — Failure to supply such copies causing prejudice to the accused vitiates the trial — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) Ss. 161 and 162. Government of the People's Republic of Bangladesh Vs. Zahir & others 1 BLD (AD) 296.

 

Conduct of the accused — Abscon-dence — Conduct of the accused cannot be accepted as the basis of his conviction but it can lend support to other evidence, oral or circumstantial, besides the con­duct The State Vs. Badaruddin 12 BLD (HCD) 3 45

1247

APPEAL

Citation: 2 BLD (HCD) 93, 6 BLD (AD) 198 Ref. AIR 1935 (PC) 89; AIR 1960 (SC) 748; PLD 1967 (SC) 545, 7 BLD (HCD) 345 Ref. 3 BCR (HCD) 239; 22 DLR (SC) 263; 25 DLR (Dhaka) 330, 8 BLD (HCD) 503 Ref. PLD 1959 (SC) 119; 11 DLR (SC) 200, 2 BLD (HCD) 116. Ref. PLD 196

Subject: APPEAL

Delivery Date: 2018-07-03

APPEAL

Criminal Appeal — Appeals are crea­tures of statutes — There is no appeal against conviction and sentence passed by the Labour Court — Such an appeal is in­competent — Employment of Labour (Standing Orders) Act (VIII of 1965) S 26.

Labour Court 'trying a case under the provisions of Standing Orders Act is not invested with powers of a Magistrate 1st Class — Labour Court is not an inferior court — High Court Division has no re-visional jurisdiction to interfere with the conviction and sentence passed under the Standing Orders Act — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 439 — Em­ployment of Labour (Standing Order) Act, (VII VIII of 1965 of 1965) S 26 Anisuzzaman & ors. Vs. Chairman, 1st Labour Court & anr. 2 BLD (HCD) 93

 

Criminal Appeal — Disposal only on the question of sentence without deciding the appeal on merit — In a Criminal ap­peal a duty is cast upon the appellate court to dispose of the appeal on merit — Without giving its finding as to the con­viction it is not permissible to dispose of the appeal on the ground of sentence only, notwithstanding any concession made by the counsel — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 423 Mil JashimuMn Vs. The State 6 BLD (AD) 198 Ref. AIR 1935 (PC) 89; AIR 1960 (SC) 748; PLD 1967 (SC) 545.

Judgment in Criminal Appeal — Ex-parte disposal in the absence of the Advo­cate of the appellant — It is a well set­tled principle of law that for disposal of a Criminal appeal the presence of the Ad­vocate of the appellant is not essential but still then the Court is to write down the judgment in accordance with the provis­ion of Section 367(1) of the Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 367).

Judgment by the Appellate Court is to show the application of the mind inde­pendently — The Appellate Court is to formulate the points for determination, consider the evidence with reference to the points in issue and give decision thereon with reasons — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) Ss. 367 & 424 Ahul Bashar & ors. Vs. The State 7 BLD (HCD) 345  Ref. 3 BCR (HCD) 239; 22 DLR (SC) 263; 25 DLR (Dhaka) 330

Withdrawal of Criminal Appeal —

The right of appeal is a creature of statute and is a privilege — If a prisoner having filed an appeal from the judgment of con­viction elects not to pursue the appeal and wants to withdraw it, the court should not insist that the appeal should be heard on merit — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 423 Nasiruddin Mia Vs. The State 8 BLD (HCD) 503 Ref. PLD 1959 (SC) 119; 11 DLR (SC) 200

 

POWER OF APPELLATE COURT

Power of Appellate Court — Resto­ration of possession — An appellate court is competent to pass an order for restora­tion of possession in an appeal against the order of conviction — No illegality com­mitted by the Sessions Judge in allowing the petition for restoration of possession — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 522(3) Sorab Ali ors. Vs. The State 2 BLD (HCD) 116. Ref. PLD 1960 (Dhaka) 23; AIR 1957 (Cal) 390; AIR 1960 (Mysore) 24

 

Criminal Appeal — Power of the Ap­pellate Court — Meaning of the word "finding" — It is the result of a judicial examination into matters of fact — The expression "may alter the finding" clearly empowers the appellate court to consider the entire evidence, both as regards fact and law, to substitute its own finding — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 423(1 )(b) Nabir Md alias Nabiruddin Vs. The State 2 BLD (HCD) 153 Ref. 6 DLR (FC) 65; PLD 1952 (Lahore) 11.

 

Criminal Appeal — Disposal without discussion of evidence — Its dismissal without writing a full fledged judgment is not proper — There should have been discussion of the evidence before affirm­ing the conviction of the appellants — There being no discussion about the nature of the offence or the part played by the individual accused persons the impugned judgment cannot be sustained — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 423 Sirajaddoula alias Md Sirajaddoula ors. Vs. The State 4 BLD (AD) 213

1248

ABSCONDING — ABSCONDING ACCUSED

Citation: 1 BLD (HCD) 286, 4 BLD (AD) 193 Ref. PLD 1969 (SC) 89; SCMR (1970) (Vol. Ill) 351; PLD 1974 (SC) 65, 8 BLD (HCD) 251.

Subject: ABSCONDING — ABSCONDING ACCUSED

Delivery Date: 2018-07-02

ABSCONDING — ABSCONDING ACCUSED

Absconding — Absconding accused __ Abscondence of the accused is a relevant fact unless the accused explains his conduct, abscondence may indicate guilt of the accused — Evidence Act ( 1 of 1872) Ss. 8 and 9. Mobarak Hossain Vs. The State 1 BLD (HCD) 286.

 

Abscondence of an accused — Ab­scondence of an accused is corroboration of the direct evidence of the eye witnesses connecting the accused with the crime but it cannot be treated to be corroboration of the confessional statement of another ac­cused so as to base thereon conviction of the absconding accused — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) Section 8 Amir Hossain Howlader Vs. The State 4 BLD (AD) 193 Ref. PLD 1969 (SC) 89; SCMR (1970) (Vol. Ill) 351; PLD 1974 (SC) 65

 

Abscondence of accused — Condi­tions necessary to treat accused as ab­sconders — The accused could not be re­garded as absconding as they were on bail and as warrant of arrest was directed to be issued but there was no execution of the warrant nor any return or report in that regard. Md Sabuj Vs. The State 8 BLD (HCD) 251.

1249

BIAS

Citation: 2 BLD (AD) 39, 3 BLD (AD) 251 Ref. 48 (AC) 187

Subject: BIAS

Delivery Date: 2018-07-08

BIAS

Bias — It is well-settled that in the case of bias the crucial test is whether there is any likelihood of bias — It is not necessary to show that the judge was, in-fact, biased — It is enough if the accused might reasonably form the impression that the judge will not give the case an unbi­ased hearing Khondker Mushtaque Ahmed Vs. Bangladesh 2 BLD (AD) 39

Bias — What it means — It denotes a departure from the standard of even-handed justice which the law requires from those who occupy judicial offices or those who are commonly regarded as holding quasi- judicial offices, such as an arbitrator — It is well settled that not only bias but even a real likelihood of bias demands that the case or matter should not be heard by the judge con- cerned Moazzem Hossain, Deputy Attorney General Vs. The State 3 BLD (AD) 251 Ref. 48 (AC) 187

 

 

1250

BAIL

Citation: 1 BLD (HCD) 66, 2 BLD (AD) 182, 2 BLD (AD) 183, 5 BLD(AD) 217, 7 BLD (AD) 91, 7BLD (AD) 154, 8BLD(AD)21, 8 BLD (AD) 208, 9 BLD (AD)2, 9 BLD (AD) 3, 9 BLD (AD) 12, 9 BLD (HCD) 520. Ref. 1969 (Pak) Cr.L.J 422; PLD 1967 (Lahore) 1302; 20 DLR (WP) (Lahore) 7

Subject: BAIL

Delivery Date: 2018-07-08

BAIL

 

Bail — Court cannot demand deposit of a sum of money instead of furnishing bail bond for release of the accused on bail — Granting of bail with a condition which cannot possibly be complied with tantamounts to refusal of the bail — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) Ss. 499 and 513 R. K. M. Reza Vs. The State 1 BLD (HCD) 66

 

Bail — refusal on mere apprehension of absconding — In the absence of any facts or materials mere apprehension that the accused may abscond does not justify the refusal of the bail to curtail the liberty of a citizen — Bail was granted by the Appellate Division till the conclusion of the trial but the trial court was given full liberty to deal with the question of bail, if misused Md, Laik alias Kayum Vs. The State 2 BLD (AD) 182.

 

Bail — When can be granted — Facts alleged constitute offence under Sections 302/149 of the Penal Code and there is continuing dispute between the parties and the trial is likely to commense within a short time — In such circumstances bail cannot be granted. Ful Mia & ors. Vs. The State 2 BLD (AD) 183

 

Bail — When there is dispute between parties over properties — When there exists a dispute between the parties over properties and there is pendng ltitigation in the civil court — Bail should not be refused to the accused — Code of Crimi­nal Procedure ( V of 1898) S 498 Syed Mahhuhur Rahman & anr. Vs. Md Abdul Matin & anr. 5 BLD(AD) 217

 

Bail — Exercise of judicial discretion—Other accused alleged to have committed the same offence being on bail, the refusal of bail to the appellants by the learned judges without considering this fact and further failing to notice the cir­cumstances that there was specific allega­tion against the appellants cannot be said to be a proper exercise of discretion in rejecting the prayer for bail of the appel­lants — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 498 Firoj Ali & Vs. The State 7 BLD (AD) 91

 

Bail — Cancellation when not proper—The Special Judge did not exercise his discretion properly in cancelling the bail of the appellant merely upon the appre­hension expressed by the prosecution as to his possible abscondence, particularly when he did not do so during the last six years when he had been on bail — In the circumstances of the case the High Court Division was not justified in rejecting the application for bail summarily — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 497(5) Sajalendu Das Vs. The State 7BLD (AD) 154.

 

Bail — When it is reasonable to grant it — There is apprehension that the trial may be further delayed and the appellants will suffer prolonged custody — In the facts of the case it will not be unreason­able to allow the appellants to remain on bail till the tirlal commences — It wil be for the trial court to see whether the ap­pellants should continue on bail during the trial — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 498 Ashraf AH Mondal & ors. Vs. The State and anr. 8BLD(AD)21.

 

Bail — Prayer for bail in a pending appeal — Whether the appellant's bail was properly refused upon a correct as­sessment of facts — The seems that the High Court Division ignored facts stated in the petition — Having regard to the good academic background and future career of the appellant, there was enough justifiable reason to let him go on bail — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 426(2) Nurul Islam alias Bablu Vs. The State 8 BLD (AD) 208

 

Bail — Whether refusal of bail on the ground that prima facie there was no ille­gality in the trial is proper — The appel­lant was tried in absentia and convicted under Section 420 of the Penal Code and sentenced to R.I. for 7 years and a fine of Taka 35,000.00 — He surrendered to the court and was granted bail — The court erred is not allowing withdrawal of the case against him — In the peculiar cir­cumstances of the case the appellant is entitled to bail, particularly when there is hardly any chance of his abscondence — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 498 Shahjahan All Tara Vs. The State 9 BLD (AD)2

 

Bail — Bail to appellant on condition of payment of fine whether sustainable— Payment of fine involving a huge amount of money may not be possible and the purpose of granting bail may be defeated if payment of fine is made a condition for the bail — This is why the court has been given the discretion to stay realisation of fine pending disposal of the appeal — The impugned order for payment of fine as a condition for the bail is not supportable either in law or on the principle of reasonableness — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 426 M(L Iqbal alias Salim Vs. The State 9 BLD (AD) 3.

 

Bail — When no material against the accused gathered during investigation — The appellant ought to have been en­larged on bail when he was not named in the FIR. and the police could not gather any material against him although the in­vestigation has been going on for over a year — The appellant shall remain on bail till the commencement of the trial, if any—   Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 498 Sree Kalyan Kumar Chowdhury Vs. The State 9 BLD (AD) 12.

 

Bail — Right of bail — Whether a per­son convicted of a bailable offence is en­titled to bail as a matter of right — In a case of bailable offence the under-trial prisoners are entitled to bail as of right — But in the case of a convict he cannot claim bail as of right — It is the absolute discretion of the court to refuge or grant bail to the convicts — Of course this discretion of the appellate court must be exercised judicially — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) Ss. 426(1) and 496 Shamsul Hoque Pramanik & ors. Vs. The State 9 BLD (HCD) 520. Ref. 1969 (Pak) Cr.L.J 422; PLD 1967 (Lahore) 1302; 20 DLR (WP) (Lahore) 7.

 

Rejection of bail petition — After rejection whether remedy lies only in an appeal — The learned Judges of the High Court Division were not right in taking the view that once a petition for bail is rejected no further application for bail can be made and the remedy lies only in an appeal — It is also not right to say that in the facts, as in the present case, (enter­tainment of bail petition and granting of bail after the same was rejected by a Division Bench) an application for bail could not be filed before the Vacation Judge and that he had no jurisdiction to grant interim bail — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 498 A. Wahab, Advocate Vs. The State 10 BLD (AD) 50

 

Bail — Interim bail pending appeal — Interim bail can not be allowed to con­tinue for an indefinite period — There is no reason for further continuation of in­terim bail simply because the appeal against conviction is pending — The ad-interim will continue for a period of only six months and appellant shall surrender to the bail bond unless within this period his appeal is disposed of — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 498 Abdul Hakim Howlader Vs. The State 10 BLD (AD) 126

 

Bail — Ad-interim — Appellant's duty-steps to be taken for early disposal of the appeal — The Appellate Division granted ad-interim bail for a limited period indi­cating expeditious disposal of the appeal — The appellants taking advantage of the bail sat over the matter unconcerned — Procrastination proved and deprecated — In such circumstances, the court declines to continue ad interim bail for indefinite period — Parties directed to take steps for early disposal of the appeal within specified time during which the appel­lants would be on bail Azjmul Huq alias AzizmI Haque & ors. Vs. The State 10BLD(AD)205.

Bail and cancellation of bail — Case and counter-case over the self-same incident — Co-accused Chunnu Chowdhury against whom cognizance has been taken under Section 302 of the Penal Code is already on bail — High Court Division while issuing Rule also issued a suo motu Rule to show cause as to why the bail granted to co-accused Bakul Howlader should not be cancelled — While disposing of the main Miscella­neous case, the High Court Division cancelled the bail of accused Bakul Howlader making the suo motu Rule absolute — In the absence of any new material the High Court Division did not exercise its judicial discretion properly in cancelling the bail of the appellant — The High Court Division failed to consider the questions of the case and counter case over the self-same incident one co-accused was already on bail, absence of any allegation of tampering with evidence and absence of any new material produced by the state justifying cancellation of the bail_Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 498 Bakul Howlader alias Shamsul Alam Vs. The State 10 BLD (AD) 290.

 

Bail — Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) - Sections 366, 376 and 4(C) of the Cruelty to Women (Deterrent Punish­ment) Ordinance, 1983 — Cancellation of bail suo motu by the learned Special Tribunal in the absence of any allegation of the abuse of the privilege of bail is arbitrary and violative of the principle of natural justice Ahmed AU & ors. Vs. The State 10 BLD (HCD) 451

 

Bail in a murder case — Appellant en­larged on ad-interim bail by the High Court Division but subsequently cancelled on a mere apprehension of the chance of tampering with evidence — Cancellation of the bail for the sake of fair and proper investigation of the case and apprehension of tampering with evidence not based on any tangible evidence — No allegation of misuse of the privilege of ad-interim bail__The High Court Division failed to ex­ercise its discretion properly in not con­firming the adinterim bail granted to the appellant — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 498 Penal Code (XLV of 1860) S 302 Gazi Abdul Hadi Vs. The State 11 BLD (AD) 64

 

Bail — Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) Section 25B( 1) — The trial court convicted and sentenced the appellants for two years — The High Court Division admitted the appeal for hearing but re­jected the prayer for bail —.The Appel­late Division granted bail on the consid­erations that the sentence is for only two years and the disposal of such an appeal normally takes time — The High Court Division failed to properly exercise its judicial discretion in rejecting the prayer for bail Md Dhanu Mia & am. Vs. The State 11 BLD (AD) 96.

 

Ad-interim bail — Granted by the lower appellate court to move the High Court in revision — The High Court Di­vision refuged the prayer for bail and di­rected the appellants to surrender and thereafter to file a separate application for bail — The Appellate Division held that when the appellants were already on bail granted by the lower appellate court, the order of the High Court Division rejecting the prayer for bail is not proper and is not in keeping with the normal practice and procedure that is traditionally followed. Baneaz,uddin Ahmed < ors. Vs. The State 11 BLD (AD 239.

 

Bail — Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) Section 32 — Penal Code (XLV of 1860) Section 376 — Prosecution case is an unusual one — Pending hearing of the appeal the appellant was allowed bail for a limited period. Md Shamsul Haque Vs. The State 11 BLD (HCD) 64.

 

Bail — Drug Control Act, 1990 (XX of 1990) — Section 19(1) Table 1 (Ka) — Special Powers Act, 1974 — Accused petitioner convicted and sentenced to suffer R.I. for three years — The material prosecution witnesses did not support the recovery of heroin from the possession of the accused petitioner — The petitioner was enlarged on bail by the High Court Division pending hearing of the appeal. Md Atiar Rahman Vs. The State 11 BLD (HCD) 291

 

Bail — Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) Sections 32 and 25B — Petitioner convicted under Section 25B for two years — Petitioner was all along on bail during the trial and never misused the privilege of bail — Little chance of early disposal of the appeal — Petitioner was enlarged on bail. Nahab Ali Vs. The State 11 BLD (HCD) 494.Ref. 11 BLD (AD) 96; 43 DLR (AD) 119.

 

Bail — Special Powers Act, 1974 (XIV of 1974) — Section 32 of the Special Powers Act is not an absolute bar against granting of bail — Even when the prose­cution opposes the prayer for bail the court can release an accused on bail when it is satisfied that there are no rea­sonable grounds for believing that the ac­cused is guilty of the offence alleged — The High Court Division summarily re­jected the appellant's prayer for bail on an erroneous view of Section 32 of the Special Powers Act. Madar Chandra Basu Vs. The State 12 BLD (AD) 129

 

Bail — Section 497 Cr.P.C. — Section 497 of the Code of Criminal Procedure enjoins upon the court to exercise its ju­dicial discretion in the matter of granting bail for ascertaining whether the materi­alsplaced before the court by the prose­cution are of such a tangible nature that if left unrebutted, they may lead to the inference of guilt of the accused. A. K. M. Mosharaf Hossain Vs. The State 12 BLD (AD) 175

 

Bail — In a pending appeal — In a pending Criminal appeal when the appel­lant files an application for bail, the court should not ordinarily issue any rule — The court may grant or refuse the bail or ask the petitioner to came up with a separate petition and may hear the state, if necessary, before disposing of an appli­cation for bail Sree Manju Kumar Saha & ors. Vs. The State 12 BLD (AD) 213

 

Bail — Special Powers Act — Section 32 — Ground for granting bail — Bail can be granted only when the Special Tri­bunal or the court is satisfied on hearing both the parties that there are reasonable grounds for believing that the accused or convict is not guilty of the offence — Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) S 32 Md Aminul Islam Vs. The State 11 BLD (HCD) 106

 

Bail — Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) — Sections 30 and 32 — Customs Act (IV of 1969) — Section 156(8)(59) read with Section 25B of the Special Powers Act — Accused Joynal Abedin's name appeared neither in the FIR. nor in the charge sheet as an accused — In the charge sheet it was mentioned that he was the owners of seized foreign clothes with a valid licence — No summons was yet served upon the prosecution witnesses_Possibility of delay in the commence­ment of the trial — Prayer for bail al­lowed. Joy mil Abedin & another Vs. The State 12 BLD (HCD) 1. Ref. 27 DLR (HCD) 427; 32 DLR (AD) 35

 

Bail — Code of Criminal Procedure — Sections 498/339C(3) — Trial could not be concluded within the specified time — Co-accused moved the High Court Divi­sion and obtained Rule — Impugned order of the Sessions Judge stayed — Most of the co-accused persons were enlarged on bail by the tr .1 court and the High Court Division — Petitioners stand on the same footing — Bail granted to the petitioners Md. Majid alias Md Abdul Majid and others Vs. The State 12 BLD (HCD) 128

 

Bail — Sections 498/339C(3) The Petitioner charged along with others under Sections 396/412 of the Penal Code — Trial not concluded within the specified time — Other accused persons moved revisional application before the High Court Division against the order rejecting the prayer for stopping the pro­ceeding — The High Corut Division stayed further proceeding till the disposal of the Criminal revision before it — The petitioner in hajat for a long period — Uncertain when the trial will commence__Other accused persons enjoying the privilege of bail — Petitioner stands on the same footing — Petitioner enlarged on bail till the commencement of the trial — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of1898) S 498 Arun Kumar Saha alias Narayan Vs. The State 12 BLD (HCD) 238.

 

Bail — Directly by High Court Division — Bail by the High Court direct is not granted as a matter of course but only in an exceptional case such as the physical inability to appear before the trial court, fear and lack of personal safety because of local rivalry, sheer lack of confidence and the pecuiliar circumstances of the case, the High Court may exercise its power in granting bail. Jahanara Imam and others Vs. The State 12 BLD (HCD) 314. Ref. 18 DLR(SC) 393

 

Bail in pending appeal — Petitioner convicted and sentenced under Section 395/397 of the Penal Code — Not named in the FIR. — No-recognition — Petitioners are two full brothers — Petitioners con­victed on the basis of confession of co-accused — Not corroborated in material particulars — No prospect of getting the appeal heard within a reasonable time — Bail granted for a limited period — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 426 Abul Kashem and another Vs. The State 12 BLD (HCD) 405.

 

1251

CIRCUMSTANTIAL EVIDENCE

Citation: 5 BLD (AD(H) 301Ref. 11 DLR (SC) 38, 5 BLD 129.Ref. AIR 1952 (SC) 343; AIR 1976 (SC) 917; AIR 1979 (SC) 826,6 BLD (AD) 79. Ref. 11 DLR (SC) 365; 16 DLR (SC) 261 and 33 DLR 320, 8 BLD (HCD) 114, 8 BLD (HCD) 344,9 BLD (HCD) 218 Ref. 37 DLR (AD) 139; 16 DLR

Subject: CIRCUMSTANTIAL EVIDENCE

Delivery Date: 2018-07-17

CIRCUMSTANTIAL EVIDENCE

Circumstantial evidence — It is well-settled that when all the evidence is cir­cumstantial, it is necessary that cumula­tively its effect should be to exclude any reasonable hypothesis of the innocence of the accused — The circumstances estab­lished in a case are to be incompatible with the innocence of the accused and are to be sufficient to exclude all possibilities of the innocence of the accused — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 3 Keshab Chandra Mistry and others Vs. The State 5 BLD (AD) 301Ref. 11 DLR (SC) 38

Circumstantial Evidence — In order to sustain a conviction on circumstantial evidence, such evidence must be complete and incapable of explanation of any other hypothesis than that of the guilt of the ac­cused — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 3 Shafiullah alias kala Mia Vs. The State 5 BLD(HCD) 129.Ref. AIR 1952 (SC) 343; AIR 1976 (SC) 917; AIR 1979 (SC) 826.

Circumstantial Evidence — Absence of reasonable explanation — There is no reason to disbelieve the evidence of son and wife of the deceased who are most natural and material witnesses as to the calling away of the deceased after which he was not found till his dead body was recovered — In the absence of any other reasonable explanation as to the safe de­parture of the deceased from the company of the appellants, no conclusion other than the guilt of the appellants can be drawn — Evidence Act (1 of1872) S 3 Anisur Rahman and others Vs. The State 6 BLD (AD) 79. Ref. 11 DLR (SC) 365; 16 DLR (SC) 261 and 33 DLR 320.

Circumstantial Evidence — When not sufficient for conviction — The accused can not be convicted merely on the ground that circumstantial evidence provides a ground for strong suspicion against the accused — If the circums­tantial evidence does not furnish con­clusive proof of the guilt of the accused, she cannot be convicted merely on the probability of having committed the offence — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 3 Alpana Rani Das Vs. The State 8 BLD (HCD) 114.

Criminal Trial — Circumstantial Evi­dence — Degree of probability required — Circumstantial evidence requires high degree of probability, sufficiently high from which a prudent man considering all facts that the life and liberty of an accused person depend upon his decision, is justified in holding that the accused has committed the crime — All facts forming the chain of evidence must point conclusively to the guilt of the accused and must not be capable of being explained on any other reasonable hypothesis. Abdul Wahab and another Vs. The State 8 BLD (HCD) 344.

Circumstantial Evidence — Whether circumstances by themselves were enough to connect the accused with the crime — It is proved beyond doubt that the deceased was last seen alive in the company of the accused, the latter are liable to offer satisfactory explanation as to the cause of death of the deceased — When circumstantial evidence led by the prosecution is quite incompatible with the innocence of the accused, the view that the circumstances themselves are not enough without anything more to connect the ac­cused with the offence is contrary to the time-honoured principle of law regarding circumstantial evidence — Evidence Act (I of 1872) S 3 Rezaul Huq and others Vs. The State 9 BLD (HCD) 218 Ref. 37 DLR (AD) 139; 16 DLR (SC) 261.

Circumstantial Evidence — Onus on the prosecution in a case based on such evidence — Circumstances taken cumu­latively should form a complete chain — Onus is on the prosecution to prove that the chain is complete — Prosecution can not derive any strength from the weakness of the defence — After the various links in the chain of circumstances are them­selves complete then a false defence plea may be called into aid to lend assurance to the court but not that the infirmity in the prosecution could be cured by a false defence — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 3 The State and others Vs. Badsha Molla 9 BLD (HCD) 257.Ref. 5 BLD (AD) 301; 5 BLD (HCD) 129; AIR 1952 (SQ343; AIR 1976 (SC) 917; AIR 1979 (SC) 190; AIR 1984 (SC) 1622.

Circumstantial Evidence — Charge of murder — No eye witness of the oc­currence to implicate circumstances the court has to guard itself against any tendency to substitute suspi­cion or to supply links which are missing to constitute the necessary chain of guilt — In evaluating the circumstances the Court must see whether the circums­tances proved by the proscution lead to the sole and certain inference of the guilt of the accused, whether they are con­sistent with the innocence of the accused and whether inference from the totality of circumstances precludes all reasonable possibilities of the accused being innocent.

The principle for appreciation of cir­cumstantial evidence — Each circum­stance reiied upon by the prosecution must be established by cogent, succint and reliable evidence, the circumstances must be of an incriminating nature or character — All the proved circumstances must unequivocably point to the guilt of the accused and exclude any hypothesis inconsistent with the innocence of the accused — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 3 Mostain Mollah and others Vs. The State 11BLD (HCD) 552.Ref. 1 SCC 530; 3 SCC 198 (202); AIR 1952 (SC) 343; AIR 1954 (SC) 660; AIR 1960 (SC) 29; 1952 SCR 1091.

Circumstantial Evidence — Last seen together — It is a well-settled law that 'last seen together' is a weak type of cir­cumstantial evidence on which a convic­tion can be based, where evidence is nec­essary to find a link between the accused and the murder — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 3 The State Vs. Sree Ranjit Kumar Pramanik 12 BLD (HCD) 284.

 

1252

CONSTITUTION OF PAKISTAN, 1962

Citation: 40 DLR (AD) 178,40 DLR (AD) 178

Case Year: 1962

Subject: CONSTITUTION OF PAKISTAN

Delivery Date: 2018-01-09

 

Constitution of Pakistan, 1962
 
Article 98 read with Constitution of Bangladesh, Article 102—
since 1962 prerogative writs were omitted and the constitutional jurisdiction to issue necessary orders on an application was conferred on the High Court (Division) in its own terms.
Radical difference in language between Article 170 of 1956 Pakistan Constitution and Article 98 of 1962 Pakistan Constitution in respect of the jurisdiction conferred on the High Courts.
Sajeda Parvin Vs. Government of Bangladesh 40 DLR (AD) 178.
 
Article 98(2)(b) read with Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972 Article 102(2)(b)(i)—
The language of Article 98 of 1962 Pakistan Constitution which has been imported into Article 102 of Bangladesh Constitution of 1972 has been couched in such a manner which is untrammeled by the formalities or technicalities of either section 491 of the Code of Criminal Procedure or the old prerogative writ of Habeas Corpus. Ref. 21 DLR (SC) 1(11).
Sajeda Parvin Vs. Government of Bangladesh 40 DLR (AD) 178.
1253

COGNIZANCE

Citation: 2 BLD (AD) 13,3 BID (HCD) 70, 3 BID (HCD) 108, 3 (BLD) (HCD) 184, 3 BLD (HCD) 267, 4 BLD (AD) 206,4 BLD (HCD) 264. Ref. 32 DLR 221,5 BLD (AD) 73, 5 BLD (AD) 185, 5 BLD (AD) 278. Ref. AIR 1965 (SC) I; AIR 1962 (SC) 63: AIR 1929 (Mad) 604, 5 BlD (AD) 285

Subject: COGNIZANCE

Delivery Date: 2018-07-22

COGNIZANCE

Cognizance — Sessions Judge has no power to take cognizance of an offence as a court of original jurisdiction unless the accused has been committed to it by a Magistrate duly empowered in that behalf_Sessions Judge can call for the record of a proceeding pending before a Magis­trate for purposes mentioned in Section 435 Cr.P.C. — but he can not initiate a new proceeding and start a criminal mis­cellaneous case against a Magistrate upon a telegram containing allegations against the Magistrate in respect of a proceeding pending before the Magistrate — Criminal miscellaneous case quashed — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) Ss. 190. 193 and 561A Haripoda Biswas Vs. The State and another 2 BLD (AD) 13.

 

Cognizance of offence — Cognizance upon a police report — When the police report is sent by a Magistrate a court of Sessions is competent to take cognizance-Rejection of a narazi petition by the Magistrate having amounted to an order of discharge, the petition could not be said to have been sent to the Court of Session.

 

The Court of Session has no jurisdiction to take cognizance of an offence as a-court of original jurisdiction — Sessions Judge righty rejected the prayer of the in­formant for taking cognizance — Subse­quent order of the Additional Sessions Judge taking cognizance was in effect a review of the Sessions Judge's order — Order of the Additional Sessions Judge was illgeal and without jurisdiction — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) Ss. 193, 203. 205C. 205D and 406 Abdur Razzaque Vs. The State and another 3 BID (HCD) 70.

 

Sessions Judges as a court of original jurisdiction — Sessions Judge can not take cognizence of an offence as a court of original jurisdiction against an accused person discharged by the Magistrate in view of the final report submitted by the police — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 193(1) Zainul Ahedin and others Vs. The State 3 BID (HCD) 108.

 

Cognizance of an offence — Sessions Judge's Power — Sessions Judge has no power under the Code of Criminal Proce­dure to summon the accused, who was earlier discharged by the Magistrate, to stand trial in a Session case — Code of Criminal Procedure ( V of 1898) S 193 FazJul Hut/ Haider alias Mollah Vs. The State 3 (BLD) (HCD) 184.

 

Cognizance of offence — Magistrate's power — The power of the Magistrate to take cognizance is not limited only to those offences which are triable exclusively by the Magistrate but it also extends to offences which are triable ex­clusively by the court of Sessions — The Magistrate has the sole jurisdiction to de­cide whether cognizance should be taken—Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898). Ss. 190. 200, 202. 204 and 205C. Ahdus Sal a in Master and another Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 267.

 

After congizance Magistrate cannot direct further investigation — Once a Magistrate has taken cognizance of an of­fence on a police report he is not entitled to sen the case to the police for further in­vestigation — If he is not satisfied with the final report he is competent to take cognizance against the accused in favour of whom final report was submitted — Police may submit supplementary charge sheet on further investigation against an accused who was earlier discharged on final report — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) Ss 173, 190 Shamsun Nahar alias Maina Vs. The State 4 BLD (AD) 206.

 

Cognizance — When value of the sto­len property does not exceed Taka 5,000.00 — The Magistrate cannot take cognizance of an offence of theft where the value of the stolen property does not exceed Tk 5,000 00 only, such a case being exclusively triable by theVillage Court The Village Court Ordinance (LXI of 1976) Ss 3 and 16 Rajah Ali and others Vs. The State 4 BLD (HCD) 264. Ref. 32 DLR 221

 

Cognizance — Whether criminal prose­cution can be initiated by a party to a civil suit against the other party when the alleged offence has been committed in re­lation to a proceeding in the civil court — No court is competent to take cognizance of such an offence except on a written complaint by the Court concerned — Moreover, so long the decree passed by civil court remains in force it is a good defence for the accused in the criminal prosecution — Such a proceeding should not be allowed to continue and it should be quashed — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898). Ss. 195, 476, and 561A Mir Mahiruddin Mia and others Vs. Rokeya Hossain 5 BLD (AD) 73.

 

Cognizance   without   sanction —Cognizance of a case triable by the Spe­cial Judge without sanction for prosecu­tion or without writing for sanction from the appropriate authority is not valid — Charge sheet was not accompanied by sanction for prosecution of the appellant who is admittedly a public servant -Special Judge also did not write for sanc­tion and as such the cognizance was not valid — Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1958 (XL of 1958) S 6(5) A. S. S. Mohammad Ali Vs. The State 5 BLD (AD) 185.

 

 

Cognizance — Offence under the Drug Ordinance — Forum for investigation and trial — The proceeding of the Magistrate was without jurisdiction in as much as special procedure has been provided for investigation of the offence by designated class of officers and the Special Court has been set up for the purpose — The case can only be tried by the Drug Corut situated at Dhaka and not by the Upazila Magistrate — The case is accordingly transferred to the Drug Court at Dhaka for trial Drug (Control) Ordinance. 1982 (VIII of 1982) S 22 The Drug Act (XXIII of 1940) S 22 — The Code of Criminal   Procedure  (V of 1898).Ss 155 and 525A Kalipada Shaha Vs. The State 5 BLD (AD) 278. Ref. AIR 1965 (SC) I; AIR 1962 (SC) 63: AIR 1929 (Mad) 604.

 

Cognizance — When barred — Cogni­zance in respect of a document produced or given in evidence in a Court — What is required is that the court must come to a conclusion that an offence has been committed — If that is the case, the court can launch a prosecution In the absence of such a conclusion by the civil court, prosecution and conviction for for­gery of a document produced in a civil court is illegal — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) Ss.195 and 476 Syed Ehadat Ali Vs. The State 5 BID (AD) 285. Ref. AIR 1927 (All) 571; AIR 19.11 (Mad) 16, AIR 1926 (Mad) 2.18; 20 DLR (Dhaka) 66

 

Cognizance by a private complaint

 

A private individual cannot prosecute a person for offences committed in relation to a proceeding in a court Such a proceeding is barred under the provision of clause (c) of sub-section (I) of Section 195 of the Code of Criminal Procedure when the offence is committed by the parties "as such" in a proceeding before any court — The expression "party to a proceeding" needs be interpreted strictly and in its ordinary meaning — Sections 195 and 476 Cr.P C. are to be read together in as much as the former section lays down the bar while the latter section lays down the method for removing the bar — Section 476 enjoins the civil court to make an enquiry when it appears that the offence has been committed in or in relation to a proceeding "in that court" — Section 195(C) Cr.P.C. applies only to a case where an offence has been committed in respect of a document which has been produced or given in evidence in such a proceeding — When the offence had been committed before the accused became a party to the proceeding, provision of Section. 195(C) is not applicable — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) Ss 195 and 476 Mosammat Saleha Khatun Vs. The State 5 (BLD) (HCD) 193 Ref. AIR 1931 (All) 443

 

Cognizance in a case of adultery —

There can be no cognizance of the offence except upon a complaint bv the husband or by some other person who had the care of such a woman — Penal Code (XLV of 1860) S 497 — Code of Crimi­nal Procedure (V of 1898) S 199 Nurul Huq Bahadur Vs. B.H. Sakina and an­other 5 BLD (HCD)269

 

Cognizance — Without examination of the complainant on oath — No cogni­zance can be taken on the result of judicial enquiry when the complainant was not ex­amined on oath before the case was sent for judicial enquiry — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) Ss. 200 and 202(1) Nurul Huq Bahadur Vs. B. B. Sakina and other 5 (BLD) (HCD) 269. Ref. 28 DLR 389; 17 DLR (SC) 626.

 

Cognizance of a non-cognizable of­fence — Whether cognizance of a non-cognizable offence by a Magistrate on the investigation report of the police without prior order or permission of the compe­tent Magistrate valid — Whether such defect or omission vitiates the proceeding or the trial — The mere fact that the imperative statutory rule of procedure has been broken is not enough to vitiate the trial of the proceeding provided there is no failure of justice — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) Ss. 155(2) and 537 Siddique Ahmed and others Vs. The State 5 (BLD) (HCD) 309. Ref. 4 BLD (AD) 7; 25 DLR 455; 30 Cr.L J 1056 (FB); AIR 1953 (Orissa) 83.

 

Cognizance when police filed final re­port — If the Magistrate is satisfied that a particular person has been improperly excluded from the charge sheet, he may take cognizance against such a person on the basis of the police report even if it is a final report — Code of Criminal Pro­cedure (V of 1898) S 190(1 )(b) Abdul Awal Vs. Abdul Mannan and another 6 (BLD) (AD) 328. H.Ref. 19 DLR (SC) 426

 

Cognizance — Whether the special judge can take cognizance on police report and not upon a complaint from the court concerned — Whether sub-section 1(C) of Section 195 of Cr PC has been superceded by the Criminal Law Amend­ment Act. 1958.

 

The provision for complaint from the court has not been specifically done away with in the Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1958 and as such the general provision of the Code remains unaffected When an offence within the meaning of the Code is committed in a proceeding before a court, then the complaint shall have to be filed by the court concerned In view of Section 6 of the Act. the provision as to taking of cognizance of a case upon a complaint from the court has remained unaffected and as such if an offence falls within the ambit of Section 195(1 )(C) of the Code then cognizance cannot be taken except upon a complaint from the Court — Criminal Law Amend­ment Act (XL of 1958) S 6 Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 195 (l)(C) Mil. Muslim Khan Vs. The State 6 BLD (AD) 164

 

Cognizance  by  Special Judge-Special Judge may direct further investi­gation after taking cognnizance but before framing of charges — Criminal Law Amendment Act (XL of 1958) S 5(6) Mil. Am jail Hossain Surilur uml another Vs. The Stute 6 BLD (HCD) 328

 

Cognizance suo motu — It is true that after discharge of the accused the case cannot be revived against him - In this case when fresh incriminating materials came up in the course of the trial the Magistrate issued process against the ac­cused suo motu — There is no illegality_Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S I90( 1 )(C) Shafiqur Rahman Vs. The State 6 BLD (HCD) 69.

 

 

Cognizance — Prosecution of a Public-Servant The petitioner is a store keeper employed by a BADC and not by the Government Although he is a public servant the bar of taking cogni­zance of any offence against him does not apply -•- Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) Ss 21 and 197(1) Shafiqur Rah man I v. The State 6 BLD (HCD) 69. Ref. 44 Cr L J 1943 (FC); AIR 1943 (FC) 18; AIR 1964 (SC) 269; AIR 1922 (Nag) 121; 22 DLR (WP) (Karachi) 48; 1982 BCR (HCD) 4

 

Cognizance -— Without a complaint by the Revenue Officer The Revenue Officer holding mutation proceeding does not act as a court wihin the meaning of Section 195( 1) Cr P C — There is no bar for a Magistrate in taking cognizance of the offence of forgery in respect of a document produced before the Revenue Officer holding a mutation proceeding in the absence of a complaint from him S A & T Act, (XXVIII of 1951) S 143, S A & T Rules. 1955. Rules 22-25 Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 195(I)(C) Ulris All ami others Vs. The State 6 BLD (HCD) 7, Ref. AIR 1950 (SC) 188; 193 1 (AC) 276; PLD 1956 (SC) (Ind) 65; Pl.D 1957 (SC) (Pak) 91; 27 DLR 388; 20 DLR 1019; 9 DLR (WP) (Lah) 40

 

Cognizance — In a case of adulterv — The bar against taking cognizance of the offence of adultery otherwise than upon a complaint by the husband is total and complete Code of Criminal Pro cedure (V of 1898) S 199 State Vs. Aynuzzaman 7 (BLD) (AD) 100

 

Cognizance — Without sanction of the Government—In the Industrial Relations Ordinance, 1969 there is no enactment relating to the manner of investigation, enquiry into or otherwise dealing with of­fences and as such the provisions of the Cirminal Procedure Code including Sec­tion 197 of the Code are applicable to cases triable by the Labour Court — Where a public servant is not removeable from his office save by or without the sanction of the Government, the Labour Court in that case cannot take cognizance of the offence without prior sanction of the Government In the absence of a prior sanction under Section 197 of the Code of Criminal Procedure the proceeding under Section 55 of the Industrial Relations Ordinance, 1969 is incompetent The proceeding is liable to be quashed Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) Ss 197 and 561A Moqhul Ahmed and another Vs. Hamidul liari 7 (BLD) (HCD) 108 Ref. 25 DLR 192

 

Cognizance without police report

Cognizance taken and proceeding started in a case under the Special Powers Act. 1974 without police report is not main­tainable in law — The order sheet shows that no police report was made in the case and the cognizance was taken by the Ses­sions Judge without any police report in violation of the provision of Section 27 of the Special Powers Act — In view of this legal provision the proceeding is liable to be quashed — The Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) S 27 — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 561A Nurul Islam and another Vs. The State and another 7 (BLD) (HCD) 288

 

Cognizance by Magistrate — Cogni­zance in a case covered by the Criminal Law Amendment Act. 1958 — Special Judge alone is competent to take cogni­zance of any offence committed within his jurisdiction triable under the Criminal Law Amendment Act The order of the Upazila Magistrate taking cognizance of the offence under Section 409 of the Penal Code and issuing warrant of arrest is illegal and without jurisdiction — The Criminal Law Amendment Act (XL of 1958) S 5(1) — Code of Criminal Proce­dure ( V of 1898) Ss 438. 439 and 561A A. Mannan Vs. LI. N. (). In-Charge Kalmakanda 8 (BLD) (HCD) 46.

 

Taking cognizance of offence — Ex­tent of Sessions Judge's Jurisdiction — Neither the Sessions Judge nor the High Court Division can direct the subordinate courts to take cognizance of an offence — The learned Sessions Judge acted illegally in interfering with the Magis­trate's order after re-assessing the evidence and taking cognizance himself and directing the Magistrate in effect to take cognizance, which is beyond the scope of the law - Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) Ss  220(1 )(2A) and 436 Yakuh AH Chowdhury and others Vs. Habihur Rahman and others 8 BLD (HCD) 276 Ref. 36 DLR (AD) 58; 35 DLR 140; 33 DLR 8; 25 DLR 125.

 

Cognizance of an offence by the Spe­cial Judge - When a Magistrate sends a complaint to the Special Judge with his comments and if cognizance is taken again bv the latter, it cannot be said that the Special Judge has not taken cognizance upon a complaint — Criminal Law Amendemnt Act (XL of 1958) S 4(I) -Code of Criminal Procedure (V of .1898) S4(h)

 

Sanction of the Government in terms of Section 197 Cr PC can be obtained even after submission of charge sheet but it will have to be obtained before the trial starts — This is also applicable in respect of sanction required under the Criminal Law Amendment Act (XL of 1958) S 6(5) -Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 197 Penal Code (XLV of I860) Ss 406/ 409 Matiar Rahman Vs. The State ami others 9 BLD (HCD) 144, Ref. 32 DLR (AD) 100; 35 DLR 249.

 

Cognizance of offence by Magistrate - His jurisdiction in a case triable by the Court of Sessions In a case exclusively triable bv Court of Sessions — A Magistrate for the purpose of ascertaining the truth or falsehood of the complaint is to consider the evidence in order to find whether a prima facie case has been made out or not but he cannot assess the evidence as in a trial but at the same time he is not a conduit pipe — He is to con­sider the evidence so far as it is necessary for compliance with the requirements of law — He has jurisdiction to decide whether all or some of the accused per­sons are to be sent for trial after en­quiry—Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S I90( I). 202( 1 )(2A) Syed Ahmed ami another Vs. Habihur Rahman and another 9 BLD (HCD) 227Ref. 36 DLR (AD) 58, 55 DLR 140; 33 DLR 8.

 

Direction for taking cognizance_Jurisdiction of superior court — Superior court can merely order further enquiry — Neither the Court of Sessions nor the High Court Division can direct the taking of cognizance — Code of Criminal Pro­cedure (V of 1898) S 436 Syed Ahmed and another Vs. Habihur Rahman and another 9 BLD (HCD) 227 Ref. 25 DLR 125; 35 DLR 140.

 

Cognizance by  Magistrate The Magistrate has wide power under Section I90(I)(C) Cr P C to take cognizance of any offence even upon his knowledge or suspicion that an offence has been com­mitted and to pass necessary order -Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 19()( 1 )(C) Ahdur Rash id Vs. The State 10 BLD (HCD) 407.

 

Cognizance Section 295A of th Penal Code — No court can tak: cognizance of any offence punishable under Section 295A of the Penal C(x| unless upon a complaint made by order or under the authority from the Govern­ment or by some officers empowered in this behalf.

 

A complaint lodged by a private person for an offence punishable under Section 295A of the Penal Code and taking cogni­zance thereof bv a Court without comply­ing with the requirements of Section 146 of the Code of Criminal Procedure is not maintainable in law — The proceeding is liable to be quashed — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) Ss 146 and 561 A Penal Code (XLV of I860) S 295A/298/109 Mil Jamir Sheikh Vs. Fakir Mil A. Wahah and another 10  BLD (HCD) 452.

 

Cognizance Without the complaint of the court — Section 195 Cr.P.C pro­vides that if a document is "produced" or "given in evidence" in a proceeding before a court, the only person competent to make a complaint with regard to such a document is the Presiding Office of the Court itself and none else The word "or" between the words "produced" and "given in evidence" in the section, the two things are disjunctive — This means that the law gives the authority to the court concerned to make a complaint not only if the document is given in evidence but also if it is produced in the proceeding.

Filing of a forged document in a pro­ceeding before a Court amounts to production of the document within the meaning of Section 195(1 )(C) Cr.P.C Mohammad Herman Ali and others Vs. The State 11 BLD (HCD) 120 Ref. 8 BLD (AD) 195.

 

Cognizance- Absence of complaint under Section 195 Cr.P.C The words "documents produced or given in a evi­dence" contemplate the original docu­ments alleged to be forged and not a certified copy of the disputed document If the document in question is not produced in the court but a certified copy of the same is produced and marked as an exibit, no complaint from the court is necessary under Section I95(I)(C) Cr.P.C- for prosecution of the alleged offenders.

The absence of complaint under section I95(|)(C) Cr PC bv the S.C.C. Judge cannot stand as a bar to the trial of the accused persons — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S I95(I)(C) Shamhhu Nath Saha and other Vs. The State 11 BLD (HCD) 333

 

Cognizance by the Special Tribunal on the application of the Public Prosecutor — Taking cognizanc eof an offence under Section 25B of the Act bv the Special Tribunal Judge on the application of the Public Prosecutor without directing the police officer of the rank of Sub-Inspector for further investigation and report, offends the mandatory provision of Section 27(1X71 of the Act Severe character of the Act providing all kinds of procedural protections to an accused person should be zealously guarded but the Court and should not be negated without any real good reason Mandatory measures of protection to the accused have not been left to the discretion of the nal Judge but these have been made obligatory upon him to act in accordance with the provisions of the Act — Any deviation from it will be contrary to the intention of the Act - Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) Ss. 25B and 27( I )(7) Jainal Abedin and another Vs. The State 12 BLD (HCD) 1.

 

Cognizance by the Sub-divisional Of­ficer — The Sub-divisional Officer is not authorised to take cognizance of any offence under the Criminal Law Amend­ment Act, 1958 on receipt of a report from the CO (Dev) — Senior Special Judge in turn took cognizance of an of­fence on receipt of the case record from the Magistrate without anv complaint from a public servant — The taking of cognizance is illegal and the same vitiated the trial — Criminal Law Amendemnt Act (XL of 1958) S 4 Abdul Jahbar Dewan Vs. The State 12 BLD (HCD) 38 .

 

Cognizance — Proceeding initiated by the complainant in a mutation case — The Revenue Officer dealing with a Mu­tation case is a Revenue Court — Pro­ceeding initiated by the complainant is a bar under Section 195(1) (C) Cr.P C. — The Court concerned has sole jurisdiction to make a complaint not only for the use of the forged document but also for the offence of forging it — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S I95(2)(C) A/it Kumar Sarkar and others Vs. Radhakanta Sarkar and others 12 BLD (HCD) 552Ref. 1987 BCR (AD) 152; 38 DLR 270; 39 DLR 109.

Cognizance — Senior Special Judge_The Senior Sepcial Judge is the only judge who has power for taking cogni­zance of an offence under the Criminal Law Amendment Act. 1958 though there may be other Special Judges within the same territorial jurisdiction — Criminal Law Amendment Act. 1958 (XL of 1958) Ss 4( 1 )(2) and S 5( l)(e) of Act II of 1947 H.M. Ershad Vs. The State 12 BLD (HCD) 610

 

Cognizance in a case covered by the Criminal Law Amendment Act

 

Special Judge alone is competent to take cognizance of any offence committed within the jurisdiction as such a case is triable under the Criminal Law Amend­ment Act The order of the Upazila Magistrate taking cognizance of the of­fence under Section 409 of the Penal Code and issuing warrant of arrest is ille­gal and without jurisdiction The im­pugned proceeding in the court of the Upazilla Magistrate shall not continueCriminal Law Amendment Act (XL of 1958) S 5(1) Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) Ss 438, 439 and 561A A. Mannan Vs. C.N.O.-ln-Charge, Kalmakanda 8 BLD (HCD) 46.

 

1254

CONTEMPT OF COURT

Citation: 1 BLD (HCD) 278, 1 BLD (HCD) 487, 2 BLD(HCD) 168, 3 BLD (AD) 251 Ref. 5 DLR (PC) 540, 3 BLD (AD) 317. Ref. 1944 ILR (Lahore) 196, 3 BLD (HCD) 232, 3 BLD (HCD) 298, 4 BLD (AD) 237, 4 BLD (HCD) 52, 6 BLD (AD) 210. Ref. PLD 1970 (SC) 350; AIR 1983 (SC) 11

Subject: CONTEMPT OF COURT

Delivery Date: 2018-07-22

CONTEMPT OF COURT

Contempt of Court — Sessions Judge rejecting prayer of an accused for a dis­charge warrant — Suit against the Judge claiming compensation — Plaint contain­ing statements imputing unfitness, corrup­tion, malafide, misuse of official power and malice — If the plaintiff had any grievance against the rejection of the prayer for discharge warrant, his remedy was to move the superior court but filing of the suit and that too containing scandalous statements against the Judge constitutes contempt of court

 

Characterization of remarks made in a judicial order as "malicious" in an appli­cation for leave to appeal is clear con­tempt.

 

Contempt of Court — Appeal against rejection of plaint in a suit filing of which constitutes contempt of court is calculated to re-open the matter and is nothing but continuation of the suit — Filing of the appeal constitutes contempt of court al­though the memorandum of appeal does not contain any contemptuous statement.

 

Contempt of Court — Duty of the drafting and filing lawyers — Lawyers should exercise great care and caution in drafting and filing application or plaint in the Court and they are to see that it does not contain anything reflecting upon the integrity of the Court.

 

Judiciary is the upholder and preserver of the liberties and rights of the people and nothing should be done to lower the judiciary in the estimation of the people Nobody should be allowed to obstruct the administration of justice, more so by law­yers, who are the integral part of the court and it is the part of their duty to uphold the dignity and prestige of the Court.

 

Contempt of Court — Expression of view by the referring judge — Judge making reference to the High Court Divi­sion should only narrate the facts and send the materials in support thereof leaving other materials for disposal by the High Court Division — Expression of views by the referring judge about the sentence to be imposed is depricated — Contempt of Courts Act (XII of 1926) S 2. The State Vs. Abdul Majid Munshi and others 1 BLD (HCD) 278.

 

Contempt of Court — Punishment for disobedience to Court's order by a public servant — The affidavit showed defiant justification of his role — It is time that the penal law of the land be applied in such cases for deterrent impact upon the public servant who chooses to disobey the orders of the Court — Punishment under the Contempt of Courts Act is not stringent enough for such glaring cases of wilful disobedience — The delinquent should be prosecuted under Section 217 of the Penal Code — Penal Code (XLV of 1860 ) S 217. Southern Fisheries Ranong Corporation and others Vs. king Fisheries Industries and others 1 BLD (HCD) 487.

 

Contempt of Court — Qtiesuon of apology — An apology however un­qualified does not by itself purge con­tempt — It can only be considered in mitigation of the offence.

 

Position of Lawyers   in relation to contempt — Lawyers are officers and integral parts of the Court — They owe a duty not merely to the clients but a/so to the court — The lawyers should exercisepetitions, plaints, etc and must avoid which contain allegations reflecting upon the integrety of the judiciary Contempt of Court — Notice issued to the Magistrate in a pending case amounts to interference with the admini­stration of justice — Notice asking him to pay to the Advocate or his client damages amounts to blackmailing and makes contempt all the more serious Contempt of Court Act (XII of 1926) The State Vs. Sharafat Hossain Chowdhury and another 2 BLD(HCD) 168.

 

Contempt of Court — Meaning of contempt — It may be constituted by any conduct that brings authority of the Court into disrespect or disregard or undermines its dignity and prestige — Scandalizing the Court is the worst kind of contempt — In making imputations touching the impar­tiality and integrity of a Judge or making sarcastic remarks about his judicial com­petence is a also a contempt.

 

The essence of contempt is an action or reaction amounting, to an interference with or obstruction to or having a tendency to interfere with or obstruct due administra­tion of justice.

 

Practice and procedure in a contempt proceeding — Nature of — It is quasi-criminal in nature and the contemner is entitled to the benefit of doubt — Rule as to proof of guilt of the contemner must he strictly observed as the Court is both the prosecutor of judge.

 

Bias - It denotes a departure from even-handed justice — It is well-settled that not only bias but even a real likeli­hood of bias demands that the cause or matter should not be heard by the judge concerned

Dignitary and authority of the court— These are to be protected by all par­ties, lawyers and other officers of the Court — The judges are themselves re­quired to protect and maintain their own dignity by proper conduct and behavior in and outside the court — They must regulate their behavior and dealings in such a way that there is no occasion of speculation or criticism about their free and fair mind and impartiality — They must guard their position zealously but they should not be touchy about it.

 

Discourtesy to the Court — It is not every act of discourtesy to the court by the counsel that amounts to contempt — Absence of the counsel on the hearing or judgment may amount to discourtesy but not contempt. Moazzam Hossain, Deputy Attorney -General Vs. The State 3 BLD (AD) 251 Ref. 5 DLR (PC) 540.

 

Contempt of Court — Deliberate and intentional disobedience of Court's order amounts to contempt of court but casual, accidental or unintentional disregard of the court's order may not constitute con­tempt of court — It is not a single act or omission for which the respondent has been charged — It is not his case that he misunderstood the order of the court or that there was any ambiguity therein — Had he any genuine intention to act ac­cording to Court's order he could have sought clarification during the long period In the circumstances there is hardly any scope for holding that the violation were committed unintentionally or it was due to misunderstanding of the Court's order.

 

Nature of contempts of courts pro­ceeding — Though a contempt proceed­ing is quasi-criminal in nature, the con­temner is not like an accused in a crimi­nal case, since he may file affidavit or make statements on oath in refutation of the allegation against him. Mahbubur Rahman Sikder and others Vs. Mujibur Rahman Sikder and others 3 BLD (AD) 317. Ref. 1944 ILR (Lahore) 196.

 

Contempt of Court — Absence of the Advocate on the date of hearing without permission of the Court and making de­liberate false statement regarding illness for not appearing on the dates fixed for the case and sending telegram and letter direct to the Court seeking adjournment All these acts constituted willful dis­obedience, discourtesy and utter contempt of court The State Vs. Moazzam Hossain, DAG 3 BLD (HCD) 232.

  

Contempt of Court — Contempt rule was issued against some Government officers for violating the order of High Court Division — Martial Law Regula tion No. ill of 1983 was promulgated declaring the order of the High Court Division as void and abating pending proceedings — The contempt proceeding cannot proceed and consequently abates Proclamation of Martial Law of March 24, 1982. Clause 'h'-Martial Law Regula­tion No. 1 1 1 of 1983 Article IV. Kalilur Rahman Vs. Mr. .lamsed Ali and others 3 BLD (HCD) 298.

 

Action for violation of Court's order__The Appellate Division passed order for keeping a vessel under attachment — Whether the High Court Division is com­petent to take action for violation of such order — After the order was passed by the Appellate Division in the civil mis­cellaneous petition, the appeal before the High Court Division was rendered infruc-tuous — The impugned order which may be argued to have merit seems to have been passed without any competence to do so — Its legality or illegality therefore loses all significance — Anxiety to do justice can not have free play so as to en­able the court to overcome the barrier of competence Md Muzzaffar Hussain Vs. King Fisheries Industries Ltd. 4 BLD (AD) 237.

 

Contempt of Court — High Court Division stayed further proceedings of a criminal case but inspire of production of that order and an application the Magis­trate refused to stay further proceedings of the criminal case — The Magistrate committed gross contempt of court Abdul Aziz and others Vs. The State and others 4 BLD  (HCD) 52

 

Contempt of Court — Obstructing course of justice by an executive officer — An executive officer himself exercising judicial powers in criminal matters has the temerity to obstruct the course of justice by such acts which exhibit scant respect for a court and as such rightly convicted for contempt of court.

 

Apology — Tendering apology to purge contempt of Court — Whether apology tendered by the contemner in ap­peal should be accepted — The applica­tion tendering apology is all too late in the day after every conceivable defence has been taken — Acceptance of apology tendered not at the earliest opportunity showing sincere regret would amount to opening and not closing the door of scan­dalizing the court — In this case the ap­pellant committed contempt of court — He ought to have thrown himself at the mercy of the Court as soon as the rule for contempt of court was served on him — After he was convicted for contempt of court he proceeded with the appeal — His action cannot be condoned as the same is not only humiliating to the presiding officer of the Court but it also amounts to clear defiance of the majesty of law Abdul Karim Sarker Vs. The State and another 6 BLD (AD) 210. Ref. PLD 1970 (SC) 350; AIR 1983 (SC) 1151; AIR 1984 (SC) 1374

 

Contempt of Court — Upazila Nirbahi Officer is guilty of contempt of court for sitting by the side of the Munsif-Magistrate and telling him publicly as tohow to conduct a criminal case and also for asking the bench officer of the Court not to work in the Court of Munsif -Mag­istrate — These are contemtuous disre­gard of the dignity of the court of law and gross interference with the working of the Court — The sight of an executive officer lecturing a member of the judiciary in the open court and creating hindrances in his smooth functioning is too much to be allowed with impunity — The execu­tive arms of the Government will not be allowed to attack or deface the honour, dignity, majesty and independence of the judicial organ of the state — If they are allowed then in no time the remaining civilised fabric of our society will collapse The UNO has no supervisory, advisory or administrative jurisdiction over the Munsif-Magistrate. The State Vs. Abdul Karim Sarkar 6 BLD (HCD) 284.  

 

 

 

Contempt of Court — Unconditional and unqualified apology — Apology, however unqualified and sincere, does not necessarily purge the contemner — Apology may be considered in awarding lenient sentence. Magistrate, Baliadanga Upazila Vs. F. R. Chowdhury, Former SP, Thakurgaon and others 6 BLD (HCD) 301.

 

Violation of stay order — Contempt when lies — Since the appeal from which the contempt petition has arisen has been dismissed, the petitioner has no legs to stand upon — As to the merit in the petition, at the time of admission the ap­pellant was satisfied by obtaining a short order of stay with respect to the High Court's Order — Effect of this court's order on the orders passed by the High Court Division or on the respondents does not appear to be clear and leaves scope for wrong understanding — Having re­gard to the circumstances, it would not be reasonable to entertain the application — The Contempt of Courts Act (XII of 1926) S 2 Charanawip Bhumihin Krishi Samahaya Shamity Limited Vs. The Deputy Commissioner, Cox's Bazar and others 8 BLD (AD) 62.

 

Contempt of Court in an Aribitration Proceeding — The High Court Division is to exercise the jurisdiction in respect of contempt committed before Courts sub­ordinate to it or before itself — As the Arbitrator is not a Court at all there can be no question of his being subordinate to the High Court Division — The opposite parties can not therefore be proceeded against by the High Court Division on an allegation of contempt of the Arbitrator — The Contempts of Courts Act (XII of 1926) S 2(1) Begum Lutfunnessa Vs. Nizamuddin Ahmed and others 8 BLD (HCD) 357. Ref. 38 DLR (AD) 172; 20 DLR 599; 25 DLR 440; 26 DLR 255

 

Contempt of Court — Court finds the affidavits of contemner Nos 2-4 to be quite adequate for the purpose of purging them of the guilt of contempt of court — But since the Daily was making a maiden venture to the field of journalism, it was essential that it was observing the ethics of journalism a little more seriously — In discharging the Rule against them the Court issued a note of warning that in the future care should be taken to see that opinions on various subjects are expressed by people who have at least some known competence to do the same

 

Contempt of Court — Contempt com­mitted by writing a letter to the Editor imputing collective dishonesty to the en­tire class of Judges — Contemner No-1, real or fictitious, can not escape the proc­ess of law — He has committed a gross contempt of court — Contempts of Courts Act (XII of 1926) S 2 M.
