A. Monir Vs. The State 8 BLD (HCD) 434

 

Contempt of Court — When apology is not acceptable — The contemner police officer did admit the orders of the Magistrate upon which the contempt pro­ceeding had arisen and at the same time he admits his guilt and tenders uncondi­tional apology — The question of apology arises only when the contemner uncondi­tionally confesses his guilt and then ten­ders apology — In the present case there was no proper apology previous orders to him and thereby threw all decorum and decency to the wind.

 

Involvement of a police officer as con­temner is a case for added concern — The police are not only the law enforcing agency of the administration but they are also the arms of the Court — The court can enforce its orders and decisions only through the police — If the police flout the orders of the court then the whole legal system is bound to collapse — The contemner committed contempt of the worst type and his apology is really no apology in the eye of law — Contempts of Courts Act (XII of 1926) S 3 Md. Abdur Razzaque, Magistrate Vs. Sheikh Serajul Islam OC, Sailkupa 9 BLD (HCD) 298

 

Contempt of Court — Failure to act in aid of the Supreme Court may lead to contempt — Since the delay in imple­menting the court's advance order of re­lease of the detenus cannot be explained in terms of any provision of the Jail Code or in terms of Government's instruction, the contemners have acted not in aid of the Supreme Court in releasing the detenus but in aid of the Home Ministry in facilitating the making and serving of a fresh order of detention — The con­temners have thus disobeyed the orders of the Court and are guilty of the Contempt of Court — Contmept of Courts Act (XII of 1926) — Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972 Art 112 Amit Kumar Banik and another Vs. Manjurul Karim, Jailor, Dhaka Central Jail and another 10 BLD (HCD) 5.

 

Contempt of Court — Effect of con­tempt to be taken into consideration — In contempt matters the intention of the contemners is not relevant — It is the effect of the contemner's action which is to be taken into consideration in deciding whether a contempt was committed or not — The effect of the contemner's action is that the Court's order has been flouted — The Court cannot be a silent spectator in this state of affairs. Mrs. Tahera Nargis Syed Vs. Mr. Shamsur Rahman, DIG of Prisons, Dhaka Central Jail 10 BLD (HCD) 73.

 

Contempt of Court — Apology — When a contemner tenders apology as an act of contrition, the Court must weigh the apology in awarding punishment — If the apology is found to be a real act of contrition, no action need be taken and a word of warning may be enough but if the apology is qualified, hesitating and sought to be used as a device to escape the con­sequences of the contemner's actions, it must be rejected — Contempt of Courts Act (XII of 1926) Mr. Shamsur Rahman, Deputy Inspector General of Prisons, Dhaka Central Jail Vs. Mrs. Tahera Nargis Syed and another 12 BLD (AD) 150.

 

The contempt proceeding — Nature of — A contempt matter is in the nature of a criminal proceeding and as such the contmner stands in the position of an accused. The allegation of contempt, therefore, must be proved by the prosecution and in the case of any doubt its benefit shall go to the accused — If no evidence is led, the allegation must fail ex­cept in a case of contempt committed in the very presence of the judge — In other cases, such as where an order of the Court has been violated elsewhere, then the act of violation is to be proved by evidence — In such a case the Court must act on the evidence and cannot re­cord a conviction by mere perusing the affidavit and counter affidavit of the con­testing parties. Md Fazlur Rahman Molla Vs. Bangladesh and another 12 BLD (AD) 220.

 

Contempt of Court — Necessity of knowledge — As soon as the executing Court comes to know of the stay order either by receiving communication of the Court passing the stay order or from an affidavit from one of the parties of the proceeding or in other way, it will stay hands till further order and, if he does not do so, he will be liable for contempt of court — No action for contempt can be taken against an executing court if it car­ries on execution in ignorance of the order of stay — Where there is no justification for doubting the authenticity of an order of the superior Court, it is the duty of the subordinante Court to carry out that order and it cannot take up the plea that as the order had not been officially commu­nicated, it was at liberty to ignore it.

 

Apology is to be offered unequivocally and at the earliest opportunity — Abe-lated apology hardly shows the contrition which is the essence of the purging of the contempt — One who has the courage of his conviction may, however, take the risk and run the gauntlet of proving that he is not in contempt.

 

In deciding a serious question as to whether there is a contmept of court or not the accuser as well as the judge of the accusation is to act with as great circum­spection as possible making all allowances for errors of judgment and difficulties the contemner might have suffered in the facts of the case — It is only in a clear case of contemptuous conduct, not explainable otherwise, that the contemner must be punished.

 

When an Advocate's information is dis­regarded by the Court, a reason must be given so that the exercise of discretion may be scrutinised by the superior Court — Contempt of Court Act (XII of 1926) Chairman, Kushtia Co-operative Indus­trial Union Ltd Vs. Md Mujibur Rahman and others 12 BLD (AD) 227.

 

Law of Contempt — In a contempt matter a Court should not be touchy and no one should be held guilty of contempt of court unless there is a wilful disrespect to a court's order with full knowledge of it.

 

A person in judiciary must be deemed to be acquainted with the law of contempt and his ignorance of law is no excuse. Ayub AH Mahalder Vs. Md Shajahan and another 12 BLD (HCD) 54

 

1255

DISCHARGE

Citation: 3 BLD (HCD) 267 Ref. 14 DLR (SC) 96; 30 DLR 344,3 BLD (HCD) 267, 10 BLD (HCD) 407, 6 BLD (HCD) 96.

Subject: DISCHARGE

Delivery Date: 2018-07-30

DISCHARGE

 

Prosecution of discharged accused —Whether without jurisdiction — If in fact it is a revival of the same proceeding, it is without jurisdiction but if the second prosecution is based on a fresh complaint it will not be without jurisdiction because the Magistrate does not preside over the same proceedings — He is functus officio in so far as the first proceedings are concerned but not in respect of the new proceeding — Code of Criminal Pro­cedure (V of 1898) S 250B Ahdus Salam Master and another Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 267 Ref. 14 DLR (SC) 96; 30 DLR 344.

 

Further inquiry after discharge of the accused — When the order of discharge is by a Magistrate, one can not file before the Magistrate a petition for revival of the same case — The aggrieved party may move the superior Court for further inquiry — The superior court can merely order for further inquiry but neither the Court of Sessions nor the High Court Division can direct the subordinate court for taking of cognizance — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 436 Abdus Sal am Master and another Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 267.

 

 

Discharge — Acceptance of Final Report necessarily results in the release of the accused form custody or from the bail bond, as the case may be, and the Magistrate's order releasing the accused is ordinarily referred to as an order of "discharge", although the term 'discharge' appears no where in Section 173 Cr.P C — This "discharge" is different from a "discharge" under Sections 253 or 209 Cr.P.C. where discharge takes place after cognizance is taken and process is issued against a person. Abdur Rashid Vs. The State 10 BLD (HCD) 407.

 

Discharge by the Sessions Judge —The Sessions Judge is empowered to discharge the accused persons when he finds no prima facie case against them — Statement of the witnesses recorded under Section 161 Cr.P.C. may be con­sidered for ascertaining a prima facie case against the accused persons — The material test is whether the fact alleged constitutes an offence or not — Whether the offence has been committed by the accused persons or not is a matter which can be decided at the trial on taking evi­dence — Section 265C Cr.P.C. authorises the Sessions Judge to discharge the accused persons if on the materials on record before him he finds no sufficient ground to proceed against them — Sec­tion 265D Cr.P.C. authorises the Court to frame charges against the accused persons if the Court is satisfied about the existence of a prima facie case against them — The Sessions Judge is to assign reasons based on materials on record for discharging the accused persons — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) Ss. 265 and 265D Md Kamiuddin Ahmed Vs. Abu Bakar and others 6 BLD (HCD) 96.

1256

WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS

Citation: 1 BLD (AD) 488, Ref. 44 CWN 709; (1969) 1 All ER 208; AIR 1946 (Lahore) 103; 7 DLR (FC) 253; (1949) 1 All ER 242; (1949) 1 All ER 373; 259 US 326; 344 US 137; 33 DLR (AD) 143; 1 BLD (AD) 378; 1 BLD (AD) 307, 1 BLD (AD) 488, 6 BLD (HCD) 272, 20 DLR 1005;

Subject: WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS

Delivery Date: 2018-07-31

WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS

 

Habeas corpus — Court Martial — Scope of enquiry and interference in habeas corpus — jurisdiction to interfere with the decision of Court Martial is narrower than in the case of other Courts or Tribunals — Constitution of Bangla­desh, 1972 Art. 102(2)(b). Jamil Huq (Ex-Captain) Vs. Bangladesh and other 1 BLD (AD) 488.

 

Ref. 44 CWN 709; (1969) 1 All ER 208; AIR 1946 (Lahore) 103; 7 DLR (FC) 253; (1949) 1 All ER 242; (1949) 1 All ER 373; 259 US 326; 344 US 137; 33 DLR (AD) 143; 1 BLD (AD) 378; 1 BLD (AD) 307.

 

Supervisory jurisdiction under Art 109— Court Martial is not a Court sub­ordinate to the High Court Division — Proceedings of such a Court cannot be interfered with on the ground of proce­dural irregularities — The writ jurisdiction will be attracted if the proceedings are coram non judice or malafide and the Writ of Habeas Corpus will be available for securing the release of the prisoner who has been committed by a Court Martial in such circumstances — Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972, Arts. 102(2)(5), 109 and 114. Jamil Huq (Ex-Captain) Vs. Bangladesh and others 1 BLD (AD) 488.

 

Detention on vague and unspecified allegations — Detention on vague, in­definite and unspecified allegations with­out giving sufficient materials to enable the detenu to make effective repre­sentation to the appropriate authority is illegal — Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974)S 3.

 

Order of detention and specific criminal case — Whether a valid order of detention can be made on the grounds for which specific cases were started against the detenu — When a specific case has been started in relation to the alleged activities of the detenu, the same activitycould not in all fairness be taken as a reasonable basis for making an order of detention — Such grounds are not legal and valid and render the order of detention illegal — Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) Ss. 2 and 3.

 

Whether a detenu can be detained on the basis of a subsequent valid order of detention when he was kept under illegal detention earlier without any valid order of detention — Subsequent valid order of detention can not validate a previous illegal detention order — Detenu having been kept under illegal detention without any order of detention at all, his subse­quent detention, even if it was a valid order, made the entire detention illegal.

 

Failure to furnish to the detenu the grounds of detention within the specified time — Failure to furnish to the detenu the grounds of detention within the specified time makes the detention illegal.

 

If the grounds of detention are not served on the detenu within 15 days of the detention, his detention becomes illegal on the expiry of 15 days.

 

Grounds of detention to be placed before the Advisory Board — Section 10 of the Special Powers Act provides that the Government shall within 120 days from the date of detention order place before the Advisory Board constituted under Section 9 of the Act grounds on which the order has been made and the representation, if any, made by the person affected by the order — Failure of the Government to do so renders the detention illegal — Special Powers act (XIV of 1974) S 10.

 

Whether a detenu can be detained on the basis of an order of detention when on the same date the order of his earlier detention was revoked by the same authority — The Government passed two inconsistent orders on the same date, one directing the revocation of the detention and his immediate release and the other for his fresh detention — This exposes the fact that on the one hand the Government felt satisfied that there was no cause for his detention and on the next breath the Government expressed its satisfaction that he should be detained — This establishes that the Government failed to apply its judicial mind in the matter of deciding the detention of the petitioner — Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) Ss. 2,3, and 10. Syedur Rahman Khalifa Vs. The Secretary, Minsitry of Home Affairs and others 6 BLD (HCD) 272.

 

Ref. 20 DLR 1005; 28 DLR 117 and 48; 31 DLR (AD) 1; 30 DLR 423; 27 DLR 245 and 576; 33 DLR 110; 18 DLR (SC) 250; 18 DLR (Dhaka) 214

 

Non-communication of the grounds of detention — After the detention the detaining authority is bound to commu­nicate to the detenu the grounds of his detention — This communication must be either at the time of detention or within 15 days from the date of detention so that the detenu is able to make an effective representation to the authority against the order of detention — The service of detention order under Section 3 of the Special Powers Act incorporating vague, indefinite, evasive and uncertain grounds can not be treated as sufficient commu­nication of the grounds of detention — Such detention order does not enable the detenu to make any effective representa­tion against the order of detention — Non-communication of the grounds of detention makes his detention illegal — Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) S 8 (1) and (2).

 

Grounds of detention to placed be­fore the Advisory Board — The grounds of detention must be placed before the Advisory Board within 120 days from the date of detention required under Section 10 of the Special Powers Act — The non-observance of this provision of Section 10 renders the detention illegal — Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) S 10.

 

Whether the High Court Division has jurisdiction to interfere with an order of detention passed under the Special Powers Act — The High Court Division has jurisdiction under Section 491 Cr.P.C to interfere with an order of detention passed under the Special Powers Act where the detaining authority does not comply with the mandatory provisions of the Special Powers Act — It cannot be said that the detention of the detenu is lawful under the provisions of the Special Powers Act — In that case the High Court Division has jurisdiction under Section 491 Cr.P.C. to interfere with an illegal detention though it purports to be under an enactment providing for preven­tive detention — Code of Crimina Pro­cedure (V of 1898) S491(3).

 

The bar to jurisdiction of the Courts — The bar provided in Section 34 of the Special Powers Act does not protect orders passed in bad faith or in abuse of the act — Consequently when these issues are raised, the same are required to be investigated and Section 34 can not stand as a bar in such investigation — Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) S 34. Sultana Ara Begum Vs. Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs and others 7 BLD (HCD) 138.

 

Ref. 30 DLR 423; 31 DLR (AD) 1; 1942 (AC) 206; 1951 (AC) 66; 19 DLR (SC) 403; 20 DLR (SC) 249; 21 DLR (SC)1, 28 DLR 172 and 259; 27 DLR 295; AIR 1940 (PC) 105.

 

Duty of the court under Section 491 Cr.P.C. — The duty of the Court under Section 491 Cr.P.C. is to see that the or­der of detention is not malafide or that the grounds given are not colourable, vague, irrelevant or evasive — The Court has got powers to examine the reasonableness of the authority's satis­faction as to detention of a person — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 491. Sultana Ara Begum Vs. Secre­tary, Ministry of Home Affairs and others 7 BLD (HCD) 138.

 

Detention — Whether its validity is to be decided in a writ petition challenging the detention — Whether the Rule becomes infructuous on the revocation of the  order  of detention  and  a fresh application is to be filed to challenge the subsequent order of detention — It is not the question of order of detention, it is the detention itself of the detenu which is the subject matter of the Rule — In case of detention the Court is to satisfy itself that the person is not being held in custody without lawful authority or in an unlawful manner — The scope of enquiry is not in any way fattered by procedures of a Writ of Habeas Corpus or the Rule laid down under the various Habeas Cropus Acts — The Court is to see that the executive authority had before it sufficient materials upon which a reasonable person would have come to the conclussion that the requirements of law were satisfied — The constitutional obligation is to see whether the person is being held without unlawful authority or in an unlawful manner — Only a valid order of detention could be continued by a subsequent order of de­tention which, of course is to be valid — An illegal order cannot be continued by a subsequent valid order of detention.

 

The only point to be determined in the writ petition is whether at the time of hearing of the Rule there is a valid order of detention before the High Court Di­vision so that it may satisfy itself that the detenu is not being held in custody without lawful authority or in an unlawful manner — The fact of detention and not the date of order of detention is the material consideration — In case of continued detention the aggrieved peti­tioner has got a running grievance.

 

Detention — If found malafide — It is well settled that malafide vitiates every­thing — The statement of the Home Minister when puts in juxtaposition with the grounds of detention the conclusion becomes obvious that the order of de­tention was passed for collateral purposes — The Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972, Art 102(2)(b). Mrs. Sajeda Parvin Banu Vs. Government of Bangladesh and others 8 BLD (AD) 129.

 

Ref. 21 DLR (SC) 1; 20 DLR (SC) 249; 31 DLR (AD) 1; AIR 1945 (FC) 18; 46 Cr.L.J. 559; DLR 29; PLD 1949 (Dhaka) 1; 3 DLR 50; 18 DLR (Dhaka) 539; 26 DLR (HCD) 201; 27 DLR (HCD) 198; 27 DLR (HCD) 199; AIR 1952 (SC) 106; AIR 1966 (SC) 1404; AIR 1975 (SC) 623; AIR 1973 (SC) 897, 34 DLR (AD) 229.

 

Service of grounds of detention on the detenu — Order of detention con­taining the object of detention can be considered to be service of grounds of detention — Whether service of grounds of detention beyond 15 days of the order of detention is valid and legal — When the order of detention does not contain the allegations for which detention order was made enabling the detenu to make an effective representation against his deten­tion the same cannot be considered as service of grounds of detention — Grounds of detention must be served upon the detenu within 15 days of his detention — Failure to furnish the grounds of detention within the required time makes the detention illegal — Even subsequent valid order of detention can­not validate the vital illegal detention — Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) Ss. 3 and 8 Syam Sundar Rajgharia Vs. M. A. Salam Additional District Magistrate, Chittagong and others 8 BLD (HCD) 127.

 

Ref. 18 DLR 214; 33 DLR 130; 31 DLR (AD) 1; PLD 1959 (Dhaka) 774; AIR 1953 (SC) 318; AIR 1970 (SC) 852; 28 DLR (1970) 2.

 

Nexus between the order of detention and the grounds of detention and the satisfaction of the detaining authority —The order of detention must co-exist with the facts and materials of detention as contanied in the grounds of detention — There is no nexus between some of the reasons shown in the order of detention and the facts and reasons for detention as disclosed in the grounds — There is divergence between the order of detention and the grounds of detention and such divergence can be interpreted as showing both lack of application of the mind by the detaining authority as well as callousness towards the person detained for which the order of detention is liable to be struck down — Since the grounds of detention are vague and indefinite the detention cannot be sustained in law — The materials disclosed in the grounds of detention will not satisfy a man of average prudence that the detention is warranted — Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) Ss. 3 and 8.

 

Detention and service of grounds by the Additional District Magistrate —Whether the Government can pass an independent order of detention without serving fresh grounds — The Government can either approve the order passed by the District Magistrate or Additional District Magistrate or pass an independent order of detention — The order dated 23.2.87 cannot be called either an order extending the earlier order of detention passed by the Additional District Magistrate or an independent order as no fresh grounds of detention were served upon the detenu — Since the order of detention by the Government has no legal foundation, all subsequent orders extending detention cannot be valid orders — Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) Ss 3 and 8.

 

Executive Orders — All executive orders of the Government shall be ex­pressed to be taken in the name of the President — Rules of business of the Government as well as the provision of the Constitution provide the same — Some of the orders of detention were made and signed in the name of the President and the others in the name of the Government — Orders made and signed, if do not conform to the provision of the Constitution and Rules of business, then they become executive orders without authority — The Constitution of Bangladesh 1972, .Art. 56(2). Md Khair Ahmed Vs. Bangladesh and others 8 BLD (HCD) 157.

 

Ref. 31 DLR (AD) 1, PLD 1959 (Dhaka) 774; AIR 1954 (SC) 179; AIR 1966 (SC) 740; AIR 1970 (SC) 852; 28 DLR 48; 27 DLR 122.

 

Detention on the ground of public safety — Whether permissible — The Special Powers Act, 1974, only empowers the Government to detain a person only to prevent him from doing prejudicial acts — There is no provision for making a detention order merely in the interest of public safety — Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974)S 3.

 

Prejudicial Act — Whether non­payment of loan taking from the Shilpa Bank is a prejudicial act — Prejudicial act also means any act which is intended likely to prejudice the economic and financial interest of the state — The act of intentional non-payment of loan has prejudiced the economic or financial interest of the state and as such it amounts to a prejudicial act — Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974)S2.

  

Detention order for default in repay­ment of loan from the Shilpa Bank is a prejudicial act but such non-payment cannot be a ground for preventive detention — Preventive detention is meant for preventing some one from doing any prejudicial act in the future — There is no authority to order detention for default already made in repayment of the loan and as such non-payment though a prejudicial act has already been done and it cannot be prevented by detention — Prejudicial act already done is an offence for which criminal case can be filed — When a specific criminal case has already been filed detention on the self­same allegations cannot be ordered — Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) Ss. 3 and 16. Mrs. Tali era Islam Vs. Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs and others 8 BLD (HCD) 262Ref. 6 BLD (AD) 49; 38 DLR (AD) 17; 20 DLR (Dhaka) 1005; 28 DLR 117

 

Order of detention — Nexus between satisfaction and order of detention — It is well settled that there must be a rational nexus between the satisfaction of the detaining authority and the order of detention — Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) Ss. 2(f)iii, (v), (vii) and (viii).

 

Grounds of detention to be placed before the Advisory  Board — Thedetention   as   become   illegal   as the Government did not place the grounds of detention  before  the  Advisory Board within 120 days from the order of de­tention — The Constitution of Bangla­desh,  1972, Arts. 31, 32 and 33 Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) Ss 10-12    Mrs.   Shahana   Begum Vs. Bangladesh 8 BLD (HCD) 28 Ref. 3 1 DLR (AD) 1

 

Communication of the grounds of detention — Communicating the grounds of detention in a leisurely manner is not permissible — The provision made in the Special Powers Act "but not later than 15 days from the date of detention" does not give a general licence to the detaining authority to cause service of grounds of detention in a leisurely manner within 15 days in every case delibaretely to deprive the detenu of his valuable legal right to make an effective representation to the appropriate authority at the earlier possible opportunity or to move the Court at once — Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972, Art. 33(5) — Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) S 8(2).

 

Report of the Advisory Board and decision of the Court — If the Rule has been issued by the Court and if the same is ready for hearing it is the duty of the court, in view of the provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure and the Constitution, to hear the matter at once giving opportunity to the parties to make their submissions and pronounce its de­cision as early as possible without waiting for the Advisory Board to report its opinion to the Government — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 491 — Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972 Art. 102.

 

Grounds of detention must have ra­tional probative value — Grounds of detention served on the detenu and the materials before the detaining authority must have rational probative value — Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) S 3(1).

 

Preventive detention of a foreigner —In the case of a citizen of a foreign country preventive detention is uncalled for — Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) S 3(1 )(b) Dr. Ma\ Habibullah Vs. Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs and others 9 BLD (HCD) 387.

 

Ref. 31 DLR (AD) 1, 20 DLR (SC) 249; 21 DLR (SC) 1; 19 DLR (SC) 403; AIR 1975 (SC)   623; 1951 (AC) 66

 

Habeas Corpus — Scope of an appli­cation under Section 491 of the Code of Criminal Procedure — The High Court has discretion in the matter as regards the nature of the order to be passed and that it may pass any order any time  — The words "illegally" or "improperly" used in the Section means that when a person is not detained within the provision of any law it becomes an illegal detention — The words"improperly" refers to cases in which although the forms of the law have been observed but there has been a fraud on the Act or an abuse of the process of the powers given to the executive — In such cases it is the duty of the Court to step in and order the detenu to be set at liberty — The scope of Section 491 Cr PC is wider than the constitutional provision — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 491 Syeda Rezja Begum Vs. The People's Republic of Bangladesh and others 9 BLD (HCD) 441.

 

Fresh order of detention — When it is illegal — The Government revoked the order of detention of the detenu but instead of releasing him passed a fresh order of detention under the Special Powers Act —i This fresh order of de­tention without releasing the detenu from the jail is illegal — Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) S 3(1 )(a).

 

Detention for over six months —Validity 'of such detention without ap­proval by the Advisory Board — It is clear from the provision of the constitu­tion that if the Advisory Board does not report within six months that there is sufficient cause for the detention, the Government can not detain the detenu beyond six months.

 

The case of the detenu must be placed before the Advisory Board within six months. The case of the detenu was not placed before the Advisory Board within six months of his detention as required by Section 10 of the Special Powers Act — The order of detention is therefore in contravention of the constitutional provi­sion — The Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972, Art. 33(4) — Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) Ss. 3 and 10. Manowara Begum Vs. Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs and others 9 BLD (HCD) 467.

 

Detention order — Time lag between prejudicial activity and detention order — Obligation of the detaining authority to explain the delay — In the present case there is a delay of over 2 years in making the detention order after the incidents of prejudicial activity — The time lag being so wide and there being no explanation as to why the detention order was passed after such a long time, the detaining authority is held to have failed to furnish a rational nexus between the grounds of detention and the passing of the order of detention and as such the same is declared illegal — Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) S 8 Mahbuba Waited Vs. Govern­ment of Bangladesh and others 10 BLD (HCD) 19

 

Person in public custody — Determi­nation of age for guardianship — The isolated statetment of the father in such a case in respect of the age of the detenu (his daughter) cannot be accepted as true unless it is supported by other inde­pendent corroborative evidence — The petitioner prayed for declaration of the detention as illegal and claimed custody of the girl on the ground of minority — He could be entitled to the custody of the girl if she was found below 16 years — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 491 — Penal Code (XLV of 1860) Ss 361 and 366A. Manindra Kumar Malakar Vs. Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs and others 10 BLD (HCD) 85.

 

Ref. 17 DLR (Dhaka) 544; 28 DLR 122; 15 DLR (Dhaka) 148; AIR 1933 (Cal) 362

Person in public custody — Question of giving her to father's custody — Even if it is presumed that at the time of occur­rence of the alleged kidnapping she was a minor but now if she is found major the Court has no power to compel the major girl to go with her father — Code of Criminal Procedure ( V of 1898) S 491 — Penal Code (XLV of 1860) Ss. 361 and 366A. Manindra Kumar Malakar Vs. Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs and others 10 BLD (HCD) 85.

 

Order of detention — Successive orders of detention passed keeping the detenu in custody after previous orders are illegal — As soon as the illegality of the order of detention is communicated to the respondents, the order of detention loses its force and becomes an illegal order unless appealed against and a stay is obtained — The order of detention pur­porting to continue an illegal detention cannot be sustained — Third order of detention falls through on this ground alone — Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974)S 3.

 

Grounds of detention — Repetition of the same grounds in support of sub­sequent orders of detention which have been declared illegal — On the ground of serving an illegal ground of detention also the detention becomes illegal — The grounds which were once declared illegal in the same cause cannot acquire legality by repeated use — They suffer the same fate — Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) S 3 and 8.

 

Fresh grounds of detention — Service of fresh grounds and the question of their validity — Within the specified time of 15 days the detaining authority can add, vary or amend any ground but after its expiry they have no legal authority to add or substitute any ground — Service of fresh grounds served beyond the specified time illegal — Such recourse to illegal grounds is an act of patent malafide — Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) Ss. 3 and 8

 

Repeated   orders   of detention —Whether every order need be specifically challenged — Respondents may pass any number of orders during the period of one's detention but it is not necessary for the petitioner to challenge every order as long as the detention is under challenge — The Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972, Art. 102 — Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) S 3 Mrs. Alam Ara Huq Vs. Government of Bangladesh and others lO BLD(HCD) 113

 

Judicial   Review   of Detentoin —Subjective satisfaction of the detaining authority and the objective satisfaction of the Court — The need for judicial review when arises — A conflict between the constitutional mandate and the arbitrary and colourable exercise of power by the detaining authority calls for the exercise of judicial review by the High Court Division to strike down actions which are "malafide, colourable exercise of statutorypower or action taken upon extraneous or irrelevant considerations or action taken on no ground or without application of mind" to deprive a citizen of his personal liberty in an unlawful manner — The order of detention must bear a rational nexus between the satisfaction of the detaining authority and the order of detention.

 

Grounds of detention — These being vague, indefinite and lacking in material particulars as to time, place and manner to conform to or to co-relate with the order of detention preventing the detenu from making proper representation to the appropriate authority have been held to be illegal — Further more, for individual isolated acts of crimes viz theft, dacoity or hijacking or collection of tolls, detention law cannot be applied to deprive the constitutionally guaranteed right of liberty of a citizen.

 

Section 3(1) — Initial order of de­tention valid upto certain period — Within that period no valid fresh order of detention was passed — After the expiry of the first order, the detention becomes illegal — Subsequent order of detention even if valid, is liable to be struck down on the ground that it proceeds on an illegal detention — Order of detention not co-relative to or co-extensive with the factum of detention, the detention is held illegal.

 

Maximum period for which a person may  be  held  in  detention  — The Government can hold a person in deten­tion for a maximum period of 120 days — The Government is bound to place the case of detenu before the Advisory Board within 120 days — Non-compliance with this mandatory provision of law renders the order of detention illegal and void — Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) S 3(1) — The Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972, Article 32 — Code of Criminal Pro­cedure (V of 1898 ) S 491. NazirAli Vs. Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs and others 10 BLD (HCD ) 258 Ref. 31 DLR(AD) 1;2 BSCR 141.

 

Grounds of detention — Section 8 of the Special Powers Act, 1974 provides that the detaining authority must furnish the grounds of detention to the detenu within 15 days from the date of making the order of detention — The detaining authority having failed to comply with this mandatory provision of law to furnish the grounds of detention to the detenu so as to enable him to submit any effective representation to the detaining authority against his detenu, the detention of the detenu becomes illegal and without any lawful authority — Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) Ss 3(2) and 8(2) Haji Md Joynal Ahedin Vs. Bangladesh and others 10 BLD (HCD) 364

 

Extension of the period of detention after its expiry — The first order of detention was made on 15.4 1989 by the Additional District Magistrate, Dhaka which expired on 14.5.1989 — The Ministry of Home Affairs by its order dated 22.5 1989 extended the order of detention with retrospective effect after the expiry of 30 days from the date of making the initial order of detention on 15.4.1989 — Under sub-Section 3 of Sec­tion 3 of the Act the Government is not authorized to extend the period of deten­tion with retrospective effect and as such the detention of the detenu is illegal and without any lawful authority — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 491 Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) S 3(2)(3). Mamtaz Sultana Vs. Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs and others 10 BLD (HCD) 367.

 

Vague  and  indefinite  grounds —Grounds of detention being vague and indefinite do not enable the detenu to make any effective representation to the detaining authority against his detention_Detention on such grounds is illegal.

 

Specific criminal case against the detenu — Pendency of a specific criminal case against the detenu should not be a ground for detention.

 

Effect of unsigned order of detention__This obviously means that no com­petent officer of the Government in the Ministry of Home Affairs applied his mindto the case at all — Non-application of mind makes the order of detention illegal—Furthermore, any order of detention not signed by the competent officer of the Government cannot be treated as a valid order of detention — Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) Ss. 33(2) and 8. Abdul Hakim Miah Vs. The Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs and others 10 BLD (HCD) 400.Ref. 40 DLR (HCD) 193; 31 DLR (AD).

 

Supply of the grounds of detention—Compliance of the provision of Section 8 of the Special Powers Act for supply of the grounds of detention to the detenu within 15 days of the initial order of detention mandatory — Failure of the detaining authority renders the detention illegal and unauthorised — Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) S 3 and 8. Md Shah Alam Vs. Bangladesh and others 10 BID (HCD) 428Ref. 4DLR 156.

 

Section 10 of the Special Powers Act — Failure of the Government to do so renders the detention illegal — Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) Ss. 2(f), 3(1) 3(2), 8(1), 10 and 12(1) Md Golam Hossain Vs. The State 11 BLD (HCD) 54. Ref. 6 BLD (HCD) 272.

 

Authority of the Government to detain a person — Under Section 3(1 )(a) of the Special Powers Act, 1974 the Govern­ment is empowered to detain any person if it is satisfied that with a view to preven­ting him from doing any prejudicial act, it is necessary to make an order directing that such a person be detained.

 

Non-payment of bank loan — Non payment of bank loan does not amount to a prejudicial act within the meaning of Section 2(f)(viii) of the Special Powers Act and as such a defaulting loanee cannot be detained under Section 3 of the Act.

 

There must be a nexus between the order of detention and the ground ofdetention — Detention for collateral purpose is malafide and as such illegal.

Article 102 (2)(b)(I) of the Constitution of Bangladesh and detention of a citizen_Scope and purpose of — Article 102(2)(b)(I) of the Constitution is intended for directing a person in custody to be brought before the Court so that it may satisfy itself that the detenu is not being detained without lawful authority.

 

Under Article 102(2)(a)(ii) of the Constitution the High Court Division may declare any act done or proceeding taken by a person performing functions in connection with the affairs of the Republic or of a local authority to have been done or taken without lawful authority and is of no legal effect — It can only be done on the application of the aggrieved persons_Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) Ss. 2(f) (viii), 3(I)(a) and 8 — Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972 Article 102(2)(b)(I) and Article 102(2)(a)(ii). Mirza Ali Ashraf Vs. The State and others 11 BLD (HCD) 88.

 

Vague and indefinite grounds of de­tention — Grounds of detention being vague and indefinite without any particu­lar or positive allegation of any kind of prejudicial act, detention on such grounds without giving sufficient materials to the detenu to enable him to make any effective representation to the detaining authority render the detention illegal — Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) Ss. 2(f) and 8 Md. Sekandar Ali Vs. TheGovernment of the People's Republic of Bangladesh and others 11 BLD (HCD) 112.

 

Ref. 31 DLR (AD) 1; 28 DLR (HCD) 259; AIR 1970 (SC) 85; PLD 1959 (Dhaka) 774; AIR 1953 (SC) 318; 40 DLR (HCD) 353

 

Communication of the grounds of detention — Under Section 8 of the Special Powers Act the grounds of detention must be communicated to the detenu within 15 days from the date of detention — Grounds supplied after the expiry of the statutory period renders the detention illegal and without lawful authority — Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) Ss. 2(f), 3(1 )(a) and 8. Hqji Md Kashem Ali Vs. Government of Bangladesh and others 11 BLD (HCD) 361

 

Continuous detention for more than two years — The detenu has been in continuous detention for more than two and half years in pursuance of successive orders of deterntion which were found illegal in various writ petitions before the High Court Division and the Court directed the respondents to set the detenu at liberty forthwith and to report compliance of the order — But instead the detenu was served with a fresh order of detention which was also declared illegal — In the meantime the detenu was shown arrested in several criminal cases in one of which he was granted bail by the High Court Division while the rest of the cases ended either in his acquittal or discharge.

 

The authority acted in a high-handed manner and paid little regard to the order of the Court to set the detenu at liberty forth with — The authority is under an obligation under Article 32 of the Constitution to protect the liberty of citizens and is further required under Article 122 of the Constitution to act in aid of the Court.The authority should not flout the laws by resorting to authoritarian acts.

 

Orders of detention were found to be illegal as being colourable exercise of powers — Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) Ss. 3(l)(a), 3(2) and 8 — The Constitution of Bangladesh 1972, Articles 32 and 112. Farzana Huq Vs. Bangladesh and others 11 BLD (HCD) 533.Ref. 40 DLR (AD) 178; 18 DLR (SC) 214; AIR 1974 (SC) 1336

 

Initial order of detention void abini-tio — Subsequent gazettee notification also becomes void — When the order of detention is a nullity and void abinitio the subsequent gazettee notification under Section 7(b) of the Special Powers Act, 1974 also becomes a nullity and void abinitio and the consequential proceeding before the Special Tribunal under Section 7(b) of the Act for non-compliance becomes illegal and without lawful authority.

 

Fundamental right of a citizen — Tocurtail the fundamental right or the personal liberty of a citizen which is en­shrined in Ariticle 32 read with Article 33 of the Constitution, it is essential that the detaining authority must have reports and materials, that is, "jurisdictional facts" for exercising its power to detain a citizen under Section 3 read with Section 8 of the Special Powers ActSpecial Powers Act (XIV of 1974) Ss. 3, 7(b) and 8 — The Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972, Articles 32 and 33. Anisul Islam Mahmood Vs. The Government of the People's Republic of Bangladesh and others 12 BLD (HCD) 239.

 

Ref. AIR 1984 (SC) 681; 43 DLR 186; AIR 1949 (Lahore) 131 (FB); PLD 1966 (SC) 802; 1 (1958) All ER 679; (686); (1969) 1 All ER 208; (1947) 1 All ER 205; 11 BLD 345; AIR 1957 (SC) 1506; AIR 1957 (SC) 882; AIR 1974 (SC) 1471; 31 DLR (AD) 1.

 

Detention on vague and indefinite grounds — No person can be detained on vague and indefinite grounds as the same do not enable him to make an effective representation to the detaining authority.

 

Pendency  of a  criminal   case —Pendency of a criminal case against the detenu cannot be the reasonable basis for detaining him under Section 3 of the Special Powers Act, 1974. Mrs. Sultana Begum Vs. The Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs and others 11 BLD (HCD) 449.

 

Satisfaction of the detaining authority— In the absence of any mention in the order of detention and the grounds of detention as to what prejudicial act or acts the detenu indulged in from which the government was satisfie with respect to any person that with a view to preventing him from doing prejudicial act or acts hisdetention was necessary — The order of detention becomes unauthorised — Cons­titution of Bangladesh, 1972, Article 102. Rashed Hasan Vs. The Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs and others 12 BLD (HCD) 363.

 

Specific Criminal Case — When there is a specific criminal case against the detenu on certain allegation, the self-same allegation can not constitute a ground for detention of the detenu under the Special Powers Act Sree Utpal Kumar Dutta Vs. The Government of Bangladesh and others 12 BLD (HCD) 375.

 

1257

HEARSAY EVIDENCE

Citation: 1 BLD (HCD) 107.Ref. AIR 1942 (Cal) 214; 1 (1956) WLR. 965; 97 IC 785, 5 BLD (HCD) 129.Ref. 1 (1956) WLR (65 9970); 1 (1960) All ER331, 8 BLD (HCD) 36, 10 BLD (AD) 251, 10 BLD (HCD) 309

Subject: HEARSAY EVIDENCE

Delivery Date: 2018-07-31

HEARSAY EVIDENCE

 

Hearsay Evidence — Generally speak­ing the statements or declarations of persons not called as witness but repeated by a third person are excluded as hearsay — But statement of a person not called as a witnesses is admissible when it is proposed to establish by evidence not the truth of the statement but the fact that it was made — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 60 S. M. Quamruzzaman Vs. The State 1 BLD (HCD) 107.Ref. AIR 1942 (Cal) 214; 1 (1956) WLR. 965; 97 IC 785.

 

Hearsay Evidence— When statement cannot be ruled out as hearsay — It is hearsay and inadmissible when the object of the evidence is to establish the truth of what is contained in the statement — It is not hearsay and is admissible when it is proposed to establish not the truth of the statement but the fact that it was madeEvidence Act (1 of 1872) S 60. Shafiullah alias Kala Mia Vs. The State 5 BLD (HCD) 129.Ref. 1 (1956) WLR (65 9970); 1 (1960) All ER331.

 

Hearsay Evidence — When it appears that all the witnesses heard about the occurrence, such kind of evidence is merely hearsay evidence and accused petitioners can not be convicted on the basis of such evidence — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 60 Yusuf Ali and others Vs. The State 8 BLD (HCD) 36.

 

Hearsay Evidence — Section 32 of the Evidence Act is an exception to the well known maxim 'hearsay evidence is no evidence' — The dying declaration though made to a police officer of a different police station is to be presumed to have been made to a private person and for non-examination of the person who recor­ded the declaration, no exception is legally sustainable as to the mode of proving the dying declaration — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 32. .V. K. Shamsur Rahman alias Shamsu Vs. The State 10 BLD (AD) 251.

 

Hearsay Evidence — When admissible — Statement of the deceased made before his murder as to the circumstances of the transaction resulting in his death is admissible in evidence — The witness stated that in the evening of the date of occurrence he heard from deceased Khalil that the two accused had hired his van and took him to Jessore to bring greencoconuts — Though this part of the evidence is hearsay from the deceased, it is admissible in evidence being the circumstances of the transaction which resulted in the death of the deceased — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 32. Abul Kashem and another Vs. The State 10 BLD (HCD) 309

 

 

 

 

1258

JUDGMENT IN CRIMINAL APPEALS

Citation: 4 BLD (AD) 213, 4 BLD (HCD) 297, 8 BLD (AD) 193

Subject: JUDGMENT IN CRIMINAL APPEALS

Delivery Date: 2018-07-31

JUDGMENT IN CRIMINAL APPEALS

 

Criminal Appeal — It's dismissal with­out discussion of any evidence and with­out writing a full-fledged judgment is not justified There should have been some discussion of the evidence before affirm­ing the conviction of the appellants — There is no discussion about the nature of the offence or the part played by the indi­vidual accused persons — The impugned judgment is set aside and the case is re­manded to the High Court Division for disposal according to law — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 423 Serajuddoula alias Md Serajuddoula and others Vs. The State 4 BLD (AD) 213.

 

Judgment in Criminal appeal — Contents of — Since the judgment contains no fact and it has given no reason for affirming the judgment of the trial Court after discussion of evidence, the appeal must be re-heard and the lower appellate Court is directed to dispose of the appeal afresh in accordance with law — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) Ss. 324 and 367. Ibrahim Bepari and others Vs. Lutfor Rahman Bhuiyan and another 4 BLD (HCD) 297

 

Contents of a Judgment — Provisions for writing out the judgment were not strictly followed by the Magistrate but the main points of the case are found to have been duly considered by him — The High Court Division rightly held that though the judgment of the Magistrate was not in proper form, the order of acquittal passed by the Magistrate did not cause any miscarriage of justice — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) Ss. 367 and 537 Md Nurul Huda Vs. Bhashanu Sardar and others 8 BLD (AD) 193.

 

1259

SANCTION

Citation: 1 BLD (HCD) 82. Ref. AIR 1943 (FC) 18; AIR 1964 (SC) 269, 4 RLD (AD) 125, 5 RLD (AD) 185. Ref. 35DLR (AD) 324, 8 RLD (HCD) 246 Ref. AIR 1955 (SC) 309; AIR 1948 (PC) 128 (133), 9 BLD (HCD) 144. Ref. 32 DLR (AD) 100; 35 DLR 249, 9 BLD (HCD) 485, 10 BLD (AD

Subject: SANCTION

Delivery Date: 2018-08-12

SANCTION

Public Servant — Sanction to prosecute Sub-Inspector of police and constables — Sub-Inspector of police and constables being removable by the Inspector General and the Superintendent of police, they are not such public servants as are not removable save by or the sanction of the Government — No sanction under Section 197 Cr.P.C. is necessary to prose­cute them, even though the police officer and the constables involved might have committed the offence while acting or purporting to act in the discharge of their official duty — Code of Criminal Proce- dure (V of 1898) S 197. Rokeya Begum Vs. Shafiqur Rahman and the State 1 BLD (HCD) 82. Ref. AIR 1943 (FC) 18; AIR 1964 (SC) 269

Purpose of Sanction for Prosecution

—   The provision for sanction is intended to protect officers of the Government from harassment by unncessary prosecu­tion — No prosecution shall lie against the public servants without prior sanction from the appropriate authority — If the Board of Revenue had reason to believe that the concerned Customs Officers acted bonafide and they had no 'mens rea' the Board could have refused sanction _Criminal Law Amendment Act (XL of 1958) S 6(5) A. K. Reazaul Karim Vs. The State 4 RLD (AD) 125

Cognizance and trial without sanction

—   Chargesheet was not accompanied by sanction for prosecution of the appellant who is admittedly a public servant — The Special Judge also did not write for sanction to the appropriate authority and as such the taking of cognizance by the Special Judge was not valid in law — Criminal Law Amendment Act (XL of 1958) S 6(5) A S. S. Mohammad AH Vs. The State 5 RLD (AD) 185. Ref. 35DLR (AD) 324.

—    

Criminal Trial — Sanction for prosecution of a public servant — When bar of sanction can be claimed — Being a mere public servant a person cannot claim the bar of sanction unless he acted as a public servant in discharge of his official duty while committing the alleged offence — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 197(1). Sudhir Chandra Das Gupta and others Vs. Rhopal Chandra Chowdhury 8 RLD (HCD) 246 Ref. AIR 1955 (SC) 309; AIR 1948 (PC) 128 (133).

Cognizance   by   special   judge —Question of validity of his taking cogni­zance upon a complaint made to a Magis­trate — A complaint made orally or in writing to a Magistrate will be a complaint and when the Magistrate sends that complaint to the Special Judge along with the deposition of witnesses recorded by him and his comments for the Special Judge to take cognizance and if on that cognizance is taken again it cannot be said that the Special Judge has not taken cognizance on a complaint — Criminal Law Amendment Act (XL of 1958) S 4(1) — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 4(h).

Criminal trial — Question of obtaining prior sanction to prosecute a public ser­vant — The interpretation that such sanction of the Government in terms of Section 197 Cr.P.C. could be obtained even after the submission of the charge sheet but before the trial had started could be made applicable in respect of sanction required under the Criminal Law Amendment Act (XL of 1958) S 6(5) — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 197 — Penal Code (XLV of 1860) Ss. 406 and 409 Matiar Rahman Vs. The State and others 9 BLD (HCD) 144. Ref. 32 DLR (AD) 100; 35 DLR 249

Prosecuting an approver — Sanction for prosecution — The contention that without the sanction of the High Court Division the prosecution of the approver was illegal has no substance for the prosecution is attracted only where after forfeiture of parden the approver is wanted to be prosecuted for giving false evidence — In this case since the ap­prover has not been prosecuted for giving false evidence but he has been prosecuted only for committing dacoity in respect of which the pardon was granted, no such sanction was required — Code of Crimi­nal Procedure (V of 1898) S 339(3). Angur Vs. The State 9 BLD (HCD) 485.

Sanction for prosecution is mandatory— Objection as to sanction when to be taken — Sanction for prosecution is a mandatory provision of law in the trial of a public servant — But objection as to sanction is to be raised during the trial or during the appeal and that having not done it cannot be raised for the first time before the Appellate Division — More­over the record shows that the order of sanction was there in the record and it was perused by the learned Special Judge as recorded in the order sheet and as such the objection as to sanction was not tenable at this stage — Criminal Law Amendment Act (XL of 1958) S 6 — Penal Code (XLV of 1860) S 409 read with 5(2) of Act 11 of 1947. Liakat Ali alias Md Liakat Ali Vs. The State 10 BLD (AD) 165.

Sanction to prosecute is the discretion of the authority — Its importance — The sanction to prosecute is a very important matter and it constitutes a condition precedent to the launching of the prosecu­tion — The Government has an absolute discretion in granting or withholding sanction — The authority is merely to see that the evidence discloses a prima facie case against the person sought to be prosecuted — The sanctioning authority can refuse sanctions on any ground which commends itself to them.

Where facts are not referred to on the face of the sanction nor is it proved by evidence that they were placed before the sanctioning authority, the sanction is in­valid — Criminal Law Amendment Act (XL of 1958) S 6 — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 197 — Penal Code (XLV of 1860) S 467. Md Abdul Hakim Vs. The State 12 BLD (HCD) 400. Ref. 1962 PLD (Dhaka) 623; AIR 1948 (PC) 82.

Jurisdiction of Senior Special Judge— The Senior Special Judge is the only judge who has power for taking cogni­zance of an offence under the Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1958 though there may be other Special Judges within the same territorial jurisdiction — Criminal Law Amendment Act (XL of 1958) S 4(1 )(2) and Section 5(1 )(e) of Act II of 1947 H. M. Ershad Vs. The State 12 BLD (HCD) 610.

Sanction when not needed — No sanction is necessary for prosecution of a public servant who has ceased to be a public servant. H. M. Ershad Vs. The State 12 BLD (HCD) 610.

1260

DEMEANOUR OF WITNESSES

Citation: 11 BLD (AD) 2, 2 BLD (HCD) 495. Ref. 20 DLR 407; 587; 21 DLR (SC) 182; 1982 BCR (HCD) 367; AIR 1948 (Lahore) 27; AJR 1954 (SC) 322.

Subject: DEMEANOUR OF WITNESSES

Delivery Date: 2018-08-12

DEMEANOUR OF WITNESSES

 

Demeanour of witnesses — The ap­preciation of evidence of the trial court based on observation of the demeanour of the witnesses should not be dismissed easily Abu Taker Chowdhuty and others Vs. The State 11 BLD (AD) 2

 

Decoy witness — To establish a case of bribery against an accused alleged to have accepted marked currency notes from a decoy witness employed by the police in furtherance of the trap against the accused, it is not a sufficient proof that the marked notes passed from the decoy witness to the accused — There must be independent corroboration of the statement of the decoy witness — The Prevention of Corruption Act (I of 1947) S 5(2). A. K. M. Mokhlesur Rahman Vs. The State 12 BLD (HCD) 495. Ref. 20 DLR 407; 587; 21 DLR (SC) 182; 1982 BCR (HCD) 367; AIR 1948 (Lahore) 27; AJR 1954 (SC) 322.

1261

WITNESS

Citation: 5 BLD (HCD) 111).Ref. 21 DLR 575; 24 DLR 217, 5 BLD (HCD) 84, 3 BLD (HCD) 277, 5 BLD (HCD) 20, 6 BLD (AD) 216, 6 BLD (HCD) 34, 7 BLD (AD) 27, 8 BLD (HCD) 106, 9 BLD (HCD) 474, 10 BLD (AD) 25 Ref. 12 DLR (SC) 289; 14 DLR (SC) 159, 11 BLD (AD) 2, 11 BLD (H

Subject: WITNESS

Delivery Date: 2018-08-12

WITNESS

Witness — Relationship of witnesses — Whether the evidence of such wit­nesses can be relied upon — The fact of relationship is no ground to discard the testimony of witnesses in a case unless there are internal marks of falsehood in their testimony — Mere relationship is no ground to disbelieve a witness if other­wise found trustworthy — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 146 Majibur Rahman and others Vs. The State 5 BLD (HCD) 111).Ref. 21 DLR 575; 24 DLR 217.

 

Non-production of witnesses named in F.I.R. and Chargesheet — Non-produc­tion of witnesses named in the F.I.R and charge-sheet weakens the prosecution case Abdul Bahar alias Abu I Hahar and others Vs. The State 5 BLD (HCD) 84.

 

Relationship of witnesses — Enemity with witnesses — Relationship and enemity of the witnesses are not the grounds for discarding the evidence of the witnesses — Enemity cuts both ways and it cannot be ground for disbelieving the positive evidence of an eye witness — Evidence Act ( 1 of 1872) S 118 Mahitullah PK. and others Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 277.

 

Non-Examination of F.LR. and Charge-sheet witnesses — Effect of — The pro­secution is not bound to examine each and every witness named in the FIR and the charge-sheet — In the absence of any material to show that these witnesses were witnesses about the actual occur­rence, no adverse inference can be drawn against the prosecution for non-exami­nation of such witnesses — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 265G. Siddique Ahmed alias Md Siddique and others Vs. The State 5 BLD (HCD) 202.

 

Tendering of Prosecution Witness —A witness may be tendered by the prose­cution if his evidence is not of much im­portance or his evidencewill make unnec­essary addition to the evidence already adduced but an important witness should not be tendered — Tendering of witnesses from motive is depricated Shamsul Huq and others Vs. The State 6 BLD (AD) 216

 

Belated examination of witnesses by the Investigating Officer — The evi­dentiary value of such witnesses — Since the witness was examined bv the Inves­tigating Officer W; months after the F.I.R. the evidence of the witness was left out of consideration — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) Ss 161 and 167 The State Vs. Mokbul Hossain 6 BLD (HCD) 34.

 

Sole witness — Situations may arise where only a single person is available to give evidence in support of a disputed fact — In such a case the court has to weigh carefully such a testimony and if it is satisfied that the evidence is reliable and free from all taints which tend to render oral testimony open to suspicion, the court can act upon such testimony.

There being no material on record to show that the lone witness has any motive to bring false allegation or that he was acting at the instance of other persons, his credibility cannot be doubted — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 134 Shahidullah and another Vs. The State 7 BLD (AD) 27.

 

Witnesses of search and seizure of arms — A judge may disbelieve a witness of search and seizure if it appears to him that the witness is making obliging state­ments in favour of the accused to save him from punishment — A judge may convict an accused solely on the basis of the unimpeachable evidence of the officer who   made   the   search   and seizure disbelieving the seizure list witnesses — But in the present case the witnesses of search and seizure cannot be disbelieved as it seems probable that the planting of pipe gun was managed by the enemy of the appellant — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 134 — The Arms Act (XI of 1878) S  19A   Nurul Islam  Vs. The State 8 BLD (HCD) 106.

 

Non-examination of F.l.R. named witnesses — Witnesses who are named in the FIR and who came to the place of the occurrence shortly after the dacoits left, renders the prosecution case shaky and doubtful J amir alias Jamiruddin Vs. The State 9 BLD (HCD) 474.

 

Interested eye-witnesses — There cannot be any bar for a person to witness an occurrence and give evidence merely because the accused has brought a case against him — His evidence however re­quires to be tested with other evidence and circumstances Shah Alam and others Vs. The State 10 BLD (AD) 25 Ref. 12 DLR (SC) 289; 14 DLR (SC) 159.

 

Conviction on the sole testimony of a single witness — It is well-settled law that a conviction may be based on the sole testimony of a single witness, if believed, and mere interestedness is no ground to reject the testimony of a witness when it is found that his evidence is trustworthy and free from doubt — It is equally settled that when a conviction rests on the testimony of a single witness, who is interested and partisan in nature, the court, apart from requiring corroboration of the said testimony subjects the same to maximum closest scrutiny. Abu Taker Chowdhury and others Vs. The State 11 BLD (AD) 2.

 

Interested witness — A police officer being an interested witness in the prose­cution case and his testimony having not been corroborated by any independent and disinterested witness in material particu­lars, the prosecution case fails. Gaziur Rahman Vs. Tlte State 11 BLD (HCD) 11.

 

Conviction on the evidence of a single witness — It is true that it is the quality and not the quantity that has to be seen in the evidence — Even on the basis of evi­dence of the single witness conviction of an accused can be maintained provided that the single prosecution witness is wholly and fully reliable — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 134 Md Joynai Ahedin Vs. The State 11 BLD (HCD) 70.

 

ground to reject the testimony of a witness when it is found that his evidence is trustworthy and free from doubt — It is equally settled that when a conviction rests on the testimony of a single witness, who is interested and partisan in nature, the court, apart from requiring corroboration of the said testimony subjects the same to maximum closest scrutiny. Abu Taker Chowdhury and others Vs. The State 11 BLD (AD) 2

 

Interested witness — A police officer being an interested witness in the prose­cution case and his testimony having not been corroborated by any independent and disinterested witness in material particu­lars, the prosecution case fails. Gaziur Rahman Vs. Tlte State 11 BLD (HCD) 11.

 

Conviction on the evidence of a single witness — It is true that it is the quality and not the quantity that has to be seen in the evidence — Even on the basis of evi­dence of the single witness conviction of an accused can be maintained provided that the single prosecution witness is wholly and fully reliable — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 134 Md Joynai Ahedin Vs. The State 11 BLD (HCD) 70.Ref. 29 DLR (SC) 221; 4 BCR (AD) 114.

 

Chance witnesses — When there is a background of enemity and the witnesses are chance witnesses and not natural wit­nesses and natural and independent wit­nesses were not produced by the prosecu­tion, it is unsafe to rely on the chance witnesses to connect the accused with the crime Nowsher Mollah and others Vs. The State 11 BLD (HCD) 295.

 

Sole Witness — The conviction of an accused can be based even upon the evi­dence of a single witness, if believed, but that witness must be wholly reliable and he must be found to be above suspicion of interestedness, incompetence or subordi­nation — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 134. Ashrafuddin Vs. The State 11 BLD (HCD) 435.

 

Interested and partisan witnesses —In a case where bitter enemity between the parties is admitted, it is required as a rule of prudence that there should be some such corroboration of the evidence of the interested witness or witnesses as may inspire confidence in the mind of the court as to the truth of the prosecution case. Abdul Mannan and others Vs. The State 12 BLD (AD) 87.

 

Interested witness — It is not safe to convict an accused on a charge of murder on the dubious, tainted and interested evi­dence. Abdul Gafur Vs. The State 12 BLD (AD) 90.

 

Solitary witness — The conviction of an accused can safely be based on the solitary evidence of an eye-witness if he is found full, complete and self-contained — It may not receive corroboration from other witnesses but when it stands fully corroborated by the circumstances of the case and the medical evidence on record, the Court can safely rely on it — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 134. Abdul Hai Sikder and another Vs. The State 12 BLD (AD) 180.

 

Number of witnesses — Law does not require a particular number of witnesses to prove a case and conviction may be based on the testimony of a solitary wit­ness — But rule of prudence, if not rule of law, requires corroboration of such evidence Muslimuddin and others Vs. The State 7 BLD (AD) 1.

 

Relationship of Witnesses — The question of their credibility — Ordinarily a close relation will be the last person to screen the real culprit and falsely impli­cate an innocent person — Relationship far from being a ground of criticism is often a source of guarantee of the truth. The State Vs. Mizanul Islam alias Dablu and another 8 BLD (HCD) 317.

 

Uncorroborated testimony of inter­ested witness — When the informant of the case is highly interested in the result of the case, his evidence, unless corrobo­rated by independent and unipeachable evidence, no reliance can be placed on it. Mati Mia Vs. The State 12 BLD (HCD) 126

 

Number of witnesses — Under Section 134 of the Evidence Act no particular number of witnesses is neces-sary to prove a case — The quality of the statement of the witnesses has to be looked into and it has no reference to the number of witnesses — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 134 Safiuddin and others Vs. Minhazuddin Chowdhurv and another 12 BLD (HCD) 301.

 

Testimony of a single witness — It is unsafe to find the accused persons guilty under Section 147 of the Penal Code rely­ing on the uncorroborated testimony of a single witness. Dr. Abdul .hilil Clwwdhury ami others Vs. The Suae 12 BLD (HCD) 467 Ref. 3441DLR.

 

Evidence of the prosecutrix — It is a settled principle of law that a prosecutrix should be corroborated by independent evidence or circumstances in order to base conviction upon her evidence, particularly when the prosecutrix is an adult woman Abdul Kashem Vs. The State 12 BLD (HCD) 513. Ref. 19 DLR (SC) 259; 10 DLR 532; 14 DLR 821; 12 DLR (SC) 165.

 

 

1262

CRIMINAL TRIAL

Citation: 2 BLD (HCD) 170. Ref. AIR 1956 (SC) 181,3 BLD (HCD) 18. Ref. 1952 SCR (Ind) 377; 10 DLR 237; 2 KB (1916) 658, 3 BLD (HCD) 182,3 BLD (HCD) 132Ref. 23 Cr.L J. 108; ILR 21 (1942) (Pat) 66. 3 BLD (HCD) 190. ref. 55 CWN 541; 3 DLR 449; 17 DLR 382, 3 BLD (HCD

Subject: CRIMINAL TRIAL

Delivery Date: 2018-07-30

CRIMINAL TRIAL

 

Criminal Trial — Common object — It is incumbent on the prosecution to lead evidence as to which deadly weapons each of the accused was carrying for proving charges of unlawful assembly and rioting — The case of each individual accused ought to have been examined so that mere spectators or friends and relations of the accused party, who had not joined the assembly and who were unaware of its motive, had not been branded as members of the unlawful assembly — The Penal Code (XLV of 1860) S 149 Ali Akhar Khan and others Vs. The State 2 BLD (HCD) 170. Ref. AIR 1956 (SC) 181.

 

Abduction and Rape — Position of victim — In cases where the victim was abduced by deceitful means or by force or if she was ravished against her will, she can not be said to be an accomplice — In such circumstances, she is a victim of an outrage.

 

Acceptance of uncorroborated testi­mony — On the basis of facts of each case the Court has to come to a finding as to whether it is safe to act upon the testimony of the victim without being supported by independent corroborative evidence in material particulars — In case the judge decides to accept her un- corroborated testimony, he should state reasons — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) Ss. 114, 111 (b) and 133.

 

Statement of a victim girl after the commission of the offence — Such a statement is legally admissible as cor­roboration — Its value and weight is, however, a different matter — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 157 Abdul Quddus and another Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 18. Ref. 1952 SCR (Ind) 377; 10 DLR 237; 2 KB (1916) 658

 

Criminal liability of the officers of the company — Officers of a company cannot be prosecuted for non-payment of outstanding dues from the company — Company incorporated under the Com­panies Act is a juristic person — Officers and agents are not personally liable for the inability, refusal or denial of the company to pay any outstanding dues and they cannot be prosecuted — Such criminal proceeding must be quashed — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 561A A. F. M. Abul Hasnat alias Raza Miah and others Vs. Idris AH and others 3 BLD (HCD) 182

 

Attempt and preparation to commit an offence of dealing in the black market — Mere possession of rationed commodities or fair price commodities will not per se attract the mischief of such an offence unless there is some evidence to show overt act or attempt or prepara­tion — The Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) S 25 and S 6.The prosecution must prove that apart from possession of the articles the accused took some steps in devising or arranging means necessary for committing the offence Basiruddin Ahmed Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 132Ref. 23 Cr.L J. 108; ILR 21 (1942) (Pat) 66.

 

Criminal breach of trust in respect of partnership property — A partner cannot be charged under Section 406 of the Penal Code in respect of partnership property jointly belonging to him and the complainant partner — Until dissolution of the partnership it cannot be said that he holds the property in a fiduciary capacity — In the absence of a special agreement between the partners that a particular property would be the separate property of a partner, there cannot be an entrustment of it to the other partner or partners — Penal Code (XLV of 1860) s 406. Mostafa Chowdhury and another Vs. The State and another 3 BLD (HCD) 190. ref. 55 CWN 541; 3 DLR 449; 17 DLR 382

 

Trial without the aid of assessors —Case records sent to the court of Sessions on 15.6.77 — Law reforms Ordinance came into force on 1.6.79 — Trial started with the framing of formal charge on 16.3 81 — Trial without the assessors is not vitiated — Law reforms Ordinance, 1978 (XLIX of 1978) S 4 Mahitullah Pk. and others Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 277 Ref.l9DLR(SC)241.

 

Relationship is no ground to disbe­lieve a witness — Relationship is not a ground for disbelieving the evidence of witness when the witness's evidence appears to be truthful — Prosecution is not bound to examine each and every witness — Enemity cuts both ways and it cannot itself be a ground for disbelieving an eye witness — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 118 Mahitullah Pk. and others Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 277.

 

A criminal proceeding when a civil suit is pending over the same matter —It is well-settled that when a matter has given rise to a civil liability and the dispute of a civil nature, the criminal proceeding should not be allowed to continue — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 561 A. Quamrun Nessa Begum and others Vs. The State and another 4 BLD(AD)215.

 

Discharging the Rule in a Criminal Revision in the absence of the Petitioner — While discharging the Rule in a criminal revision in the absence of the petitioner, the High Court Division should not comment on the merit of the case. Md Torab Ali Biswas Vs. The State and another 4 BLD (AD) 34.

 

A Magistrate has no jurisdiction to oust a person in possisson — A Magis­trate has no jurisdiction to oust a person in possession when the subject matter of the case before him is in seisin of the civil court. Professor Md Shahul Huda Vs. Md Shaft 4 BLD (AD 165.

 

Review of judgment or order — It is well-settled that a judgment or order passed on merit cannot be reviewed by the criminal Court — Section 369 Cr.P C operates in full force and applies to all judgments of all criminal courts — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 369 JohedAli Vs. The State 4 BLD (AD) 168.

 

Judgment in  Criminal  Appeal —Judgment in criminal appeal should discuss evidence, nature of the offence and the part played by individual accused persons — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 423 Serajuddowla and others Vs. The State 4 BLD (AD) 213.

 

Criminal Liability of a surety — Asurety incurs civil as well as criminal liability for his failure to produce the tractor before the court as promised — Both civil and criminal liabilities may co­exist and are not mutually exclusive — Penal Code (XLV of I860) S 405. Shahidullah Patwary Vs. The State 4 BLD (AD)25 Ref. AIR 1967 (Cal) 460.

 

Contents of judgment by the Appel­late Court — A judgment in criminal appeal should contain discussion of facts the evidence on record and conclusions with reasons, otherwise the appeal must be reheard Ibrahim Bepari and others Vs. Lutfur Rahman Bhuiyan and another 4 BLD (HCD) 297.

 

No revision lies when appeal is open— Court has no power to entertain any proceeding by way of revision at the in­stance of the party when an appeal was open to him. Alt Hossain and others Vs. The State and another 4 BLD (HCD) 221.

 

Objection to jurisdiction of a crimi­nal court — It can be taken at any stage of the proceeding even before the High Court Division in revision. If the Court had no jurisdiction to try the case, the question of submitting to jurisdiction cannot arise as parties by mutual consent can neither confer nor take away juris­diction Rajah AH and others Vs. The State 4 BLD (HCD) 264.

 

Restoration of a criminal case — Dropping of a criminal proceeding and release of the accused persons on erro­neous view of law do not operate either as discharge or as acquittal — In such a case the Court can restore the case Moklesur Rahman and others Vs. The State 4 BLD (HCD) 65.

 

Findings of the criminal court —These are not binding on the civil Court — An order passed under section 145 Cr.P.C. cannot be treated as substantive evidence of possession — A judgment of acquittal in a criminal case only decides that the accused has not been found guilty of the offence charged with but the opinion and conclusion expressed in the judgment are not admissible in evidence in civil courts — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 43. Akhter Hossain Shariff and others Vs. Munshi Akkas Hossain and others 3 BLD (AD) 334Restoration of a criminal revision dismissed for default — The order of dismissal of a criminal revision for default without touching the merit of the case is not a judgment of conviction or acquittal and as such an order of such dismissal can be vacated and the case heard again — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 369 Muzahar Sikder Vs. Fariduddin Ahmed and others 3 BLD (HCD) 96. Ref. AIR 1949 (FC) 1; 22 DLR (SC) 258.

 

Summary  dismissal  of appeal —Summary dismissal of an appeal without disposal on merit is not in accordance with law and the spirit of dispensation of justice — It is not contemptated by law — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 407 Jamsed and others Vs. Abdus Samad and other 3 BLD (HCD) 68.

 

Trademark dispute — When a bonafide dispute exists between the par­ties as to the right to use a trade mark action should be taken before a civil court and not before a criminal court Md. Salahuddin and another Vs. Abdul Hakim and another 3 BLD (HCD) 315Ref. ILR 22 (Mad) 488; 1 1 CWN 887 AIR 1936 (Cal) 488.

 

Duty of the prosecution in framing charge — The accused must be specifi­cally told in the accusation under Section 242 Cr.P.C with what specific offence and acts he is being charged with — The prosecution must also prove that apart from possession of articles   the accuser took some steps in devising or arranging means necessary for committing the offence Basiruddin Ahmed Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 132Ref. 23 O.L.J (1922) 108, ILR 21 (1942) (Pat) 667.

 

Inmates of the house when not ma­terial witnesses — The deceased was not killed in his house and as such the inmates of the house and the relations of the deceased were not material witnesses. Sudhir and others Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 293.

 

Order of conviction and sentence passed by Assistant Sessions Judge —Appeal against any judgment passed by the Assistant Sessions Judge deemed to be an Additional Sessions Judge involving sentence not exceeding five (5) years imprisonment lies to the Court of Sessions and not to the High Court Division — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) Ss. 9(3), 29C, 31(4), 408 and 410. Shawkat Ali Kayal Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 250.

 

Adjournment cost in criminal pro­ceeding — Adjournment cost cannot be awarded against the absentee accused though in exceptional circumstances the criminal court can award adjournment cost — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 344 Md Habihur Rahman Vs. The State and another 1 BLD (HCD) 443.Ref. 19 Cr.L.J 326; 23 Cr L.J 243; 4 Cr L J 78; 48 CWN 684; 49 Cr.L.J. 304; AIR 1962 (Cal) 98.

 

Criminal Trial — Omnibus statement and assessment of evidence — Omnibus evidence in general terms to the effect that all the other accused persons armed with lathis have also assaulted the deceased need, of necessity, be scrutinized very strictly in order to eliminate all chances of false and mistaken implication. Anil Krishna Somaddar and other Vs. The State 1 BLD (HCD) 401.

 

 

Inordinate delay in holding trial —Shockingly inordinate delay in holding the trial is a ground for quashing the proceeding_Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 561A Md Shafiqullah Vs. The State 1 BLD (HCD) 119. Ref. PLD 1963 (Lahore) 32; PLD 1965 (HCD) 287

 

Imprisonment in default of payment of fine — Section 33(1) Cr PC authorizes the Magistrate to award terms of imprisonment in default of payment of fine__Section 33(1) Cr PC governs cases punishable with sentence and fine as well as cases punishable with fine only — Where the offence is punishable with imprisonment as well with fine and where the offence is punishable with fine only, the imprisonment in default of payment of fine shall be simple and the maximum term is for six months — All Courts possess power to direct recovery of fine when the offence is punishable with fine only by any of the three methods, such as by issuing distress warrants or by referring the matter to the Collector or by committing the offender to the prison — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) Ss. 33(1), 386(1) The State Vs. Abul Kashem 5 BLD (AD) 166

 

Conviction without framing charge _A conviction of an accused who was not charged with the offence cannot be maintained by taking recourse to Section 533 Cr.P.C. — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 535/(2) Joynal Abedin and others Vs. The State 5 BLD (AD) 257. Ref. 9 BLD (HCD)419.
