"Marriage" — Meaning of — It means and inlcudes not only the ceremony of marriage but also the newly entitled to go according to her free will — For the purpose of Section 366A of the Penal Code she must be between 16 and 18 years — If she is above 16 but below 18 and if no force is used to go with the accused, it will not be an offence under the Penal Code or the Ordinance — Penal Code (XLV of 1860) S 366A — Cruelty to Women (Deterrent Punishment) Ordi­nance (LX of 1983) S 4(b). Manindra Kumar Malakar Vs. The State 10 BLD (HCD) 119. Ref. AIR 1933 (Cal) 362; 23 DLR (DAC) 126; 35 DLR 127

1267

FAMILY COURTS ORDINANCE, 1985

Citation: 42 DLR 450.

Case Year: 1985

Subject: FAMILY COURTS

Delivery Date: 2018-01-13

Family Courts Ordinance, 1985
[XVIII of 1985]
 
Sections 3, 5 & 27—
Order for maintenance of wife and son—purpose of the Family Courts Ordinance is to provide for speedy disposal of family matters by the same forum. There will be anomaly and multiplicity of proceedings if, in spite of the establishment of Family Courts, the Magistrate continues to entertain cases for maintenance. Provisions made in the Family Courts Ordinance have oust4ed the jurisdiction of the Magistrates to entertain application for maintenance which is a family court matter.
Md. Abdul Khaleque Vs. Selina Be gum 42 DLR 450.
1268

ABDUCTION

Citation: 3 BLD (HCD) 18, 3 BLD (HCD) 108. Ref. 19 DLR (SC) 259; 12 DLR (SC) 165, 12 BLD (HCD) 490

Subject: ABDUCTION

Delivery Date: 2018-07-02

ABDUCTION

Abduction and rape — On the basis of the facts of each case the Court has to come to a finding as to whether it is safe to act upon the testimony of the victim without being supported by independent corroborative evidence — Statement of the victim girl after the commission of the offence is legally admissible as corrobo­ration but the value and weight it will carry is, however, a different matter — Evidence Act (I of 1872) S 157 Abdul Quddus & another Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 18.

Abduction and rape — Uncorrobo­rated testimony of the prosecutrix is not sufficient for conviction.

It is understandable that an occurrence of abduction and rape may not be actually witnessed by any one other than the vic­tim but even in such a situation it is re­quired that such an occurrence shall have to be proved by strong circumstantial evi­dence supporting the case of the victim. Zainul Abedin & others Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 108. Ref. 19 DLR (SC) 259; 12 DLR (SC) 165

Abduction — Section 364 of the Penal Code — The Section is attracted even though the person abducted was not, in fact, murdered in consequence of the ab­duction Al-Haj Abdul Gani Vs. The State 12 BLD (HCD) 490

1269

ABETMENT

Citation: 1 BLD (HCD) 377, 5 BLD (AD) 99 (101), 6 BLD (HCD) 402, 7 BLD (HCD) 11(13), 10 BLD (HCD) 179, 12 BLD (HCD) 429 (435), 11 BLD (HCD) 552

Subject: ABETMENT

Delivery Date: 2018-07-02

ABETMENT

Abetment— Abetment is an offence by itself and unless it is specifically made punishable in a Special Act, a person can not be called upon to answer a charge of abetment merely by reference to the Penal Code — The purpose of Section 6(5) of the Muslim Family Laws Ordinance, 1961 seems to be that the person who contra­venes the provision is alone liable and none else Abdul Halim Pattadar and others Vs. M. Rahmat All and another 1 BLD (HCD) 377

Abetment — After having discharged the principal accused no useful purpose can be served by continuing the proceed­ing against the abettors — After having discharged the principal accused there is no valid reason to prosecute the abettors only. Moyna Miah Vs. The State and another 5 BLD (AD) 99 (101).

Abetment — Law does not provide that in the absence of any formal charge order of conviction cannot be passed for abetment on the facts proved while charged for the substantive offence — It is only as a rule of prudence that an alternative charge for abetment is framed Abdur Rouf and others Vs. The State 6 BLD (HCD) 402

Abetment — After the principal of­fender was acquitted in the previous trial, no useful purpose can be served by trying the abettors in a subsequent proceeding Twahid Khan alias Twahid Kha and others Vs. The State & others 7 BLD (HCD) 11(13)

Abetment — Mere taking away of the victim from his house without any overt act in the form of any hostile attitude or initial intention to kill will not justify conviction for abetment — The theory of 'last seen' must carry along with it a high degree of probability, excluding all other theories 'except the hypothesis of the guilt of the accused. Soleman others Vs. The State 10 BLD (HCD) 179.

Abetment — The charge of abetment fails when the substantive offence is not established against the principal offender__ Abetment under the Penal Code in­volves actual complicity on the part of the abettor prior to the actual commission of the offence — The essence of the offence of abetment is that the abettor should substantially assist the principal offender towards commission of the offence. Dabir Talukder Vs.The State 12 BLD (HCD) 429 (435)

Abetment — Gist of the offence — In order to make an accused liable for commission of any offence, it must be shown that he has committed the crime or aided or instigated the same in the same form or manner as the other accused did _ It is a settled principle of law that the mere presence of the accused near about the place of occurrence does not consti­tute the offence under Section 109 of the Penal Code — Intentional aiding and active complicity is the gist of the offence of abetment committed by the accused — Penal Code (XLV of 1860) S 109 Mostain Mollah and others Vs. The State 11 BLD (HCD) 552

1270

APPROVER

Citation: 9 BLD (HCD) 485, Ref. AIR 1959 (SC)13; AIR 1925 (Lahore) 15; AIR 1920 (Lahore) 376; 1930 CWN 773; PLD 1969 (Lahore) 1071; AIR 1935 (Lahore) 799; AIR1937 (Lahore) 551; AIR 1939 (All) 43; AIR 1929 (Nagpur) 189; AIR 1929 (Oudh) 529,

Subject: APPROVER

Delivery Date: 2018-07-04

APPROVER

Approver — Prosecuting an approver___ Condition for prosecution — The first condition for prosecuting an approver is a certificate by the Public Prosecutor that the approver has not complied with the condition on which pardon was tendered.

—   It must also be established that the approver forfeited his pardon — Pardon was on the condition that the approver will speak the truth and in this case the approval has spoken the truth by saying that he implicated the accused as he had litigations with them — There being no finding by the trial court that the tender of pardon has been forfeited, which is the sine quo non for prosecuting an approver, the prosecution is incompetent — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) Ss. 337 — 339 Angur Vs. The State 9 BLD (HCD) 485

Ref. AIR 1959 (SC)13; AIR 1925 (Lahore) 15; AIR 1920 (Lahore) 376; 1930 CWN 773; PLD  1969 (Lahore) 1071; AIR 1935 (Lahore) 799; AIR1937 (Lahore) 551; AIR 1939 (All) 43; AIR 1929 (Nagpur) 189; AIR 1929 (Oudh) 529

 

1271

ARMS ACT, 1878

Citation: 7 BLD (AD) 22, 7 BLD (HCD) 289, Ref. AIR 1954 (Cal) 157; AIR 1955 (Cal) 599; AIR 1956 (Cal) 96, AIR 1957 (Madras) 692; MR 1956 (Punjab) 33, 13 DLR (SC) 66, 8 BLD (AD) 114. Ref. AIR 1956 (Cal) 96; AIR 1954 (Raj) 264; PLD 1965 (SC) 90; 16 DLR (SC) 722, 8 B

Case Year: 1878

Subject: ARMS

Delivery Date: 2018-07-04

ARMS ACT (ACT XI OF 1878)

 

Illegal search of the house of the ac­cused — Its effect when search con­ducted in an irregular manner — respect­ability of a witness is of no importance when search is not made in accordance with law — Irregularity in a search con­ducted by an authorised officer may not ordinarily affect the legality of a proceed­ing but it may affect the weight of evi­dence — Search, recovery and seizure of alleged incriminating articles not by a Magistrate or a police officer but by members of the public are illegal — Arms Act (XI of 1878) S 25 — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 103 Tamijuddin Vs. Tlte State 7 BLD (AD) 22.

Right to possess Fire Arms — The granting of license for firm arms is dis­cretionary — No one has a right to pos­sess or carry a fire arm — The legal right to possess or carry a fire arm is created only after the license is granted — The grant of license amounts to conferment of a privilege.

 

The licensee acquires a right to possess, carry, defend and maintain his fire arms once a license is issued to him — So long as he does not violate the terms and con­ditions of his license and so long as the appropriate authority does not deem it necessary to cancel or suspend his license for the security of public  peace, he acquires a right to defend his right and privilege to possess and carry fire arms — A licensee of a fire arm can challenge the cancellation of his license by filing writ petition under Article 102 of the Constitution of Bangladesh.

The appropriate authority should record the reason of cancellation himself— Only in rare cases he may pass an order ditto­ing the reasons and suggestion of his subordinate officer — If he does not record the reason himself the Court will certainly scrutinize his order and will strike it down if it has been passed with­out application of mind — Arms Act (XI of 1878) S 18 „VA. Ali A/tmmed Vs. The Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs and others 7 BLD (HCD) 289

 

Ref. AIR 1954 (Cal) 157; AIR 1955 (Cal) 599; AIR 1956 (Cal) 96, AIR 1957 (Madras) 692; MR 1956 (Punjab) 33, 13 DLR (SC) 66

 

The Arms Act, 1878 (XI of 1878) S 18 — Cancellation of license for fire arm — Since there is no provision of ap­peal against an order of cancellation, the order will not be struck down for non-communicating the reasons — A licensee has, however, the right to know the rea­sons if the order is challenged in a Court of law and the appropriate authority must lay before the Court the reasons for its decision and the materials behind it.

 

Cancellation of license for fire arm without notice and principle of natural justice — The absence of a prior no­tice/hearing may not always invalidate the order cancelling license for fire arm, the subject matter being directly related to the security of the public peace — It may not be possible nor advisable to adhere to the principle of natural justice of a prior show-cause in every case because of exi­gencies of the situation — Each case has to be examined on its own merit to see whether a prior notice has to be given.

 

Cancellation of license for fire arm — When the violation of the principles of natural justice is deprecated — It is no case where the police was making a report to the Magistrate in course of his normal public duty, nor a case where the police received information in course of their ordinary investigation — The en­quiry was undertaken on a sprawling pri­vate complaint — There appeared to be no emergency or any compelling situation preventing giving of notice of enquiry' to the appellant — There is nothing on re­cord to show that any specific case was started against him involving misuse of his revolver — In the facts of the case it was absolutely necessary to hold an en­quiry with notice to and in presence of the appellant — The authority did not act properly in the matter and we have no hesitation in holding that the impugned order is of no legal effect as the same has been passed in violation of the principle of natural justice — The Arms Act, 1878 (XI of 1878) S 18. Sk. Ali Ahmed Vs. Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs, Govt of Bangladesh and others 8 BLD (AD) 114. Ref. AIR 1956 (Cal) 96; AIR 1954 (Raj) 264; PLD 1965 (SC) 90; 16 DLR (SC) 722.

 

Arms and Ammunitions — Cancella­tion of Licence of fire arms — Under Arms Rules, 1924, Licence for the possession of firm arms and ammunitions may be granted by the District Magistrate or the Sub-Divisional Magistrate specially empowered by the Government in that behalf — Under Section 16 of the Arms Act such licence may be cancelled by the officer by whom the same was granted or by any authority to whom he may be subordinate or by any Magistrate of a District for reasons to be recorded in writing for the security of the public peace or by any Judge or Magistrate convicting a licensee of fire arms for an offence under the Arms Act — When the District Magistrate has granted the licence the same can only be cancelled or suspended by the District Magistrate himself or by any authority to whom he is subordinate for reasons to be recorded by him in writing for the security of the public peace — There is nothing to show that the Government especially empo­wered any Sub-Divisional Magistrate to grant any licence for possessing the fire arms — The Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Shariatpur had no authority to cancel the licence granted by the District Magistrate, Faridpur-Arms Act (XI of 1878) Ss. 17 & 18 — Arms Rules 1924 R 33 Md Anwar Hossain Majhee & ors. Vs. The State 8 BLD (HCD) 14. Ref. AIR 1946 (All) 484; 47 Cr.L.J. 638; AIR 1953 (All) 476; AIR 1954 (Cal) 157; AIR 1956 (Cal) 96.

 

Search and Seizure of Arms — A Judge may disbelieve a witness of search and seizure if it appears to him that the witness is making obliging statements in favour of the accused to save him from punishment — A judge may convict an accused solely on the basis of the unim­peachable evidence of the officer who made the search and seizure disbelieving the evidence of witness of search and sei­zure — But in the present case the wit­nesses of search and seizure can not be disbelieved and it seems probable that the planting of the pipe gun was managed by the enemy of the appellant — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 134 — Arms Act (XI of 1878) S19 A Nurul Islam Vs. The State 8 BLD (HCD) 106

 

Arms Act — Possession of pipe gun without barrel — Possession of even any part of any arms is an offence under the Arms Act — Arms Act (XI of 1878) S 19(f)

 

Possession of Arms — Plea of illegal­ity in the procedure of search when not tenable — Since it was at the instance of accused Kochi that accused Hosne Ara brought out and made over the pipe gun to the police there is no scope of search and as such there was no question of the application of the procedure of search provided in law — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 103

 

Constructive possession of Arms —

 

For constituting an offence under the Arms Act there must be either possession or control of the arms — Accused Kochi had the pipe gun under his control as he possessed it constructively through accused Hosne Ara and as such he is equally guilty - Arms Act (XI of 1878) S 19(f). Kochi alias Jishan & ors. Vs. The State 8 BID (HCD) 412

 

Arms Act (I of 1878) Secion 19A & (f)

 

Arms Rules, 1924 Table — I of Schedule I, rule 3 read with schedule 1, clause 1(a) — Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) Section 26 — Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972 — Article 52 — Im­munity of the President.

 

Upon the scrutiny of the FIR and the charge sheet it cannot be said that the proceeding is barred by any law or that prima facie it does not attract the provision of the Arms Act.

 

Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972 — Article 52(1) — President's immunity from criminal prosecution — The immu­nity is available to the President only while he is an office. Hussain Mohammad Ershad Vs. The State 11 ELD (AD) 55

 

Ref. 18 Cr.L.J. 781; 92 IC 589; 28 DLR (AD) 38, 30 DLR (SC) 58; 3 1 DLR (AD) 69; 34 DLR (HCD) 287; 35 DLR (HCD) 100; 38 DLR (AD) 18

 

— Section 19A & (f)— Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) — Section 3 — In a case under the Arms Act read with the Special Powers Act the prosecution has to establish accused's possession and effective control over the alleged unau­thorised arms and ammunitions beyond all reasonable doubts by cogent and reliable evidence — Prosecution's failure to do so amounts to a case of no evidence and results in the acquittal of the accused on benefit of doubt Gaziur Rahman Vs. The State 11 BLD (HCD) 11

 

— Sec­tions 19A & (f) and 27(a) — Arms Rules, 1924 Rule 3(1 )(b) and Schedule I and item 1(a) of the Table of the Rules — Notification No. 896 Sec (II) dated Dhaka, the 19th November. 1973 column 2(1) Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) — Section 26.

 

The decision on the case depends on

(a)      Whether the seized arms and am­munitions or any part of them were recovered from the custody and possession of the petitioner.

(b)      Whether the arms and ammunitions come within the exception of column 2 of the Table Schedule I of Arms Rules, 1924 as amended by Notification No. 896 — Sec. (II) dated Dhaka the 19th November, 1973 and subsequent amendment of any in that Table.

(c)      Whether the seized arms and am­munitions were registered with the authority prescribed in paragraphs 36 and 37 of Section (IV) Chapter III, rules and orders of Arms Act Manual, 1924, as laid down in column 3 of the Table of the Notification  If not, whether it comes within the mischief of sec­tion 23 of the Arms Act.

(d)   Whether the recovery of the arms and ammunitions comes within the perview of the amnesty declared by the Government for voluntary surrender of arms and ammunitions within the specified date.

(e)    Whether the petitioner enjoys ex­emption from having licence in respect of the arms seized

From the facts disclosed in the present case it can not be said that it is such a case in which the extraordinary power of the High Court Division is required to be exercised to secure the ends of justice or to prevent the abuse of the process of the court Hussain Mohammad Ershad Vs. The State 11 (BLD) (HCD) 57

 

Ref. 38 DLR (AD) 18; 38 DLR (HCD) 382; (3%); 31 DLR (AD) 69; 35 DLR (HCD) 100; 34 DLR (HCD) 387; 30 DLR (SC) 58

 

Section 18 — Cancellation of gun licence and principle of natural justice — Prnciple of natural justice is to be observed in the matter of exercising the power of cancellation of the licence of guns under Section 18 of the Arms Act and such cancellation without issuing any notice upon the licensee and without giving the licencee a chance of being heard is illegal and of no legal effect as being violative of the principle of natural justice — The order of cancellation or suspension of licence is also not legal if reasons are not recorded in writing Md.Reazul Karim & anr. Vs. The Secretary, Ministry of Home Affair & ors. 11  BLD) (HCD) 42H Ref. 40 DLR (AD) 170

1272

AUDI ALTERAM PARTEM

Citation: 11 (BLD) (HCD) 428. Ref. 40 DLR (AD) 170

Subject: AUDI ALTERAM PARTEM

Delivery Date: 2018-07-05

AUDI ALTERAM PARTEM

 

The principle of Natural Justice is to be observed in the matter of exercising the power of cancellation of the licenses of guns under Section 18 of the Arms Act and the order cancelling the licenses of guns without issuing any notice upon the licensee and without giving the licensee a chance of being heard is illegal and of no legal effect as being violative of the prin­ciple of natural justice — The order of cancellation or suspension of licenses is also not legal if reasons are not recorded in writing — Arms Act, 1878 (XI of 1878) S 18 Md Rezaul Karim & anr. Vs.Ministry of Home Affaris & ors. 11 (BLD) (HCD) 428. Ref. 40 DLR (AD) 170

1273

CASE AND COUNTER CASE AND SIMULTANEOUS TRIAL

Citation: 3 BLD (HCD) 156, 6 BLD (AD)3 Ref. 7 DLR 395, 13 DLR 414, 18 DLR (SC) 474,21 DLR 958, 6 BLD (AD) 216, 8 BLD (AD) 221, 12 BLD (AD) 59. Ref. 7 DLR 395; 13 DLR 414; 1971 PLD (SC) 713

Subject: CASE AND COUNTER CASE AND SIMULTANEOUS TRIAL

Delivery Date: 2018-07-08

CASE AND COUNTER CASE AND SIMULTANEOUS TRIAL

Case and counter-case — Final report by the Investigation Officer — It is none of his business to decide the case for himself when two sides came up with contradictory versions of the same occur­rence — The quality of evidence is the same in both the cases and there were in­juries on both sides — In a case like this both the version should be placed before a court of law so that truth can be found out upon receiving evidence from both sides and justice done to the parties — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 173 Syed Abdul Hannan Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 156.

Criminal Trial—Trial of case and counter-case — When there is a case andcounter-case, both the cases should be tried one after another by the same court — The trial court in such a case should be on its guard so that the evidence of one case is not imported in the other and thereby divert the course of justice to a wrong channel Abdul Aziz Vs. The State 6 BLD (AD)3 Ref. 7 DLR 395, 13 DLR 414, 18 DLR (SC) 474,21 DLR 958 

Criminal Trial — Practice and Proce­dure — The triai of cross-cases — Trail of cross-cases arising from the same inci­dent by the same court enables it to better appreciate the evidence — By such trial the court gets both sides of the picture and arrives at correct decision avoiding conflicting findings — Though no express provision of law requires trial of cross-cases by the same court, practice and experience of over a century dictate such a trial. Shamsul Huq alias Shamsul and others Vs. The State 6 BLD (AD) 216

Simultaneous Trial of Two Cases — Requirements for holding such trial — The requirement of a simultaneous trial is that the trials must be held in quick suc­cession so that there occurs an over-all picture to the mind of the judge — If there is a long gap between the two trials, the purpose for which a simultaneous trial is held by the same court is almost lost Alauddin Molla and others Vs. The State and others 8 BLD (AD) 221 

Usual practice of trial of cross-cases

— The usual practice of trial of cross cases is that both should be tried by the same judge simultaneously or one after another and judgment therein should be delivered after concluding the hearing of both the cases — When there is a fight between the two rival factions giving rise to the complaint and the counter-com-plant, the most desirable course is that both the cases should be tried by the same judge and judgments in these cases should be delivered after concluding the hearing of both the cases — In such trials, records of each case should be kept distinct and separate — The evidence of one case cannot be used in the other case and each case must be decided on its own evidence on record Siddique Munshi Vs. The State 12 BLD (AD) 59. Ref. 7 DLR 395; 13 DLR 414; 1971 PLD (SC) 713

1274

CHANGES IN PROCEDURAL LAW

Citation: 8 BLD (HCD) 270Ref. 3 (AC) 582; 5 (AC) 369; AIR 1927 (PC) 242, 8 BLD (HCD) 64, Ref. AIR 1950 (E Punjab) 25; 20 DLR (SC) 315; 21 DLR (SC) 123; 3 (AC) (1878) 582, AIR 1927 (PC) 242; 1905 (AC) 369, 8 BLD (AD) 84. Ref. AIR 1939 (FC) 743; AIR 1941 (FC) 5; AIR

Subject: CHANGES IN PROCEDURAL LAW

Delivery Date: 2018-07-09

CHANGES IN PROCEDURAL LAW

Changes in Procedural Law — Effect of— It is well-settled that changes in the adjective law or procedural law made in the statute have retrospective effect unless contrary intention is expressed in the statute or unless there be some good rea­son against taking such a view Ruhul Amin Vs. The State 8 BLD (HCD) 270Ref. 3 (AC) 582; 5 (AC) 369; AIR 1927 (PC) 242

Change in procedural law — Whe­ther change by amendment of procedural law is prospective or retrospective in operation— Any change in procedural law has retrospective effect unless that construction be textually inadmissible or unless there is some reason or other why they should not be so Al-haj Mamtaj Meah Vs. The State 8 BLD (HCD) 64

Ref. AIR 1950 (E Punjab) 25; 20 DLR (SC) 315; 21 DLR (SC) 123; 3 (AC) (1878) 582, AIR 1927 (PC) 242; 1905 (AC) 369

Change in Law — Such change taking place before the disposal of the appeal — Whether the appellate court is competent to take into account legislative changes since the decision under appeal was given—The appellate court may take into consideration subsequent change of law

—  It is now well settled that an appeal is a rehearing of the case and the rights of the parties thereto are to be determined according to the law as it stands — This is also necessary for shortening litigations keeping in view the rights of the parties under the law which has been enacted since the decision appealed from. M. A. Hai and others Vs. Trading Corporation of Bangladesh 8 BLD (AD) 84. Ref. AIR 1939 (FC) 743; AIR 1941 (FC) 5; AIR 1973 (SC) 171; AIR 1974 (SC) 2068

1275

CIRCUMSTANTIAL CORROBORATION

Citation: 7 BLD (AD) 27,

Subject: CIRCUMSTANTIAL CORROBORATION

Delivery Date: 2018-07-17

CIRCUMSTANTIAL CORROBORATION

Circumstantial corroboration — Effect of — The fact of recovery of money al­most of the same amount from the accused soon after the informant was robbed of lends circumstantial corrobora­tion to the evidence of identification of the accused, which would have been otherwise difficult to accept — Evidence Act (I of 1872) S 134 Shahidullah and another Vs. The State 7 BLD (AD) 27.

 

 

1276

CODE OF CRIMINAL PROCEDURE (V OF 1898) (Part-1)

Citation: 10 BLD (AD) 190, 1 BLD (AD) 314, 2 BLD (HCD) 131, 7 BLD (AD) 100, 9 BLD (HCD) 144 Ref. 30 DLR (AD) 100; 35 DLR 249, 9 BLD (HCD) 271 Ref. AIR 1955 (SC) 765; 17 DLR (SC) 392; (1973) 1 All ER 576 (PC), 8 BLD (AD) 123, 3 BLD (HCD) 250, 4 BLD (HCD) 250 Ref.

Case Year: 1898

Subject: Criminal Law

Delivery Date: 2018-08-12

CODE OF CRIMINAL PROCEDURE (V OF 1898)

 

Sections 1(2) and 339C — Applica­bility of the Code of Criminal Procedure to the proceedings under the Special Powers Act and the Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1958. Section 1(2) of the Code of Criminal Procedure says "in the absence of any specific provision to the contrary, nothing herein contained shall affect any special law now in force". Similarly Section 2, theSpecial Powers Act provides that provisions of the Code shall apply tc case under the Act if they are not ino sistent with any provision of the said i — The Tribunal in view of this enabl provision will apply the provisions of Code in the trial before it.

 

Provisions in Section 6 of Criminal L Amendment Act (XL of 1958) and th< of Section 29 of the Special Powers / 1974, are exactly similar since there is dispute that the specified time for cone sion of the appellant's trial expired lo ago, further proceedings in respect of trial stand stopped and he stands relas&The court is clearly of the view tl Section 339C of the Code of Crimii Procedure is applicable to the procee ings as to trial of the appellant under t Special Powers Act, 1974 Kamruzzaman  Vs. The State 10 BLD (AD) 190.

 

Section 4 (l)(m) — "Judicial procee ings include any proceeding in the cour of which evidence is or may be lega taken on oath "

 

When the Magistrate directs a furtr enquiry under Section 202 of the Code Criminal Procedure for ascertaining t truth or falsehood of the allegations < vulged in the complaint, no proceeding c be said to have yet started Dr. Jamsk Bakht Vs. Ameenur Rashid Chowdhu 1 BLD (AD) 314

 

Section    4(1 )(h) —    The word complaint has been defined in Sectic 4(l)(h)ofthe Code of Criminal Proce­dure as follows: "Complaint means the allegation made orally or in writing to a Magistrate, with a view to his taking action under this Code, that some person, whether known or un­known, has committed an offence, but it does not include the report of a police of­ficer."

 

Thus the report of a police officer has been specifically excluded from the defi­nition of the term 'complaint' Solicitor, Government of Bangladesh Vs. Mil Yasin Ali alias Gaddu 2 BLD (HCD) 131

 

Section 4(1 )(h) — Definitions of the term 'complaint' requires that in order to constitute a complaint an allegation re­garding the commission of an offence by known or unknown persons must be made either orally or in writing to a Magistrate — It does not say that such an allegation to a Magistrate would be channelled through a police officer On the contrary, the definition expressly mentions that it does not include the report of the police officer The State Vs. Aynuzzaman 7 BLD (AD) 100.

 

Section 4(1 )(h) — Cognizance of of­fence by Special Judge — Question of validity of his taking cognizance upon complaint made to a Magistrate — When the Magistrate sends the complaint, which is an allegation made in writing or verbally to a Magistrate, to the Special Judge with his comments and if cognizance is taken again by the latter, it cannot be said that the Special Judge has not taken cognizance on a complaint — Criminal Law Amendment Act (XL of 1958) S 41 — Code of Criminal Proce­dure (V of 1898) S 4(1 )(h). Matiar Rahman Vs. The State and others 9 BLD (HCD) 144 Ref. 30 DLR (AD) 100; 35 DLR 249.

 

Sections 6(1) and 9 — Court of Ses­sion and Sessions Judge — Whether they mean the same thing — By establishing a Court of Sessions the Government consti­tutes a class of criminal court for the pur­pose of trial of criminal cases as a court of original jurisdiction — But by appointing a judge of such a Court, the Government does not constitute a court, it creates an office — The Court of Sessions is a criminal court but the Sessions Judge is an office and they are not inter-changeable — When the Government appoints an Additional Sessions Judge or an Assistant Sessions Judge it does not constitute an Additional or Assistant Sessions Court — There can be only one Judge of the such Sessions Court and that is the Sessions Judge — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) Ss 6 (1) and 9 Nurul Huq Vs. Eahauddin and others 9 BLD (HCD) 271 Ref. AIR 1955 (SC) 765; 17 DLR (SC) 392; (1973) 1 All ER 576 (PC).

 

Section 8 — Extension of time limit for pending cases — Ordinance No 37 of 1983 extended the period for conclusion of trial of the cases pending on the date of its commencement on 8.8.83 — Charge sheet in the present case was submitted on 16.6.1983 and the case record was in due course forwarded to the Sessions Judge for trial. As such the trial of the case was pending within the meaning of Ordinance No. 37 of 1983 which was intended to save such trials which could not be com­pleted within the time limit specified in Section 339C of the Code of Criminal Procedure The State Vs. Modhu Mirdha 8 BLD (AD) 123.

 

 

 

Sections 9(3), 29C, 31(4), 408 and 410— Sentence not exceeding 5 years passed by an Assistant Sessions Judge deemed to be an Additional Sessions Judge — In view of the full and unfettered operation of Section 408 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, any appeal against any judg­ment passed by any Assistant Sessions Judge deemed to be appointed as Addi­tional Sessions Judge under proviso to Sub-section (3) of Section 9 read with Sub-section (4) of Section 31 of the Code of Criminal Procedure involving conviction and sentence for a term not exceeding 5 years shall exclusively lie to the Court of Sessions and not to the High Court Division as the provisions of Section 410 of the Code do not apply and operate in such a case Shawkat Kayal Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 250

 

Sections 9(3), 29C, 31(4), 408, 409, 410, 439A(3) and 538(2) — Forum of appeal against sentence of imprisonment not exceeding 5 years by an Assistant Sessions Judge deemed to be an Addi­tional Sessions Judge — Under the scheme of the law the Assistant Sessions Judge is deemed to be an Additional Sessions Judge only for a limited purpose for awarding higher sentence in a trial — If it were the intention of the law makers that the Assistant Sessions Judge should be deemed to be an Additional Sessions Judge for the purpose of appeal also, then Section 408 would have been accor­dingly amended — An appeal against such a sentence by the Assistant Sessions Judge shall lie to the Court of Sessions under Section 408 subject to the proviso thereunder Monir Hossain and another Vs. The State 4 BLD (HCD) 250 Ref. 36 DLR 93; 35 DLR 363.

 

Section 9(3) — Jurisdiction of the Assistant Sessions Judge deemed to be an Additional Sessions Judge — Whether jurisdiction is limited to trial of Sessions Cases only — By legal fiction he is to be treated as an Additional Sessions Judge not only for the purpose of trial of Ses­sions cases but also for the purpose of hearing appeals, revisions and references made over to him for disposal. Abdul Latif and other Vs. Nurjahan Begum and another 5 BLD (HCD) 316. Ref. 34 CWN (PC) 230: 121 IC (1930) 532; 1952 (AC) 109; AIR 1953 (SC) 244.

 

Sections 9(3), 29C, 31(4), 409 and 431A— Power of Assistant Sessions Judge deemed to be an Additional Sessions Judge — An Assistant Sessions Judge deemed to be appointed as an Additional Sessions Judge can exercise all the powers and discharge all the functions of an Additional Sessions Judge subject to the only limitation that such an Assistant Sessions Judge cannot pass a sentence of death — He is competent to hear revi-sional applications and appeals Nazir Ahmed and others Vs. Yonus Meah and others 5 BLD (BCD) 41.

 

 

 

Sections 9(3) and 408 — Forum of appeal against sentence of imprisonment not exceeding 5 years passed by an Addi­tional Sessions Judge deemed to be an Assistant Sessions Judge — The law­makers although amended Section 407 Cr.P.C. which deals with the forum of appeal from the sentence passed by Mag­istrates of the Second Class and Third Class did not amend Section 408 Cr.P.C relating to forum of appeal from the sen­tence passed by the Assistant Sessions Judge and Magistrates of the First Class — The consensus of judicial opinion is that notwithstanding the proviso to sub­section (3) of Section 9 of the Code of Criminal Procedure an appeal against an order of conviction and sentence not exceeding 5 years passed by such an As­sistant Sessions Judge shall lie to the Court of Sessions under Section 408 Cr.P.C. subject to the proviso to clause (b) and (c) thereunder when appeal shall lie to the High Court Division Shamsul lludit and others Vs. The State 6 (BLD) (HCD) 367.Ref. 35 DLR 362: 1983 BCR 298; 5 BLD 41; 36 DLR 93; 4 BLD 250; 37 DLR 19; 5 BLD 316; 5 BCR 286

 

Sections 9(3), 17(3), 28, 31(4) and 528(1) — Status and extent of jurisdiction of an Assistant Sessions Judge deemed to have been appointed as an Additional Sessions Judge — Such an Assistant Ses­sions Judge does not acquire the status of an Additional Sessions Judge — He only acquires the same jurisdiction as that of an Additional Sessions Judge in respect of trial of cases subject to such limitation as to passing of sentence — An Additional Sessions Judge is not subordinate to the Sessions Judge and they exercise co-ordi­nate powers but an Assistant Sessions Judge is subordinate to the Sessions Judge — There is only an added authority for him to try cases which were hitherto tri­able by the Additional Sessions Judge and to impose a higher sentence. Nurul Huda Vs. Bahauddin and others 9 BLD (HCD) 271.

 

 

Ref. 35 DLR 362; 36 DLR 93; 37 DLR .18; 38 DLR 20; 4 BLD 250 and 367; PLD 1968 (Dhaka) 975, 34 CWN (PC) 230; 121 IC (1930) 532; 1952 (AC) 109; AIR 1953 (SC) 244; AIR 1940 (PC) 167; AIR 1973 (SC) 1016.

 

 

 

Sections 10 and 11 — Authentication of Publication — Whether authentication by the Additional District Magistrate is valid in law — Having reference to the definition of District Magistrate provided by law. if not in the Act concerned but elsewhere having general application, the provisions of the Code of Criminal Pro­cedure provide that the Additional District Magistrate may perform the functions of the District Magistrate — Printing Press and Publications (Declaration and Regis­tration) Act, 1973, Ss. 12, 23 and 24 — General Clauses Act (X of 1897) S 19 Waliul Bari Chowdhury Vs. District Magistrate, Kushtia and others 6 BLD (AD) 284.Ref. AIR 1948 (All) 129; (1956) 3 All ER 939.

 

Section 12 — Power of Upazila Nir-bahi Officer as Magistrate to dispose of pending cases — Upazila Nirbahi Officer though a Magistrate of the First Class he has been given limited judicial powers, namely, to take cognizance of an offence under Section 190 of the Code of Crimi­nal Procedure, to grant bail and to adjourn the hearing of pending cases when the Upazila Magistrate remains absent but he has not been given the power to hear and dispose of pending cases. Shabuddin Vs. Tasiruddin and another 6 BLD (HCD) 416. Ref. 37DLR204

 

Section 29 — Subject to the other pro­visions of the Code , any offence under any other law shall, when any Court is mentioned in this behalf in such law, be tried by such court but when no court is mentioned, it may be tried by any court constituted under this Code Therefore, the Labour Court as well as the court of the Magistrate First Class have been vested with the power to try an offence under Section 29 of the Industrial Rela­tions Ordinance, 1969. Kamaluddin Chowdhury Vs. Masiuddawllah and another 10 BLD (HCD) 440.Ref. 5 BLD (HCD) 278.

 

Sections 33(1) and 386(1) — Whether a Magistrate can order for imprisonment in default of payment of fine when the of­fence is punishable with fine only — Section 33(1) authorises the Magistrate to award such terms of imprisonment in de­fault of payment of fine as is authorized by law in case of such defautl — Where the offence is punishable with imprison­ment as well as fine and where the offence is punishable only with fine, the imprison­ment in default of payment of fine shall be simple and the maximum term is six months — All courts including the court of the Magistrate got power to direct re­covery of fine when the offence is punish­able only with fine by any of the three methods, such as by issuing distress war­rants or by referring the matter to the Collector or by committing the offender to the prison The State Vs. Ahul Kashem 5 BLD (AD) 166

 

Sections 87 and 88 — They are not synonymous — Expression used in Section 87 Cr.P.C. is different from the language used in Section 339B Cr.P.C. In Section 87 the word 'may' while in Section 339B the word 'shall' has been used. Moktar Ahmed Vs. Haji Farid Ahmed and another 10 BLD (HCD) 278

 

Sections 87, 88 and 339B — The Spe­cial Judge is required under law to follow the procedure as laid down under Sections 87, 88 and 339B of the Code of Criminal Procedure without takinu anv notice as to whether there was any publication of the notification in 1 he official gazette earlier by the Martial Law Court before cognizance was taken and trial held in the absence of accused appellant.

 

Trial in the absence of the accused ap­pellant without complying with the proce­dure laid down in the Section is a nullity. Where the mandatory provision of law re­lating gazette notification has not been complied with, the order of conviction and sentence is without jurisdiction. Md. Mozibul Hoque Vs. The State 12 BLD (HCD)376Ref. 43 DLR 387; 10 DLR 459; 35 DLR243; AIR 1963 (SC) 153.

 

Sections 100 and 552 — Complaint of kidnapping — Father's custody of alleged victim when not sustainable — Magistrate cannot detain a person unless he or she is an accused in a criminal case and, when above 16 years, cannot be said to be mi­nor within the meaning of kidnapping un­der the Penal Code — The girl in the in­stant case being above 16 years cannot be handed over to her father or to anybody but she has to be set at liberty — Penal Code (XLV of 1860) S361. Fatema Begum Vs. Gageswar Nath and another 9 BLD (HCD) 469.

 

Section 103 — Illegal search of the house of accused — Its effect when search is conducted in an irregular manner — Respectability of a witness is of no importance when a search is not made in accordance with law — Any self-respect­ing person would not be a party to the kind of search made in the case — Irregularities in a search conducted by an authorised  officer  may  not ordinarily affect the legality of a proceeding and it may only affect the weight of the evidence Search, recovery and seizure of alleged incriminating articles not by a Magistrate or opolice officer but by members of the public are illegal — Arms Act (XI of 1878) S 25. Tamijuddin Ahmed Vs. The State 7 BLD (AD) 22

 

Sections 103 and 156 —  Seizure list Preparation of seizure list during in­vestigation while collecting alamats of a case and preparations of seizure list after conducting search — Whether presence of two respectable persons of the locality is necessary while preparing the seizure list after collection of alamats during the investigation of a case — The procedure laid down in Section 103 Cr.P.C. is not required to be followed at the time of sei­zure of alamats by the Investigating Offi­cer — Any person present at the time of seizure of alamats can be made a witness to the seizure list — Procedure of search under Section 103 Cr.P.C. and that of the seizure of alamats at the place of occur­rence by the Investigating Officer stands altogether on different footings Majibur Rahman and others Vs. The State 7 BLD (HCD) 380Ref. 26 DLR 297.

 

Section 103 — Possession of arms — Plea of illegality in the procedure of search when not tenable — Since it was at the instance of accused Kochi that accused Hosne Ara brought out and made over the pipe gun to the police there was no scope of search and as such there was no question of application of the procedure of search provided in law under Section 403 Cr.P.C. Kochi alias Jishan and others Vs. The State 8 BLD (HCD) 412.

 

Sections 107, 112 and 145 — Criminal proceeding for restraining a person from entering into the disputed land — It is different and independent from a proceed­ing for executing a bond for keeping the peace — An order restraining a person from entering into a land is not contem­plated in a proceeding for executing a bond to keep peace — To meet a situation arising out of a dispute over land the Magistrate is required to proceed under Section 145 Cr.P.C. — In the course of such a proceeding a Magistrate is competent to proceed under Section 107 Cr.P.C. to prevent the breach of the peace.

 

Criminal proceeding to bind down a person for keeping peace — Hearing of parties cannot be a substitute for an order to show cause as to why a bond should not be executed — Show cause according to the procedure provided in section 112 Cr.P.C. is mandatory and cannot be avoided even in the case of an emergency. Sultan Ahmed, Advocate and others Vs. Haji Sultan Ahmed and others 2 BLD (AD) 156.

 

Sections 107, 119 and 439 — Revi-sional jurisdiction — Extent of this juris­diction to be exercised by the High Court Division to interfere with an order of dis­charge — Under the revisional jurisdic­tion the occasion to interfere with an order of discharge under Section 119 Cr.P.C. should be rare, particularly at the instance of a private party — But in the instant case bias has been so patent on the part of the concerned Magistrate that the High Court finds its proper to interfere and pass an order binding down the opposite parties to keep peace, without sending the case back to him on remand — The remarks in the body of the impugned judgment against the petitioner are ex-punged. Sultan Ahmed Vs. Golam Mostafa alias Dulal and others 9 BLD (HCD) 85.

 

Sections 133 and 138 — Proceeding under Section 133 and constitution of jury in violation of Section 138 — A jury constituted in violation of the provision of Section 138 is not a legally constituted one and is incapable of making a legally binding award — As the second party prayed for appointment of a jury, the Magistrate was required to appoint a 'legally constituted jury' according to the provision of Section 138 (l)(a) Cr.P.C and then proceed with the case — Order of filing the case on the basis of the report by the illegally constituted jury cannot be sustained. Abdus Salam Vs. Musabbir Ali and others 1 BLD (HCD) 60.

 

Section 145 — Proceeding under Sec­tion 145 Cr.P C. — Transfer application under Section 528(2) Cr PC filed — S. D M. called for records and fixed date of hearing — No stay order — Magistrate having received intimation of the S. D. M'.s order is not competent to dispose of the proceeding under Section 145 Cr.P C finally before the transfer the application was heard Md Mofazzalur Rahman Vs. Abdus Salam and others 1 BLD (AD) 213.

 

Sections 145 and 146 — Property at­tached under Section 145 or 146 Cr. PC. is in custodia legis — Suit for declaration of title without a prayer for recovery of possession in respect of such property is maintainable and the civil court is com­petent to appoint a receiver in such a suit Specific Relief Act (1 of 1877) S 42. Jogendra Kumar Dutta Vs. Nur Mohammad and others 1 BLD (AD) 248.Ref. AIR 1943 (PC) 94; AIR 1938 (PC) 73 and AIR 1966 (SC ) 359.

 

Sections 145 and 517 — A proceeding under Section 145 Cr.P.C. is not a proceeding to decide the disputed question of title but it is limited to the question as to who was in possession of the disputed property at the relevant time _The question of title can be decided only by the civil court — Law requires the other party, who was not found to be in possession, to establish his right, title, if any, in a civil court and to get recovery of possession in due course of law — Until that is done, the order passed by the Magistrate as to the right to possess will be final. "Land and Water" — Meaning of — It also includes crops standing on the land _Under Section 517 Cr.P.C. property also includes its converted or exchanged form — The property in his converted form may be handed over to the party who was found to be entitled to possession under Section 145(6) Cr.P.C.

— Hence the order of the Magistrate directing the handing over of the sale proceeds of the crops to the successful party suffers from no illegality. Mohammad Hossain Khalifa Vs. Kala Chand Das and others 3 BLD (HCD) 262.

 

Section 145 — lurisdiction of the Magistrate when a civil court is already seized of the subject-matter of dispute — There is no legal provision which em­powers a Magistrate to physically oust a person in possession of the disputed premises during the pendency of such pro­ceeding Professor Md Shahabul Huda Vs. Md Shaft 4 BLD (AD) 165.Ref. 23 DLR(SC) 14.

 

Section 145 — Drawing up proceeding under Section 145 Cr.P.C. without stating grounds of satisfaction — The elements necessary for vesting the Magistrate with jurisdiction to act being all present in the case, the mere omission to set out the grounds of satisfaction about the appre­hension of breach of peace would not vi­tiate the order — There were materials before the Magistrate upon which his sat­isfaction as required under the law could very well be based and that being so, the order cannot be said to be illegal. Mrs. .J until a Mannan Vs. Aminur Rasul alias Farid Mia and others 4 BLD (HCD) 8.Ref. 33 DLR 93; 13 DLR (SC) 138.

 

Section 145(6) — Whether a fresh proceeding under Section 145 Cr.P.C. between the same parties over the same land maintainable — An order in such a proceeding is binding on the parties andan unsuccessful party cannot be allowed to start a fresh proceeding in respect of the settled matter — The purpose of such a proceeding is not to decide title between the parties in a dispute but to maintain status quo till the party found not in pos­session by the Magistrate comes up with a decree from a civil court in his favour — Till that is done the order of the Mag­istrate is final so far as the proceeding un­der Section 145 Cr.P.C. is concerned —' To allow the unsuccessful party to open it up afresh on the same grounds as to the right to possess would nulify the finality attached to the Magistrate's Order. Harunar Rashid Haider Vs. Intaj Sheikh and others 4 BLD (HCD) 29 Ref. 27CWN 171

 

Section 145 — Whether a person out of possession can start such a proceeding — Person out of possession cannot invoke the jurisdiction of the Magistrate on the alleged ground of apprehension of breach of the peace except as provided in proviso to sub-section 4 of Section 145 Cr.P.C. A. B. M. Hasan Kabir Vs. Vntesh Chandra Dey 4 BLD (HCD) 68.

 

Section 145 — Proceeding under Sec­tion 145 Cr.P.C. when competent — In the instant case the Magistrate does not appear to have considered the case as one of emergency and merely attached the subject-matter of dispute in a routine manner without applying his mind judicially — The impugned order of attachment and appointment of receiver is set aside. Abu Sadek and others Vs. Md NurulAlam 4 BLD (HCD) 324.

 

Sections 145(4) and 146(1) — Order of attachment — Magistrate's power to withdraw such an order — If the Magis­trate is satisfied that there is no longer any likelihood of breach of the peace in re­spect of the subject of the dispute and the discretion is exercised properly there is no case for interference by a Revisional Court — There is no authority to support the contention that beforewithdrawing the attachment he was required to consider that if the order of attachment and appointment of receiver is recalled, there would be a likelihood of breach of peace. Nazir Ahmed and others Vs. Younus Meah and others 5 BLD (HCD) 41

 

Sections   145, 439, 439A and 561A__Whether the Sessions Judge in exercise of his revisional powers can quash a proceeding under Section 145 Cr.P.C — Once a proceeding under Section 145 Cr.P.C. has been started with the preliminary order it must be followed up by enquiry and end with final order — There is no question of stopping in the middle unless the Miagistrate is satisfied that breach of peace does not exist — A revisional court can stop such a proceeding only in exceptional circums­tances — Sessions Judge acting under Section 439A Cr PC. cannot exercise inherent powers as are available to the High Court Division under Section 561A _The Sessions Judge has no power to quash a proceeding under Section 145 Cr.P.C. initiated by the Magistrate. Md. Shahjahan Sheikh and others Vs. The Sessions Judge, Pirojpur and others 6 BLD (AD) 261.

 

Sections 145 and 561A — Additional Sessions Judge set aside an order of at­tachment and appointment of a receiver passed by the Magistrate — In view of the fact that there was serious apprehen­sion of immediate breach of peace and a case of emergency was made out the peti­tioner was entitled to an order under sub -section (4) of Section 145 Cr.P.C. — The order passed by the Addtional Sessi­ons Judge setting aside the order of at­tachment and appointment of receiver is illegal and amounts to an abuse of the process of the Court — The order of the Additional Sessions Judge is quashed un­der Section 561A Cr.P.C. Rita Kundu Vs. AkbarAli and others 6 BLD (HCD) 185.

 

Section 145 — Dispute concerning land — Pre-condition for appointment of re­ceiver — Recording of observation that the case is one of emergency is a sine quo non and if the condition precedent is ab­sent the Magistrate acts illegally and without jurisdiction. Abdul Karint Vs. The State ami another 6 BLD (HCD) 296. Ref. 31 DLR 169; (FB), 35 DLR 286; 36DLR 141

 

Sections 145 and 439A — Drawing up of a proceeding and attachment of property depends upon the satisfaction of the Magistrate  as to the existence of a dispute likely to cause a breach of the peace — The satisfaction of the Magistrate cannot be substituted by the satisfaction of the Sessions Judge exercising revisional power — A procee­ding under Section 145 Cr.P.C. can be drawn up only upon the condition that a Magistrate is satisfied about the likelihood of breach of peace — In the instant case the Magistrate was not satisfied about the likelihood of breach of peace — Upon the satisfaction of the Sessions Judge a proceeding under Section 145 Cr.P.C. cannot be drawn up since there is no legal scope for any revising authority to revise the order of the Magistrate in refusing to draw up a proceeding under Section 145 Cr.P.C. Kazi Farhad Hossain and others Vs. S. A. Khyar 7 BLD (HCD) 399.

 

 

Section 145 — Dispute over possession of land — Magistrate's jurisdiction to give directions regarding property in dispute — The power concerning such dispute is an extra-ordinary power which can be exercised in a case of emergency and not as of routine — In this case the Mag­istrate having found that there was no ap­prehension of breach of the peace and some of the parties were in joint posses­sion in the proceeding lands, the Magis­trate was under the legal obligation to put an end to the proceeding and his orders restraining such parties from entering the land and attaching the same is illegal. Ciura Miah and others Vs. Fazar AH and others 9 BLD (HCD) 18. Ref. 25 DLR 317; 20 DLR 575, (DB); 16 DLR(SC) 246; 4 CWN 426

  

Section 145 — Dispute over immov­able property — Question of continuance of a proceeding relating to such dispute—At any stage of the proceeding the Magistrate may cancel the proceeding if he is satisfied that the apprehension of breach of the peace does no longer exist—When a Magistrate passes a pre-/iminary order he  has  to  exercise a subjective satisfaction with regard to such matter but when he decides to cancel the preliminary order he is required to take an objective decision after going through the paper and documents produced by the contending parties — An order passed under  sub-section  (1)   is  passed on subjective satisfaction and a higher court will not substitute its own satisfaction in place of the satisfaction of the Magistrate but an order passed under Sub-section (5) is based on objective satisfaction and as such it is open to wider challenge before the Revisional Court Moslemuddin Dhali and others  Vs.  HelaJuddin Dhali and others 9 BLD (HCD) 232. Ref. 16 DLR (SC) 246, 13 DLR 138.

 

Section 145 — Dispute concerning land Such a proceeding not only fixes a li-ity which arises for causing breach of peace and is personal in nature but the urt in giving finding of possession in h matters incidentally also finds title — ; finding would survive one's death and ce till the proceeding attains finality heirs or successors-in-interest would fcecessary parties in the proceeding.

 

Power of the Magistrate to bring on re-the legal representatives on the death party during enquiry stage would ex­tend to a criminal revision before higher courts — Such a proceeding does not abate or becomes infructuous merely on the death of a particular party at the enquiry stage or the revisional stage. Hazi Abdul Ali and another Vs. Md Mesbauddin and others 10 BLD (HCD) 70.

 

 

Section 145 — Status and function of a receiver — The receiver appointed by the Magistrate under Section 145 Cr PC is an agent of the Court and he manages and administers such property under his control to the approval of the Court — He can attach any condition to the auction held for leasing out the attached property — But in the absence of any such condi­tion attached by the receiver or the Mag­istrate, part of bid money deposited by the bidder cannot be forfeited on his failure to deposit the balance of the bid money but the bid can be cancelled and fresh auction held Amir Hossain Farhad Vs. Doctor A Mannan 12 BLD (HCD) 275. Ref. 33 DLR 399.

 

Section 154 — The FIR is not a sub­stantive evidence — The trial court com­mitted illegality in considering the FIR. as substantive evidence by quoting it is extenso. Amina Bibi alias Amena Bibi and another Vs. The State 4 BLD (HCD) 144Ref. AIR 1951 (Cal) 305; AIR 1963 (SC) 1531.

 

Section 154 — FIR — Effect of omission in FIR — FIR is an in­formation relating to the commission of a cognizable offence reported to the police  by any person with the object of putting the police in motion for investigation — Minute details about the occurrence may not be found in the FIR. — Mere omis­sion of some details in the FIR. does not detract from its correctness — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 32. Majibur Rahman and others Vs. The State 5 BLD (HCD) 110.Ref. PLD 1978 (Lahore) 1285; PLD 1977 (SC) 529; PLD 1971 (Lahore) 883; AIR 1960 (Raj) 24; 31 DLR (AD) 101.

 

Section 154 — First Information Report __Its value the FIR. is not a substantive piece of evidence and statements con­tained in the FIR. cannot be taken to contradict the testimony of the witnesses except the maker thereof — FIR. cannot be expected to contain all the details — When the FIR is not lodged by an eye­witness, contradiction of the said FIR. by an eye-witness does not prejudice the prosecution case Abdul Karim Biswas Vs. Abul Hossain and others 6 BLD (HCD) 382.

 

Section 154 — First Information Re­port — Meaning of — Information about the occurrence, which is carried to the police at the earliest opportunity after the occurrence is the First Information Report and all subsequent information fall within the purview of Section 161 Cr.P.C. Muslimuddin and others Vs. The State 7 BLD (AD) 1.

 

Section 154 — First Information Report Whether statement recorded by the po­lice during investigation of the earlier in­formation upon which the police started investigation is to be treated as the FIR.

 

—   Police did not take up investigation on the basis of any other information or statement — The statement recorded in the FIR. Ext-1 was not made to the police in the course of investigation and as such it is not inadmissible in evidence — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 162 Nurul Islam and others Vs. The State 7 BLD (HCD) 193.

 

Section 154 — First Information Report __Its value in case of apparent omission of fact — FIR. is not a piece of sub­stantive evidence but it may be used for corroborating or contradicting its maker only — The attention of the witness having not been drawn to his omissions in his cross-examination under Section 145 of the Evidence Act, the defence cannot take advantage of the contradictions. Dipok Kumar Sarkar Vs. The State 8 BLD (AD) 109.

 

Section  154 — G D Entry and FIR Requirements to qualify an information to be a First Information Report — FIR has to be an information relating to a cognizable offence, it is to be reduced to writing as clearly as possible in the language of the man without any dictation from outside and it must be signed by the informant or his thumb impression be put thereon and the report is required to be entered in the Register — A G.D. Entry which does not fulfil these requirements cannot be treated as the First InformationReport Nurjahan Begum Vs. The State 8 BLD (HCD) 389.

 

 

Section 154 — First Information Report __Question of its admissibility and worth __If there is any information to the police relating to the commission of a cognizable offence it becomes admissible in evidence and as such though the police officer may have neglected to record it in accordance with law, it becomes the FIR. of the case __Even when an information is given orally but the police officer does not re­duce it to writing, the police officer is do­ing what he ought not to have done — Any other information by any other person subsequently recorded is not admissible in evidence. Zilu Miah and others Vs. The State 8 BLD (HCD) 418. Ref. 5 DLR 210, PLD 1950 (Bagdadul Jadid) 51; 35 CWN 623; AIR 1968 (Madras) 117 (DB); AIR 1961 (Kerala) 99(FB).

 

Section 154 — First Information Re­port — Value of — It being the earliest record of a case it enables the Court to see what the prosecution case was when it was started and to check up any subse­quent embellishment or any departure therefrom as the case proceeds through different stage. Harun Sheikh alias Haronor Rashid and another Vs. The State 8 BLD (HCD) 425, Ref. 2BCR8.

 

Section 154 — FIR. — Its value — First Information Report is the foundation of the prosecution case — When its foun­dation is removed the whole prosecution case falls — If the witnesses depose dif­ferently on essential particularls of the FIR. they are liable to be disbelieved — When the prosecution has a definite or positive case, it must prove the whole of it — Partial departure affects the credi­bility of the witnesses while a complete departure from the FIR. case robs of their credibility CI opal Rajgor and others Vs. The State 9 BLD (HCD) 358 Ref. 16 DLR 189; 39 DLR 16.

 

 

Section 154 — FIR. — Delay in lodging it makes the prosecution case shaky. Abdul Mannan Miah alias Mannan Gain Vs. The State 9 BLD (HCD) 461.

 

 

Section 154 — Delay in lodging Frist Infromation Report — Effect of delay of 4 days without explaining sufficient cause renders the prosecution case doubtful — Non-examination of FIR. named witnesses who came to the place of occurrence after the dacoits left renders the prosecution story shaky and doubtful Jamir alias Jamiruddin Vs. The State 9 BLD (HCD) 474.

 

 

Section 154 — First Information Report and charge sheet — Evidentiary value — FIR. and the charge sheet are not substantive evidence and no con­viction can be based placing reliance on the FIR and the chargesheet Rustum Ali and others Vs. The State 9 BLD (HCD) 477.

 

Section 154 — FIR — Value of The FIR  being  the  earliest recorded version of the prosecution case may be looked into for the prupose of comparingthe same with the statements made subsequently at the trial by the pro-sectuion witnesses — Any deviation or departure from the FIR. story makes the prosecution case doubtful and casts serious doubt as to the credibility of the prosecution witnesses — Partial departure creates suspicion as to the truth of the prosecution case while a total departure from the FIR story sometimes warrants exclusion of the prosecution evidence from consideration Nawsher Mollah and others Vs. The State 11 BLD (HCD) 295.

 

Section 154 — First Information Report — Its importance and evidentiary value — Although the FIR. is not a substantive evidence still it goes a long way to determine the soliditarity or infirmity of the prosecution case — The statements made in the FIR can be looked into with a view to finding the prosecution story as a whole as set out at the earliest stage — FIR is undoubtedly a very important document in a criminal case — It may not be an evidence by itself but it can certainly furnish a valuable clue to the possible truth of the allegations against the accused — In fact, it is the basis of the prosecution case. Lalu alias Lai Miah Vs. The State 11 BLD (HCD) 1.

 

Section 155 — For of an offence under the Drug Ordinance special procedure has been proviuol for investigation of the of­fence by a designated class of officers and a special Court has been set up for the prupose — Such a case can only be tried by a Drug Court situated at Dhaka and not by the UpazilaMagistrate — The case is accordingly transferred to the Drug Court at Dhaka for trial — Drug (Control) Ordinnace (VIII of 1982) S 22 — The Drug Act (XXIII to 1940) S 22. Kalipada Shaha Vs. The State 5 BLD (AD) 279. Ref. AIR 1965 (SC) 1; AIR 1962 (SC) 63; AIR 1929 (Mad) 604.

Section 155 — Cognizance of a non-cognizable offence by a Magistrate on the investigation report of the police without prior order or permission of the competent Magistrate — Whether valid and vitiated the proceeding or trial — The mere fact that an imperative statutroy rule or procedure has been broken is not enough to vitiate the trial or proceeding provided there is no failure of justice — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1988) S 537 Sidique Ahmed and others Vs. The State 5 BLD (HCD) 309. Ref. 25 DLR 455, 30 Cr L.J 1056 (FB); AIR 1953 (Orissa) 83; 4 BLD (AD) 7.

 

Sections 155 & 190 — Investigation by the police of a non-cognizable offence without the order of the Magistrate and cognizance of the case on the basis of such investigation report whether valid in law — A report by the police in a non-cognizable offence without the order of the Magistrate to investigate the case can be treated as a reprot falling under caluses (b) of Section (1) of Section 190 Cr.P.C or in the alternative as a complaint under clause (a) of Sub-section (1) of Section 190 Cr.P C and cognizance upon such a report will not vitiate the trial. Moslem Uddin and others Vs. The State 6 BLD (HCD) 139.

 

Sections 157(5) and 167(5)(6) — Plea of quahsing the proceeding on the ground of expiry of time for investigation — The Investigation Officer made an irregualr petition before the Sessions Judge who also irregularly extended the period of investigation — The irregular order passed on 26.7.83 could have been set aside by the High Court Division if the petitioner had come soon thereafter — But the right of the prosecution to move the Sessions Judge accrued after 29.7.83 for obtaining an order for further investi­gation — Therefore although the order dated 26.7.83 was irregular but the subse­quent orders passed by the Sessions Judge are quite valid. Sabitri Rani Dey Vs. The State 5 BLD (HCD) 341.

 

Section 161 — The Investigating Officer is not required to record the statement of witnesses in minute details. — It is not expected that the witnesses will be asked by the I.O. to give the minor details — Therefore minor omissions do not materially affect the merit of the prosecution case. Siddique Ahmed alias Md Siddique and others Vs. The State 5 BLD (HCD) 202.

 

Section 161 — Delay in examination of the witnesses by the Investigating Offi­cer — Legal impact — Evidence of a witness given before the Court should be left out of consideration since he was ex­amined by the Investigating Officer long after the FIR The State Vs. Mokbul Hossain 6 BLD (HCD) 34.

 

 

Sections 161  & 162 — Withholding of statements recorded under Section 161 Cr.P.C. at the trial — Whether evidence of the prosecution witnesses at the trial can be relied on when the accused were deprived of the opportunity of cross-examining them with reference to the statements recorded by the Investigating Officer — It appears from the record that the case diary is not available — No useful purpose will therefore be served by examining the 1.0. — Due to withholding of statements under Section 161 Cr.P.C. made by material prosecution witnesses to the 1.0. the accused persons have been seriously prejudiced and as such no reliance should be placed on the evidence of such witnesses. Nazir Ahmed and others Vs. The State 7 BLD (HCD) 426.

 

Ref. 9 DLR 594; 50 Cr.L J. 340 (PC); 51 CWN 474 (PC); 39 CWN 164; 48 Cr L.J 58; AIR 1948 (Nag) 74, AIR 1945 (Nag) 1;ILR 53 (All) 458.

 

 

Sections 161 and 162 — Statement be­fore the police — It enables the accused to contradict a witness by drawing his attention to the statements recorded by the police under Section 161 Cr.P.C. — Such statement can never be used as substantive evidence either in favour of or against the accused and conviction can not be based on such statement —Evidence Act (1 of 1872)S 145. Mil Nasir alias Nasir Ahmed Vs. The State 9 BLD (HCD) 502.

 

 

Section 161 — Right giving to the ac­cused for getting copies of-statements re­corded under Section 161 of the Code of Criminal Procedure is a valuable right — Failure to supply to thcacused such copies caused prejudice to the accused and vitiated the trial. Government of the People's Republic of Bangladesh Vs. Zahir and others 1 BLD (AD) 296.

 

 

Section 164 — Statement by witness recorded under Section 164 Cr.P.C. can not be used as substantive evidence — Such statements can be used to corroborate or contradict a witness but it can never be used to establish facts stated there in — It can be used to test the veracity of a witness but cannot be used to substantiate the facts stated therein Toyezuddin Pramanik and others Vs. The State 1 BLD (HCD) 433. Ref. AIR 1941 (Cal) 406; 73 IA 1; 8 DLR 404; 2 DLR (PC) 1; 8 DLR (FC) 1.

 

 

Section 164 — Statements recorded under Section 164 Cr.P.C. cannot be treated as substantive evidence — Such statement can only be used for contradicting the maker of it or for the purpose of corroborating him — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 145, 155 and 157. Khasru alias Khorshed Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 318. Ref. 33 DLR 320; 50 CWN (PC) 353; AIR 1942 (Cal) 36.

 

Section 164 — It is well-settled that a statement of witness recorded under Sec­tion 164 Cr.P C. is not a substantive evi­dence — It can only be used for contra­dicting or corroborating a witness — Merely because the witness was dead at the time of the trial, his statement recorded by a Magistrate does not become admissible as it was not recorded in a judicial proceeding and the accused had no opportunity to cross-examine him Rahij alias Ghatoo Vs. The State 4 BLD (HCD) 44. Ref. 50 CWN (PC) 353; 2 DLR (PC) 39, 33 DLR 320 and 35 DLR 1 19.

 

 

Section 164 — Recording of confes­sional statement — Usual form for recording confessional statement was not used and the Magistrate recorded the confessional statement of a accused on a plain piece of paper which was signed by the Magistrate at the bottom — Such confessional statement is not admissible in evidence — The defect is not curable even by subseqent examination of the recording Magistrate Zaheda Bewa and another Vs. The State 5 BLD (HCD) 9. Ref. AIR 1936 (PC) 253; 20 DLR (Dhaka) 780.

 

 

Section 164 — Statement made by a witness under Section 164 Cr.P C is not a substantive evidence — Such a statement can be used only to contradict or corroborate a witness — No conviction can be based on such statement Anis AH Master and others Vs. The State 5 BLD (HCD) 318.Ref. 50 CWN (PC) 348; 53 CWN (PC) 609, AIR 1972 (SC) 468.

 

 

Section 164 — Statement of a witness recorded under Section 161 Cr.P C can­not be treated as substantive evidecne and conviction can not be based upon it — Even if a previous statement relates to a relevant fact it cannot be proved for the purpose of substantiating the existence of that fact — But when the witness is examined in Court the statement made by him before a Magistrate can be used to support or challenge the evidence given in Court by him Mahiruddin and others Vs. The State 6 BLD (AD) 318. Ref. 76 IA 147; AIR 1949 (PC) 257.

 

 

Section 164 — Duty of the Magistrate recording confessional statement — It is imperative that the Magistrate recording the confessional statement must ask the maker thereof as to the motive of the con­fession and to ascertain the voluntariness of the same — The Magistrate must ask the accused person as to how long he was in police custody, whether any pressure was brought to bear upon him, whether he was subjected to torture or he was given any allurement or inducement — Besides that the Magistrate must inform the ac­cused that he is not bound to make any statement but if he makes any statement that might be used against him at the trial and that after he makes the statement he would be sent to judicial lock-up and not to the police custody — A Magistrate recording the confessional statement should endeavour to place the confessing accused at ease, dispel all or any lurking fear, inducement and hope from the mind of the accused to enable him to make of his own volition an absolutely free and voluntary statement according to the best dictates of his own inner conscience — Before proceeding to record a con­fessional statement the Magistrate must assure himself and satisfy his own judicial conscience about it and this satisfaction must flow out of the answers given by the accused to the questions put to him by the Magistrate — A mere statement of satisfaction by the Magistrate does not satisfy the test that the confession was voluntary and it may be relied upon — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) Ss. 24 and 28. Abdul Wahah and another Vs. The State 6 BLD (HCD) 390.

 

 

Section 164 — Confession — Value of the objection that the Magistrate before recording the confession did not inform the accused that he would not be remanded to police custody even if he did not make any confession does not detract from its value as there is no requirement the under law to inform the accused to the avove effect — Of course, if the Magistrate has any reason to beleive that the accused is apprehensive of the police, he may assure him as above but that is not to say that if it were not said, the voluntariness of the confession would be in doubt.

 

 

Extra-Judicial Confession — When not to be considered — The High Court Division rightly left out of consideration the extra-judicial confession which was made in presence of the dafadar and there was some evidence of beating by him. I hp ok Kumar Sarkar Vs. The State 8 BLD (AD) 109.

 

 

Section 164 — Requirements of a confessional statement — The Court must affirmatively satisfy itself thai the state­ment'is voluntary and true — Theie must be meticulous observance of all necessary \ formalities and precautions provided in Section 164(3) of the Code of Criminal Procedure with minute particularity so as to ensure that the confession is absolutely free from slightest tinge of extraneous in­fluence — Before recording a confession a Magistrate is bound to make a real and substantial enquiry as to the voluntariness of the confession — The Magistrate must put questions with a view to finding out the real object of confession. Habibur Rahman alias Habib Vs. The State 8 BLD (HCD) 210.Ref. 5 BLD 9; AIR 1936 (PC) 253.

 

 

Section 164 — Confessional Statement — When it loses credibility — The con­demned prisoner was kept under the charge of a police personnel when he was given time for reflection — In doing so gross illegality was committed by the Magistrate and the confessional state­ments stands vitiated. The State Vs. Mizanul Islam alias Dahlu and another 8 BLD (HCD) 317.

 

 

Section 164— Confession — Meaning of — It means admission of certain facts which constitute an offence and it should be directly on the point admitting material facts— No statement that contains self-exculpatory matters can amount to confession — Confession must either admit in terms of the offence or at any rate substantially all facts which constitute an offence — Evidence Act (I of 1872) S 24.

 

Recording of confession — Magis­trate s duty while recording confession — The Magistrate can not be casual and act mechanically in the enquiry made from the accused before recording his confession He should endeavour to place him at ease, dispel all or anv lurking fear, in­ducement and hope from accused's mind to enable him to make of his own volition an absolutely free and voluntary statement according to the best dictates of his inner conscience Abdul Wahab and another Vs. The State 8 BLD (HCD) 344

 

Section 164 and 533 — Confession — Question of time for reflection — There is no absolute rule that a confessing ac­cused should be given any specific time for reflection — The rule referred to at the confession form has not the force of law — Any irregularity in recording the confession is curable Rattan Khan alias Rattan and others Vs. The State 8 BLD (HCD) 396.Ref. 19 DLR (Dhaka) 573; 20 DLR (Dhaka) 526.

 

 

1277

CODE OF CRIMINAL PROCEDURE (V OF 1898) (Part-2)

Citation: 8 BLD (HCD) 505.Ref. 8 BLD 210; PLD 1957 (SC) (Ind) 555; 39 DLR (AD) 117, 9 BLD (HCD) 187.Ref. 1 BLD 433; 2 DLR (PC) 1; 8 DLR 404; 8 DLR (FC) 1; AIR 1941 (Cal) 401, 9 BLD (HCD) 477Ref. 1968 (Pak) Cr.L J (Karachi) 155; 1960 PLD (Karachi) 817, 35 DLR 185 a

Case Year: 1898

Subject: Criminal Law

Delivery Date: 2018-08-12

CODE OF CRIMINAL PROCEDURE (V OF 1898)

 

Sections 164, 364 and 533 — Confes­sional statement when not admissible in evidence — There is nothing to show that the accused was given any time for reflec tion and any question was put to him to ascertain whether he was prepared to make the statement of his own free will — The Magistrate did not make any genuine effort to find out the real character of the confession — The omissions to fill up certain paragraphs in the form for the statement are not curable Use of confessional statement against co-accused — The confession made by a person affecting himself and some other persons being jointly tried may be taken into consideration against such other per­sons — But such evidence only lends assurance to other evidence, if there be any — The same by itself cannot form the basis of conviction of a co-accused — Evidence Act (I of 1872) S 30. Mil Azad Shaikh alias Azad Sk. Vs. The State 8 BLD (HCD) 505.Ref. 8 BLD 210; PLD 1957 (SC) (Ind) 555; 39 DLR (AD) 117.

Section 164 — Statement of witness — Use of — Such statement cannot be used as substantive piece of evidence of the truth of the fact stated therein — It can only be used in cross-examination of the witness to show that the evidence given in the Court was false but not to use it for showing that the statement recorded was true — The statement can not be used for filling up the lacuna or for strengthening the prosecution evidence which is other­wise weak. Asaddar Ali and others Vs. The State 9 BLD (HCD) 187.Ref. 1 BLD 433; 2 DLR (PC) 1; 8 DLR 404; 8 DLR (FC) 1; AIR 1941 (Cal) 401.

 Section 164 — Confessional statement — Value of — The accused having been kept in ' police custody for 3 days preceding the recording of his confession, his confession can not be considered as voluntary — The Court first has to find the confessional statement to be true and voluntary and then only he may place reliance on it — Extra-judicial confession made in presence of the police cannot be used against the accused — Uncorrobo­rated confessional statement has no evidentiary value and it cannot be used as evidence against other accused persons Rustom AH and others Vs. The State 9 BLD (HCD) 477Ref. 1968 (Pak) Cr.L J (Karachi) 155; 1960 PLD (Karachi) 817, 35 DLR 185 and 7 BCR (AD) 508

Sections 164 and 342 — Confessional statement — When it cannot be used against the accused though it was used in an earlier case where he gave evidence as an approver — The Magistrate who re­corded the confessional statement was ex­amined in court in the case against 2 other accused — The Magistrate's statement recorded in the earlier case can not be taken into consideration in this case as in the former case he was a witness and the accused did not have the opportunity to cross -examine the Magistrate So the Magistrate's evidence cannot be consid­ered in this case and the confessional statement too cannot be used against the accused appellant — Moreover the con fessional statement and the evidence of the recording Magistrate having not been placed before the trial Court, the same cannot be used as evidence in this case — While examinning the appellant the trial Court has not also drawn his attention to the confessional statement nor did it state anything regar-ding any incriminating evi­dence — In such circumstances, the con­fessional state-ment cannot be used against the appellant — Evidence Act (1 of 1872 S 33 Angur Vs. The State 9 BLD (HCD) 485.

Sections 164 and 533 — Confessional statement recorded in plain sheet of paper — While recording the statement in plain sheet of paper due to the non-availability of the printed form the Magistrate ob­served all legal formalities in recording the statement except that he did not record the questions and answers — Further memorandum recorded was not in strict terms of Section 164(3) of the Code of Criminal Procedure — Such omissions or the defective recording of the memoran­dum being not fatal are curable under Section 533 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. The State Vs. Kalu liepari 10 BID (HCD) 373.

Sections 164 and 533 — A Magistrate acts illegally in recording the confessional statement of an accused without strictly following and observing the mandatory provisions contained in Section 164(3) Cr.P.C. Non-compliance with the manda­tory provisions of Section 164 Cr.P.C. on material points is not curable under Section 533 of the Code of Criminal Procedure   and   such   a confessional statement is not admissible in evidence Abdul Hakim and others Vs. The State 10 BLD (HCD) 430Ref. AIR 1936 (PC) 253, 37 DLR (HCD) 66.
