Section 164 — Purpose of recording such statements — The statements of a witness recorded under Section 161 Cr.P.C. is meant for binding him down to the statement, and in the case of any glar­ing inconsistency amounting to purgery, the witness may be prosecuted for giving false evidence — The defence may use it to contradict the witness whereas the prosecution may use it to corroborate him when he gives evidence in the Court It is now well-settled that the statement of a witness recorded under Section 164 CfiP.C. is to be received by the Court with caution — If there are other circumstances on record which lend support to the truth of the evidence of such a witness, then his evidence can be relied upon Abu Taher Chowdhury and others Vs. The State 11 BLD (AD) 2.

Section 164 — Confessional statement — The statement was recorded by the Magistrate in a plain paper — On the ba­sis of the alleged confessional statement the police claimed to have recovered incriminating articles from the possession and control of the accused — But this statement was alleged to have been made on 29.10 90 while the recovery of the ar­ticles took place on 23.10.90 ie; 6 days ahead of making the confessional state­ment — Neither the  confessional state-merit was produced before the Court nor the Magistrate was examined in the case — Such a confessional statement cannot be accepted (iaziur Rahman Vs. The State 11 BLD (HCD) 11.

Section 164 — In a confessional state­ment an accused may implicate himself and also make some untrue statement re­garding other part or implicate some other persons falsely. Although the confession does disclose the full picture, it can be used against the maker and there is not le­gal bar in upholding the conviction on the basis of the confession Hazrat AH and other Vs. The Sate 11 RID (AD ) 270.

Section 164(3) — The requirement of adherance to the provisions of section 164(3) Cr.P.C. is not merely a matter of form only of substance.

Section 164(3) Cr.P.C. is a mandatory provision of law and it must be strictly complied with Md. Aktar Hossain alias Rahul Vs. The State 12 BLD (HCD) 105.

Ref. 42 DLR (AD) 186; 38 DLR 311; 6 BCR 278; 3 BLD 206; 8 BLD 344; 36 DLR 185; 20 DLR 780; 18 DLR (WP) 112; AIR 1933 (PC) 253; PLD 1969 (Dhaka) 405; AIR 1957 (SC) 637, PLD 1960 (Karachi) 817; PLD 1969 (Dhaka) 504; AIR 1956 (SC) 217.

Section 167 — Time limit for comple­tion of investigation by police — Failure to conclude investigation within the specified or extended time stops further investigation and entitles the accused to be released — But when investigation is completed within the extended period from the date of receipt of the information, though chargesheet was received by the Court beyond that time, the Magistrate committed no illegality by failure to stop the further investigation and releasing the accused on the expiry of period 90 days. Syed Ahmed and another Vs. The State and another 4 BLD (HCD) 133.

Section 167 — Whether the Special Judge is justified in discharging the ac­cused on the ground that investigation was not completed within the prescribed time from the date of reciept of information of commission of the offence — The expression "from" preceding the words "the date of receipt of the information relating to the commission of the offence or the order of the Magistrate or investigation" occurring in Sub-section (5) of Section 167 Cr.P.C. is indicative of the method to be adopted for the purpose of computation of the period prescribed in the Section — Under Section 9(1) of the General Clauses Act the date of receipt of the FIR relating to the commission of the offence must be excluded in computing the period for investigation — General Clauses Act (X of 1897) S 9 Md. Ahdur Razzuk Khan Vs: Md. Abdul Hamid Shaikh and another 6 BLD (HCD 245.

Sections 167 and 173 — Chargeshet validity of— The police validly submitted the chargesheet as the power to make further investigation is always available to them and if there has been no order stop- ping the proceeding and releasing the ac­cused after the expiry of the period of in­vestigation — Secondly, the petitioner does not seem to have raised the question at any stage that the submission of the chargesheet was bad in law — It is held that charge sheet has been validly submit­ted. Shah Alam Chowdhury Vs. The State 9 BLD (AD) 127.

Section 167 — Power of the Sessions Judge to direct further investigation — The power given to the Sessions Judge to direct further investigations is retrospec­tive in nature and he has been empowered to direct further investigation into an of­fence when further investigation is stopped on the expiry either of the speci­fied time or of the extended time — The legislature has not put any limitation on the power of the Sessions Judge to direct further investigation into an offence — General Clauses Act (X of 1897) S 14(1) Md Anwar Hossain Maji and others Vs. The State and another 9 BLD (HCD) 401.

Sections 167(5)(6) (7A), 169 and 173 (3B) — Re-opening of investigation — Question of further investigation into an offence after "discharge" of the accused upon final report — Legal position of the procedure in the face of the time limit for completing such investigation — The or­der of discharge of the accused by the Magistrate on receipt of the final report is like releasing the accused on the ground of deficiency of evidence — In such a position the Magistrate has no occasion to take cognizance of the offence and his or­der of discharge merely amounts to dis­charge from custody and not from the case — By his order dated 6.10.87 the Chief Metropolitan Magistrate did not release the accused on stopping the investigation on the expiry of the specified time or the extended time but merely discharged the accused from custody — Subsequent insertion of provisions in Section 167 Cr.P.C. has not affected the legal duty of the police to re-open investigation — The Police Regulations, 1943, R 277(a) — General Clauses Act (X of 1897) S 14(1). Shah Alam Chowdhury Vs. The State 10 BLD (HCD) 28. Ref. 14 DLR (Dhaka) 511; PLD 1965 (Lahore) 734; 26 DLR (HCD) 211; 29 DLR (SC) 256

Sections 167 (7A), 10(2) and 18(2) -Revival of a case — Jurisdiction for re­vival after release of accused following period of investigation extended by the Sessions Judge — The District Magistrate or the Chief Metropolitan Magistrate in­cluding the Additional District Magistrate or the Additional Chief Metropolitan Magistrate has jurisdiction to revive a case within the specified period even when the Sessions Judge has extended the period of further investigation for a lim­ited period under Sub-section (6) of Sec­tion 167 Cr.P C. Ahmed Hossain Bhuiyan Vs. The State 10 BLD (HCD) 185.

Section 167(7) — Law contemplates completion of the investigation by the police within the to re-open investigation — The Police Regulations, 1943, R 277(a) — General Clauses Act (X of 1897) S 14(1). Shah Alam Chowdhury Vs. The State 10 BLD (HCD) 28Ref. 14 DLR (Dhaka) 511; PLD 1965 (Lahore) 734; 26 DLR (HCD) 211; 29 DLR (SC) 256

Sections 167 (7A), 10(2) and 18(2) -Revival of a case — Jurisdiction for re­vival after release of accused following period of investigation extended by the Sessions Judge — The District Magistrate or the Chief Metropolitan Magistrate in­cluding the Additional District Magistrate or the Additional Chief Metropolitan Magistrate has jurisdiction to revive a case within the specified period even when the Sessions Judge has extended the period of further investigation for a lim­ited period under Sub-section (6) of Sec­tion 167 Cr.P C. Ahmed Hossain Bhuiyan Vs. The State 10 BLD (HCD) 185.

Section 167(7) — Law contemplates completion of the investigation by the police within the prescribed time and not the date on which the police report is received by the Court Abdur Rashid Vs. The State 10 BLD (HCD) 407 Ref. 4 BLD (HCD) 133.

Section 167 — Conclusion of investi­gation — The investigation of a criminal case has to be concluded within 60 days from the date of receipt of the information relating to the commission of an offence or from the date of order of the Magistrate for such investigation — If it is not so concluded, the Magistrate empowered to take cognizance of the offence or making the order for inves­tigation shall make the order stopping further investigation into the case unless the Magistrate being satisfied for special reasons and in the interest of justice extends the period upto 30 days for continuance of the investigation. Nurul Islam Vs. The State 12 BLD (HCD) 41

Section 173(3)(b) — Re-investigation and further investigation — There is no provision in the Code of Criminal Proce­dure for re-investigation after scrapping earlier investigation report of the case but further investigation may be made on ob­taining further evidence Abdul Latif Biswas Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 155.

Section 173 — Final report by the In­vestigating Officer — When improper — It is none of his business 1.0 to decide the case for himself when two sides come up with contradictory versions of the same occurrence — The quality of evidence is the same in each case and there were injuries caused to both sides — In a case like this both the versions should be placed before a Court of law so that the truth can be found out upon receiving evidence from both sides Syed Abdul Hannan Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 156.

Section 173 — Supplementary charge sheet — There is no scope in the scheme of the Code of Criminal Procedure to direct the Investigating Officer to submit any supplementary chargesheet on the ba­sis of materials on record — Magistrate's order for such a chargesheet is without any lawful authority Abdus Salik alias Sarkumullah and others Vs. The State and another 3 BLD (HCD) 314.

Section 173 and 190 — Competence of Magistrate to direct the police for further investigation after taking cogni­zance on acceptance of the charge sheet — Once a Magistrate has taken cogni­zance on a police report he is not entitled to send the case to the police for further investigation — If he is not satisfied with the final report he is competent to take cognizance against the accused recom­mended for discharge by the police on the basis of the materials on record — If he does not take cognizance at that stage but subsequently evidence transpires against a person, cognizance may be taken against him — The Magistrate may also direct further investigation if he is not satisfied with the police report before cognizance is taken — The police may submit supplementary charge sheet on further investigation against an accused who was(XLV of 1860) S 467 Sree Jagannath Chandra Bakshi and others Vs. The State 9 BLD (HCD) 247

Sections  4(1 )(m), 190, 202, 203 and 204 — Filing of complaint in a Court sets the ball rolling - Section 190 Cr.P.C. empowers the comptent Magistrate to take cognizance of any offence upon re­ceiving a complaint of facts which consti­tute such "offence" while Section 200 Cr.P.C. provides that "a Magistrate taking cognizance of an offence on' complaint shall at once examine the complainant upon oath and the substance of the exami­nation shall be reduced to writing" — Section 202 authorises the Magistrate to postpone the issue of process and to direct an investigation to be made by himself or by a subordinate Magistrate or by a Police Officer for ascertaining the truth or falsehood of the complaint — Section 203 authorises the Magistrate to dismiss the complaint if there is in his judgment no sufficient ground for pro­ceeding — Section 204 authorises the Magistrate to issue porocess against the accused persons — It is not correct to say that the complaint filed in the Court is no part of the proceeding of the Court — Such a view would tantamount to upsetting the chronology or order of a criminal prosecution Dr. Jamshed Bakth Vs. Ameenur Rashid Chowdhury 1 BLD (AD) 314 Ref. 38 (Cal) 888; 28 (Bom) 228; 49 (Mad) 315, 17CWN 554; 19CWN 935; AIR 1937 (All) 90; 1 (QB) 65

 

Sections 190, 193, 435 and 561A —Sessions Judge can call for the record of a proceeding pending before a Magistrate for purposes mentioned in Section 435 Cr.P.C. but. he has no power to take congizance of an offence as a Court of original jurisdiction and as such he is not competent to initiate a new proceeding — Sessions Judge started a Criminal Mis­cellaneous Case against a Magistrate upon a telegram containing allegations against the Magistrate in respect of a proceeding pending before the Magistrate — The Sessions Judge acted without jurisdiction and the Criminal Miscellaneous Case is quashed Haripada Biswas Vs. The State and another 2 BLD (AD) 13.

Sections 190, 200, 202, 204 and 205C— Magistrate's power to take cogni­zance — This power is not limited only to those offences which are triable exclu­sively by the Magistrate but it also ex­tends to offences which are triable exclu­sively by the Court of Sessions — The Magistrate has the sole jurisdiction to de­cide whether under the given circums­tances cognizance should be taken or not. Ahdus Salam Master and another Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 267. 

Section 190 — Once a Magistrate has taken cognizance on a police report he is not entitled to send the case to the police for further investigation but if he is not satisfied with the final report submitted by the police he is competent to take cogni­zance against the accused in favour of whom final report was submitted — If he does not take cognizance at that stage, still he can take cognizance against a person against whom evidence transpires subsequently Shamsun Nahar alias Maina Vs. The State 4 BLD (AD) 206.

Section 190(l)(b) — Power of a Magistrate to take cognizance against an accused in whose favour the police has submitted the final report — Meaning of the words "Charge Sheet" and "final report" — Ordinarily a charge sheet means a police report in which the police recommends for the prosecution of the accused while a final report means a police report in which no accused is recommended to be prosecuted — If the Magistrate is satisfied that a particular person has been improperly excluded from the charge sheet he may take cognizance against such a person on the basis of a police report even though it is a final report Abdul Awal Vs. Abdul Mannan and another 6 BLD (AD) 328Ref. 19DLR(SC)426.

Sections 190(1) and 202(1 )(2A) —Cognizance of offence by Magistrate and extent of his jurisdiction — In a case ex­clusively triable by the Court of Sessions, a Magistrate for the purpose of ascertain­ing the truth or falsehood of the complaint is to consider the evidence in order to find whether a prima facie case has been made out or not but he cannot assess the evi­dence as if in a trial but at the same time he is not a conduit pipe — He is to con­sider the evidence so far as it is necessary for compliance with the requirements of law — He has jurisdiction to decide after enquiry as to whether all or some of the accused are to be sent for trial. Syed Ahmed and another Vs. Habibur Rahman and another 9 BLD (HCD) 227.Ref. 36 DLR (AD) 58; 35 DLR 140 and 33 DLR 8.

Section 190 (1) — Whether the Police Report is binding upon the Magistrate — The Magistrate is not bound by the Police Report recommending release of the ac­cused — He may accept such a report or may take cognizance on his personal perusal of the report or he may direct further police investigation or may direct judicial enquiry or even he may take cognizance upon any information or upon his own knowledge.

Powers of the Magistrate — Power of the Magistrate under Section 190(1) of the Code of Criminal Procedure are wide enough and unfettered by the Police Report under Section 173 Cr.P C Abdur Rahsid Vs. The State 10 BLD (HCD) 407.Ref. 28 DLR 1, 36 DLR (AD) 58; 19 DLR (SC) 426, 37 DLR 335; 4 BLD (HCD) 133 and 14 DLR (SC) 96.

 

Section 190(1)(C) — Cognizance after discharge — It is true that after discharge of the accused the case can not be revived against him—In this case when fresh in­criminating materials came up in course of trial the Magistrate issued process against the accused suo motu — There is no ille­gality in it Shafiqur Rahman Vs. The State 6 BLD (HCD) 69

Sections 193, 205C and 205D — Re­jection of a Naraji petition amounts to an order of discharge of the accused and dismissal of the complaint — The only remedy against such an order is to ap­proach the Sessions Judge for a direction to make further enquiry — The Sessions Judge has no jurisdiction to take cogni­zance of an offence as a Court of original jurisdiction — The Sessions Judge rightly rejected the prayer of the informant for taking cognizance against accused in re­spect of whom the naraji petition was earlier rejected by the Magistrate. Abdur Razzaque Vs. The State and another 3 BLD (HCD) 70.

Section 193(1) — Sesssions Judge's power to take cognizance against dis­charge accused — The Sessions Judge cannot take cognizance of an offence as a Court of original jurisdiction against ac­cused, persons discharged by Magistrate in view of the final report submitted by the Police Zainul Abedin and others Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 108.

Section 193 — Cognizance of an of­fence by the Sessions Judge — Sessions Judge has no power to summon the ac­cused discharged by the Magistrate — Unless a Magistrate sends an accused to the Court of Sessions for trial, the Ses­sions Judge has no power under the Code of Criminal Procedure to issue process against any person to stand trial in a Session case. Fazlul Huq Haidar alias Mollah Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 184.

Section 193 — A Court of Session can not take cognizance of any offence as a Court of original jurisdiction unless an accused is sent to him for trial by the Magistrate Kedareswar Chakraborty and others Vs. The State 10 BLD (HCD) 368.

Sections 195(C) and 476(1) — Cogni­zance on the basis of a police report of an offence in relation to a proceeding in a Court — If valid — Cognizance taken by the Special Judge against a public servant on the basis of a police report sought for by the Magistrate to whom complaint was sent by the Munsif concerned is legal. Syed Ebadad AH Vs. The State 2 BLD (HCD) 179.Ref. 20 DLR 66.

Sections 195, 476 and 561A — A criminal prosecution launched by a party to a civil suit against the other party alleg­ing offences alleged to have been commit­ted in relation to a proceeding in the Civil Court is not maintainable in law in view of the bar imposed by Section 195(1) Cr.P.C — Only the Court concerned can lodge a complaint before a competent Court — Moreover, so long the decree passed by the Civil Court remains in force it provides a good defence for the accused appellants in the criminal prosecution — Such a proceeding should not be allowed to be continued and should be quashed. Mr. Mahiruddin Mia and others Vs. Rokeya Hossain 5 BLD (AD) 73.

 

Sections 195 and 476 — Cognizance of an offence — Cognizance in respect of a document produced or given in evidence in Court — What is required is that the Court concerned must come to the conclusion that an offence has been committed in relation to a proceeding before him — If that is the case, the Court can launch a criminal prosecution — In the absence of such conclusion by the Civil Court prosecution and conviction for forgery of a document produced in the Civil Court is illegal Syed Ebadad Ali Vs. The State 5 BLD (AD) 285.Ref. 20 DLR (Dhaka) 66, AIR 1927 (All) 571; AIR 1931 (Mad) 16; AIR 1926 (Mad) 238.

Sections 195 and 476 — Prosecution at the instance of a private individual — When barred — A private individual can not prosecute a person for an offence committed in relation to a proceeding in a Court as such a proceeding is barred un­der the provision of clause (c) of Sub-sec­tion (1) of Section 195 Cr PC - - The expression "party to a proceeding" needs be interpreted strictly and in its ordinary meaning — Sections 195 and 476 Cr.P.C. are to be read together in as much as the former section lays down the bar while the latter section lays down the method for removing the bar — Section 476 enjoins the Civil Court to make enquiry when it is of the opinion that an offence has been committed in or in relation to a pro­ceeding "in that Court" — Section 195(C) applies only to cases where an offence has been committed in respect of a document which has been produced or given in evidence in such a proceeding — When the offence is committed before the accused became a party to the proceeding the provisions of Section 195 (c) Cr P C are not applicable Mosatnmat Saleha Khatun Vs. The State 5 BLD (HCD) 193 Ref. AIR 1931 (All) 443.

Section 195(1)(C) — Whether sub­section 1 (c) of Section 195 Cr P C has been superseded by the Criminal Law Amendment Act. 1958 — The provision for complaint from Court as envisaged by Section 195(1)(C) Cr.P.C. has not been specifically done away with and as such the general provision of the Code remains unaffected — When an offence within the meaning of the Code is committed in or in relation to a proceeding before a Court, then the complaint shall have to be filed bv that Court — The provision for taking cognizance of an offence on a complaint from the Court has remained unaffected and as such if an offence falls within the ambit of Section 195(I)(C) Cr P C then cognizance can not be taken except upon a complaint from the Court — The Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1958 (Act XL of 1958) Md. Muslim Khan Vs. The State 6 BLD (AD) 164.

 

Section 195(1)(C) — Complaint by a Revenue Officer — The Revenue Officer holding a mutation proceeding is not a Court within the meaning of Section 195 (1) Cr.P.C and as such there is no bar for the Magistrate to take cognizance of the offence of forgery in respect of a docu­ment   produced   before   the Revenue Officer without any complaint from him. Idris Ali and others Vs. The State 6 BLD (HCD) 7. Ref. AIR 1950 (SC) 188; 1931 (AC) 276; PLD 1956 (SC) (India) 65 PLD 1957 (SC) (Pakistan) 91; 27 DLR 288; 20 DLR 1019; 9 DLR (WP) (Lahore) 40.

 

Sections 195 and 476 — Whether a person can be ordered to be prosecuted by a Court for producing a fabricated document before a police officer — Ad­mittedly the disputed document was not produced by any of the accused persons before any Court — Since the document in question, even if admitted by the parties to be a fabricated one, was not produced in any Court or given in evidence in any Court, the Sessions Judge committed an errro of law in passing the imupgned order for lodging a compliant against the accused appellant. Ali Hossain Vs. The State and another 7 BLD (HCD) 93.

 

Sections 195(1)(C), 476 and 561A —Prohibition against private complaint — Purposes of the prohibition and the extent of the right to make complaint — The legislative intent in imposing prohibition against a private complaint is to save a party from vexatious prosecution and to avoid conflicting decisions in two Courts — The main ingredient of the prohibitory provision is the production in a Court proceeding a forged document by a party thereto — If a forged document is produced in a proceeding by a party the Court will acquire the sole jurisdiction to make a complaint under Section 476Cr.P.C. if it is found expedient in the interest of justice, not only for the use of the forged document but also for the offence of forging it, irrespective of the date of forgery — The two offences are so inter-connected that one cannot be separated from the other. When the docu­ment docu­ment has been used by a party to the proceeding the offences fall very much within the ambit of Section 195(C) — No cognizance thereof can be taken except on a complaint by the Court — The proceed­ing in respect of appellant No. 1 is therefore quashed. Abdul Hai Khan and others Vs. The State 8 BLD (AD) 195.

 

Ref. AIR 1931 (All) 443; AIR 1971 (SC) 1935; AIR 1973 (SC) 1100; AIR 1974 (SC) 299; AIR 1976 (SC) 2225; AIR 1981 (SC) 1417; AIR 1936 (Bom) 221; AIR 1923 (Bom) 105; AIR 1966 (All) 124; AIR 1969 (All) 189; AIR 1943 (Nag) 327; AIR 1930 (Mad) 869; AIR 1965 (Guj) 70; 21 CWN 640; ILR 39 (Mad) 677; 20 DLR 66; 38 DLR (AD) 60; AIR 1953 (SC) 293 and 20; 5 BLD 193; 5 BCR (HCD) 150.

 

Section 195(l)(b) — Prosecution for false charge — Whether complaint by Magistrate is necessary in respect of a case ending in a final report — Orders passed by a Magistrate in a case initiated on the basis of an FIR ending in discharge of the accused or acceptance of a final report are not proceedings of a Court within the meaning of Section 195 Cr.P.C. as these are merely in the category of "Police Proceedings" — In such a    case the embargo placed by Section 195 Cr.P.C is not applicable and no complaint by a Magistrate for prosecu­tion on account of false charges is necessary — The Additional Sessions Judge acted illegally in allowing the appeal on the ground of non-filing of complaint by the Magistrate — Penal Code (XLV of 1860) S 211. Abdul Quader Vs. Serajuddowla and others 9 BLD (HCD) 517.Ref. AIR 1941 (Cal) 263; ILR 33 (Cal) 30; AIR 1917 (Cal) 593; ILR 43 (Cal) 1152; 28 DLR59

Sections   195(1)(C)   and   561A —Prosecution for forging document — When it is to be quashed — The bainapatra in question having been given in evidence in the suit, no Court can take cognizance of any offence covered by Section 463 of the Penal Code without complaint by the Court — There being no complaint from the Court concerned the proceeding against the accused persons in connection with the forgery thereof is liable to be quashed — But this will not debar the competent Court to make any complaint in accordance with law — Penal Code (XLV of 1860) Ss. 463, 467 and 471. Sona Mia and others Vs. The State and another 9 BLD (HCD) 209 Ref. 7BCR (AD) 152.

 

Section 195(1)(C) — The words documents produced or given in evidence' contemplate the original document alleged to be forged and not the certified copy of the same—If the document in question is not produced in the Court but a certified copy of the same is produced and marked as an exhibit, no complaint from the Court is necessary under Section 195(1) Cr.P.C for prosecution of the alleged offenders.

 

The absence of complaint under Section 195(1)(C) Cr.P.C. by the SCC Judge can not stand as a bar to the trial of the ac­cused person. Shambhu Nath Saha and other Vs. The State 11 BLD (HCD) 333.

 

Section 197 — Public Servant — Sanction to prosecute — Sub-Inspector of police and constables being removable by the Inspector General and the Superintendent of Police, they are not such public servants as are not removable save by or with the sanction of the Government — No sanction to prosecute them is necessary. Rokeya Begum Vs. Shafiqur Rahman and another 1 BLD (HCD) 82.Ref. AIR 1943 (FC) 18; AIR 1964 (SC) 269.

 

Sections 21 and 197(1) — Prosecution of Public Servant — The petitioner is a store keeper employed by the BADC and not by the Government. — Although he is a public servant the bar of taking cogni­zance of any offence against him does not apply. Shafiqur Rahman Vs. The State 6 BLD (HCD) 69.Ref. 44 Cr.L.J. (FC) 1943; AIR 1943 (FC) 18; AIR 1964 (SC) 269; AIR 1922 (Nag) 121; 22 DLR (WP) (Karachi) 48; 2 BCR(HCD) 4.

 

—     Sections 197 and 561A — Code of Criminal  Procedure  and Labour Court In the Industrial Relations Ordinance, 1969 there is no enactment relating to the manner of investigation, enquiring into or otherwise dealing with offences and as such the provisions of the Code of Crimi­nal Procedure including Section 197 of the Code are applicable to cases triable by the Labour Court — Where a public servant is not removable from his office save by or with the sanction of the Gov­ernment, the Labour Court in that case cannot take cognizance of the offence without prior sanction of the Government _In the absence of prior sanction under Section 197 of the Code of Criminal Procedure the proceeding under Section 55 of the Industrial Relations Ordinance, 1969 is incompetent and as such the pro­ceeding is liable to be quashed — The In­dustrial Relations Ordinance 1969 — Section 55. Moqbul Ahmed and another Vs. HamidulBari 7 BLD (HCD) 108Ref. 25 DLR 192.

Section 197(1) — Sanction for prose­cution of a public servant — When the bar of sanction can be claimed — Being merely a public servant a person cannot claim the bar of sanction unless he acted as a public servant in the discharge of his official duty while committing the alleged offence. Sudhir Das Gupta and others Vs. Bhupal Chandra Chowdhury 8 BLD (HCD) 246Ref. AIR 1955 (SC) 309; AIR 1948 (PC) 128 (133).

Section 197 — Question of obtaining prior  sanction  to  prosecute  a public servant — The intepretation that such sanction of the Government in terms of Section 197 Cr.P.C could be obtained even after the charge-sheet was submitted but before the trial started is applicable in respect of sanction required under the Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1958 — Criminal Law Amendment Act (XL of 1958) S 6(5) Matiur Rahman Vs. The State and others 9 BLD (HCD) 144 Riff. 32 DLR (AD) 100; 35 DLR 249.

Section 199 — Prosecution for adultery — There can be no cognizance of the of­fence except upon a complaint by the hus­band or by some other person who had the care of such a woman — Penal Code (XLV of 1860) S 497. Nurul Huq Bahadur Vs. B. B. Sakina and another 5 BLD (HCD) 269.

Section 199 — Adultery and enticing of a married woman — Bar of taking cogni­zance in such offences — The bar against taking cognizance of such offences other­wise than upon a complaint by the hus­band is total and complete — Penal Code (XLV of 1860) Ss. 497 and 498. The State Vs. Aynuzzaman 7 BLD (HCD) 100.

Section 200 — Naraji petition — In­formant — Petitioner submitted a naraji petition stating that the police being influ­enced by the accused persons might submit a final report — The Sub-divisional Magistrate called for the case diary without passing any order on the naraji petition, which was for all practical purposes a fresh compliant — When the Magistrate accepted the final report and discharged the accused there has been an implied dismissal of the naraji petition — The Magistrate acted illegally in not giving any consideration to the fresh complaint before accepting the final report.

—  He was not bound to accept the final report and he ought to have considered the facts of the case and the naraji petition — The Magistrate is therefore directed to hold further enquiry into the matter. Syed Abdul Hannan Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 156

Section 200 — Cognizance of an of­fence on complaint — A Magistrate is competent to take cognizance of an of­fence after examining the complainant alone — He commits no illegality in sum­moning the accused only after examining the complainant in the absence of any other witness. Gour Chandra Shamaddar Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 216.

Section 200 — Examination of the complaint before taking cognizance of the offence by the Magistrate — Examination of the complainant under Section 200 Cr.P.C. is not a mere form but an intelligent enquiry into the subject-matter of the complaint carried far enough to enable the Magistrate to exercise his judgment as to whether there is sufficient ground for proceeding against the accused—       Allegations are to be scrutinized thoroughly and if the complaint is found to be false or it does not disclose the offence alleged and it is merely intended to harass the accused, then the Magistrate should not issue process — It is not also proper to make indiscriminate use of the police agency for investigating the complaint Shahjahan Vs. Atiqur Rahman 7 BLD (HCD) 164.

Sections 200, 537 and 561A — Non-examination of the complainant — When not curable — It is incumbent upon the Magistrate to examine the complainant on oath before taking cognizance of the of­fence alleged — It is however well-settled that non-examination of the complainant is an irregularity which is curable and that such irregularity can not always be a ground for quashing the proceeding unless such non-examination caused prejudice to the accused persons and occasioned a failure of justice. Md Jahar AH Vs. Afrajul Islam Chowdhury and others 9 BLD (HCD) 509. Ref. 25 DLR 471, 37 DLR 223 and 227; 17 DLR (SC) 626; 31 CWN 271

Sections 202(2A), 205B and 205C —Case triable by the Court of Sessions — The Magistrate cannot hold an enquiry under Section 202*(2A) Cr.P.C. after issu­ance of process against the accused. Abdul Bari Vs. The State 1 BLD (HCD) 52.

Section 202 — Enquiry — Whether more than one enquiry is permissible — The Magistrate has jurisdiction to direct holding of more than one enqiry into a complaint if the previous eqnuiry does not appear to him to be satisfactory — There is no bar in law in holding more than one enquiry. Nazimuddin Ahmed and others Vs.   The State and another 2 BLD (HCD) 205 Ref. 11 DLR9; 33 DLR 8.

Sections 202 and 203 — Naraji peti­tion — When it should be rejected — When upon perusal of the complaint or the evidence brought on record under Section 202 Cr.P.C. the essential ingredi­ents of offences alleged are absent or there are patent absurdities in the complaint or in the evidence, then the Magistrate should dismiss the complaint but when a prima facie case is made out, he should issue process against the accused — Whether evidences are sufficient for conviction or not can be decided at the trial and not at the enquiry stage. Amir Ali Bhuiyan Vs. The State and others 3 BLD (HCD) 256.

Section 202 — Participation of the ac­cused in an enquiry proceeding — It is now well-settled that in an enquiry under Section 200 Cr.P.C. a Magistrate has no jurisdiction to ask the persons complained against to take part in any manner in such an enquiry. Md Showkat Rabbani Vs. Md Showkat Osmani 3 BLD (HCD) 301Ref. ILR 49 (Mad) 918; ILR 39 (Cal) 1041; ILR 14 (Cal)141; 21 Cr L.J 621.

 

Section 202(1) — Examination of the complainant on oath — No cognizance can be taken on the result of a judicial enquiry when the complainant was not examined on oath before the case was sent for judicial enquiry   Nurul Huq Bahadur Vs.   Bibi Sakina and another 5 BLD (HCD) 269 Ref. 28 DLR 389; 17 DLR (SC) 626.

Section 202 — Fresh complaint on the self-same occurrence not a bar — The naraji petition was kept on record and no order was passed even after receipt of the charge sheet — Since no action was taken on the naraji petition, it may be treated as dismissed — So there was no bar for the informant to file a fresh complaint on the self same occurrence Twahid Khan alias Twahid Kha and others Vs. The State and others 7 BLD (HCD) 11

Section 202 — Magistrates authority to order for more than enquiry — If it appears to the Magistrate from a naraji petition or otherwise that there was no proper and impartial enquiry he is always competent to direct holding more than one enquiry — General Clauses Act (X of 1897) S 13(2) Sanvar Kama! and others Vs. The State and others 7 BLD (HCD) 129.Ref. 36 DLR (AD) 58; 35 DLR 176; 34 DLR 424; 19 DLR (SC) 426; 13 DLR (Dhaka) 9

Sections 202 and 203 — Dismissal of a complaint — Its propriety — The main ground cited by the Magistrate for dis­missal of the case is that the police submitted charge-sheet in the case arising from the same occurrence — This is pal­pably wrong — The Magistrate must)nfine himself to the evidence on record oduced before him and if on such evi-;nce a prima facie case is made out he ill issue process Bangladesh Vs. Yakub irdar and others 8 BLD (AD) 180

Sections 202 and 203 — Dismissal of mplaint — Extent of Magistrates thority to dismiss — There is no sub-mce in the contention that simply be-use the allegations are triable by the >urt of Sessions the Magistrate can not believe the complaint and cannot dis­ss it — The Magistrate shall be compe-it to accept the final report and dis-irge the accused even when the offence nplained is triable exclusivey by the urt of Sessions. Md Naimuddin mdal Vs. The State and others 8 BLD (HCD) 373

Sections   202(1 )(2A)   and   436 —dng of cognizance — Extent of sions Judge's Jurisdiction  — Neither Sessions Judge nor the High Court ision can direct a Subordinate gistrate for taking cognizance — The sions Judge acted illegally in rfering with the Magistrate's order r re-assessing the evidence and taking nizance himself and directing the gistrate in effect to take cognizance — h an order is beyond the scope of law. ub AH Chowdhury and others Vs. nbur Rahman and others 8 BLD 276.Ref.   36 DLR (AD) 58; 35 DLR 140; )LR8; 25 DLR 152.

Sections 203 and 436 — Rejection of naraji petition and application for taking cognizance — Such rejection amounted to dismissal of the complaint — The only remedy against such dismissal was to ap­proach the Sessions Judge for a direction to make further enquiry — The Court of Sessions has no original jurisdiction to take cognizance of an offence as a Court of original jurisdiction Abdur Razzaque Vs. The State and another 6 BLD (HCD) 70.

Section 203 — Dismissal of a case takes place where no cognizance is taken and no process is used against the accused. Abdur Rashid Vs. The State 10 BLD (HCD) 407Ref. 36 DLR (AD) 58; 14 DLR (SC) 96.

 

Sections 221 and 227 — Power of the Magistrate to frame charges — The Magistrate has power to frame charge un­der any appropriate Section of law other than the section mentioned in the charge sheet and he is never bound by the Sec­tions mentioned therein — The Court has wide discretion to alter or add a charge — It is always competent to frame proper charges for offences disclosed in the allegations or in the enquiry report or in the evidence and in proper cases it can amend charge at any time before pro­nouncement of judgment. Kadam Ali and others Vs. The State 5 BLD (HCD) 155

 

Section 222 — Charge of misappropriation — Where dates of mis -appro- priation of various items extend over a period of more than one year, they cannot be lumped together in the same charge — In the instant case misa-appropriation took place over a period of six years but only one charge was framed — The framing of charge is contrary to law and as such the trial is illegal. S. K. Abdul Majid Vs. The State 7 BLD (HCD) 413

Sections 225, 237 and 238 — Whether conviction of the accused under Section 381 of the Penal Code without framing a charge thereunder is maintainable — In the instant case the accused was charged under Section 408 of the Penal Code but he was convicted under Section 381 of the Penal Code although no charge was framed thereunder — As the accused petitioner had the ocassion to hear the evidence revealing all the elements of the offence under Section 181 of the Penal Code and he had all the opportunity to cross-examine the prosecution witnesses on the facts and circumstances appearing against him, it cannot be said that he was prejudiced in his trial for want of framing a charge under Section 381 of the Penal Code — Penal Code (XLV of 1860) Ss. 381 and 408 Mahabubul Aldm Vs. The State 9 BLD (HCD) 419.Ref. 7 BLD 366; 21 DLR 384; 12 DLR 57; AIR 1952 (SC) 167; PLD 1962 (Karachi) 756 (DB); AIR 1960 (SC) 400; AIR 1960 (All) 380

Sections 227, 241, 241A, 242, 250B, 265C and 265D — Framing of additional charge — In this case the police after in­vestigation submitted charge-sheet against the accused petitioner and others on 7.9.91 under Sections 409/34/109 of the Penal Code read with Section 5(2) of the Prevention of Corruption Act (II of 1947) and the Special Judge on hearing the par­ties framed charges on 4.5.92 under Sec­tion 5(1 )(d) of the Prevention of Cor­ruption Act punishable under Section 5 (2 of the said Act. On the prayer of the prosecution the Special Judge after hear­ing both the parties under Section 241A Cr.P.C. on the same day i.e; 4.5.92 framed further charge against the accused petitioner under Section 5(1 )(e) of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 for having acquired property beyond the known sources of his income — Charges were read out to the petitioner who pleaded not guilty to the charges — The impugned order of framing further charge suffers from no illegality or impropriety as the accused was not taken by surprise and no prejudice caused to him — If the Court is prima facie satisfied on applica­tion of his judicial mind on the materials on record it is always competent to frame further charges. H. M. Ershad Vs. The State 12 BLD (HCD) 610.

 

Sections 236 and 237 — Accused charged under Sections 302/34 of the Penal Code but convicted under Section 201 of the Penal Code — Whether legal — Although the accused persons were charged under Sections 302/34 of the Penal Code yet their conviction under Section 201 of the Penal Code is valid in law, though no charge under Section 201 of the Penal Code was framed against them — Penal Code (XLV of 1860) Ss. 201 and 302 /34 Kalu and another Vs. The State 1 BLD (AD) 299 Ref. 26 Cr L.J. 1050.

 

Sections 236, 237 and 403 — Prohibi­tion against double jeopardy — The sec­ond trial which the appellant is now facing is with respect to different offence — Since they occurred during the same transaction or arose from the same facts, the appellant should have been charged for all such offences in the previous trial. Sultan Mahmudul Hossain Vs. The State 5 BLD (AD) 203.

Section 238 — Conviction of an ac­cused for abetment of an offence in the absence of any formal charge though charged with the commission of the substantive offence — Law does not provide that in the absence of any formal charge an accused can not be convicted for abetment though he was charged with the substantive offence — It is only as a rule of prudence that an alternative charge for abetment is framed in case of any doubt — In the absence of any such alternative charge no miscarriage of justice has occurred nor the accused prejudiced when his attention was drawn by the Court to the relevant evidence proved against him in his examination under Section 342 Cr.P.C Abdur Rouf and others Vs. The State 6 BLD (HCD) 402.

Section 241A — Discharge of accused without assigning reasons — The Magis­trate is not authorised by law to pass an arbitrary order of discharge of an accused person — He must assign reasons and come to a clear finding that there is no prima facie case against the accused warranting framing of charges and that the charges are groundless — The prosecution can not be throttled by the Court arbitrarily but it must be given due opportunity to prove its case. Haji Azizur Rahman and others Vs. Syeedul Haque Chowdhury and others 7 BLD (HCD) 335.

Section 241A — It empowers the Magistrate to discharge the accused with­out framing any charge if he considers the allegations to be groundless — The pro­vision in Section 241A is not altoghether new in the Code of Criminal Procedure. Previously Section 253(2) Cr.P.C. pro­vided for discharge of an accused without framing any charge if the Magistrate considered the allegations groundless — Section 241A Cr.P.C. has been brought in by amendment by Ordinance No XL of 1982 — By this and other Ordinances, procedure for trial of summons cases by the Magistrate was made applicable to trial of all cases by Magistrates abolishing the distinction between erstwhile sum­mons cases and warrant cases. Nannu Gazi Vs. Awlad Hossain and others 11 BLD (AD) 110

 

Sections   164,   243   and   265E —Whether defence suggestion can be taken as the basis for conviction — In the existing scheme of criminal trials an ac­cused can be convicted either on his pleading guilty to the charge or on his confession under Section 104 Cr P C or extra-judicial confession if strongly cor­roborated — Suggestions by the defence lawyer can not be construed as an admis­sion of guilt of the accused who is not re­quired to prove his innocence - The prosecution must prove the guilt of the accused failing which the accused will be acquitted Mil. Khaliluddin alias Khaliluddin Vs. The State 6 BU) (AD.

 

Section 243 — Admission of guilt by the accused — The reply of the accused while pleading guilty to the charge should be set down as nearly as possible in his own words and that having not been done the Court is not in a position to know what he actually admitted The accused may not understand the implication of the charge unless it is cleaiiv explained to him that the consequence of admission of guilt shall be fraught with punishment like hanging or transportation for life — Bas­ing the conviction solelv on admission is disapproved by all superior Courts be­cause murder is a mixed question of fact and law and unless the Court is satisfied that the accused knew exactly what was implied by his pleading guilty, the plea should not be accepted but the case should be proceeded with — It is not safe at all to base a conviction on the plea of guilt alone by the accused in a case of murder Abdul Lutif Vs. The State 7 BLD (HCD) 432.Ref. 1 1 DLR 5; AIR I92X (Cal) 775

 

Sections 247, 417(2), 439 and 439A- Acquittal Relief against - A revi­sional application against an order of ac­quittal is incompetent when an appeal lies against an order of acquittal in view of the amended provision of Section 417 of the Code of Criminal Procedure — Ses­sions Judge acted illegally in setting aside the order of acquittal m exercising his re-visional power under Section 43QA Cr P C Ayub Ali and others Vs. Suna Mia 4 HI A) (HCD) 16.

Section 247 — Acquittal of accused on the non-appearance of the complainant — Failure of the complainant to appear in Court on any date makes it imperative for the Magistrate to acquit the summoned accused irrespective of the fact whether the accused persons have appeared or not unless for some reasons the Magistrate thinks it proper to adjourn the hearing of the case to some other date Md. Islam Vs. The State and others 5 HID (HCD) 230.Ref. AIR 1948 (Mad) 45

 

Section 247 Acquittal for non-ap­pearance of the complainant — Whether the accused can be acquitted for non-ap­pearance of the complainant on a date fixed for execution report of warrant of arrest against some of the accused In such a case three conditions are to be sat­isfied before the accused are acquitted There should be service of summons, the date should be for appearance of the ac­cused and the complainant is to be found absent — Unless these conditions are present the Magistrate is not authorised to pass an order of acquittal (iolam Sasir Vs. Abdul Azh. and others 6 HI A) (HCD) 303.

 

1278

CODE OF CRIMINAL PROCEDURE (V OF 1898) (Part-3)

Citation: 8 BLD(HCD) 117, 9 BLD (HCD) 210., 3 BLD (HCD) 267.Ref. 14 DLR (SC) 96; 30 DLR 344, 4 BLD (HCD) 277.Ref. 14 DLR (SC) 96; 1978 BSCR 237, 4 BLD (HCD) 166.Ref. 30 DLR 344; 29 DLR (SC) 256. 14 DLR (SC) 96, 3 BLD (HCD) 33.Ref. 14 DLR (SC) 96; 15 DLR (SC) 55, 1

Subject: Criminal Law

Delivery Date: 2018-08-14

CODE OF CRIMINAL PROCEDURE (V OF 1898)

 

 

Section 247 — Non-appearance of the complainant on the date of hearing — Consequence of non-appearance — In such a case acquittal of the accused is mandatory unless the Magistrate adjourns the case for some cogent reasons Most. Azivan Khatun Vs. Abu Tayeh Md. Iqbal 8 BLD(HCD) 117.

 

Section 250 — False acquisition — Jurisdiction to pass order for compensa­tion — The Assistant Sessions Judge was of the opinion that the complainant insti­tuted a false or vexatious case and he was liable to pay compensation to the accused persons — But the relevant offence being not triable by Magistrate, the Assistant Sessions Judge acted beyond jurisdiction in making the impugned order in as much as the provision for such compensation under Section 250 Cr PC relates to an offence which is triable only by the Mag­istrate Karim dad Vs. Abul Hossain and others 9 BLD (HCD) 210.

 

Section 250B — Prosecution of the discharged accused for the second time — Whether always without jurisdiction — If it is in fact the revival of the same proc­eedings, it is without jurisdiction — If the second prosecution is based on a fresh complaint, it will not be without jurisdic­tion, because the Magistrate does not pre­side over the same proceedings — He is functus officio in so far as the first proc­eedings are concerned but not so in re­spect of a new proceeding Abdus Solum Master and another Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 267.Ref. 14 DLR (SC) 96; 30 DLR 344

 

Sections   250E(3)   and 350(1)Recalling a witness for further cross-examination — Discretion of the Magis­trate to recall a witness already cross-examined Further cross-examination can not be claimed as of right — The Court has every right to ask as to which witnesses should be further cross-examined and on what points - While furnishing points for further cross-examination the defence is not required to disclose the exact nature of questions to be put in cross-examination — It is only for enabling the succeeding Magistrate to form an opinion whether he should permit further recall or resummon witnesses earlier discharged after cross-examination — Points submitted by the defence should not be shown to the prosecution Surat Kumar Biswas Vs. Cecil Sudin Baroi, 3BLD (HCD) 187.

 

 

Sections 250B and 200 — Whether a discharged accused can be prosecuted on the same charge - - Entertaining a fresh complaint against the discharged accused if permissible — There is no longer any dispute regarding the fact that although the same case cannot be revived against the accused after thev are discharged, yet there is no bar in an appropriate case in entertaining a fresh complaint in respect of the same occurrence Abdul Kader Chowdhury and others Vs. The State and another 4 BLD (HCD) 277.Ref. 14 DLR (SC) 96; 1978 BSCR 237.

 

Section 250B — Discharge of accused and question of fresh enquiry Inproperprosecution by private persons for of­fences in connection with any public insti­tution should be guarded — The proper procedure in such cases is to gear the institutional mechinery for the purpose of bringing in the culprits to book — The Principal of a private College should not be prosecuted at the instance of a private individual without the concurrence of the Governing Body Mil Wasefudddin Vs. Habibur Rahman and others 6 BLD (AD) 7.

 

Sections 252 and 253 — Discharge of accused — Whether second prosecution permissible after dishcarge — It is per­missible if the order of discharge was not passed on merits after recording of evi­dence — There can be no valid objection if cognizance is taken on the basis of a fresh complaint — In a proper case an application for revival may amount to a fresh complaint. Prajapati Ran/an liarua Vs. Mong Raja Mongpru Salim and another 4 BLD (HCD) 166.Ref. 30 DLR 344; 29 DLR (SC) 256. 14 DLR (SC) 96,

 

Section 253 — Discharge of accused by the Magistrate after considering the evidence recorded — Whether the ac­cused can be tried on the same complaint — When the accused was discharged on the ground that no prima facie case was made out against him, the case can not be revived against him without a fresh com­plaint or a fresh police report in respect of the same offence Nurul Islam Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 33.Ref. 14 DLR (SC) 96; 15 DLR (SC) 55

 

Section 253 — Discharge of accused prosecution by private persons for of­fences in connection with any public insti­tution should be guarded — The proper procedure in such cases is to gear the institutional mechinery for the purpose of bringing in the culprits to book — The Principal of a private College should not be prosecuted at the instance of a private individual without the concurrence of the Governing Body Mil Wasefudddin Vs. Habibur Rahman and others 6 BLD (AD) 7.

 

Sections 252 and 253 — Discharge of accused — Whether second prosecution permissible after dishcarge — It is per­missible if the order of discharge was not passed on merits after recording of evi­dence — There can be no valid objection if cognizance is taken on the basis of a fresh complaint — In a proper case an application for revival may amount to a fresh complaint. Prajapati Ran/an liarua Vs. Mong Raja Mongpru Salim and another 4 BLD (HCD) 166.Ref. 30 DLR 344; 29 DLR (SC) 256. 14 DLR (SC) 96

 

Section 253 — Discharge of accused by the Magistrate after considering the evidence recorded — Whether the ac­cused can be tried on the same complaint — When the accused was discharged on the ground that no prima facie case was made out against him, the case can not be revived against him without a fresh com­plaint or a fresh police report in respect of the same offence Nurul Islam Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 33, Ref. 14 DLR (SC) 96; 15 DLR (SC) 55.

 

Section 253 — Discharge of accused The Magistrate is competent to pass an order of discharge after taking all the evidence produced by the prosecution and not all the evidence that might have been produced — Law does not require the Magistrate to make communication with the police to see whether the warrant of arrest issued against the prosecution witnesses was properly served on them. Mahmudul Huq and others Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 114.

 

Section 258 — Order of acquittal — A Magistrate cannot pass an order of acquit­tal on account of absence of the prosecu­tion witnesses for cross-examination while the accused himself was absent — In the absence of the accused no cross-examination can be made — Under such circumstances the order of acquittal passed by the Magistrate is illegal and it causes miscarriage of justice Moulana Ahmmadnllah Vs. Motinr Rahman and another 6 BLD (HCD) 423.Ref. 1959 PLD (Dhaka) 41 1

 

Sections   263, 264, 367 and 537 —Summary trial — Judgment in such a case In case of a conviction in a summary trial brief reasons need be given in the judgment but in case of an acquittal law does not require reasons to be given — For want of a well-reasoned judgment the order of acquittal is not bad in law but nevertheless it is desirable that the Mag- istrate passing an order of acquittal, a brief statement of reasons for his finding is given Mil. Matiur Rahman Vs. Asgar ali and others 4 BLD (AD) 227.Ref. 14 DLR 595; AIR 1942 (Sind) 52; AIR 1963 (Mysore) 77.

 

Section 265K — Hearing the accused on sentence — Hearing the accused on the question of sentence after finding him guilty is mandatory in nature — Non­compliance of the same prejudiced the condemned prisoners The State Vs. Ahu Jiakkar anil others 3 BLD (HCD) 240.Ref. 2 BCR (HCD) 332.

 

Section 265D — Discharge of accused under Section 265 D The Assistant Sessions Judge was not justified in dis­charging the accused merely on the ground that there was a civil dispute between the parties — Without making any reference to the evidence, which was yet to be adduced, the Judge could not legitimately hold that the identity of the person setting fire to the hut was not established Mohar Ali Vs. Raizuddin and others 4 BLD (HCD) 285.

 

Section 265G — Examination of all FIR. named and charge sheeted witnesses — The prosecution is not bound to examine all the witnesses mentioned in the FIR and the charge sheet — The prosecution is required to produce only the material and important witnesses Whether witnesses not named in the FIR. can be examined — Such witnesses can be produced at the trial in support of the prosecution case and there is no illegality in examining them. Hairat Ali and others Vs. The State 4 BLD (HCD) 257.Ref. 5 DLR <FC) 1. II DLR 120; 16 DLR (SO 94, 22 DLR 279.

 

Section 265G Duty of the prosecu­tion to call the witnesses - It is the duty of the prosecution to call all the witnesses to prove the connection of the accused persons with the transaction in question as they might be able to give important in­formation -- If such witnesses are not examined, without satisfactory explana­tion, the Court may properly draw an ad­verse presumption against the prosecution — But the prosectuion is not bound to examine a witness who is not expected to give truth to the Court although he was mentioned in the F I R and the charge-sheet — The prosecution is required to produce all material witnesses to unfold the narrative on which the prosecution is based — In the instant case non-produc­tion of witnesses named in the FIR. and the charge-sheet without cogent explana­tion has weakened the prosecution case and as such an adverse inference should reasonably be drawn against the prosecu­tion Abdul liahar alias Ahiil liahar and others Vs. The State 5  BLD (HCD) 84.

 

Section 265A - Acquittal for non-pro­duction of prosecution witnesses — After the charge is framed the Court of Ses-siosns can not pass an order of acquittal for non-appearance of the witnesses un- less the Court exhausts all available means for securing the attendance of the wit­nesses — After the charge is framed the Sessions Judge can acquit the accused persons only after complying with the provision of Section 265H of the Code of Criminal Procedure — In a Session trial there is no provision for acquitting the ac­cused simply for non-appearance of the prosecution witnesses — Onlv after ex­hausting all processes for securing the at­tendance of the prosecution witnesses the Sessions Judge can record an order of ac­quittal Md Taheruddin Vs. Abut Kashem and others 5 BLD (HCD) 144.

 

Section 265G — Non-examination of FIR named and chargesheeted witnesses _Effect of — The prosecution is not bound to examine each and every witness named in the FIR and the charge-sheet _In the absence of anv material to show that these witnesses were witnesses of the occurrence, no adverse presumption for their non-examination can be drawn against the prosecution Sitldique Ahmed alias Md Siddique and others Vs. The State 5 BLD (HCD) 202.

 

Sections 265A, 265C, 265D(2), 265E, 265G, 265H and 339C Release and acquittal of the accused - The expressions 'acquittal1 and 'release' have different conceptual meanings in Criminal Law — Ordinance No 37 of 1083 authorised the stopping of a proceeding and release of the accused — The Ses­sions Judge ought to have exhausted all processes including issuance of warrant of arrest to secure the attendance of the witnesses and as such it must be held that the Sessions Judge erred in law in passing the impugned order of acquittal — The proceeding will commence from where it was on 22.12.1983 Mrs. Amena Hoque Vs. Rajah Ah and others 6 BID (AD) 323.

 

Sections 265C and 265A When the Sessions Judge can discharge the accused — The Sessions Judge is empowered to discharge the accused persons when there is no prima facie case against them — Statement of witnesses recorded under Section of CrPC can be used for ascertaining whether there is a prima facie case against the accused persons -The material test is whether the fact alleged constitutes an offence and not whether the offence has been committed by the accused persons — This is a matter which is to be decided at the trial on evidence yet to be produced — Section 265 Cr P C authorises the Sessions Judge to discharge the accused persons if on the materials on record there is no sufficient ground to proceed against the accused persons while Section 265D authorises the Court to frame a charge if he presumes that the accused has committed the offence The Sessions Judge is to assign reasons borne out by materials on record for discharging the accused persons. Md. Kamiuddin Ahmed Vs. Aha liakar and others 6 BLD (HCD 96.

 

Section 265H — When accused can be acquitted by the Sessions Judge After the framing of the charge in a trial before the Court of Sessions there can be either an order of acquittal or conviction — On the failure of the prosecution to adduce any evidence the Additional Sessions Judge was competent to pass the order of acquittal after framing of the charge and giving sufficient opportunity to the prose­cution to prove its case and after exhaust­ing all processes for compelling the at­tendance of prosecution witnesses. Kumar AH Vs. Abdul Manaf and another 7 BLD (HCD) 13 Ref. 35 DLR 75; 5 BLD 144.

 

Section 265K — Hearing the accused on the question of sentence — Section 265 K of the Code of Criminal Procedure enjoins that the accused be heard on the question of sentence but when the sentence of imprisonment for life is imposed in a case under Sections 302/34 of the Penal Code, such a question does not arise as the minimum sentence con­templated by law was awarded — So far as the question of death on Mokbul Hussain is concerned, ends of justice demands that instead of prolonging the proceeding for giving him an opportunity of being heard on the question of sentence, the sentence of death should be commuted to one for imprisonment for life The State Vs. Mokbul Hussain 6 BLD (HCD) 34.Ref. 2 BCR (HCD) 832.

 

Section 288 — Evidence of witnesses before Committing Court — It is well-set­tled that the provision of Section 145 of the Evidence Act must be complied with before the evidence of any witness givi in the Committing Court can be treated! evidence at the trial under Section21 Cr.PC. Evidence Act (I of 1871 S 145 Amino liibi alias A menu liibl and another Vs. The State 4 BLD (HCD) 144 Ref. 15 DLR 517.

 

 

Section 288 — The evidence of a wil ness recorded in the Committing Court M The evidence of a witness in the Commil ting Court can be treated as evidence if the discretion of the Judge only when thi witness is produced at the trial and his atl tention is drawn to the statements made by him in the Committing Court, whidj are contrary to the statements made bl him in the Sessions Court - Mere production and tendering of the witness! the Sessions Court is not sufficient for the] prupose — His attention to the state! merits made in the Committing Courl which are in contradiction with his statements made in the Sessions Court! must be drawn as required by Section I4l of the Evidence Act. Hafizulldh and others Vs. The State 5 BLD (HCD) 185Ref. 15 DLR (Dhaka) 517.

 

Sections 324 and 367 — Judgment in] criminal appeal — Contents of judgment — Since the judgment contains no facts and it gives no reasons for affirming the judgment of the trial court after discussion) of evidence on record, the impugned judgment can not stand and the appeal must be re-heard Ibrahim Bepari and others Vs. Lutfor Rahman Bhuiyan and another 4 BLD (HCD) 297

 

 

Sections 337 — 339 — Prosecuting an approver — Conditions necessary for prosecution — The first condition for prosecuting an approver is a certificate by the Public Prosecutor that the approver has not complied with the conditions on which pardon was tendered to him — It must also be established that the approver forfeited his pardon — Pardon was on the condition that the approver will speak the truth and in this case the approver has given the truth by saying that he implicated the accused as he had litigations with them — There being no finding by the trial Court that the tender of pardon has been forfeited, which is the sine qua non for prosecuting an approver, the prosecution is incompetent Angur Vs. The State 9 BLD (HCD) 4S5.Ref. AIR 1955 (SC) 13, AIR 1925 (Lahore) 15; AIR 1920 (Lahore) 376, 1969 PLD (Lahore) 1071. AIR 1935 (Lahore) 799; AIR 1937 (Lahore) 551; AIR 1939 (All) 43; AIR 1929 (Nag) 189.

 

 

Sections 339 and 537 — Certificate as to tender of pardon — Question of curing the defect in such certificate — In the present case the Public Prosecutor who conducted the earlier Sessions case has not issued any certificate and there is no finding that the approval has broken the condition on which the pardon was ten­dered — Such defect is not curable under Section 537 Cr.RC. Angur Vs. The State 9 BLD (HCD) 485.

 

 

Section 339C — Pending case — What it means — Whether time-limit imposed by Section 339C Cr P C is applicable in a pending case — A case becomes pend­ing as soon as the First Information Report is lodged or cognizance is taken by the Magistrate - Time-limit under Section 339C Cr PC as amended has no application in a pending case - Transi­tory provision as laid down under Section 35 of Ordinance No XXIV of 1982 shall be applicable in a pending case - Code of Criminal Procedure (Second Amend­ment) Ordinance (XXIV of 10X2) S 351 time-limit for disposal of pending cases - - The time limit for disposal of a pending criminal case is merely directory in nature The legislature has not provided anv penal provision for non-compliance of the same. liardir Molla and others Vs. The State 4 BLD (HCD) 57. Ref. 32 DLR (AD) 100; 33 DLR (AD) 154.

 

 

Section 339C — Time limit for con­clusion of a trial of a criminal case whether mandatory From the language of Sub-section 4 of Section 330C it is clear that the provision is mandatory in nature — But this provision has no appli­cation in a pending case — This new law is not retrospective but prospective Dropping of a criminal proceeding and the release of the accused persons on an erroneous view of law do not operate either as discharge or acquittal —- In such a case the Court can restore the case. Moklesur Rahman anil others Vs. The State 4 BLD (HCD) 65.

 

 

Section 339C — Restoration of a criminal case — Whether the Sessions Judge is competent to restore a case in which the accused persons were released — The order stopping the criminal pro­ceeding and releasing the accused persons is neither acquittal nor discharge of the accused nor disposal of the case — The case remains pending — Court stopped proceedings and released accused persons for not holding of the trial within time Subsequently time was extended — Under such circumstances the Court is competent to restore the case for trial — Code of Criminal Procedure (Second Amendment) Ordinance (XXIV of 1982) S 35C Mil Jolni alias Shamsuzzoha and another Vs. The state 5 BLD (HCD) 7

 

 

Section 339B — Trial in absentia — Question of its legality — Since neither the Upzilla Magistrate nor the Ex-Officio Sessions Judge asked the accused to ap­pear before the trial Court on any particu­lar date nor directed the sureties to pro­duce him. he cannot be said to have ab­sconded or failed to appear before the Court Kala Meah (Member) Is. The State 5 HLD (HCD) 21.

 

 

Section 339C — Stopping further pro­ceedings and releasing accused — Charge sheet was submitted on Id.6 1983, the .case was received by the Sessions Judge on 3 1 1 1983, the case was transferred to the Additional Sessions Judge on 8.11 1983 for disposal but the trial having not been completed within the specified time, the accused filed an application on 15.11.1984 for stopping further proceed­ing and releasing them as 120 days expired from the date of receiving the case for trial but the prayer was rejected by the trial Court — As the trial was not concluded within the specified time or extended time further proceedings were stopped and accused released Madhu Mridha Vs. The State 6 BLD (HCD)139.

 

 

Section 339C Stopping further proc-eedings and releasing the accused — Thecase was received by the AdditionalDistrict Magistrate on 16.7.1987 for trialbut the trial could not be completed bvhim till 25 II 1984 when the record ofthe case was called for by the DistrictMagistrate Time   specified having expired long before 25. II 1984, further trial of the case stands stopped and the ac­cused released M(tslemuddin and others Vs. The State 6 BLD (HCD)1.

 

 

Section 339C - Power of the Court to hold trial after time limit expires — The appellants may have submitted to the jurisdiction of the Court for trial but that will not give the Court the power to con­tinue the trial if, in the mean time, the time-limit for disposal of the case has expired - - The language Of Section 339C is mandatory in nature and the case must be disposed of within the specified period of 150 working days — The trial having not been concluded within the specified time the accused must be released and the conviction and sentence of the accused must be set aside Sukanta Mondal Vs. The State 7 BLD (HCD) 30.Ref. 37 DLR 252

 

Section 339C — Stopping further pro­ceeding of criminal trial and releasing the accused — The time-limit for trial of criminal cases and how working days are to be counted — Time taken for leave and Upazilla Court inspection is to be ex­cluded — Working days mean the days on which a Judge works as such — So the days when the Sessions Judge was on leave and outside the station, these should not be regarded as working days and those days should be excluded while com­puting the time for disposal of the Ses­sions case. Akbar AH and others Vs. The State 7 BLD (HCD) 135

 

Section 339C — Stopping the proceed­ing and releasing the accused — Whether a criminal proceeding is to be stopped and accused released in a case under Sections 409/109 of the Penal Code read with Sec­tion 5(2) of Act 11 of 1947 before the Special Judge on the expiry of the time-limit for trial — Whether Section 339C of the Code of Criminal procedure is applicable in such a case — Section 6 of the Criminal Law Amendment Act envisages that the provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure shall apply in so far as they are not inconsistent with this Act in respect of the procedure of the trial of a Special Case and there is no inconsistency of the provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure with those of the Criminal Law Amendment Act — More than 150 working days have elapsed before the Divisional Special Judge and as such the proceeding is liable to be stopped and the accused are to be released —Criminal Law Amendment Act (XL of 1958) S 6 Ahdur Rahnmn Bhuiyan and another Vs. The State 7 BLD (HCD) 169.

 

Section 339C — Stopping further pro­ceeding of a trial by Magistrate and re­leasing the accused charged with an of­fence under the Muslim Family Laws Or­dinance — Whehter Section 339C Cr.P.C. applies to such a case — Section 339C of the said Code provides that a Magistrate shall conclude the trial of a case within 120 days from the date on which the case was received by him for trial — Though the Muslim Family Laws Ordinance prescribes no time limit for conclusion of a trial but since a criminal case under the Muslim Family Laws Ordinance is triable by a Magistrate, the provision of Section 339C Cr.P C. is attracted in such a case and the Magistrate must conclude the trial within 120 days from the date on which he received the case for trial. Md Suruj Miah Vs. Rashida Akhter and another 7 BLD (HCD) 192.

 

Section 339C — Stopping further pro­ceedings of a case and release of the ac­cused — Whether the accused has a vested right to be released and whether fresh period for conclusion of the trial will be counted after transfer of a case — Section 339C Cr.P.C. provides for computation of the time limit for conclu­sion of the trial to run from the date when the Court receives a case for trial by him — The computation of time in the case of the Sessions Judge will run when he   actually receives a case for trial by himself and in other cases the time will run when the Court concerned receives a case for trial on transfer from the Sessions Judge — Section 339C is no doubt a provision meant for speedy disposal of criminal cases and fixes a time limit for the individual trying Judge to conclude the trial within 150 working days, now 240 days after amendment by Ordinance No XXIII of 1986, from the day on which the case is received by him for trial — The provision does not confer any vested right on the accused but it only provides a contingency that if the trying judge fails to conclude the trial within the period, the proceeding shall stand stopped and the accused will be released. Shahabuddin and others Vs. The State 7BLD (HCD)250.

 

 

Section 339C — Extension of time limit for disposal of a pending case — Ordinance No XXXVII of 1983 extended the period for conclusion of the trial of the cases pending on the date of its commencement on 8.8.1983 — Charge-sheet in the instant case was submitted on 16 June, 1983 and the case record was in due course forwarded to the Sessions Judge for trial — As such the trial was pending within the meaning of the Ordinance — Construction put to the Ordinance by the Judges of the High Court Division is not correct. The State Vs. Madhu Mridha 8 BLD (AD) 123

 

Sections 339B, 339C(2)(4)(6) and 526B — Sessions Judge's power to transfer cases — He has power to transfer a case from one criminalCourt to another under his judgeship whenever he thinks it expedient for the ends of justice.

 

Question of limitation on transfer of a case — Limitation shall run afresh from the date on which the case is received by the transferee trial Court Ahdus Sukkur and others Vs. The State 8 BLD (HCD) 340.

 

Section 339C — "Working days"— What the words mean — The law as it has been framed has simply mentioned the words" "working days" without qualifying them as the working days of a particular Magistrate and as such it is to be held that 'Working days" mean the working days of the Court — If a particular Magistrate refrains from working on a particular working day or working days either be­cause of his personal reasons or being en­gaged otherwise that cannot mean that such days are not working days of the Court — So even if it is assumed that the Magistrate engaged himself for some days by working with the Martial Law Court such days cannot be discounted from working days — There is no scope to deduct such days from the 89 working days of the Court — In such a position the Magistrate had no other alternative than to stop further proceedings in respect of the trial. Nayon alias Fazlul Huq Vs. The State 8 BLD (HCD) 450

 

Section 339C — "Working days" — Meaning of — The expression "working days" as appearing in sub-section 6 of Section 339C would mean the days on which a particular Judge or a Magistrate actually worked as such in his court where the case is pending. Ekramul Hoq alias Tuku and others Vs.   The State 8 BLD (HCD) 464 Ref. 7 BLD 135; 38 DLR415.

 

Section 339C — Time-limit for dis­posal of cases — Mandatory or directory __Whenever a statute prescribes that a particular act is to be done within a cer­tain time or in a certain manner and lays down that a failure to comply with this re­quirement shall lead to a specific conse­quence, such a prescription must be re­garded as mandatory — If a law, even though procedural in character, insists that an act must be done within a particular time the Courts are bound to enforce the law as it stands.

 

Time-limit for disposal of cases — Law does not provide for deducting the time consumed by adjournment made at the instance of either party. Habibur Rahman and another Vs. The State 9 BLD (HCD) 131.Ref. 37 DLR252.

 

Section 339C(1)(3) and (6) — Limita­tion for conclusion of trial — The statutory provision makes it unambigu­ously clear that the limitation of working days is in respect of the individual Mag­istrate who has received the case for trial The provision of law does not permit the addition of the number of working days of all the Magistrates who may have received the case previously for trial Mokbul Guora and others Vs. The State 9 BLD (HCD) 405.

 

Sections 339B, 537, 87 and 88 — In Section 87 the word 'may' has been used while in Section 339B the word 'shall' has been used — The expresxsion "in at least one Bengali Daily Newspaper" occurring in Section 339B Cr.P.C. indicates that the provision contained therein is mandatory and not directory — Section 537 Cr.P C does not cover a case falling under Sec­tion 339B of the said Code Moktar Ahmed Vs. Haji Farid Alam and another 10 BLD (HCD)2 78.Ref. 40 DLR (HCD) 150.

 

 

Section 339C Cr.P.C. and Section 26 of the Special Powers Act — Provisions of Section 339C of the Code of Criminal Procedure are not applicable to the trial of cases by the Special Tribunal cons­tituted under Section 26 of the Special Powers Act, 1974 Kamruzzaman Vs. The State 10 BLD (HCD) 328.

 

Section 339C and 1(2) of Cr.P.C. —Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) — Section 29— Applicability of the Code of Crimianl Procedure to the proceedings under the Special Powers Act — Held, Section 339C of the Code of Criminal Procedure is applicable to the proceedings as to trial of the appellant under the Special Powers Act, 1974. Kamruzzamna Vs. The State 10 BLD (AD) 190.

 

 

(The Case of Kamruzzamna Vs. The State, reported in 10 BLD (HCD) 328 overruled by necessary implication by the decision reported in 10 BLD (AD) 190)

 

 

Sections 339C, 526B and 561A —Scheme of Sections 339C and 526B Whether scheme of Section 526B em­powering the Sessions Judge to withdraw or transfer any particular case from one criminal Court to another criminal Court in his Sessions Division on his own mo­tion by way of transfer and retransfer and taking fresh cognizance of the case amounts to make nugatory the provision of Section 339C by giving a dead case a new lease of life — Whether taking recourse to such transfer and retransfer renders further proceedings in respect of the trial bad in law — The High Court Division held that it was not so — It has also been held that the discretion exercised by the Sessions Judge on grounds of expediency under Section 526B Cr.P.C. is not a subject-matter of an appeal or revision as the discretion so exercised by the Sessions Judge is neither perverse nor totally unwarranted.

 

Section 339C has not repealed directly or even impliedly Section 526B of the Code of Criminal Procedure and they are not in conflict and thus run pari passu Kadareswar Chakraborty and others Vs. The State 10 BLD (HCD) 368.

 

Section 339B — Trial in absentia — The accused escaped from the police custody while he was being brought to the Court — As his presences would not be secured he was tried in absentia under Section 339B(2) of the Code of Criminal Procedure, being represented by a lawyer engaged by the State. The State Vs. Kalu Bepari 10 BLD (HCD) 373.

 

Section 339C (4) and 339D — Trial not concluded within the specified time and further proceeding in respect of the trial stands stopped and the accused re­leased - Under Section 339D Cr.P.C. such a proceeding can be revived if an application for such revival is made by the Government within 90 days from the date of order to the Court where such proceedings were pending on the date they were stopped of The limitation of 90 days regarding the filing of an application by the Government in the Court for revival of such a case runs from the date on which the Court concerned actually stopped the proceed­ing in respect of the trial of the case and not from the date on which the proceedings of the trial of the case should have been stopped or should be deemed to have been stopped. A. H. M. Kamaluddin and another Vs. The State 10 BLD (HCD) 443.

 

Sections 339C and 339D Cr.P.C. and Section 6 of the Criminal Law (Amendment) Act, 1958 — It is well-settled that the provisions of Sections 339C and 339D Cr.P C are applicable to the proceedings before the Court of the Special Judge and this legal position has been accepted by the Legislature by enact­ing Act No XIII of 1987. A. H. M. Kamaluddin Vs. The State 10 BLD (HCD) 443.

 

Sections 339C and 339D — Section 339D of the Code of Criminal Procedure will not be precluded from operation in cases under the Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1958 merely because 339D of the Code of Criminal Procedure mentions the cases stopped under sub-section 4 of Section 339C of the Code which is applicable in respect of cases under the Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1958. in view of Section 6( 1) of the said Act A. B. M. Shamsul Alam and another Vs. The State 12 BLD (HCD) 446 Ref. 42DLR(AD)250.

 

Section 342 — Examination of the ac­cused under the Section is mandatory and attention of the accused is required to be drawn to the material evidence TazJnmddin Sarker Vs. The State 1 BLD (HCD) 302.
