Section 342 — Purpose of the Section — The purpose of Section 342 Cr.P.C. is to enable the accused to give his explana­tion to the incriminating material evidence on record — The statement of the ac­cused may rebut or explain the prosecution evidence and if the defence case on the basis of this statement and other materials on record appear to be reasonable and probable, there can not be any conviction Mofizuddin Vs. The State 1BLD (HCD) 461.

 

 

Section 342 — Circumstances appear­ing in evidence against the accused must be brought to his notice so that he gets a chance  to  explain  the circumstances Golam    Kader Sardar Vs.  The State 2BLD (HCD) 107.

 

 

Section 342 — The right conferred un­der Section 342 Cr.P C. is a basic right of the accused and it is not a mere formality— The failure of the Court to ascertain from the accused whether he will examine any witness or if he has any defense make renders the conviction illegal — Non-compliance of the requirement of the Cr.P.C. Harun Shaikh alias Haronor Rashid and another   Vs.   The State 8 BLD (HCD) 425 Ref. 2BCR (HCD) 8.

 

 

Section 342 — Examination of the ac­cused — An incriminating circumstance in respect of which an accused was not ex­amined can not be used against him. State and others Vs. Badsha Mollah

9  BLD (HCD) 257.Ref. AIR 1953 (SC) 468; AIR 1976 (SC) 557.

 

 

Section 342 — Statement of the ac­cused — Legal value of — It is meant for giving the accused an opportunity to explain the circumstances appearing against him at the trial and it is entirely for the benefit of the accused and accused only — This statement cannot be used by the Court against him nor the prosecution is permitted to use it to fill up any gap in the prosecution evidence. Shah Alam and others Vs. The State 10 BLD (AD) 25.Ref. 1923 ILR (Lahore) 50; 1903 ILR (Madras) 238.

 

 

Sections 342 and 537 — The view that omission to examine the accused un­der Section 342 of the Code of Criminal Procedure is curable under Section 537 Cr.P.C is not sustainable in law — After the prosecution closes its evidence the Court shall examine the accused and ask them whether they will adduce any evi­dence in defence and omission to do so vitiates the conviction, if such omission prejudiced the accused in their defence. A Gafur alias Haji Abdul Gafur and others Vs. Jogesh Chandra Roy and another 11 BLD (AD) 108.

 

 

Section 344 — Adjournment cost in criminal proceeding — Adjournment cost cannot be awarded against the absentee accused though in exceptional circum­stances the Criminal Court can award ad­journment cost. Md. Hahihur Rahman Vs. The State and another 1 BLD (HCD) 443.Ref. 19 Cr.L.J 326, 4 Cr.L.J 78; 23 Cr.L.J. 243; 48 CWN 684; 49 Cr.L.J. 307; AIR 1962 (Cal) 98; AIR 1932 (Bomb) 470.

 

 

 

Section 344 — When stay of criminal proceeding should be granted — When the stay of a criminal proceeding means a stay for an uncertain and indefinite period and the criminal proceeding has already been delayed for a long period and parties to the criminal case and the civil suit are not the same and the issues involved in the two cases are not materially the same, the criminal case should not be stayed. Rafique Ahmed Vs. Badiul Alam 4 BLD (HCD) 319.Ref. AIR 1942 (Cal) 219; 13 DLR 215.

 

 

 

Section 344 — When under the facts and circumstances of the case it does not appear at all reasonable to stay indefinitely a criminal proceeding pending disposal of a civil suit, the Magistrate can not grant such a stay indefinitely as 'sine die' adjournment of a criminal case is against the policy of law. Shahar Banoo Ziwar Sultana Beyad Vs. Wahida Khan and others 6 BLD (HCD) 315.Ref. 4 BLD 319; 20 DLR 674; 9 DLR (WP) 7; 22 DLR 502; 25 DLR 33 1.

 

 

 

Section 344 — Stay of criminal pro­ceeding during the pendency of the civil suit, which was instituted before the filing of the F.I.R. — Questioned documents in original which the informant claims to be forged, are yet to be produced and exam­ined by the Civil Court. Under such cir­cumstances the criminal proceeding should be stayed till the disposal of the civil suit. Zakir Hossain and other Vs. The State and another 10 BLD (AD) 287.

 

 

Section 345(5) — Compounding of offence — Our criminal administration of justice encourages compromise of certain disputes — Offences under Section 379 of the Penal Code are compoundable by the owner of the property stolen — Since the matter was pending by way of special leave, The Appellate Division allowed the composition and acquitted the accused. Abdus Sattar and others Vs. The State and another 6 BLD (AD) 105.Ref. AIR 1974 (SC) 1744; 4 BCR (AD) 29.

 

 

Sections 360 and 537 — Reading over and explaining evidence recorded before obtaining signature of the witness in the deposition sheet — When the witnesses put his signature in the deposition sheet it can reasonably be presumed that the wit­nesses being conversant with the contents and meaning of evidence put their signa­tures on the deposition sheet — So it canbe inferred that the deposition was read over to the witnesses and they put their signatures on the deposition sheets after being satisfied about the correctness of the recording of evidence — Omission to read over the evidence to the witnesses constitutes an irregularity which is cur­able under section 537 Cr.P.C. Majibar Rahman and others Vs. The State 7 BLD (HCD) 380 Ref. 1957 PLD (Dhaka) 327.

 

 

 

Section 367 — Whether a criminal ap­peal can be disposed of exparte in the ab­sence of the Advocate by the party preferring the appeal — It is well-settled that for the disposal of a criminal appeal the presence of the Advocate of the appellant is not essential but the Appellate Court has to write the judgment in accordance with the provision of Section 367(1) of the Code of criminal Procedure. Abul Bashar and others Vs. The State 7 BLD (HCD) 345.Ref. 22 DLR (SC) 263.

 

 

 

Sections 367 and 424 — Judgment in criminal appeal — Judgment of the Ap­pellate Court must show the application of the mind of the judge independently on material facts — The Appellate Court should not base its conclusion on the dis­cussion found in the judgment of the trial Court — The Appellate Court is to for­mulate the points for determination, con­sider the evidence with reference to the points at issue and give decision thereon with reasons. Abdul Bashar and others Vs. The State 7 BLD (HCD) 435.Ref. 25 DLR (Dhaka) 330; 3 BCR (HCD) 239.

 

 

Sections 367 and 424 — Contents of judgment in a criminal appeal — Section 367 Cr.P.C. requires that a judgment shall contain the points for determination . the decision thereon with reasons in support of the decision — It is incumbent on the Court to consider not the case of one particular party alone but the Court should take into consideration the cases of both the contending parties side by side in all their bearings — Court's conclusion must emanate from the consideration of the evidence on record — The law requires that there must be a substantial compliance of the provision of Section— 367 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. Ahdus Sattar and others Vs. The State and another 7 BLD (HCD) 395.

 

 

Sections 367 and 537 — Contents of judgment — Provisions for writing out the judgment were not strictly followed by the Magistrate but the main points in the case under Sections 379 and 147 of the Penal Code are found to have been duly considered by him — The High Court Division observed that though the judgment of the Magistrate was not in proper form yet some reasons have been given for acquitting the accused persons — No miscarriage of justice has been caused by non-compliance with the provisions provided for writing a judg­ment — Such a defect is curable under Section 537 Cr.P.C Md. Nurul Huda Vs. Bhashanu Sardar and others 8 BLD (AD) 193.

 

 

 

Section 367 — Contents of a judgment — There is a duty cast upon the Court to decide the issue framed for its decision and to decide the same with reasoning. Abul Bashar Vs. Nurun Nabi and others 8 BLD (HCD) 189.Ref. 3 BCR (HCD) 239

 

Section 369 — Dismissal for default in a criminal revision — The order of dis­missal not touching in the merit of the case is neither a judgment of conviction nor of acquittal — Under such circums­tances the ends of justice demands that the petitioner should be afforded an opportunity of being heard in the matter. Muzahar Sikder Vs. Fariduddin Ahmed and others 3 BLD (HCD) 96.Ref. AIR 1949 (FC) 1; 22 DLR (SC) 258.

 

 

 

Sections 369 and 561A — It is well-settled that Section 369 Cr.P C operates in full force and applies to all judgments of all the criminal courts — The order passed by he High Court Division decid­ing a Criminal Revision on merit can not be reviewed by resorting to Section 561A of the Code of Criminal Procedure. JohedAli Vs. The State 4 BLD (AD) 168.

 

 

 

Sections 369 and 561A — No Court after signing its judgment can alter or re­view the same except correcting clerical mistakes — An order passed earlier by a Court of competent jurisdiction (Addi tional Sessions Judge) can not be interfered with by the succeeding judge in any way whatsoever as it tantamount to reviewing and altering the judgment — Section 369 Cr.P.C. puts a seal of finality to the judgment already delivered and signed Dr. Mil. Abdul Baten Vs. The State 10 BLD (HCD) 411.

 

 

 

Section 386 — Army Act (XXXIX of 1952) S 142 — Sentence of fine imposed by Summary Military Court — Whether such a fine is a decree and whether it can be executed through the Civil Court — Having regard to the provision of the Army Act. 1952 which has been made applicable in the case of Summary Military Courts and the Code of Criminal Procedure, there was nothing wrong in executing the decree passed by the Summary Military Court in respect of the sentence of fine in accordance with the procedure laid down under the Code of Criminal Procedure Sasltanka Sekhur Rose Vs. Bangladesh 1 BLD (HCD) 481.

 

 

 

Section 401 — Power to suspend or remit sentence is within the absolute dis­cretion of the Government or the Presi­dent and the Court cannot give any direc­tion in this regard Kh. Ehteshamuddin Ahmed alias Iqhai Vs. Bangladesh and others 1 BLD (AD) 107.

 

 

 

Sections 403 and 494 — Withdrawal of criminal case Withdrawal of a criminal case after examination of the ac­cused under section 242 Cr.P.C. amounts to acquittal —   Fresh trial on the self­same charge is barred under - Section 403 of the  Code   of Criminal Procedure Hahibur Rahman Vs.  The State 1 BLD (AD) 415.

 

 

Section 403 — After an illegal dismissal of an earlier case, the lodging of a fresh FIR. in respect of the same offence and starting a fresh case on the basis of such an FIR is not barred — General Clauses Act (V of 1897) S 26 Al-haj Mamtaj Meah Vs. The State 8 BLD (HCD) 64.Ref. 14 DLR (SO 96; 36 DLR (AD) 58.

 

 

 

Section 407 — Summary disposal of appeal An appeal under Section 407 Cr P C gives a substantive right to the appellant to be heard on merit — The spirit of Second Amendment (Ordinance No XXV of 1982) is to dispose of cases expeditiously but this does not mean dis­posal of cases summarily without assign­ing anv reason — The Additional District Magistrate failed to apply his judicial mind to the materials on record in summarily dismissing the appeal — Expeditious disposal at the cost of justice is not contemplated in law Jamshed and others Vs. Ahdns Samad and others 3 BLD (HCD) 68.

 

 

 

Section 408 Forum of appeal Appeal against an order of conviction in­volving sentence of imprisonment not ex­ceeding five years by an Assistant Ses­sions Judge — "Sentence of imprisonment for a term exceeding five years' in proviso (b) of Section 408 CrP.C.  does not include imprisonment in default of pay­ment of fine, the operation of which is contingent only on non-payment of fine — The present appeal before the High Court Division against the sentence of imprisonment for five years and to pay fine, in default to suffer RI for a further period of three months, is therefore incompetent Shahizuddin and another Vs. The State 4 BLD (HCD) 5Ref. AIR 1918 (Lahore) 348; 19 Cr L J 742; ILR 16 (Cal) 799.

 

 

 

Section 410 —Whether jurisdiction of the High Court Division to entertain an appeal under Section 36 of the Industrial Relations Ordinance. 1969 has been ousted by Martial Law Order No. 19 of 1982 — An appeal lies to the High Court Division against conviction and sentence passed by the Labour Court as it is deemed to be a Court of Sessions for the purpose of appeal from all sentences — When offences are tried by the Labour Court it acts as a First Class Magistrate but when punishment is given and sentence is recorded by it. then for the purpose of appeal, it shall be deemed to be a Court of Sessions — MLO 19 of 1982 dealt with the decision and not with the award or sentence — So jurisdiction of the High Court Division to entertain appeal against the sentence passed by the Labour Court has not been ousted — Industrial Relations Ordinance (XXIII of 1969) S 36 — Martial Law order No. 19 (MLO 19 of 1982) Maqhul Hossain and others Vs. Bangladesh Milk Producer's Co-Operative  Union  Limited 5 BLD.

 

 

 

Sections 410 and 426 — The appel­lants surrendered before the Sessions Judge upon conviction and obtained an interim bail for filing a revision case before the High Court Division — It is true that the order of bail granted by the Sessions Judge was illegal but the fact remains that they submitted themselves to the sentence passed and obtained bail albeit wrongly — In the facts of the case it will be less than charitable to call them "fugitives from law" — Since the appellants were not covered by a legal order of bail, the High Court Division ought to have directed them to surrender within a certain time before taking up the petition of appeal for hearing — Since the appeal has not been heard on merit an order of remand is called for Saidur Rahman alias Chan Miah and others Vs. The State X BLD (AD) 217.

 

 

Sections — 417, 439 and 439A Whether revision lies against a judgment which is appealable — In view of the provision of sub-section (5) of Section 439 Cr P (' even the High Court Division has no power to entertain any proceeding by way of revision at the instance of a party who could have appealed — The Sessions Judge has no jurisdiction to en­tertain any proceeding by way of revision under Section 43 9A of the Code of Crimi­nal Procedure against an appealable judgment AH Hossain and othen Vs. The State and another 4 BLI. (HCD) 221 Ref. 35 DLR (AD) 127.

 

Section 417 — Condonation of delay in filing appeal by the complainant — Limi­tation for filing an appeal by the com­plainant against acquittal is a special limitation prescribed by Section 417(3) of the Cod of Criminal Procedure and it is different from the limitation prescribed bv Article 157 of the Limitation Act. Provi­sion of Section 5 of the Limitation Act has not been made applicable to an appeal by the complainant in a complaint case under Section 417 (2) Cr.P.C and as such the Court has no jurisdiction to condone the delay in filing the appeal — Limitation Act (IX of 1908) Ss. 5 and 29(2). Authorised officer, CD A Vs. The State and others 6 BLD (HCD) 91.

 

 

Section 417(2)(3) — Condonation of delay — Since the provisions of Section 417(2)(3) are special law. Section 5 of the Limitation Act is not available to the complainant after the expiry of the prescribed period of 60 days — Limitation Act (IX of 1908) S 5 and 29(2) Aftahuddin Vs. Sajjad AH and others 6 BLD (HCD) 235.

 

 

 

Sections 417 and 561A — Whether delay can be condoned when the order of acquttal is patently perverse — Section 417 being a provision of the Code of Criminal Procedure can not control or limit the application of 561A of the Code — In an appropriate case the High Court Division for securing the ends of justice may treat a time-barred petition of appeal of a private complainant as an application for the purpose of exercising its inherent jurisdiction under Section 561A of the Code of Criminal Procedure Aftahuddin Vs. Sajjad AH and others 6 BLD (HCD) 235.

 

 

 

Sections 417 and 439 — Whether an incompetent appeal can be converted into a revision to set aside an illegal order of acquittal —- An appeal bv a private com­plainant against an order of acquittal of the accused is not maintainable in rela­tions to a case which was started before the Law Reforms Ordinance. 1978 came into force when there was no provision for appeal by a private complainant — The impugned order of acquittal was found to be patently illegal and it caused a miscarriage of justice — Under the circumstances the appeal was converted into a revision and the impugned order of acquittal was set aside and the Magistrate was directed to proceed with the trial of the accused in accordance with law Maolana Ahmmadullah Vs. Motiur Rahman and another 6 BLD (HCD) 423.

 

 

 

Section 417(2) - Appeal against ac­quittal — Whether an appeal against ac­quttal can be filed by a person other than the complainant — It is only the com­plainant who is legally competent to prefer an appeal against an order of acquittal passed in a case instituted upon complaint and none else Asuprava Bhattacharjee and another Vs. Makhan Lai Bhattacharjee 8 BLD (HCD) 198.

 

 

 

Sections 417 and 423(l)(a)(b)(20) Order of acquittal — Whether such order can be reversed in an appeal from co­nviction — There was no appeal by the Government against acquittal — The order of acquittal was converted into one of conviction by the High Court Division and then by recourse to its revisional powers under Section 439 Cr.P.C the sentence was enhanced — In the absence of an appeal by the Government against acquittal, the same can not be interfered with in the manner aforesaid Mafizuddin alias Mahi Vs. The State 9 BLD(AD) 20 Ref. 55 IA 390; 6 DLR (FC) 80, AIR 1966 (SC) 1742; AIR 1962 (SC) 240; ILR 1944 (All) 403; ILR 1942 (Lahore) 129.

 

 

Sections 417, 418 and 423 — Superior Court's power to review an order of ac­quittal — The High Court Division has full power to review at large the evidence upon which the order of acquittal was founded and to reach the conclusion that upon the evidence on record the order of acquittal should be reversed — No limi­tation should be placed upon that power unless it be found expressly stated in the Code — The governing consideration must always be to see whether in relation to the proved facts and circumstances justice has been done in accordance with law. Shah Alam and others Vs. The State 10 BLD (AD) 25.Ref. AIR 1966 (SC) 1775; 16 DLR (SC) 605.

 

 

 

Section 417(l)(a) — Appeal against an order of acquittal — The State is authorized to file an appeal against an order of acquittal but in the instant case no such appeal was preferred by the State — One of the charge-sheeted witnesses, who filed an appeal before the High Court Division, also filed a petition for leave to appeal before the Appellate Division — The Leave Petition was held to be not main­tainable Fqiar Ali alias Manik Chand Vs. Fazar Ali and others 11 BLD (AD) 60.

 

 

 

Section 423 — Withdrawal of Criminal Appeal - - The appellant has the right to withdraw the appeal tiled by him. Yunus Fakir Vs. The State I liLD (HCD) 39S.Ref. PLD 1959 (SC) 11.

 

 

 

Section 423(1 )(b) Power of the Appellate Court in criminal appeal — Meaning of the word "finding" — It is the result of a judicial examination into matters of fact — The expression "may alter the finding" really empowers the Appellate Court to consider the entire evidence both as regards fact and law and to substitute its own finding Nahir Md. alias Nahiruddin Vs. The State 2 BLD (HCD) 153.Ref. 6 DLR (FC) 65.

 

 

 

Section 423 — Dismissal of a criminal appeal without writing a full-fledged judgment — Whether legal In the judgment of the Appellate Court there is no discussion about the nature of the offence or the part played by the individual accused persons — In the judgment of the appellate Court there should have been some discussion of the evidence on record before affirming the order of conviction — The impugned judgment cannot be sustained and it is set aside Serajuddoula alias Md Serajuddoula and others Vs. The State 6 BLD (AD) 213.

 

 

Section 423 — Retrial when not per­missible — When the Appellate Court finds that there is no legal evidence on re­cord to sustain the order of conviction a retrial should not be directed indulgently to an indolent prosecution to have another opportunity for bringing better evidence against the accused Amino liihi alias Amena liihi and another Vs. The State 6 BLD (BCD) 144.Ref. 15 DLR 517.

 

 

Section 423 Disposal of criminal appeal only on the question of sentence _In a criminal appeal a duty is cast upon the Appellate Court to dispose of the ap­peal on merit and as such disposal of the appeal on the ground of sentence only without giving its findings as to the con­viction is not permissible in law, not­withstanding the concession made by the counsel Md Jashimuddin Vs. The State 6 BLD (AD) 198.Ref. AIR 1935 (PC) 89; AIR 1960 (SC) 748; PLD 1967 (SC) 545.

 

 

Section 423 — Alteration of simple imprisonment into rigorous imprisonment__In the absence of any opportunity given to the accused petitioners to show cause, the order of the Sessions Judge in so far as it relates to the alteration of the sentence of simple imprisonment to one of rigorous imprisonment cannot be sus­tained as it amounts to enhancement of sentence Kalu Mirza and others Vs. The State and others 6 BLD (HCD) 16.

 

 

Section 423 :When retrial of a criminal case should not be ordered al­though trial by the Magistrate is found to be without jurisdiction — In the instant case the accused persons have gone through the motion of a full-scale trial and although the trial itself was without jurisdiction, it will be an act of injustice if they are required again to go through the motion of a fresh trial - The impugned judgment and order are set aside as being void and without jurisdiction Shaiful Islam Vs. Ahu Taker alias Taleh and another 6 BLD (I I CD) 1S9.

 

 

Sections 423 and 439 Remand for retrial — When should be ordered — There appears some disputed questions of tact having direct bearing in the result of the case When there is no positive proof of certain essential facts the accused cannot be convicted — On such vital questions the defiance ought to have been given an opportunity to place its case without proceeding ex-parte This is thus a tit case to be sent on remand for retrial .loynal Ahedin alias Tara Chand Master Vs. The State 7 BLD (HCD)2S3.

 

 

Section 423 — Alteration of conviction of the accused to a different offence by the Appellate Court for which the accused was to be charged — The Appellate Court is competent in an appropriate case to alter the conviction passed by the trial Court from one section to another section — In the instant case conviction of the appellant under Section 468 of the Penal Code was altered to Section 471 of the Penal Code while maintaining the sentence passed upon him Jahangir Hossain Vs. The State 7 BLD (HCD) 366.Ref. AIR 1952 (SC) 167; PLD 1962 (Karachi) 756; PLD 1955 (SC) (India) 243.

 

 

Section 423 — Withdrawal of cirminal appeal — The right of appeal is a creature of the statute and it is a privilege for the aggrieved — If a convict after having filed an appeal from the judgment of con­viction elects not to pursue the same and wants to withdraw, the Court can not refuse it. Nasiruddin Mia Vs. The State 8 BLD (HCD) 503

Ref. PLD 1959 (SC) 1 19

 

Section 423 — Remand for retrial — When there is sufficient evidence on re­cord for disposal of an appeal there can be no justification for remand of the case for retrial — Such an order is particularly uncalled for when the case has been pending for about 16 years — To prove whether the defence case is probable is no ground for retrial Ahu Siddique alias Abu Siddique Ahmed Vs. The State 10 BLD (AD) 166.

 

 

Section 424 — Judgment by the Appel­late Court — An Appellate Court must discuss the evidence in detail, make criti­cal analysis of the evidence and consider the facts and circumstances of the case independent of the decision of the trial Court and arrive at its own findings — The judgment of the Sessions Judge shows that he considered the judgment of the trial Court but avoided detailed dis­cussion of the evidence on record and concurred with the findings of the trial Court It cannot be held that this finding is not independent of that of the trial Court. Mil Hadiuzzunian alias Abdul Hadi and others Vs. The State 6 BLD (AD) 191.

 

 

Section 426(2) — Prayer for bail in a pending appeal —• It seems that the High Court Division ignored facts stated in the petition for bail and refused the prayer for bail without correct assessment of facts _Having regard to the good academic background and the future carreer of the appellant, there was enough justifiable reasons to allow him bail Nurul Islam idias liahlu Vs. The State 8 BLD (AD) 208.

 

 

 

Section 426 Bail on condition of payment of fine — Payment of fine involving a huge amount of money as a pre-condition for bail may defeat the purpose of the bail — The Court has been given the discretion to stay the realization of fine pending the disposal of the appeal

—  The impugned order for payment of tine as a condition for bail is not supportable either in law or on the principle of rea­sonableness Md. Iqbal alias Salim Vs. The State 9 BLD (AD) 3.

 

Section 426(1) and 496 Right of bail — In a case trial Court It cannot be held that this finding is not independent of that of the trial Court. Mil Hadiuzzunian alias Abdul Hadi and others Vs. The State 6 BLD (AD) 191.

 

 

Section 426(2) — Prayer for bail in a pending appeal —It seems that the High Court Division ignored facts stated in the petition for bail and refused the prayer for bail without correct assessment of facts _Having regard to the good academic background and the future carreer of the appellant, there was enough justifiable reasons to allow him bail Nurul Islam idias liahlu Vs. The State 8 BLD (AD) 208.

 

Section 426 Bail on condition of payment of fine — Payment of fine involving a huge amount of money as a pre-condition for bail may defeat the purpose of the bail — The Court has been given the discretion to stay the realization of fine pending the disposal of the appeal _The impugned order for payment of tine as a condition for bail is not supportable either in law or on the principle of rea­sonableness Md. Iqbal alias Salim Vs. The State 9 BLD (AD) 3.

 

 

Section 426(1) and 496 Right of bail — In a case of bailable offence the under-trial prisoners are entitled to bail as of right but in the case of a convict he cannot claim bail as of right — It is the absolute discretion of the Court to either refuse or grant bail to the convicts but this discretion must be exercised judicially Shamsul Hoque Pramanik and others Vs. The State 9 BLD (HCD) 520.Ref. PLD 1967 (Lahore) 1302; 20 DLR (WP) (Lahore) 7; 1967 (Pak) Cr.L.J. 422.

 

 

Section 426(2) — In a pending crimi­nal appeal when the appellant files an application for bail before the High Court Division it should not ordinarily issue any Rule — The Court may grant or refuse bail or ask the petitioner to come up with a separate petition and may hear the State, if necessary, before disposing an applica­tion for bail Sree Monju Kumar Shaha and others Vs. The State 12 BLD (AD) 213.

 

 

Section 428 — Remand for fresh trial — The trial Court found evidence suffi­cient for establishing the guilt of the ac­cused — If the Appellate Court did not consider the evidence sufficient, it was within his jurisdiction to call for addi­tional evidence — Fresh trial is likely to prolong the criminal proceeding — The Appellate Court should have disposed of the appeal without directing a retrial Md Shah Alam alias Shah AH and others Vs. The State and another 6 BLD (AD) 88

 

Sections 431, 435, 439, 439A and 561A — Substitution of the heirs of the deceased accused The principle on which a criminal proceeding is allowed to continue ever after the death of the ac­cused "in an appeal" is that the sentence of fine may affect the properties falling in the hands of the legal representatives of the deceased accused and in such circum­stances the legal representatives of the ac­cused may be interested in proceeding with the appeal to protect their interest Dr. Md. Abdul liaten Vs. The State 10 BLD (HCD) 411.Ref. 22 DLR (Dhaka) 244. AIR 1942 (Madras) 24Y; 9 Cr L .1 103. 

 

Sections 435 and 439 - Under Sec­tion 435 Cr.P.C. the High Court Division may call for and examine the record of any proceeding before any inferior Criminal Court for satisfying itself as to the regularity of any proceeding — The Court can even slid motu call for the records of such proceedings — The complainant is also competent to file a revisional application before the High Court Division when the State does not prefer any appeal against an order of acquittal even in a case instituted on police report — The jurisdiction of the High Court Division in exercising revisional  powers is wide enough to interfere with the finding of facts arrived at by the Court of appeal below if any illegality is found in the impugned order Tofazzal Hossain Shaikh Vs. Mir Mohammad Akand and others 4 blD (AD) 156.

 

 

Sections 435 and 437 Interference by the Sessions Judge with the Magis trate's order of discharge before the omi­ssion of Section 437 Cr.P.C. — The of­fence being exclusively triable by the Court of Sessions and there being some evidence in support of the prosecution case, the Magistrate was not competent to discharge the accused persons and he ex­ceeded his jurisdiction in weighing and sifting the evidence as in a trial — The Sessions Judge rightly interfered with the order of discharge since Sections 435 and 437 Cr.P.C. clearly empower him to do so _The High Court Division erroneously held that the Sessions Judge was not competent to interfere with the finding of facts arrived at by the Committing Mag­istrate Jusmat Ali Shaikh Vs. Mosiran Bibi and others 4 HI A) (AD) 217.

 

 

Section 435 — An Assistant Sessions Judge is an inferior Criminal Court in re­lation to the Sessions Judge and as such a revision under Section 435 Cr. P C. lies before the Sessions Judge against an order of the Assistant Sessions Judge either in original or appellate jurisdiction. Mohar Ali Vs. Raizuddin and others 4 HU) (HCD) 2X5.

 

 

Sections 435, 436, 438 and 439A Power of revision, reference and review __Authority to exercise such powers Provisions of the Code of Criminal Pro­cedure clearly provide that the Sessions Judge may exercise such powers - Re-visional power has not been given to the Court of Sessions at all, it has been given to the office of the Sessions Judge. Nurul Huda Vs. Hahauddin and others 9 BLD (HCD) 271.

 

Sections 435, 439 and 561A_ A party filing a revisional application before the Sessions Judge under Section 439A OP C is debarred from invokving the aid of Section 439 Qt P. C before the High Court Division in view of the bar imposed by Sub-section (4) of Section 439 Cr.P.C. but in an appropriate case he can invoke the aid of Section 561A Cr PC to prevent an abuse of the process of the Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice - Power of the High Court Divi­sion under Section 561A Cr P C has not been restricted by any clause of Section 439 Cr P C or b\ any other law Dr. Md. Abdul Hat en Vs. The State 10 HU) (HCD) 411.Ref. 41 DLR (HCD) 385; PLD 1961 (Karachi) 432. 33 DLR (HCD) 88; 22 DLR ( Dhaka) 244; AIR 1942 (Madras) 249; 9 Cr L J 103. 38 Cr L .1 918; 36 CWN 024.

 

 

 

Sections 435 and 436 — The Proce­dures as laid down in the Code of Criminal Procedure are to be followed by the Special Tribunal trying offences covered by the Special Powers Act. 1974 but by this he is not empowered to act as a "Revisional Court" — Calling for the re­cords by the Sessions Judge and then con­vening himself into Special Tribunal is not contemplated by law Satya Narayan Sarda Vs. The State 10 HU) (HCD) 54.Ref. 30 DLR 125 3 1 DLR 241, 32 DLR (AD) 39, 229.

 

 

Section 436 Direction for further enquiry — Section 439 Cr.P.C. but in an appropriate case he can invoke the aid of Section 561A Cr PC to prevent an abuse of the process of the Court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice - Power of the High Court Divi­sion under Section 561A Cr P C has not been restricted by any clause of Section 439 Cr P C or  any other law Dr. Md. Abdul Hat en Vs. The State 10 HU) (HCD) 411.Ref. 41 DLR (HCD) 385; PLD 1961 (Karachi) 432. 33 DLR (HCD) 88; 22 DLR ( Dhaka) 244; AIR 1942 (Madras) 249; 9 Cr L J 103. 38 Cr L .1 918; 36 CWN 024.

 

 

 

Sections 435 and 436 — The Proce­dures as laid down in the Code of Criminal Procedure are to be followed by the Special Tribunal trying offences covered by the Special Powers Act. 1974 but by this he is not empowered to act as a "Revisional Court" — Calling for the re­cords by the Sessions Judge and then con­vening himself into Special Tribunal is not contemplated by law Satya Narayan Sarda Vs. The State 10 HU) (HCD) 54.Ref. 30 DLR 125 3 1 DLR 241, 32 DLR (AD) 39, 229.

 

 

 

Section 436 Direction for further enquiry — High Court and the Sessions Judge have power to direct further enquiry and this power is confined to a case under Section 203 or Sub-section (3) of Section 204 CrJP.C or into the case of any accused person who has been discharged by the Subordinate Court — A proceeding under Section 145 Cr.P.C. does not come within the mischief of the aforesaid provision Basiruddin Sarkar Vs. Shiraj Ali Sarkar and others 3 BLD (HCD) 148.

 

 

Section 436 — Further enquiry — Section 436 Cr.P.C empowers the Ses­sions Judge to direct further enquiry into a case by the Magistrate — The Additional Sessions Judge while directing further en­quiry also gave a direction to issue proc­ess against the accused persons — This part of the order for issuing process is beyond his jurisdiction Rafiqul alias Rafiqul Islam and others Vs. Md. Meshahuddin 3 BLD (HCD) 317.

 

 

Section 436 — The order of discharge by a Magistrate — One cannot file before the Magistrate a petition for revival of the same case — The aggrieved person can move the Sessions Judge for further en­quiry under Section 436 Cr.P.C. — The superior Court can order further enquiry but neither the Sessions Judge nor the High Court Division can direct the taking of cognizance Ahdus Salam Master and another Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 267.

 

 

Sections 436, 439, 439A and 561A Power to order for trial — Neither the Sessions Judge nor the High Court Divi­sion is empowered to order for trial of an accused against whom no process has been issued - When the complaint was dismissed by the Magistrate on erroneous view of law, the only course open to the Sessions Judge was to direct further en­quiry — The High Court Division quashed the proceeding whereby the Sessions Judge had directed the Magistrate to send the case to him for trial - The proper course for the High Court Division was to modify the order of the Sessions Judge and to direct further enquiry, Bangladesh Vs. Yakuh Sarder and others 8 HI J) (AD) 180.

 

Section 436 — Further enquiry — The superior Court can direct the Magistrate to hold further enquiry but neither the Court of Sessions nor the High Court Division can direct him to take cognizance Syed Ahmed and another Vs. Hahihur Rahman and another 9 BLD (HCD) 227.Ref. 36 DLR (AD) 58; 33 DLR 8; 35 DLR 140; 25 DLR 152.

 

 

Sections 438. 439 and 561A ASpecial Judge alone is competent to take cognizance of any offence committed within his jurisdiction triable under the Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1958 — The order of the Upazila Magistrate taking cognizance of an offence under Section 40() of the Penal Code and issuing warrant of arrest against the accused is illegal and without jurisdiction. A Mannan Vs. UNO — In Charge, Kalmakanda 8 BLD (HCD) 46.

 

 

 - Section 439 — Conversion of criminal appeal into revision — Under Sections 435 and 439 Cr.P.C. the High Court Divi­sion is competent to treat an appeal as a revision in an appropriate case — But the Labour Court being not an inferior Court, the High Court Division has no revisional jurisdiction to interfere with the convic­tion and sentence passed by the Labour Court under Standing Orders Act, 1965 Anisuzzaman and others Vs. Chairman, 1st Labour Court and another 2 BLD (HCD) 9J.Ref. 9 DLR 424; 11 DLR (WP) 62; 32 DLR (AD) 1; 32 DLR (HCD) 142; 16 DLR (Dhaka) 877; 25 DLR 192; 22 DLR (Dhaka ) 569; 29 DLR 358.

 

 

Sections 439 and 439A — Maintain­ability of a revisional application before the High Court Division against an order passed by the Sessions Judge in revision — There is a conflict between Sub­sections (1) and (4) of Section 439 on the one hand and Sub-section (4) of Section 439 and Sub-section (2) of Section 439A on the other hand of Sessions Judge's jurisdiction under Sec­tion 439A has been made co-equal with that of the High Court Division under Section 439. Therefore the person who moved the Sessions Judge under Section 43 9A cannot move the High Court Division against that order under Section 439 but there is no bar for the aggrieved opposite party to move the High Court Divison under Section 439 Sub-section (4) of Section 439 completely bars the High Court Division to entertain any application against an order passed by the Sessions Judge under Section 439A — This Sub-section (4) takes away what Section 439A is supposed to confer, leading to an apparent conflict between the two.

 

Despite the bar created by 439A Cr.P.C, the power of the High Court Division to call for the records of the subordinate Courts is not restricted High Court Division's general power of superintendance to correct any illegality of the subordinate Court remains unhampered __The supervisory power of the High Court Division is also guaranteed under Article 109 of the Constitution.

 

The Sessions Judge while exercising power under Section 439A Cr.P.C. acts as an ordinary criminal Court subordinate to the High Court Division Shafiqur Rahman Vs. Nurul Islam Chowdhury and others 3 BLD (AD) 279.

 

 

Sections    439, 439A and 561A —Quashing of proceedings — When the power can be exercised — A proceeding can be quashed and cognizance set aside only when it is manifestly evident that there is a legal bar against the prosecution of The Sub-Divisional Magistrate after perusing the enquiry report issued warrant of arrest against the accused — The Ses­sions Judge acting under Section 439A Cr.P.C. set aside the order passed by the Sub-Divisional Magistrate taking cognizance against the accused under Sections 342/364 of the Penal Code and quashed the proceeding — The superintendence to correct any illegality of the subordinate Court remains unhampered _The supervisory power of the High Court Division is also guaranteed under Article 109 of the Constitution.

 

 

The Sessions Judge while exercising power under Section 439A Cr.P.C. acts as an ordinary criminal Court subordinate to the High Court Division Shafiqur Rahman Vs. Nurul Islam Chowdhury and others 3 BLD (AD) 279

 

Sections  439, 439A and 561A —Quashing of proceedings — When the power can be exercised — A proceeding can be quashed and cognizance set aside only when it is manifestly evident that there is a legal bar against the prosecution of The Sub-Divisional Magistrate after perusing the enquiry report issued warrant of arrest against the accused — The Ses­sions Judge acting under Section 439A Cr.P.C. set aside the order passed by the Sub-Divisional Magistrate taking cognizance against the accused under Sections 342/364 of the Penal Code and quashed the proceeding — The Sessions Judge's order clearly amounts to an abuse of the process of the Court and the same is liable to be set aside. Siddiqur Rahman Vs. The State and others 4 BLD (HCD) 248.

 

Section 439 — Exercising suo motu power under Section 439 Cr.P.C. the High Court Division can set aside conviction and sentence of non-appealing accused. Mahmud Ali and others Vs. The State, 5 BLD (HCD) 218.Ref. 2 DLR 305; 28 DLR 253; PLD 1949 (Lahore) 179; PLD 1965 (WP) (Karachi) 637.

 

 

 

Sections 439 and 439A — The Sessi­ons Judge exercising power under section 439A Cr.P.C. cannot dispose 6f ex-parte a Criminal Motion without serving any no­tice on the opposite party an and without hearing him — Section.439 (2) provides for notifying the opposite party and giving him an opportunity of being heard — The powers exercised by the Sessions Judge are the powers which are exercised by the High Court Division under Section 439 Cr.P C. and as such the Sessions Judge is not only bound by the terms of Section 439 Cr.P.C. but he is also bound by the procedure contained therein Md Ahul Eashar and others Vs. The State and another 6 BLD (HCD) 249.

 

 

Section 439 — Revisional power of the High Court Division is to be exercised sparingly only when grave injustice is likely to be caused or where there has oc­curred a clear miscarriage of justice or when the impugned order is found to be illegal and perverse — The observation made by the Sessions Judge in respect of giving a chance to the complainant to ex­amine the Investigating Officer and the Medical Officer is aimed at doing justice to the party and as such it cannot be said that the observation made by the Sessions Judge is manifestly illegal or against legal principle Putin Eehari Eanic and others Vs. The State 7 BLD (HCD) 123.

 

Sections 439, 439A and 204 — The power to order for trial of an accused against whom no process has been "issued by the Magistrate is not included in the revisional power either of the Sessions Judge or of the High Court Division — By implication it cannot be held that the Sessions Judge has the power to try an accused against whom no process has been issued and who has not been sent for trial — When the complaint was dis­missed on an erroneous view of law the only course open to the Sessions Judge was to direct further enquiry Eangladesh Vs. Yakuh Sarder and others 8 BLD (AD) 180.

 

 

Section 439 — Setting aside conviction of a non - appealing accused — It is now well-settled that the appellate Court while disposing the appeal of the co — accused can set aside the conviction of an accused who has not appealed against his conviction Md Ali Haider and others Vs. The State 8 BLD (HCD) 305.

 

 

Section 439 (4) — Re-appraisal of evi­dence in revisional jurisdiction — With the change of time and the circumstances attending the administration of criminal justice time has come and experience also demands that the High Court Division will have to be a little more.scrutinizing even in a case of acquittal because in the ulti­mate analysis it is the interest of public-justice which prompts the Court of revi­sion to interfere in a particular case — The Court of revision can legitimately ex­amine whether correct principle relating to the appraisal of evidence has been fol­lowed or not and whether some material piece of evidence has been overlooked or misappreciated which could have a pro­found bearing on the order of acquittal. Kashem AH Vs. The State ami others 9 BLD (AD) 13

 

Section 439 — Interference with con­current finding of facts — Though ordi­narily the High Court Division does not interfere with concurrent finding of facts arrived at by the Courts below, the instant case will be an exception since the trial Court as well as the appellate Court have completely overlooked glaring defects which vitiated the findings of facts causing miscarriage of justice. Nur Mohammad alias Bog Master Vs. The State 9 BLD (HCD) 314.

 

 

Sections 439, 439A and 561A – Bar on the ground of being a second revi-sional application when not tenable — The extra-ordinary power of the High Court Division under Section 561A Cr.P.C. for quashing a proceeding may in appropriate cases be exercised even after the Sessions Judge was moved under Sec­tion 439A Cr.P.C. — If the conditions for the exercise of inherent jurisdiction of the Court are fulfilled, the High Court Divi­sion can exercise that power to prevent the abuse of the process of the Court or to secure the ends of justice Fatema Begum alias Urmila Rani Vs. (iageswar Nath ami the State 9 BLD (HCD) 469 Ref. 4 BCR (AD) 87; 4 BCR (AD) 468.

 

 

Section 439 — A time-barred appeal under the Special Powers Act can not be treated as a revisional application under Section 439 Cr.P.C. Mtl. Shamsul Haque Vs. The State, 10 BLD (HCD) 360.Ref. 39 DLR (HCD) 164; 5 BLD (HCD) 335; 37 DLR (HCD) 59; 32 DLR (AD) 1; 23 DLR (WP) (Peshwar) 12; 9 DLR 424.

 

 

Section 439 — Proper exercise of discrection - The appellant produced a medical certificate showing her age at 18 years and the parties were living as man and wife — She also gave brith to a child — The Sessions Judge gave a direction for examination of the appellant by a Medical Board pending which she was to remain in lawyer's custody or in judicial custody — The appellant preferred a criminal revision before the High Court Division and obtained a Rule but her prayer for ad-interim stay of the impugned order was refused — On appeal the Ap­pellate Division held that under the facts and circumstances of the case the operation of the impugned order concerning the custody of the appellant might spell disaster to both the baby and the mother and in that view of the matter the refusal by the High Court Division to grant an interim stay was not a judicious and sound exercise of discretion. Mrs. Azima Begum Vs. Mil. Yusuf Khan and others 12 BLD (AD) 183.

 

 

 

Sections 439A and 561A — Inherent power of the High Court Divison — Notwithstanding the finality given by Sec­tion 439A Cr.P.C. the inherent powers of the High Court Division is still available to the High Court Divisions under Section 561A of the Code to secure the ends of justice. Abdul Halim Pattader and others Vs. M. Rahamat All and another I BLD (HCD) 377.

 

1279

CODE OF CRIMINAL PROCEDURE (V OF 1898) (Part-4)

Citation: 4 BLD (HCD) 169, 6 BLD (AD) 128, 6 BLD (HCD) 69 Ref. 4 BLD (AD) 7, 6 BLD (HCD) 158, 7 BLD (HCD) 112.Ref. 35 DLR(AD) 127, 12 BLD (AD) 54.Ref. AIR 1945 (PC) 18; AIR 1928 (Cal) 610; AIR 1966 (Goa) 36, 8 BLD (HCD) 224, 6 BLD (AD) 128, 9 BLD (HCD) 387, 9 BLD

Case Year: 1898

Subject: Criminal Law

Delivery Date: 2018-08-26

                     CODE OF CRIMINAL PROCEDURE (V OF 1898)

Section 439A — Revisional power can only be exercised where there is an ille­gality in the impugned order — The order of the Sessions Judge directing a fresh trial without finding any illegality in the order of the trying Magistrate can not be sustain in law. Habibur Rahman and others Vs. Wasefuddin and another 4 BLD (HCD) 169.

 

Section 439A — Practice and proce­dure — An order allowing maintenance allowance to the wife was allowed exparte but the order was set aside by an Additional Sessions Judge in revision and the case was remanded to the Magistrate to allow the husband opportunity to ad­duce evidence — The Appellate Division modified the said order of remand with a direction that if the husband failed to avail of the opportunity of adducing further evidence within six weeks the original order for maintenance would stand — The husband having failed to adduce further evidence within six weeks, the Magistrate affirmed his earlier order of maintenance — On revision an Assistant Sessions Judge deemed to be an Additional Sessions Judge set aside the Magistrates order and remanded the case to the Magistrate for rehearing — The High Court Division set aside the order holding that the Additional Sessions Judge has no jurisdiction to re-open the matter settled by the Appellate Division and that a second revision under Section 439A was not maintainable in the same Court — A Magistrate has got power under Sub­section (6) of Section 488 Cr.P C to hear and determine a case for maintenance exparte if the opposite party willfully neglects to attend the Court. Abdul Moneyem Chowdhury Vs. Md Shamsul Hussain Chomlhury 6 BLD (AD) 128.

 

Sections 439A, 439(4) and 561A_Inherent power — When cannot be in­voked — The extra-ordinary power of the High Court Division under Section 561A of the Cr.P.C. cannot be invoked by a per­son after becoming unsuccessful in an applicaton under Section 439A Cr.P.C. except for specific purposes set out in that Section Shafiqur Rahman Vs. The State 6 BLD (HCD) 69 Ref. 4 BLD (AD) 7.

 

Section 439A further enquiry after charge sheet Magistrate rightly rejected the application for further enquiry after charge sheet was submitted — The Addi­tional Sessions Judge exercising power under Section 439A Cr.P C. acted ille­gally and without jurisdiction in ordering further enquiry which is not covered by any law and is beyond the scope of Sec­tion 439A of the Code Sultan Ahmed Matbar Vs. The State and another 6 BLD (HCD) 158.

 

 

Sections 439A and 439(4) — The High Court Division has no jurisdiction to en­tertain an application under Section 439 Cr.P.C. in respect of an order passed by the Sessions Judge under Section 439A of the Code of Criminal Porcedure. Mohd Ali Khan Vs. Serajul Islam Khan and others 7 BLD (HCD) 112.Ref. 35 DLR(AD) 127

 

Sections 439A and 561A — The in­herent jurisdiction of the High Court Di­vision under Section 561A is available even to a party who lost in revision before the Sessions Judge under Section 43 9A — But this power should be exercised sparingly and with caution and only in those cases where such exercise is essential and justified by the test specially laid down in the provision itself. Aminul Islam Vs. Mujibur Rahman and others 12 BLD (AD) 54.Ref. AIR 1945 (PC) 18; AIR 1928 (Cal) 610; AIR 1966 (Goa) 36.

 

 

Sections 464- 475 — Plea of insanity by the accused — Procedure to be followed — Onec the plea of insanity is validly taken by the accused and the same is prima facie found as such, the Court is under an obligation to take recourse to the provisions as laid down in Chapter XXXIV of the Code of Criminal Procedure as the Court is not expected to come to a definite finding as to whether the accused is suffering from insanity. Abdul Latif Vs. The State 7 BLD (HCD) 432 Ref. 11DLR5, AIR 1928 (Cal) 775.

 

 

Sections 476 and 561A — The judge issued a notice to a party in a case for making false statement — It being within his statutory jurisdiction, there was no abuse of the process of the Court — It is well-settled that when a Court acts, which is empowered by law, such act cannot be interfered with unless there has been a failure of justice — The application for quashing the proceeding is rejected. A. N. M. Rezwan Vs. Fariduddin Chowdhury 8 BLD (HCD) 224.

 

 

 

Section 488 — Maintenance allowance to wife — Whether an application for maintenance filed by the father of the wife is maintainable — An application for maintenance filed by the father or brother of the wife whom her husband neglected to maintain is maintainable. Abdul Moneycm Chowdhury Vs. Md Shamsul Hussain Chowdhury 6 BLD (AD) 128.

 

 

Section 491 — The High Court Divi­sion has jurisdiction under 491 Cr.P.C. to interfere with an order of detention passed under the Special Powers Act — Wherethe detaining authority does not comply with the mandatory provisions of the Special Powers Act, it cannot be said that the detention of the detenu is lawful and in that case the High Court Division has ample power under Section 491 Cr PC to interfere with an illegal detention though it purports to be under an enactment providing for preventive detention.

 

The bar provided in Section 34 of the Special Powers Act, 1974 does not pro­tect orders passed in bad faith or in abuse of the Act— Consequently when these is­sues are raised, the same are required to be investigated — The Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) S34. Sultana Ara Begum Vs. Secretary Ministry of Home Affairs and others, 7 BLD (HCD) 138.Ref. AIR 1940 (PC) 150; 28 DLR 259.

 

 

Section 491 — Preventive detention — If a rule has been issued on an application under Section 491 Cr P C and the same is ready for hearing it is the duty of the Court to hear the matter and pronounce its decision as early as possible without waiting for the Advisory Board to report its opinion to the Government Dr. Md Habibullah Vs. Secretary, Ministry of the Home Affairs and others 9 BLD (HCD) 387.

 

 

Section 491 — Habeas Corpus— Di­rection of the nature of a Habeas Corpus and scope of an application under the Sec­tion — The words "illegally or improperly detained" used in the Section indicate that when a person has not been detained within the provision of any law it becomes an illegal detention — The expression 'improperly' as made in the Section has a wider connotation than the word "illegally" — The word "improperly" refers to cases in which although the forms of the law have been observed but there has been fraud on an Act or an abuse of the process of the powers given to the executive — In such cases it is the duty of the Court to step in aid of the detenu to a set him at liberty — The scope of Section 491 Cr.P C is wider than the relevant constitutional provision. Syeda Rezia Begum Vs. The People's Republic of Bangladesh and others 9 BLD (HCD) 441.

 

 

Section 491 — Production of a minor girl from judicial custody for determina­tion of age — Since the girl is prima facie a minor aged only about 14 years her refusal to go with the parents is not at all material. So far as the custody and well-being are concerned it is the parents who are the best persons to get custody of the minor children.

 

Kidnapped immature girl — Deter­mination of her age — The moot question for determination is the age of the alleged kidnapped girl on the facts alleged and proof furnished — Guardians and Wards Act, 1890 (VIII of 1890) read with the Majority Act, 1875 (IX of 1875) S 3 — Age of 18 years is the determining factor.

 

 

Conflicting and contradicting state­ments — Parents state on oath that the girl's date of birth was on 5.2.76 and this an Act or an abuse of the process of the powers given to the executive — In such cases it is the duty of the Court to step in aid of the detenu to a set him at liberty — The scope of Section 491 Cr.P C is wider than the relevant constitutional provision. Syeda Rezia Begum Vs. The People's Republic of Bangladesh and others 9 BLD (HCD) 441.

 

Section 491 — Production of a minor girl from judicial custody for determina­tion of age — Since the girl is prima facie a minor aged only about 14 years her refusal to go with the parents is not at all material. So far as the custody and well-being are concerned it is the parents who are the best persons to get custody of the minor children.

 

Kidnapped immature girl — Deter­mination of her age — The moot question for determination is the age of the alleged kidnapped girl on the facts alleged and proof furnished — Guardians and Wards Act, 1890 (VIII of 1890) read with the Majority Act, 1875 (IX of 1875) S 3 — Age of 18 years is the determining factor.

 

Conflicting and contradicting state­ments — Parents state on oath that the girl's date of birth was on 5.2.76 and this was corroborated by the school leaving certificate of the Head Master of the school on the basis of the Admission Register — The girl's affidavit, kabin-nama and the medical report showed her a major — The Court preferred the parents version of the date of birth of the girl to be on 5.2.76 on the basis of the affidavits of the parents — These statements were found to be positive, clear and definite to that of the unreliable medical report based on superficial general observations — On physical observation of the girl the Court found that she did not look like a fully-developed adult woman intelligent enough to understand and decide her well-being and the Court prima facie accepted her date of birth as 5.2.76 — She being a minor her refusal to go with the parents was not at all material regarding her cus­tody and well-being — It was held that the minor girl was illegally detained in judicial custody and she was set at liberty with a direction to make her over to the custody of her father.

 

 

Weight of medical report in determ­ining age — Doctor's report on age of the girl was found to be superficial, undependable an too general in nature and the same was rejected in view of other cogent evidence.The statement of the minor girl regarding her age carries no weight and parent's version was accept ed. Krishna Pada Dutta Vs. The Secretary of Homes Affairs, the Government of the People's Republic of Bangladesh and others 10 BLD (HCD) 301Ref. AIR 1033 (Cal) 632, 15 DLR (Dhaka) 148; AIR 1916 (PC) 242; 42 DLR (HCD) 79; 28 DLR (HCD) 128; ILR 37 (Madras) 567 Paras 16 and 17; AIR 1916 (PC) 242 (Para — 19).

 

 

Section 491 — Special Powers Act (XIV Of 1974) S 3 (2) (3) — The first or­der of detention was made on 15 4.89 by the Additional District Magistrate, Dhaka Subsequent order of extension of deten­tion was made on 15 5 90 by the Assistant Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs after the expert of the fast order The Gov­ernment is not authorized under Sub-sec­tion (3) of Section 3 of the Special Pow­ers Act to extend the period of detention with retrospective effect after the expiry of the first order of detention Mamtaz Sultana Vs. Secretary. Ministry of Htune Affairs and others 10 BLD (HCD) 367.

 

 

Section 494 — Withdrawal of a crimi­nal case According of consent for withdrawal is not a mechanical process but a judicial act and it should be exer­cised judiciously with due care and cau­tion after proper application of the mind — There must be materials on record to justify the order Abdul Mannan Talukder Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 222.

 

 

Section 494 — Withdrawal of a crimi­nal case ----- Consent for withdrawal is not to be given mechanically — The Court is to exercise its jurisdiction judicially before giving consent This implies that the Court will have to examine the materials on which the Government decides the withdrawal of case — It ,is open to the Court to see whether the Government's order for withdrawal was malafide or made for collateral purposes. Syed Matiur Rahman alias Motiur Rahman Vs. The State 4 BLD (AD) 261.

 

 

 

Section 494 — Withdrawal from prosecution — Giving of consent by the Court for withdrawal is a judicial act and the Court will have to be satisfied that the executive decision to withdraw from the prosecution has not been improperly ex­ercised. K. A. T. M. Amanullah Vs. Gulam Sultan and another 4 BLD (HCD) 202.Ref. 31 DLR (AD) 135; AIR 1948 (Lahore) 74; AIR 1938 (PC) 266; AIR 1956 (SC) 289; AIR 1972 (SC) 496; AIR 1940 (Sind) 233.

 

 

 

Section 494 — Withdrawal of criminal appeals — Giving consent to withdrawal is a judicial act and this will not be done as a matter of course — Before permis­sion for withdrawal is accorded some material should be produced before the Court showing the reason for the with­drawal Anwar a Bewa Vs. Razz.ak and others 5 BLD (AD) 327.Ref. 30 DLR (SC) 297; 35 DLR (AD) 329.

 

 

 

Sections 496, 497 and 498 — The pe­titioner is an accused in a case under Sec­tions 109/111 of the Banking Companies Act, 1991 — The Chief Metropolitan Magistrate of Dhaka took cognizance of the offence and issued warrant of arrest but the police could not secure the arrest of the accused and proclamation and at­tachment of properties were made under Sections 87 and 88 Cr.P.C.

 

 

Petitioner instead of surrendering before the Chief Metropolitan Magistrate filed an application under Section 498 Cr.P.C. for anticipatory bail seeking protection of the Court against arrest and harassment by the police — The petitioner is a member of the Parliament and Chairman of the Bangladesh Commerce and Investment.

 

The Court refuses to allow him anticipa­tory bail without first surrendering before the Chief Metropolitan Magistrate, Dhaka Mustafizur  Rahman   Vs.   The State 12 BLD (HCD) 507.Ref. 5 DLR (FC)86; 18 DLR (SC) 383; 19 DLR (SC) 39).

 

 

 

Section 497 — Enlarging an accused on parole in the garb of a temporary order for bail — The Sessions Judge has no jurisdiction to pass such an order under the provision of the Code of Criminal Procedure — The mere fact that the Government has allowed the right to address public meetings by a candidate in the election does not ipso facto justify an order of parole — The Government which has permitted a limited right to the can­didate is opposing the right of the accused on the ground of prejudice to the prosecu­tion — The limited right of the individual must be subordinated to the interest of the society Md. Shahahuddin Vs. The State andAzam Khan 5 BLD (HCD) 306.

 

Sections 497 and 498 Discretions in granting bail should be properly exer- cised — It has been overlooked that other accused alleged to have committed the same offence were enlarged on bail and there was no specific allegations against the appellants —• It was held that the High Court Division has not properly exercised its discretion in refusing bail to the appellants Feroj AH and another Vs. The State 7 BLD (AD) 91.

 

Section 497(5) — Cancellation of bail when not proper — The Special Judge did not exercise his jurisdiction properly in cancelling the bail of the appellant merely upon the apprehension expressed by the prosecution as to his possible abscon-dence ignoring the fact that he did not do so during the last six years he had been on bail — In the circumstances the High Court Division was wrong in rejecting the applicaton for bail. Sajalendu Das Vs. The State 7 BLD (AD) 154.

 

 

Section 497 — Discretion in the matter of granting bail — Section 497 Cr PC. enjoins upon the Court a duty to exercise its judicial discretion in the matter of granting bail for ascertaining whether the materials placed before the Court by the prosecution are of such a tangible nature that if left unrequited they may lead to the inference of guilt of the accused — The High Court Division committed an error of law in refusing bail to the appellant holding that "it is very difficulty at this stage to believe that there is no reasonable ground for believing that he has not committed an offence under Section 409 as alleged" — The approach of the High Court Division was wrong and the order of refusal of bail was illegal. A. K. M. Mosharaf Hossian Vs. The State 12 BLD (AD) 175.

 

 

Section 498 — Anticipatory bail — From the facts stated in the petition and the circumstances metioned therein, it appears that the appellant may reasonably apprehend that the police might arrest him to prevent his participation in the election—His arrest may even destroy the chances of his winning the election — Political activities cannot be restrained even by the possibility of resorting to a criminal prosecution — Bail granted to the appellant till 1 (one) week after the postponed election Golam Sarwar Kamal Vs. The State 5 BLD (AD) 110.

 

 

Section 498 — The case of the appel­lant is that he is in possession of the disputed holding and he has already filed Title Suit No 117 of 1983 against the respondent who threatened him to dispossess from his peaceful possession __There is apparent disputes between the parties and as such there was no justifi­cation to refuse him bail Syed Mahbubur Rahman alias Mahhubur Rahman and another Vs. Abdul Matin and another 5 BLD (AD) 217.

 

 

Section 498 — When it is reasonable to grant bail — There is apprehension that the trial may be further delayed and the appellants will suffer prolonged custody in the facts of the case it will be rea­sonable to allow the appellants to remain Section 498 — The appellant was tried in absentia and was convicted under Sec­tion 420 of the Penal Code and sentenced to R.I. for 7 years and to pay a fine of Tk 35,000.00 — He filed an appeal before the High Court Division and prayed for bail but his prayer for bail was rejected on the ground that prima facie there was no illegality in the trial — Since there is hardly any chance of abscondence the appellant was entitled to bail. .V. M. Shajhahan Ali Tara Vs. The State 9 BLD (AD)2.

 

 

 

Section 498 — The appellant is not named in the FIR. and the police could not gather any material against him although the investigation has been going on for over a year — In the circumstances of the case the High Court Division ought to have enlarged him on bail — The Appellate Division allowed his prayer for bail. Sree Kalyan Kumar Chowdhury Vs. The State 9 BLD (AD) 12.

 

 

Section 498 — Rejection of bail peti­tion — Whether appeal is the only rem­edy — The High Court Division was not right in taking the view that once a peti­tion for bail is rejected no further appli­cation can be made before the same Court and the only remedy for the aggrieved lies in an appeal — It is not also right to say than an application for bail could not be filed before the Vacation Judge and that he had no jurisdiction to grant interim bail as the prayer for bail of the appellant was earlier rejected by a Division Bench. M. A. Wahah Advocate Vs. The State 10 BLD (AD) 50.

 

 

Section 498 — Interim bail pending appeal — An interim bail can not be al­lowed to continue for an indefinite period—There is no reason for further exten­sion of the interim bail simply because the appeal against his conviction is pending in the High Court Division — The ad interim bail was, however, extended for a period of six months from date on the expire of which the appellant was to surrender to his bail bond unless within this period his appeal was disposed of by the High Court Division Abdul Hakim Howlader Vs. The State 10 BLD (AD) 126.

 

Section 498 — Cancellation of bail—Case and counter-case pending between the parties over the self-same incident — Co-accused Chunnu Chow­dhury against whom cognizance has been taken under Section 302 of the Penal Code is already on bail — The High Court Division while issuing Rule also issued a suo motu Rule to show cause as to why bail granted to co-accused Bakul Howlader should not be cancelled — While disposing of the main Miscellane­ous Case, the High Court Division cancelled the bail of co-accused Bakul Chowdhury making the suo motu Rule absolute — It was held by the Appellate Division that in the absence of any allegation of tampering with the evidence dence on the application of the Public Prosecutor that the doctor holding the post- mortem examination was not avail­able — The information which is evidently vague does not fulfill any of the conditions laid down in Section 509A Cr.P.C and the application of the Assistant Public Prosecutor cannot be a substitute for legal evidence — The post-mortem report was excluded from consideration. The State Vs. Mokbul Hassan 6 BLD (HCD) 34.

 

Section 509A — Post-mortem report — Whether admissible in evidence without examining the doctor who held it — A post­mortem report can not be used as a substantive evidence unless the conditions mentioned in Section 509A Cr.P.C. are satisfied. Ezahar Sepai Vs. The State 7 BLD (HCD) 328.Ref. 37 DLR 156; AIR 1966 (Orissa) 21.

 

Section 509A — Post-mortem report — When none of the conditions necessary for admitting the post-mortem report into evidence has been proved, the report can not be considered Md Ali Haider and others Vs. The State 8 BLD (HCD) 305.

 

Section 512 — For application of the provisions of Section 512 of the Code of Criminal Procedure there must be a find­ing by the trial Court that the accused per­son has absconded and that there is no immediate prospect of his arrest. Hamez Ali alias Amir Ali Vs. The State 12 BLD (HCD) 650.Ref. 1980 (Pak) Cr.L.J 1101; 34 DLR 222.

 

Section 514 — Liability of a surety in respect of a bail for productin of the property before the Court — The appel­lant's bond is liable to forfeiture and he suffers a civil liability in terms of his bond is not a ground for his exoneration from the criminal liability — By his failure to produce the tractor in question he has incurred both civil and criminal liabilities which are not mutally exclusive — Penal Code (XLV of 1860) S 405 Shahidullah PaUvary Vs. The State 4 BLD (AD) 25.

 

Sections 517 and 520 — Disposal of property — Appellate Court's power to make orders — To make the orders the Appellate Court must be in session  of the matter involving an order passed by Sub­ordinate Court — It cannot be said that after passing the judgment and order on July 29, 1980 in disposing of the criminal appeal, the Court was no longer in session of the matter — The order passed by the Magistrate was no longer pending con­sideration by the Additional Sessions Judge — He had obviously no jurisdic­tion to pass the impugned order on Sep­tember 11. 1980. Northern Engineers Ltd Vs. Moklesur Rahman 5 BLD (AD) 181.

 

Section 522(3) — Restoration of pos­session — Appellate Court is competent to pass an order for restoration of posses­sion of a property in an appeal against the order of conviction. Sorah Ali and others Vs. The State 2 BLD (HCD) 116Ref. AIR 1957 (Cal) 390; AIR 1960 (Mysore) 24; PLD 1960 (Dhaka ) 23

 

Section 522(1) — In the face of the Civil Court's order of injunction in favour of the accused a Criminal Court cannot accept the claim of possession in the dis­puted property made by a party who is obliged to get the order of injunction va­cated — The appellant armed with an or­der of injunction in his favour could not be legally convicted for criminal trespass _The order of conviction and that of restoration of possession are set aside Samiruddin Ahmed alias Santir Mia Vs. The State 8 BLD (AD) 157.

 

Sections 526 and 561A — Transfer of a criminal case from one Court sub­ordinate to one Bench of the High Court Division to another Court subordinate to another Bench of the High Court Division ___Benches of the High Court Division constitute the integral part of the one and same High Court Division of the Supreme Court — The power of the High Court Division to transfer a case under Section 526 Cr.P.C. remains unaffected even after the promulgation of the Proclamation (Second Amendment) Order, 1982 — The High Court Division has power under Section 526 read with Section 561A Cr.P.C. to transfer a case from one Criminal Court to another Criminal Court within Bangladesh Kari Palan Mia and others Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 173.

 

Section 526 — Power of the High Court Division — The High Court Division has power to transfer a case pending in the court of any Special Judge to the court of another Special Judge irrespective of the territorial limits of either of the two Special Judges — This transfer by the High Court Division may be anywhere within Bangladesh while the jurisdiction of transfer of a case by the Senior Special Judge is limited within his district The State Vs. The Divisional Special Judge Khulna and another 12 BLD (AD) 166.

 

Section 528(2) — A transfer applica­tion in respect of a proceeding under Sec­tion 145 Cr.P.C. was filed before the S. D. M. who called for the record of the case and fixed a date of hearing but no order of stay was passed — The trying Magistrate having received the intimation of the S. D. M.'s order was not competent to dispose of the proceeding under Section 145 Cr.P.C. finally before the transfer application was heard by the S DM Md. Mqfdzztriur Raluunn Vs. Ahdus Salam and others 1 BLD (AD) 213.

 

Section 533 — When a confession has been recorded by a Magistrate in accor­dance with law by observing all the legal formalities, prescribed by law, the con­fession becomes admissible under Section 80 of the Evidence Act without calling for the Magistrate who recorded it — The two requirements for admitting such con­fession are: (1) it was taken in accordance with law and (2) the identity of the ac­cused has been satisfactorily proved — The Privy Council deprecated the practice of examining the Magistrates and Judges except in special circumstances such as those provided  by Section 533 Cr.P.C. Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 80. Md Emran All and others Vs. The State 5 BLD (HCD) 95.

 

Sections 533 and 164 — A Magistrate observed all the legal formalities in re­cording the confessional statement except that he did not record the questions and answers and that the memorandum re­corded was not in strict terms of Section 164(3) Cr.P.C — This defective record­ing of the memorandum was not consid­ered fatal as it was curable under Section 533 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. The State Vs. Kalu Bepari 10 BLD (HCD) 373

 

Section 535(2) — Whether conviction of the accused who was not charged with an offence can be maintained — Since it appears that a failure of justice has been occasioned by the omission to frame a proper charge, the conviction cannot be maintained by taking recourse to Section 535 Cr.P C Joynal Ahedin and others Vs. The State 5 BLD (AD) 257.

 

Section — 537 - - When a Court or Tribunal having no jurisdiction to try the accused assumes jurisdiction, if vitiates the proceeding and the defect is not curable by taking recourse to Section 537 Cr.P.C Abdul Mannan Miah alias Mannan Gain Vs. The State 9 BLD (HCD) 461.

 

Section 540 — The scope of section 540 Cr.P.C. is very wide and it gives discretion to the Court to examine any witness at any stage of the proceeding — It is imperative for the Court to examine a witness if his evidence appears to be es­sential for the just decision of the case. Akhtar .hihem anil others Vs. The State 9 BLD (HCD) 339.Ref. 35 DLR 41; 35 DLR 422; AIR 1951 (Madras) 707; AIR 1968 (SC) 178; AIR 1957 (Madras) 466; ArR 1958 (All) 321.

 

Section 540 — Power of the Court to take additional evidence — Section 540 Cr.P.C. empowers the Court to call for additional evidence when it feels that such evidence will clear the evidence already on record — The Sessions Judge is the arbiter and the Judge and he is not a party nor an investigator — He is not ex­pected to fill up the gaps left by the prose­cution — The over-riding consideration for exercising power under Section 540 Cr.P.C. is for advancing the cause of justice. Negligence on the part of the prosecution can never be a ground for taking additional evidence Hahihullah and others Vs. The State 12 BLD (HCD) 454

 

Section 561A — Inordinate delay in holding the trial amounts to gross abuse of the process of the Court and provides a ground for quashing the impgned proceeding — Of course, the circums­tances connected with the delay will have to be examined in each case to determine whether the delay constitutes an abuse of the process of the Court Md Shafiqullah Vs. The State 1 BLD (HCD) 119.Ref. PLD 1963 (Lahore) 32; PLD 1965 (SC) 287.

 

Sections 561A and 439A — Notwith­standing the finality given by Section 439A Cr.P.C. the inherent powers of the High Court Division under Section 561A are still available to secure the ends of justice Abdul Halim Pattader and others Vs. M Rahamat AH and another 1 BLD (HCD)377.

 

Section 561A — Quashing the proceeding under the Special Powers Act— A criminal preceding under the Special Powers Act is liable to be quashed if it is found that the accused person has not committed any offence under the said Act — Section 561A Cr.P.C. is not inconsistent with any provision of the Special Powers Act. Mohammad Nazrul Islam Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 65.

 

Section 561A — Company incorpo­rated under the Companies Act is a juristic person — Officers and agents of the company are not personally liable for the inability, refusal or denial of the company to pay any outstanding dues and as such the criminal proceeding against them on such counts is liable to be quashed A. F. M. Ahul Hasanat alias Raza Miah and others Vs. Idris AH and others 3 BLD (HCD) 65.

 

Section 561A — When the Managing Director of a Company did not pass the order of dismissal and he is not responsi­ble for not reinstating the dismissed worker following the order of the Labour Court for his re-instatements, the criminal proceeding against the Managing Director does not lie and it is liable to be quashed Md. Mohammadul Hoque Vs. Md. ShamsulAlam 3 HLP (HCP) 260.

 

Section 561A — When a bonafide dis­pute exists between the parties as to the right to use a trade mark, action should be taken before a Civil Court and not before a Criminal Court — The impugned crimi­nal proceeding amounts to an abuse of the process of the Court and is therefore liable to be quashed Md. Salahuddin and another Vs. Abdul Hakim and another 3 BLD (HCD) 315.Ref. 1LR 22 (Madras) 488; 11 CWN 887; AIR 1936 (Cal) 488.

 

Sections 561A 439 and 439A — Theprovision of Section 561A Cr.P.C. can not be invoked by a person after becoming unsuccessful in an incompetent application for revision which is barred by law Nader Ali Shaikh Vs. The State and another 4  BLD (AP) 7.

 

Section 561A — In the face of a spe­cific allegation of collusion between the accused Manager and the appellant, the truth of which can be ascertained only on taking evidence at the trial, the proceeding against one of the two accused cannot be quashed. Nokuleswar Saha Vs. The State 4 BLD (AP) 10Ref. 2 B L D 603.

 

Section 561A — A criminal proceed­ing against a partner of a business firm — Once it is found that it was a partnership business and the complainant and the ac the witnesses under Section 161 Cr.P.C. - In the facts and circumstances of the ise, the High Court Division committed no illegality in refusing to quash the proceeding and directing the trial Court to include the trial on the basis of the available records within 3 months — The appellate Division directed the trial Court to   conclude the trial within 3 months ailing which the proceeding will stand quashed. Azhar Ali Khan and others Vs. The State 5 BLD (AD) 75.

 

 

Section 561A — Quashing a criminal proceeding — In the absence of any challenge made in a previous civil suit between the parties regarding the genu-iness of the kabalas, the trial Court de­creed the suit — The respondent cannot be allowed to harass the appellants by starting the criminal proceeding against them and the same is quashed Md. Farooque and others Vs. The State and another 5 BLD (AD) 80.

 

Section 561A — Since the appellants helped the police in discharging their duties, whatever the appellant's real motive might have been, their prosecution in the instant case would serve no useful purpose and the impugned proceeding will amount to an abuse of the process of the Court — The proceeding is quashed. Md Khorshed Ali and others Vs. The State and another 5 BLD (AD) 223

 

Section 561A — When a competent Court finds that a prima facie case has been made out and it frames charge, the High Court Division will be reluctant to quash a proceeding unless it could be shown that on the face of the charge-sheet no offence is disclosed Mosammat Saleha Khatun Vs. The State 5 BLD (HCD) 193 Ref. 3 1 DLR 39; 34 DLR 371.

 

 

Section 561A — The Director and the Chairman of the Board of Directors of a Company are trustees in respect of the fund of the Company which is under their control and they can be proceeded against for misappropriation of the fund of the company — But this principle can not be applied to the facts of the present case — Therefore the criminal case against the appellants at the instance of the respon­dents, who retired from the company be­fore filing of the complaint, is quashed as the dispute is a civil dispute. Md Yameen and another Vs. K. A. Basilar and others 6 BLD (AD) 305.Ref. 17 DLR (SC) 52; 34 DLR (AD) 47, AIR 1963 (Cal) 64, (1884) 1 Ch Div. 616.
