Section 561A — Inherent power— In a case where there is an abuse of the process of the Court the High Court Divi­sion may exercise its discretion to inter­fere with the order passed by the Session; Judge   under Section 439A Cr.P.C. fo securing the end of justice Sultan Ahmet Mathar   Vs.   The State  and anothe 6 BLD (HCD) 158.Ref. 4 BLD (AD) 7; 36 DLR (AD) 44.

 

Section 561A — Quashing a proceec ing  — The mother quite fairly deservi the benefit of the exception under Section 361 of the Penal Code because she took away her minor daughter believing in good faith to be entitled to the lawful cus­tody of the child — In the absence of any material to show that she had any im­moral or unlawful purpose or motive for taking the girl, the act in taking away the daughter from the father's custody can not constitute offences under Sections 363, 379 and 411 of the Penal Code — No criminal case lies against the mother and the proceeding is quashed. Akter Jahan Tanzia alias Bah and another Vs. The State 6 BLD (HCD) 281

 

Section 561A — Quashing of proceed­ings — Mere making of a false or untrue statement in a document does not constitute an offence of forgery, where the document is executed by a person who purports to execute it — The ingredients of the offence of cheating are not at all attracted upon the facts alleged in the case — The proceeding is quashed Radhahallah Sarker Vs. Pijush Kanti Chakravorty and another 7 BLD (AD) 32.

 

Section 561A — Prosecution of abettors — Since the principal offender was acquitted in the previous trial, no useful purpose will be served by trying the alleged abettors in a subsequent proceed­ing — The proceeding is quashed. Twahid Khan alias Twahid Kha and others Vs. The State and others 7 BL D HCD) 11.

 

Section 561A — Quashing of proceeding — The police has a statutory right to investigate into a case and submit a report — When the police has the benefit of the exception under Section 361 of the Penal Code because she took away her minor daughter believing in good faith to be entitled to the lawful cus­tody of the child — In the absence of any material to show that she had any im­moral or unlawful purpose or motive for taking the girl, the act in taking away the daughter from the father's custody can not constitute offences under Sections 363, 379 and 411 of the Penal Code — No criminal case lies against the mother and the proceeding is quashed. Akter Jahan Tanzia alias Bah and another Vs. The State 6 BLD (HCD) 281

 

Section 561A — Quashing of proceed­ings — Mere making of a false or untrue statement in a document does not constitute an offence of forgery, where the document is executed by a person who purports to execute it — The ingredients of the offence of cheating are not at all attracted upon the facts alleged in the case — The proceeding is quashed Radhahallah Sarker Vs. Pijush Kanti Chakravorty and another 7 BLD (AD) 32.

 

Section 561A — Prosecution of abettors — Since the principal offender was acquitted in the previous trial, no useful purpose will be served by trying the alleged abettors in a subsequent proceed­ing — The proceeding is quashed. Twahid Khan alias Twahid Kha and others Vs. The State and others 7 BL D HCD) 11.

 

Section 561A — Quashing of proceeding — The police has a statutory right to investigate into a case and submit a report — When the police has - submitted the report under Section 173 Cr.P.C. finding a prima facie case, the High Court Division will  not quash  the proceeding __The High Court Division can quash a proceeding if the FIR. and the charge sheet taken together do not disclose any offence Abdul Alint Vs. The State 7 BLD (HCD) 32.

 

Section 561A — Civil dispute — The basic ingredient of an offence under Section 406 of the Penal Code is the entrustment with the dominion of the property — But in the instant case possession was made over in pursuance of a contract of deferred payment — The dispute is of civil nature arising out of breach of the contract and as such prolongation of the case amounts to an abuse of the process of the Court and the proceeding is liable to be quashed. Azizul ttoque Vs. The State 7 BLD (HCD) 132.

 

Section 561A — Quashing of the Criminal proceeding — On the facts stated in the petition of complaint no criminal offence has been made out and the sole purpose of launching the criminal proceeding is to coerce, harass and humiliate the accused and to compel him to refund the earnest money which stands forfeited as per terms of the contract — The tendency to use the Criminal Court for enforcing a civil right is highly improper — A breach of civil contract cannnot give rise to criminal prosecution Further continuation of the impugned proceeding clearly amounts to an abuse of the process of the Court and the same is liable to be quashed. Shahjahan Vs. Atiqur Rahman 7 BLD (HCD) 164.

 

Section 561A — The Sessions Judge has no power to take cognizance of the case without any police report in violation of Section 27 of the Special Powers Act — In view of this legal infirmity the proceeding is liable to be quashed. Nurul Islam and another Vs. The State and another 7 BLD (HCD) 288

 

Section 561A — Prima facie case — When the allegations prima facie disclose offences under Sections 147, 448 and 380 of the Penal Code, quashing the proceeding is not called for Haji Azizur Rahman and others Vs. Syeedul Haque Chowdhury and others 7 BLD  (HCD) 335Ref. 28 DLR(AD) 38.

 

Section 561A — Criminal liability of the legal representatives of the trustee — A trust is an obligation attached to the ownership of the property and it can be traced in the hand of the legal representatives — A mere retention of the unspent money does not amount to criminal misappropriation but if the retention is followed by an intention to wrongfully deprive the owner of its use and secures it for his own benefit, it will amount to a criminal breach of trust — In the face of a prima facie case the proceeding cannot be quashed Samarendra Nath Haider Vs. The State 7 BLD (HCD) 348.

 

Section 561A — The Village Court — The High Court Division has no jurisdiction under Section 561A Cr.P.C. to interfere with any order passed by the Village Court or the Sub-Divisional Magistrate under Section 8 of the Village Courts Ordinance, 1976 Sydul Haque Sawdagar Vs. Ahul Kashem Chowdhury and others 7 BLD (HCD) 410Ref. 32 DLR (AD) I.

 

Section 561A — Quashing of pro­ceedings — A proceeding is liable to be quashed when the allegation on the face of it appears to be groundless or is so preposterous that no man of ordinary prudence will take any notice of it — But a mere delay in lodging the complaint can not be a ground for quashing the proceeding — Doubt in the allegation is a matter to be considered at the trial. Md Shamsuddin alias Lamhu and others Vs. The State and others 8 BLD (AD) 93.

 

Section 561A The High Court Division in exercise of its inherent powers can not embark upon an enquiry to ascertain whether the prosecution case or the defence case is true. Al-haj Mamtaj Meah Vs. The State 8 BLD (HCD) 64Ref. 28 DLR (AD) 38.

 

Section 561A — Trial without juris­diction — When the Special Tribunal had no jurisdiction to take cognizance of the offence on 16.5.78 after the coming into force of Ordinance No XL of 1977 on 3.8.77, the impugned order of conviction and sentence is illegal and without jurisdiction — The Appellate Tribunal likewise had no jurisdiction to hear the appeal — The impugned order of conviction and sentence is set aside under Section 561A Cr P C Sakya Pada liarua and others Vs. The State and others 8 BLD (HCD) 71

 

Ref. 32 DLR (AD) 1; 36 DLR 200); 37 DLR 59; (1878) 3 (AC) 582; AIR 1927 (PC) 242; AIR 1950 (East Punjab) (FB) 25; 20 DLR (SC) 315; 21 DLR (SC) 123; Corpus Juris Vol  59 Page 4147

 

Section 561A — Quashing when not permissible — As the Rule has been issued and stay order has been passed before the submission of the charge- sheet or the final report and no cognizance has been taken by any competent Court, the Rule for quashing the impugned proceeding is liable to be discharged at this stage Makhul Hossain and others Vs. The State and another 8 BLD (HCD) 366.

Ref. 36 DLR (AD) 14; 26 DLR (SC) 17; AIR 1964 (SC) 703; AIR 1945 (PC) 18; AIR 1957 (Cal) 379.

 

Section 561A — Quashing Proceedings — It is now well-settled that while exercising the inherent power the High Court Division cannot embark upon an enquiry into facts — When the allegation prima facie discloses offence a proceeding can not be quashed Mrs. Manjuda Lohani and another Vs. The State 8 BLD (HCD) 438.

 

Section 561A — Expunging remarks in a judgment — The petitioner was not a party to the case in question and as such no adverse remarks should have been made against him without giving him an opportunity of being heard - No such party should be saddled with the liability to pay the cost of the proceeding — The impugned remarks are quite unnecessary and are against the principle of natural justice and therefore expunged M .V. Nurul Alum Vs. The State 8 BLD (HCD) 469.Ref. PLD 1958 (SC) 333; 14 DLR 23; 17 DLR 101.

 

Section 561A — Legal principle against quashing — When a prima facie case has been disclosed and cognizance taken, the Court will not embark upon an enquiry to ascertain whether the allegations are reliable or not and will not stifle the proceedings before the prosecution gets an opportunity to prove its case. Salema Khatun and others Vs. The State 9 BLD (HCD) 73.Ref. 28 DLR (AD) 38, 31 DLR (AD) 69; 38 DLR 18, 5 BCR (AD) 498.

 

Section 561A — Prosecution for forging a document already used in a suit — The bainapatra in question having been given in evidence in the suit no court can take cognizance of an offence covered by Section 463 of the Penal Code without complaint by the Court concerned — The criminal proceeding against the accused persons is quashed — But this will not debar the competent court to make any complaint   in   accordance   with law. Sana Mia and others Vs. The State and another 9 BLD (HCD) 209 Ref. 7 BCR (AD) 152.

 

Section 561A — Since the charge has already been framed and the date of trial has been fixed, the Court is reluctant to embark upon an enquiry as to whether the materials on record are sufficient for securing conviction Abdul Ma/id and others Vs. The State 9 BLD (HCD) 344

Ref. 28 DLR (AD) 38; 24 DLR 448; 32 DLR 182; 32 DLR (AD) 1; 34 DLR 377; 36 DLR (AD) 14; 38 DLR (AD) 18; PLD 1976 (Pesh) 225; 8 BLD (AD) 93; 8 BLD 65; 8 BLD 71; 1 BCR (AD) 68; 25 DLR (SC) 39

 

Section 561A — A Criminal proceed­ing is liable to be quashed only if the facts alleged in the FIR. or the petition of complaint, even if admitted, do not constitute any criminal offence or the proceeding is barred by any specific provision of law .V. M. Khalilur Rahman and others Vs. The State 10 BLD (AD)1.

Section 561A — Business transaction — Money fallen due in the course of long business transaction can not form the basis of a proceeding for cheating — Liability, if any, is essentially of civil nature — Civil claims are not to be brought in Criminal Courts as a con­trivance to put pressure upon the accused for repayment of dues — Civil claims are to be settled and sorted out in the Civil Court — To hold otherwise is to ignore the realities of the business world — The proceeding is quashed. Syed AH Mir and another Vs. Syed Omar AH and another 10 BLD (AD) 16H.

 

Section 561A — Inordinate delay in holding the trial constitutes a ground for quashing the proceeding — The sword of the prosecution has been hanging over the head of the petitioners since 1979 — They have been attending the Court every month — The case is being dragged on for such a long time for no fault of the petitioners, who have been made to carry the stigma of being accused before the society — This is a sheer abuse of the process of the Court and the proceeding is liable to be quashed. Md Mosharrraf Hossain and others Vs. The State 10 BLD (HCD) 110.

 

Section 561A — Authority of the High Court Division — The power of the High Court Division under Section 561A Cr P C. has not been restricted by any clause of Section 439 or by any law — The High Court Division can always act to prevent the abuse of the process of the court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice Dr. Md. Abdul Baten Vs. The State 10 BLD (HCD) 411.Ref. 41 DLR 385; PLD 1961 (Karachi) 432 (Paras 25 and 26)

 

Section 561A — Quashing of proceed­ings — Disputed questions of facts such as possession of arms, enjoyment of exemptions from having license of the arms seized and the immunity claimed by the petitioner and the scope of amnesty cannot be decided in an application under Section 561 A Cr.P.C. — These questions of facts can only be decided at the trial on taking evidence — The impugned pro­ceeding cannot be quashed. Hussion Mohammad Ershad Vs. The State 11 BLD (AD) 551.Ref. 38 DLR (AD) 18; 35 DLR 100; 34 DLR 287; 31 DLR (AD) 69; 30 DLR (SC) 58; 28 DLR(SC)38.

  

Section 561A — Jurisdiction of the High Court Division — The High Court Division has the general jurisdiction over all the subordinate criminal courts of Bangladesh — It has the inherent power to give effect to any order of any such court subordinate to it and can quash a criminal proceeding to prevent an abuse of the process of any such court or otherwise to secure the ends of justice —-The exercise of this jurisdiction will depend upon the facts and circumstances of each case — Interference even at the initial stage may be justified where facts are so preposterous that even on the admitted facts no case can stand against the accused and that a further prolongation of the proceeding would amount to an abuse of the process of the Court Haji Ohaidul Haque and another Vs. The State and another 12 BLD (HCD) 304

Ref. 28 DLR (AD) 38; 38 DLR (AD) 18; AIR 1932 (Patna) 72; AIR 1942 (Lahore) 134; PLD 1962 (Peshwar) 167; AIR 1938 (Madras) 129.

 

Section 56IA — Circumstances justi­fying quashing — The FIR discloses no allegation of misappropriation or of an entrustment of money — The charge — sheet also does not disclose a case of criminal breach of trust — Facts alleged in the FIR even if they are accepted do not constitute any offence of criminal breach of trust - The proceeding has been continuing since 1985 — The proceeding is quashed Mir Amir AH Vs. The State 12 BLD (HCD) 526.Ref. 1 BLD (HCD) 150; 1939 Cr.L.J (Karachi) 225.

 

Section 561A — Police after investiga­tion submitted charge-sheet against the accused persons under Section 409'109 of the Penal Code read with Section 5(2) of Act II of 1947 and the Special Judge took cognizance of the case and framed charges — The High Court Division refused to embark upon an enquiry of facts to ascertain the involvement or otherwise of the accused in the alleged offence M. M. Rahmatullah Vs. The State 12 BLD (HCD) 600. Ref. 34 DLR 287, 28 DLR (AD) 38; 30 DLR 58, 3 1 DLR (AD) 69.

 

Section 561A — Quashing a criminal proceeding at the earliest stage — A criminal proceeding at its earliest stage can be quashed if the facts are preposterous and even taken in their entirety do not constitute any offence under any law Asrarul Hussain Vs. Zahiruddin Ahmed and others 12 BLD (HCD) 622.Ref. 30 DLR (SC) 58; 32 DLR 182; 17 DLR (SC) 153

 

Section 561A — In the face of a clear averment in the petition of complaint that the accused totally denied the receipt of any money from the complainant, the question of civil liability does not arise and the High Court Division rightly refused to quash the impugned pro­ceeding Abdur Rahim alias A. N. M. Abdur Rahim Vs. Enamul Huq and another 12 BLD (AD) 130.

 

1280

COMMUTATION OF SENTENCE — EXTENUATING CIRCUMSTANCES

Citation: 3 BLD (HCD) 145, 3 BLD (HCD) 304, 5 BLD (HCD) 129, 6 BLD (HCD) 402. Ref. 13 DLR 646/203; 21 DLR (WP) 49; 32 DLR 227; 4 BLD 228, 7 BLD (AD) 324, 8 BLD (AD) 109. Ref. 39DLR (AD) 194, 10 BLD (AD) 89, 10 BLD (HCD) 38, 10 (BLD (HCD) 373, 4 BLD (HCD) 228 Ref.

Subject: COMMUTATION OF SENTENCE — EXTENUATING CIRCUMSTANCES

Delivery Date: 2018-07-22

COMMUTATION OF SENTENCE — EXTENUATING CIRCUMSTANCES

 

Extenuating circumstances — Consider­ing the facts and circumstances of the case and the further fact that the accused is a young man and his death sentence has remained pending for over two years, the sentence of death is altered to a sentence of transportation for life. Mujibar Rahman Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 145.

 

Extenuating circumstances Warran­ting modification of death sentence —Fact revealed that the accused sought to revenge assault and injury on his father only because of his youthful wrath and rashness — In consideration of his young age and the fact that he was rotten in the death cell for over two years the accused is sentenced to transportation for life in­stead of death — Penal Code (XLV of 1860) S 302 Abdul Majid Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 304.

 

Commutation of sentence — An irate and exasperated husband caused some in­juries to his wife without any weapon on the heat of the moment — He has a minor child by the deceased wife who has got to be looked after — It will be pretty inhuman to keep the father in confinement for long — His conviction is altered to Part II of Section 304 from Section 302 of the Penal Code and he is sentenced to suffer R.I. for 4 years only — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 376 Shafiullah alias Kala Mia Vs. The State 5 BLD (HCD) 129.

 

Commutation of Death Sentence —The condemned prisoner was used by some veteran criminals whom the court is unable to catch hold of and other culprits who engineered the whole game were not brought before the court either on the failure of the state machinery or the Public Prosecutor — The condemned prisoner participated in the war of liberation and he has been in jail hajat for 6 years before his conviction and he has been in the con­demned cell for 1 year and 5 months since his conviction — Delay in disposal of the Death reference may also be taken into consideration as an extenuating circum­stance to commute the death sentence to transportation for life — Code of Crimi­nal Procedure (V of 1898 ) S 376. Abdur Rouf and others Vs. The State 6 BLD (HCD) 402. Ref. 13 DLR 646/203; 21 DLR (WP) 49; 32 DLR 227; 4 BLD 228.

 

Commutation of death sentence —Inordinate delay in execution of the sen­tence may be a good ground for commutation of the sentence in some cases but delay which is not due to any laches of the prosecution should not be considered as a ground for commutation — Section 302 of the Penal Code does not specify in which case death sentence should be given and in which case transportation for life to be awarded but leaves the matter to the discretion of the court — Bitter matrimonial relationship played a part in the nefarious situation which cannot be overlooked — Ends of justice will be met if the appellants are sentenced to transportaton for life instead of death — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 376. Nowsher Ali Sardar and others Vs. The State 7 BLD (AD) 324

 

Sentence for murder — The High Court Division was right in taking the view that a delay of one year and seven months in disposal of the Death reference could not be taken as an extenuating factor for commutation of the death sentence.

 

Circumstances attending the crime are to be taken notice of — The occurrence followed a tenure of a rancorous married life, it was not a blissful union from the beginning and the parties thereto must have been under occasional strains — Death sentence is commuted to imprison­ment for life. Dipak Kumar Sarkar Vs. The State 8 BLD (AD) 109. Ref. 39DLR (AD) 194.

 

Commutation of death sentence —Facts showing mental agony of the ac­cused to be considered — The con­demned prisoner has been in custody since 15.6.76 — He was once before sentenced to death on 31.5.78, retried and again sentenced to death on 11.5.85 — He is in mental agony for over 10 years — His sentence is commuted to impris­onment for life — Code of Criminal Pro­cedure (V of 1898) S 376. The State Vs. Ful Mia 8 BLD (HCD) 79.

 

Death sentence — What constitutes extenuating circumstances — It is not ca­pable of any precise formulations but it will have to be judicially determined in the facts of each particular case — Among other things, grave and sudden provoca­tion is considered as an extenuating circumstance — Delay in execution of death sentence for want of confirmation cannot by itself constitute a mitigating cir­cumstance but an abnormal and excessive delay may be considered for commutation of death sentence — There was no circumstance to take lenient view in the matter of sentence to temper justice with mercy — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) Ss.367 and 374 — Penal Code (XLV of 1860) 302. Abed Ali Vs. The State 10 BLD (AD) 89.

 

Commutation of sentence — In view of the delay in the trial of the accused and disposal of the reference and appeal along with others extenuating - circumstances, justice will be sufficiently met if the sen­tence of death is commuted to imprison­ment of life — Code of Criminal Proce­dure (V of 1898) S 374 Hazrat Ali and another Vs. The State 10 BLD (HCD) 38.

 

Commutation of sentence and extenu­ating circumstances — There was no pre meditation for committing the murder — Condemned prisoner having two minor children (the younger one being only 20 days old on the date of occurrence) — Regard being had to the facts and circum­stances of the case, the sentence of death is altered to imprison-ment for life — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 374 — Penal Code (XLV of 1860) S 302. The State Vs. Kalu Bepari 10 (BLD (HCD) 373 .

 

Extenuating circumstances — Young age of the condemned prisoner and the delay in disposl of the reference are ex­tenuating circumstances for commuting the sentence of death to transportation for life — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 376 State Vs. Masudur Rahman alias Masud 4 BLD (HCD) 228 Ref. 13 DLR 646; 27 DLR 77

 

Extenuating circumstances for com­mutation of death sentences — The condemned prisoners who are under peril of death sentence for almost three years suffering from serious mental agony and torments and thereby partially purging their guilt, their life may be spred — Sentence of death commuted to one of imprisonment for life — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 302 Abul Kashem and another Vs. The State 10 BLD (HCD) 309 Ref. 1989 BSCR (Vol III) 417; 10 BLD (AD) 89; 7 BLD (AD) 212; 39 DLR (AD) 117

1281

COMPLAINT

Citation: 7 BLD (AD) 100

Subject: COMPLAINT

Delivery Date: 2018-07-22

COMPLAINT

Complaint Meaning of In or­der to constitute a complaint an allegation must be made to a Magistrate — Such an allegation does not include the report of the police officer — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 4(l)(h.) The State Vs. Aynuzzaman 7 BLD (AD) 100.

 

1282

CONFESSION

Citation: 1 BLD (HCD) 286. Ref. AIR 1931 (Lahore)38; 62 IC 570; AIR 1941 (Oudh) 517, 3 BLD (AD) 329, 3 BLD (HCD) 162, 3 BLD (HCD) 206, 3 BLD (HCD) 240 Ref. 31 DLR 3 12, 3 BLD (HCD) 293, 3 BLD (HCD) 325, 6 BLD (AD) 193 Ref. 76 IA 147; PLD 1960 (SC) 313; 12 DLR (SC)

Subject: CONFESSION

Delivery Date: 2018-07-22

CONFESSION

Confession — Confession of an accused though not a substantive evidence against other accused, the court may take such confession into consideration and can use the same to lend assurance to other evidence for the purpose of conviction of other accused — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) Ss. 3 and 30. Moharak Hossain Vs. The State 1 BLD (HCD) 286. Ref. AIR 1931 (Lahore)38; 62 IC 570; AIR 1941 (Oudh) 517.

 

Extra-Judicial confession — It is to betaken into consideration along with other evidence — Since other evidence has been found meagre, which also lacks indepen­dent corroboration, the confession of the co-accused, even if accepted as true, cannot be the basis of conviction of the appellant — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 30 Moharak Hossain alias Md Moharak Hossain Vs. The State 3 BLD (AD) 329.

 

Confessional Statement — Not legally proved nor marked exibit — Magistrate recording the confessional statement simply said that he observed all formalities Such confessional state-ment is not admissible in evidence Truth and voluntariness of the confessional statement must be venhed — In the absence of proof, confession could not be admitted in evidence nor could it be referred to by the Judge — Evidence Act (I of 1872) S 24 Mahidur alias Mahidul Islam and others Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 162.

 

Conviction solely based on confession— Conviction solely based on confession is valid in law if such a confession is be­lieved to be true and voluntary.

 

Conviction of an accused solely based on the confession of a co-accused is not valid — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 24 and 30 Abdur Rashid and others Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 206.

 

 

Retracted confession — When the retracted confession is found to be volun­tary and true and not obtained by threat, coercion and inducement, the same can be the basis for conviction — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 25. The State Vs. Abu Bakkar and others 3 BLD (HCD) 240 Ref. 31 DLR 3 12.

 

 

 

Oral confession — Question of verac­ity — When a confession does not indi­cate any injury referred to in the post mortem report being committed while murdering the victim and there being nothing in the alleged oral confession as to where, when and in what manner the murder was committed — Such oral confession not also supported by any independent witness cannot be believed — Evidence Act (1 of 1872). S 24 Sudhir and others Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 293.

 

Conviction and confession of co-ac­cused — Conviction of an accused based on the confession of a co-accused can not be sustained unless it is supported by other evidence — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 30 Safar Ali Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 325

 

Confession of a co-accused and re­tracted confession — The statement of a co-accused does not fall within the definition of evidence as it is not made on oath in presence of the person affected and its veracity is not tested by cross-examination — Though it is admissible, it is much weaker than the evidence of an approver — It is the established rule of evidence as well as rule of prudence that the confessional statement of a co-ac­cused shall not be used as the sole basis of conviction in the absence of independent corroborative evidence — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) Ss. 3 and 30.

 

Retracted confession — A retracted confession may form the sole basis of conviction of its maker but as against the co-accused the evidentiary value of re­tracted confession is practically nil and in the absence of corroboration it is uselessEvidence Act (1 of 1872) Ss. 24 -30 Amir Hossain Howlader Vs. The State 6 BLD (AD) 193 Ref. 76 IA 147; PLD 1960 (SC) 313; 12 DLR (SC) 156; PLD 1969 (SC) 89; SCMR (1970) Vol. Ill 351; PLD 1964 (SC) 65.

 

Confessional statement — Partly in­culpatory and partly ex-culpatory — The court can consider the inculpatory portion of the confessional statement

 

Retracted confession — In law it isimmaterial whether a confessional state­ment is retracted or not If the court thinks that the confessional statement is true and voluntary the same can form the basis of conviction against the maker himself — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 24. State Vs. Masudur Rahman alias Masud 4 BLD (HCD) 228.

 

Recording of confessional statement

—              Form of recording the same — con­fessional statement of the accused re­corded by the Magistrate on a plain piece of paper and signed by the Magistrate at the bottom — Usual form for recording confessional statement not used — Such confessional statement is not admissible in evidence — Defect is not curable even by subsequent examination of the recording Magistrate — Code of Criminal Pro­cedure (V of 1898) Ss. 164 and 364(3). Zaheda Bewa and another Vs. The State 5 BLD (HCD) 9. Ref. AIR 1936 (PC) 253; 20 DLR (Dhaka) 780.

 

— Retracted confession — The confes­sion made by an accused even if retracted can form the sole basis of conviction of its maker if the confession is found to be true and voluntary — Evidence Act (I of 1872) S 30.

 

 

— Whether confession of an accused can be used for corroboration — The con­fession of one accused cannot be used to corroborate the confession of another ac­cused for the purpose of convicting the other accused who have not confessed Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 30. Abdul Malik and others Vs. The State 5 BLD (HCD) 67.Ref. ILR 38 (Cal) 559; AIR 1937 (Bomb) 31; 76 IA 147; 12 DLR (SC) 217; 27 DLR (AD) 29; 60 IC 786 (Lahore); 10 DLR (Dhaka) 155.

 

Confession — Whether examination of the recording Magistrate necessary — When a confession has been recorded in accordance with law by observing all the formalities prescribed by law and the said confession is duly taken and tendered in the Sessions Court, it proves itself under Section 80 of the Evidence Act without calling the Magistrate who recorded it —The two requirements for admitting such a confession into evidence are that it was taken in accordance with law and that the identity of the accused has been satisfac­torily proved — The Privy Council de-pricated the practice of examining the Magistrate and Judges except in special circumstances such as those provided by Section 533 Cr.P.C — Evidence Act (I of 1872) S 80 — Code of Criminal Proce­dure (V of 1898) S 533. Md Emran All and others Vs. The State 5 BLD (HCD) 95 Ref. 3 DLR (Dhaka) 383; AIR 1929 (Cal) 617; AIR 1936 (Patna) 11; 12 DLR (Dhaka) 615; 30 DLR 320; AIR 1936 (PC) 253; AIR 1952 (SC) 159.

 

Confession of co-accused implicating other accused — Its effect — It is much weaker than the evidence of the approver — It is an established rule of evidence as well as rule of prudence that confessional statement of a co accused shall not be used as the sole basis of conviction in the absence of independent corroborative evidence — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) Ss. 3 and 30 Md Emran All and others Vs. The State 5 BLD (HCD) 95. Ref. 4 BLD (AD) 193.

 

Confession — What amounts to con­fession — The statement in order to amount to confession must either admit in terms of the offence or at any rate substantially all the facts which constitute the offence — The confession of a co-accused is not evidence against another co-accused whose guilt is under consideration — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) Ss 3 and 30 Abdul .Mil and others Vs. the  State 5 BLD (HCD) 137. Ref. AIR 1976 (SC) 1167; 25 DLR 41; 76 IA 147; 12 DLR (SC) 156; 27 DLR (AD) 29; 29 DLR (SQ271; 1952 SCR (Ind) 526

 

Retracted confession — It's Value — It is now well settled that conviction can be based on retracted confession alone if it is voluntary and true, though as a matter of paidence some corroboration may be asked for — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 30 Abdul J alii and others Vs. The State 5 BLD (HCD) 137.

 

Confession of co-accused — Whether evidence against other accused persons — Confession of a co-accused is not evi­dence within the meaning of section 3 of the Evidence Act — Confession of a co-accused may be taken into consideration along with other evidence — In the ab­sence of any other evidence a court can­not take into consideration the confession of a co-accused and conviction cannot be based on the sole basis of confession of a co-accused—Evidence Act (1 of 1872) Ss. 3 and 30. Mahmud Ali and others Vs. The State 5 BLD (HCD) 218 Ref. 76 TA 147; 12 DLR (SC) 156; 1952 SCR (Ind) 526; 27 DLR (AD) 29; 29 DLR (SC) 271; 4 BLD (AD) 193.

 

Confession by the accused — When can be relied upon — Confession means admission of certain facts which constitute an offence committed by the maker thereof who is charged with the offence and which is the subject-matter of the statement— Confession should be directly on thepoint admitting facts — No state­ment that contains self-exculpatory matter can amount to confession — Confession must either admit in terms of the offence or at any rate substantially all facts which constitute the offence — Evidence Act, (1 ofl872)S25.

 

Duty of the Magistrate recording confessional  statement   —It is imperative that the Magistrate recording a confessional statement must ask the maker thereof as to the motive of the confession and to ascertain the volun­tariness of the same and he must ask the accused person as to how long he was in police custody, whether any pressure was brought to bear upon him, whether he was subjected to torture or he was given any allurement or inducement — Besides that, the Magistrate must inform the accused that he is not bound to make any statement but if he makes any statement that might be used against him at the trial and that after he makes the statement he would be sent to judicial lock-up and not to the police custody — The Magistrate should endeavour to place the confessing accused at ease, dispel all or any lurking fear, inducement and hope from the mind of the accused which enable him to make of his own volition an absolutely free and voluntary statement according to the best dictates of his own inner conscience — Before proceeding to record a confes­sional statement the Magistrate must as­sure himself and satisfy his own judicial conscience about  it and this satisfaction must flow out of the answers given by the accused to the questions put to him by the Magistrate — A mere statement of satisfaction by the Magistrate does not prove that the confession was voluntary — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 164 — Evidence Act ( 1 of 1872) Ss. 24 and 28. Abdul Wahab and another Vs. The State 6 BLD (HCD) 390

 

Retracted confession — Its value — On consideration of the evidence on re­cord if it is found that a confession is vol­untary and true, conviction of the maker himself can solely be based upon the same, no matter whether it is retracted or not — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 30.

 

Confessional statement — Partly ex­culpatory and partly in-culpatory — When a confessional statement of an accused contains both exculpatory and inculpatory statements, whether it must either be accepted or rejected as a whole — In­culpatory part of the statement can be accepted rejecting the other part when there is corroborative evidence in support of the inculpatory part — Evidence Act (1 of 1872)S 30.

 

Confession of a co-accused — Con­viction of the co-accused can not be solely based on the retracted confession of an­other co-accused — The value of the re­tracted confession of an accused against a co-accused is practically nil and he can­not be convicted unless the said confes­sion is corroborated in material particulars by independent evidence on record — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 30. AH Ajgar and another Vs. The State 6 BLD (HCD) 436 Ref. 16 DLR (SC) 598; 11 DLR (WP) 58;4DLR311

 

Confessional statement against co-ac­cused — Confessional statement of the co-accused against another co-accused can be taken into consideration in a lim­ited manner — It cannot be made the foundation of the conviction in the absence of any other reliable evidence tending to prove the guilt of the accused—Such a confession may be used only in support of other evidence for corrobora­tion — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 30. The State Vs. Lalu Miah and another 7 BLD (AD) 212. Ref. AIR 1969 (SC) 422; 27 DLR (AD) 29; AIR 1952 (SC) 1; AIR 1939 (PC) 47; AIR 1952 (SC) 343

 

Confession its worth — It is no con­fession but a mere testimony by an ac­cused against the other accused when the maker does not involve himself in any part of the commission of the alleged offence—The prosecution should have examined the confessor as a witness instead of making him an accused so that the other accused could cross-examine him — If the direct oral evidence does not qualify to be trustworthy, the alleged confession can be of no avail for sustaining convic­tion — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 30 Ibrahim Motlah and others Vs. The State 7 BLD (AD) 248.

 

Confessional statement — Its lan­guage — Confessional statement should be recorded in the words of the prisoner__But it is not correct to say that confes­sion not recorded exactly in the prisoner's own words is inadmissible evidence.

 

Confessional statement — Whether its validity is affected when part of it is made after the arrival of the dafadar — If any further statement had been made when the dafadar arrived the earlier statement would not be affected as if it was not made in presence of the dafadar or while the accused was in custody of the police__The confessional statement is voluntary and true if it agrees with the established facts of the case — Evidence Act (I of 1872) Ss. 25 and 26. Nausher Ali Sorter and others Vs. The State 7BLD (AD) 324

 

Value of retracted confession — Re­daction of confession is wholly immaterial if if is found that it was voluntary as well as true — The confessional statement being true and voluntary it is alone sufficient for conviction of the accused___Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 164 — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 30  Bhagahan Chandra Chakma Vs. The State 7 BLD (HCD) 351. Ref. AIR 1957 (SC) 637; 29 DLR (AD) 271; 36 DLR 275; 12DLR(SC) 157.

 

Extra-Judicial confession — When can not be considered — The High Court Division rightly left out of consideration the extra-judicial confession which was made before the dafadar and there was some evidence of beating of the accused by the dafadar — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 24.

 

Confession — Value of— Whether the objection that the Magistrate before recording the confession did not inform the appellant that he would not be re­manded to police custody even if he did not make any confession, renders the con­fession unacceptable — There is no re­quirement of law to inform the accused as above — Of course, if the Magistrate has any reason to believe that the accused is apprehensive of the police, he may assure him as above, but that is not to say that if it were not said, the voluntariness of the confession would be' in doubt — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 164 Dipak Kumar Sarkar Vs. The State 8 BLD (AD) 109

 

Retracted confession — Its value — A judicial confession, whether retracted or not retracted, can in law validly form the basis of conviction of the maker of the confession but as a matter of prudence and caution , which has become virtually a rule of law, the court does not generally consider it safe to base a conviction on a retracted confession alone without cor­roboration in material particulars — Evidence Act (I of 1872) S 30 '

 

Requirements of a confessional state­ment — The court must affirmatively satisfy itself that the statement is voluntary and true — There must, be me­ticulous observance of all necessary for- malities and precautions provided in Sec­tion 164(3) of the Code of Criminal Pro­cedure with minute particularity so as to ensure that the confession is absolutely free from the slightest tinge or extraneous influence — Before recording a confes­sion a Magistrate is bound to make a real and substantial enquiry as to the voluntari­ness of the confession — The Magistrate must put questions with a view to finding out the real object of the confession — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 164 Habibur Rahman alias Hahib Vs. The State 6 BLD (HCD) 210 Ref. 5 BLD 9, AIR 1936 (PC) 253.

 

Confessional statement — When it loses credibility — The condemned prisoner was kept under the charge of a police personnel when he was given time for reflection — Gross illegality was committed by the Magistrate in recording the confessional statement — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 30 The State Vs. Mi-anal Islam alias Dablu and another 8 BLD (HCD) 317.

 

Confession — It means admission of certain facts which constitute an offence — Confession should be directly on the point admitting facts — No statement that contains self-exculpatory matters can amount to a confession — Confession must either admit in terms of the offence or at any rate substantially all facts which constitute offencec — Evidence Act (I of 1872)S 24.

 

Recording of Confession — Duty of the Magistrate — The Magistrate cannot be casual and act mechanically in the enquiry made from the accused before re­cording his confession — He should endeavour to place him at ease, dispel all or any lurking fear, inducement and hope from the mind of the accused to enable him to make of his own volition an absolutely free and voluntary statement according to the best dictates of his own inner conscience — Code of Criminal Proceedure (V of 1898) S 164 Abdul Wahab and another Vs. The State 8 BLD (HCD) 344.

 

Confession of co-accused — It cannot be used against other co-accused — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 24. YusufAli and others Vs. The State 8 BLD (HCD) 361.

 

Confession — Time for reflection — There is no absolute rule that a confessing accused should be given any specific time for reflection — The rule referred to in the confessional form has not the force of law — Any irregularity in recording confession is curable — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) Ss 164 and 533 Rattan Kha alias Rattan and others Vs. The State 8 BLD (HCD) 396.Ref. 19 DLR (Dhaka) 573; 20 DLR (Dhaka) 526.

 

Confession   by   statement: When not admissible in evidence -Therei s nothing to show that the accused was given any time for reflection and that any quesion was put to him to ascertain whether he was prepared to make any genuine effort to find out the real character of the confession — The omission to fill up certain paragraphs in the form for the statement is not curable__Code of Criminal Procedure (V Of 1898) Ss. 164, 364 and 533.

 

Confession   by   co-accused   — A confession made by a person affecting himself and some other persons being jointly tried may be taken into considera­tion against such other persons — But such evidence can only lend assurance to other evidence, if there be any — The same by itself cannot form the basis of a conviction of a co-accused — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 30 Mil. Azad Shaikh alias Azad Sk. Vs. The State 8 BLD (HCD) 505 Ref. 8 BLD 210; PLD 1957 (SC) (Ind) 555; 39 DLR (AD) 117

 

Extra-judicial confession — Its value By its very nature it is a very weak type of evidence — It is unsafe to base conviction of an accused on his extra­judicial confession alone — The value of such confession as evidence depends on the veracity of the witnesses to whom it was made — In a case of such confession material corroboration by evidence of unimpeachable character is required — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 24 The State and others Vs. Badsha Molla 9 BLD (HCD) 257. Ref. 6 DLR 246

 

Confessional statement — Value of The accused having being kept in police custody for three days preceding the recording of his confession, the con­fession can  not be considered voluntary—The court has first to find the confes­sional statement to be true and voluntary and only then he may place reliance on it__Extra-judicial confession made in presence of the police shall not be used against the accused — Uncorroborated confessional statement has no evidentiary value and it can not be used as evidence against other accused persons — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 164 Rustom AH and others Vs. The State 9 BLD (HCD) 477. Ref. 1968 (Pak) Cr.L.J. (Karachi) 155, 1960 PLD (Karachi) 817; 35 DLR 185, 1987 BCR (AD)508

 

Confessional statement — When it cannot be used against the accused appel­lant though it was used in an earlier case where he gave evidence as an approved The Magistrate who recorded the confessional statement was examined in court in the case against two other ac­cused — The Magistrate's statement recorded in the earlier case cannot be taken into consideration in this case as he was in the former case a witness and did not have as such the opportunity to cross-examine the Magistrate — The Magis­trate's evidence cannot be considered in this case and the confessional statement too cannot be used against the appellant Furthermore, the confessional state­ment and the evidence of the recording Magistrate having not being placed before the trial court the same cannot be used as evidence in this case — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 164 Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 33. Arthur Vs. The State 9 BLD (HCD) 485

 

Statement of accused before police

 

— When it is admissible in evidence — Such statement as far as it leads to the discovery of the dead body is a relevant fact for finding out the clue to the crime and hence admissible in evidence — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 27 Hazrat Ali and another Vs. The State 10 BLD (HCD) 38 Ref. 32 DLR 227

 

Confessional statement — When can be the sole basis for conviction — Conviction can be based solely on the confession of the maker of it if it is found voluntary and true though the rule of pru­dence may require some sort of corrobo­ration in the given facts — It is not necessary that each and every circum­stance regarding the maker's complicity must be corroborated — It is enough if the general trend of confession is substan­tiated — The court has to examine the confession in the light of the materials on record and the broad probabilities of the case.

 

Retracted Confession — Once a confession if found to be true and volun­tary, conviction can be based solely on the confession even if it is retracted — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 2.4. Hazrat Ali and another Vs. The State 10 BLD (HCD) 38 Ref. 1 BCR 105; SCR 1979 (Vol. 3) 417; 12 DLR 157; 12 DLR (SC) 156; 16 DLR (SC) 598; 19 DLR 818; 31 DLR 316; 32 DLR 227

 

Confession by a co-accused — Re­tracted during trial and partly inculpatory and partly exculpatory — Whether such confessional statement can be relied upon and upto what extent — When the con­fessional statement of a co-accused is found to be voluntary and partly exculpa­tory and partly inculpatory, the exculpa­tory part being improbable, contrary to reason and ordinary human conduct and as such false, is liable to be rejected and the inculpatory part can be relied upon even if the confessional statement is subsequently retracted by the accused during his trial — Inculpatory part of such a confessional statement can also be used against other co-accused jointly tried for the same offence — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) Ss 22-30 Ahul Kashem ami another Vs. The State 10 BLD (HCD) 309. Ref. 7 BLD (AD) 212; 39 DLR (AD) 117

 

Confessional statement — Omission or defective recording not being fatal is curable under Section 533 Cr PC. — Confession recorded in a plain sheet of paper without using the prescribed form for non-availability of printed form in the court — Magistrate observed all legal formalities in recording the statement with the exception that he did not record the questions and answers and that the memorandum recorded was not in strict terms of Section 164(3) Cr.P.C. — Such omission being considered not fatal, the defects are formal defects curable under Section 533 Cr.P.C. — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) Ss 164 and 533 The State Vs. Kalu Bepari 10 BLD (HCD) 373

 

Confession by co-accused — Section 30 of the Evidence Act contemplates that a confession made by a co-accused in a joint trial for the same offence affecting himself and others may be taken into con­sideration — In other words, the con­fession of a co-accused may lend assu­rance to the other evidence on record but the confession of a co-accused cannot lend any additional assurance to substantive evidence — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 30 Babor Ali Molla and others Vs. The State 11 BLD (AD) 256.

 

Confession — Partly true and party false — A confessional statement even if is partly true and partly false or in other words it does not disclose the full picture, can be used against the maker and there is no legal bar in upholding the conviction on the basis of the confession — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 164 Hazrat Ali and others Vs. The State 11 BLD (AD) 270.

 

Confessional statement — Recorded in plain paper — On the basis of the alleged confession the police is alleged to have recovered incriminating articles from the possession and control of the accused — The statement was alleged to have been made on 29.10. 90 and the recovery of articles was made on 23.10.90, six days ahead of the confession— Confessional statement not produced before the court nor the Magistrate examined — Confes­sion not acceptable — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 164. Gaziur Rahman Vs. The State 11 BLD (HCD) 11.

 

Confession — The duty of the Mag­istrate — After recording confession the accused person should be sent to judicial custody and he should be informed before hand that he shall not be sent back to the police custody even if he does not make any confession and if the accused is sent back to the police custody after the recording of the confession, in such a case the voluntary nature of the confession stands vitiated.

 

Weight to be attached to a confession— It depends upon the facts and cir­cumstances of each case — The most important consideration for evaluating a judicial confession is whether it appeal’s to the court to be truthful and voluntary — In order to do so, it would be necessary to go into other pieces of evidence produced by the prosecution t» see if the story given by the confessing accused stands confirmed or not.

 

Duty of the Recording Magistrate —Instructions to the Magistrate for recording confession ?e, in fact, directory in nature — The ^ole object and the dominant purpose behind all these instructions are  the Magistrate must make a real an' earnest Endeavour to ensure that the confession is free and voluntary and not caused by any inducement, threat, promise or torture — The Magistrate's satisfaction to the voluntary nature of the confession must flow out of the answers given by the accused to the questions asked by the Magistrate — Code of Criminal Pro­cedure (V of 1898) S 164 The State Vs. Md. Alt Kibria alias Shahjahan 11 BLI) (HCD) 336.

 

Confession by co-accused — Section 30 of the Evidence Act does not make a confession "evidence" within the meaning of Section 3 of the Evidence Act — It has given the court merely a discretion to take it into consideration along with other evidence in the case and in a proper case it can lend assurance to other evidence — But if there is no other evidence in the case, the confession alone cannot form the basis of conviction — The confession of a co-accused cannot be treated as sub­stantive evidence — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 30 Hannan alias A Hannan Vs. The State 12 BLI) (HCD) 147.

 

1283

CRUELTY TO WOMEN (DETERRENT PUNISHMENT) ORDINANCE, 1983

Citation: 8 BLD (HCD) 122, 9 BLD (HCD) 43, 9 BLD (HCD) 73, 10 BLD (HCD) 119. Ref. AIR 1933 (Cal) 362; 23 DLR (DAC) 126; 35 DLR 127

Case Year: 1983

Subject: Criminal Law

Delivery Date: 2018-08-27

CRUELTY TO WOMEN (DETERRENT PUNISHMENT) ORDINANCE (LX OF 1983)

 

Cruelty to Women —When the offence is not constituted — It has not been alleged anywhere that the accused attempted to cause death or grievous hurt while demanding dowry — It has been simply alleged that accused beat the informant while demanding dowry — Such an allegation does not come within the mischief of the Ordinance — Cruelty to Women (Detterrent Punishment) Ordinance (LX of 1983) Ss 6 and 10 Appeal — Informant's competence to take an appeal in a case under the Special Powers Act — In the matter of filing a complaint before the Special Tribunal the informant has no locus stand and as such it follows that she has no locus stand in the matter of filing an appeal also — The Government or the accused alone can file an appeal against any order, judgment or sentence of the Special Tribunal — The Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) Ss. 27 and 30. Firoza Begum Vs. Hor mux. AH and another 8 BLD (HCD) 122.

 

Power of Sessions Judge — In view of the case made in the FIR and the evidence of the PWs and the observation of the Sessions Judge himself that it is a devilish cruelty to a woman for dowry, the alleged offence is beyond his jurisdic­tion to be tried as an ordinary criminal case — The death reference is therefore rejected and the case is sent back to be registered as a Special Tribunal Case and tried as such — Cruelty to Women (Deterrent Punishment) Ordinance (LX of 1983) S 6 — Special Powers Act (XIV of 1974) Ss. 10 and 26 Para — 4B to Sch. of offences The State Vs. Khalilur Rahman 9 BLD (HCD) 43.

 

"Dowry" — Property or valuable security constitutes "dowry" only when it is demanded before or at the time of marriage — The husband of the victim woman or the husband's parents, guardian or any relation may commit the offence of demanding "dowry" as consideration for marriage at any time after the marriage — Cruelty to Women (Detterrent Punish­ment) Ordinance (LX 1983) S 6 Salema Khatun and others Vs. The State 9 BLD (HCD) 73.

 

Kidnapping a woman for unlawful purposes — When the charge is not sustainable — If the alleged victim is below 16 years her father can claim her custody but if she is above 16 she is entitled to go according to her free will — For the purpose of Section 366A of the Penal Code she must be between 16 and 18 years — If she is above 16 but below 18 and if no force is used to go with the accused, it will not be an offence under the Penal Code or the Ordinance — Penal Code (XLV of 1860) S 366A — Cruelty to Women (Deterrent Punishment) Ordi­nance (LX of 1983) S 4(b). Manindra Kumar Malakar Vs. The State 10 BLD (HCD) 119. Ref. AIR 1933 (Cal) 362; 23 DLR (DAC) 126; 35 DLR 127

 

1284

DOUBLE JEOPARDY

Citation: 6 BLD (AD) 94, 8 BLD (HCD) 64 Ref. 14 DLR (HCD) 96; 36 DLR (AD) 58

Subject: DOUBLE JEOPARDY

Delivery Date: 2018-07-30

DOUBLE JEOPARDY

 

Application of the rule of double jeopardy — Discharge from the criminal case can not by itself disentitle the competent authority to award punishment in accordance with the Service Rules — Similarly escape from punishment in a departmental proceed-ing by itself cannot be a ground for discharge of an accused in the criminal case Government of Bangladesh Vs. Md Misfor AH and others 6 BLD (AD) 94.

A fresh case on the same offnece —When no bar — After an illegal dismissalof an earlier case, the lodging of fresh FIR. in respect of the same offence and starting a afresh case on the basis of such FIR. is not barred — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 403 — The General Clauses Act (V of 1897) S 26. Al-haj Mamtaj Meah Vs. The State 8 BLD (HCD) 64 Ref. 14 DLR (HCD) 96; 36 DLR (AD) 58

1285

DYING DECLARATION

Citation: 3 BLD (HCD) 193, 5 BLD (AD) 63, 5 BLD (HCD) 110Ref. PLD 1978 (Lah) 1285; PLD 1977 (SC) 529; PLD 1971 (Lahore) 883, 8 BLD (AD) 152, 8 BLD (HCD) 389, 8 BLD (HCD) 459.Ref. 22 DLR (SC) 16, 9 BLD (AD) 13, 10 BLD (AD) 61, 10 BLD (AD) 251

Subject: DYING DECLARATION

Delivery Date: 2018-07-30

DYING DECLARATION

 

Dying declaration — The declaration having been made immediately after the victim was assaulted and while he was in dying state there is no reason to disbelieve it as in such condition and at such time he is not supposed to make a statement falsely implicating the accused — If believed, dying declaration can form the basis for conviction — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 32 Tuku Miah Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 193.

 

Absence of the name of the accused in the dying declaration — Whether the accused can be convicted relying on the FIR. — The name of appellant Amjad Hossain was not mentioned in the dying declaration although his name appears in the FIR. — Since the conviction of the appellants has been based on the dying declaration and the name of appellant Amjad Hossain is not mentioned therein, his conviction and sentence cannot be maintained — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 32. Amjad Hossain and others Vs. The State 5 BLD (AD) 63

 

 

 

Dying declaration — Omission about dying declaration in the FIR. — Effect of FIR. is an information relating to the commission of cognizable offences re­ported to the police by any person with the object of putting the police in motion for investigation — Absence of dying declaration in the F.I.R. does not by itself render the dying declaration unacceptable_Mere omission of some details in the FIR. does not detract from its cor­rectness — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 154 — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 32. Majihar Rahman and others Vs. The State 5 BLD (HCD) 110Ref. PLD 1978 (Lah) 1285; PLD 1977 (SC) 529; PLD 1971 (Lahore) 883

 

 

 

Dying declaration — Whether the ap­pellant is entitled to be acquitted when part of the dying declaration relating to co-accused was disbelieved — In this case the FIR. was lodged on the same day and the Magistrate recorded the victim's dying declaration on the same day — The evidence of PW1 who rushed to the victim immediately after the occurrence appears to be convincing — The trial court's acceptance of the plea of alibi of co-accused Abdur Rashid does not destroy the dying declaration — Evi­dence Act (1 of 1872) S 32(1). Abdul Hakim alias Lokman Hakim Vs. The State 8 BLD (AD) 152

 

 

 

Dying declaration — The expectation of imminent death is not a requirement for treating declaration as a dying declaration _Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 32. Nurjahan Begum Vs. The State 8 BLD (HCD) 389.

 

Dying declaration — Its credibility — Where the dying declaration is the sole basis of conviction, utmost care must be taken by the Court in considering the surrounding circumstances and compare them with the statement in the dying declaration for safe dispensation of justice It is imperative to determine not only that the dying declaration was actually made but also that it is true and genuine ___There is no denying the fact that a dying declaration having being made on the apprehension of approaching death, has a degree of sanctity under the law but in view of the state of affairs now prevailing in our society it is necessary to find out that the dying declaration was true, because truthfulness of the deceased during his life time is of no less considera­tion for the purpose — Evidence Act (I of 1872) S 32 Abdul Majid Vs.The State 8 BLD (HCD) 459.Ref. 22 DLR (SC) 16.

 

 

 

Dying declaration — Question of its credibility — The dying declaration not being a voluntary statement of the decea­sed but made in response to questions put by the doctor and the questions not being recorded by the doctor, it deserves to be ignored as it was not a voluntary statement of the deceased — It is a matter of great puzzle to see that a sinking man could make a statement with such completeness as would put a man in his full sense to shame — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 32 Kashem All Vs. The State and others 9 BLD (AD) 13.

 

Dying declaration — Way of making such a declaration — A dying declaration may be recorded by any person who is available — It may be written or it may be verbal, it may also be indicated by signs and gestures, in answer to questions, if the person making it is not in a position to speak.

 

Dying declaration — The worth that it commands — The legislature in its wisdom has put a dying declaration at par with the evidence on oath for the reason that a man under the apprehension of death is not likely to speak falsehood and involve innocent persons in preference to his assailant — That is why particular sanctity is attached to such statement and it is admissible as substantive evidence — But the Court must take care to see that the statement is genuine — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 32.

 

Dying declaration — Its utility as evidence — There is no wrong is treating a dying declaration as First Information Report, for prior to this no other information was lodged with the police regarding the assault and injury of the victim — Had the victim survived her statement would not have attained the sanctity of a substantive evidence but would remain just a First Information Report — When an injured person lodged an FIR. about his injuries at a time when there was no apprehension of his death therefrom but subsequently he succumbed to his injuries, the statement served both the purposes of dying declaration and FIR. — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 32 — Code of Criminal Procdure (V of 1898) S 154 Nurjahan Begum Vs. The State 10 BLD (AD) 61.

 

Dying declaration — Where it is highly doubtful and its probative value is little or nil — where the alleged dying declaration is the only piece of evidence against an accused and it is not free from reasonable doubt — Such a dying dec­laration cannot be accepted to form the basis of conviction — If the dying state­ment is found essentially true and genuine the Court can act upon it — Evicence Act (1 of 1872) S 32 .Shamsur Rahman alias Shamsu Vs. The State 10 BLD (AD) 251

 

1286

EVIDENCE ACT. 1872 (ACT 1 OF 1872) (Part-1)

Citation: 1 BLD (HCD) 286.Ref. 27 DLR (AD) 29; 12 DLR (SC) 156, 217; II DLR (SC) 38 & 81, AIR 1931 (Lahore) 38, 4 BLD (AD) 193.Ref. 12 DLR (SC) 156; PLD 1960 (SC) 313; 76 IA 147, 5 BLD (AD) 301.Ref. 1 I DLR (SC) 38, 5 BLD (HCD) 129.Ref. AIR 1922 (SC) 343; AIR 1976

Case Year: 1872

Subject: EVIDENCE

Delivery Date: 2018-08-27

EVIDENCE ACT, 1872 (ACT 1 OF 1872)

 

Section 3 and 30 — Confession of a co-accused — It is well settled that the confession of an accused is not sub­stantive evidence within the meaning of Section 3 of the Evidence Act — But it is also well-settled that although the con­fession of a co-accused cannot be treated as substantive evidence against the co-accused and cannot be the sole basis for conviction of another accused but still then along with other evidence the Court may take into consideration such confession and can use the same to lend assurance to other evidence. Mobarak Hossain Vs. The State 1 BLD (HCD) 286.Ref. 27 DLR (AD) 29; 12 DLR (SC) 156, 217; II DLR (SC) 38 & 81, AIR 1931 (Lahore) 38.

 

Sections 3 and 30 — Confession of a co-accused — The statement of a co-accused does not fall within the definition of evidence as it is not made on oath in presence of the person or persons affected and its veracity is not tested by cross-examination — Though it is admissible, it is much weaker than the evidence of an approver — It is the established rule of evidence as well as rule of prudence that the confessional statement of a co-accused can not be accepted as the sole basis of conviction in the absence of independent corroboration Amir Hossain Howlader Vs. The State 4 BLD (AD) 193.Ref. 12 DLR (SC) 156; PLD 1960 (SC) 313; 76 IA 147.

 

Section 3 — It is well-settled that where all the evidence is circumstantial it is necessary that cumulatively its effect should be to exclude any reasonable hypothesis of the innocence of the accused — The onus always remains with the prosecution to establish the guilt of the accused beyond reasonable doubts — To base a conviction on circumstantial evidence, circumstances established in the case must be incompatible with the innocence of the accused and must be sufficient to exlude all possibilities of their being innocent Keshab Chandra Mistry and others Vs. The State 5 BLD (AD) 301.Ref. 1 I DLR (SC) 38.

 

Section 3 — Circumstantial evidence — To base a conviction on circumstantial evidence it is necessary that circumstances proved in the case must be complete and incapable of explanation of any other hypothesis other than the guilt of the accused Shafiullah alias Kala Mia Vs. The State 5 BLD (HCD) 129.Ref. AIR 1922 (SC) 343; AIR 1976 (SC)917; AIR 1979 (SC) 190, 826.

 

Sections 3 and 30 — Confession — In order to constitute confession a statement must either admit in terms of the offence, or at any rate, substantially all the facts which constitute the offence — The confession of a co-accused is not evidence against another co-accused whose guilt is under consideration and material witnesses as to the calling away of the deceased after which he was not found till his dead body was recovered.

 

—    In the absence of any other reasonable explanation as to the safe departure of the deceased from the company of the accused-appellant, no conclusion other than the guilt of the accused can be drawn Anisur Rahman and others Vs. The State 6 BLD (AD) 791. Ref. 11 DLR (SC) 365; 16 DLR (SC) 261;32DLR320.

 

Section 3 — Benefit of doubt — In a criminal case the accused is always entitled to the benefit of doubt but it is a reasonable doubt which is considered to be a ground for giving its benefit to the accused — A faint doubt, which has no reasonable basis, is not contemplated in law. The State Vs. Tayeh Ali and others 7 BLD (AD) 265.

 

Section 3 — Circumstantial evidence _Merely because the accused had called and taken away the victim in the previous evening it will be most unreasonable to thing that none but the accused abetted the murder which took place so many hours after the taking away of the victim __It is the fundamental principle of ^he criminal jurisprudence that the circums­tantial evidence should point inevitably to the conclusion that the accused and the accused only were the perpetrators of the offence and such evidence should be incompatible with the innocence of the accused. Hossain Ali and another Vs. The State 7 BLD (HCD) 80.Ref. 33 DLR 402; PLD 1956 (SC) (Ind) 286.

 

 

Section 3 — Circumstantial evidence — The accused can not be convicted merely on the ground that the circumstantial evidence provides a ground for strong suspicion against her — If the circumstantial evidence does not furnish conclusive proof of the guilt of the accused she cannot be convicted merely on the probability of having committed the offence Alpana Rani Das Vs. The State 8 BLD (HCD) 114.

 

 

Section 3 — Circumstantial evidence _If it is proved beyond doubt that the deceased was last seen alive in the company of the accused, the latter are liable to offer satisfactory explanation as to the cause of death of the deceased — When the circumstantial evidence led by the prosecution is quite incompatible with the innocence of the accused the view that the circumstances themselves are not enough without anything more to connect the accused with the offence is contrary to the time-honoured principle of law regarding circumstantial evidence Rezaul Huq and others Vs. The State 9 BLD (HCD) 218.Ref. 37 DLR (AD) 139; 16 DLR (SC) 261; PLD 1956 (SC) (Ind) 286.

 

 

Section 3 — Circumstantial evidence _The circumstances proved in the case taken cumulatively should form a complete chain and the onus is on the prosecution to prove that the chain is complete — The prosecution cannot derive any strength from the weakness of the defence — After the links in the chain of circumstances are themselves complete. then a false defence may be called in aid lending assurance to the Court, but not that the infirmity in the prosecution case could be cured by a false defence. The State and others Vs. Bailsha Mullah 9 BLD (HCD) 257. Ref. 5 BLD (AD) 301; 5 BLD (HCD) 129; AIR 1952 (SC) 343; AIR 1976 (SC) 917; AIR 1979 (SC) 190; AIR 1984 (SC) 1622

 

Sections 3 and 5 — The injuries found by the doctor who held the post-mortem examination on the deadbody of the deceased do not tally with the injuries alleged to have been inflicted on the deceased as mentioned by the eye- witnesses __Glaring inconsistencies between the injuries on the deadbody of the deceased as found by the doctor and the evidence of the prosecution witnesses about the inujries caused by the appellants led to the conclusion that the occurrence did not take place in the manner as alleged by the prosecution. Kudu and others Vs. The State 10 BLD (HCD) 236.

 

Section 5 — Appreciation of evidence _When concurrent findings of facts are liable to interference — A careful examination of the deposition of the witnesses reveals that the evidence of the vital witnesses was not sifted and assessed according to rules of evidence by either of the courts below — The circumstances in which victim Majid received the fatal injury remained a mystery — The pro-ecution has failed to prove the charges against the accused appellant — The

Appellate Division set aside the order of conviction and sentence and acquitted the accused Shahjahan Biswas and others Vs. The State 9 BLD (AD) 18.

 

Section 5 — Appreciation of evidence _If PW 2 had actually seen the killing of his mother he would have certainly raised hue and cry to attract the neighbours and he would not have waited for half an hour to see that the assailant safely escape — On examining PW4, one of the two eye witnesses, the doctor found some abrasions on his body which could be easily fabricated for the purpose of a case __The crucial uestions why the appellants abducted him and released him after 4 days knowing that the release meant they would be implicated in a case of capital sentence — Omissions and due-con­tradictions of these two eye-witnesses were not given consideration by the courts below — The contradictions and omissions in the evidence of PW4 makes the defence case probable and as such the appellants are entitled to acquittal as a matter of right Ahul Kashem and others Vs. The State 9 BLD (AD) 122.

 

 

Sections 5 and 9 — Appreciation of the evidence relating to recognition of the accused — Recognition of the accused by the focus of the torch light when the focus was directed towards the witness is doubtful — Recognition of an unknown accused by moonlight is very much doubtful, rather it is impossible. Jamir alias Jamiruddin Vs. The State 9 BLD (HCD) 474.

 

 

Section 8 — A relevant fact — The fact that the person affected (being dead and not examined) made a complaint relating to the crime shortly after its commission is relevant and admissible under Section 8 of the Evidence Act. S. M. Quamruzzaman Vs. The State 1 BLD (HCD) 107. Ref. AIR 1954 (Mad) 215.

 

 

Sections 8 and 9 — Abscondence of the accused — The mere fact of abscondence of the accused is of little importance if there is nothing beyond that — The importance of the fact of abscondence of the accused will depend on the facts of each case — In certain cases abscondence may indicate guilt of the accused unless he explains his conduct Mobarak Hossain Vs. The State 1 BLD  (HCD) 286.Ref. AIR 1931 (Lahore) 38; 62 IC 570, AIR 1941 (Odh) 517.

 

 

Sections 8 and 27 — Incriminating object — If an incriminating object is recovered in consequence of an infor­mation given by the accused it may be allowed to be given in evidence — It is also admissible in evidence as an act or conduct of the accused Khasru alias Khorshed Vs. Tlie State 3 BLD  (HCD) 318.

 

 

Section 8 — Abscondence of the accused — Abscondence of an accused under given circumstances may be corroboration of the direct evidence of eye witnesses connecting the accused with the crime — But the abscondecne of an accused cannot be treated to be corroboration of the confessional state­ments of another accused so as to base thereon the conviction of the absconding accused Amir Hossain Hawlader Vs. The State 4 BLD  (AD) 193.Ref. PLD 1969 (SC) 89; PLD 1974 (SC) 65; The Supreme Court Monthly Report (1970) Vol III, 351.

 

 

Section 8 — Abscondence of the accused after the commission of the offence — Abscondence by itself is not an incriminating matter, for even an innocent person sometimes absconds to avoid harassment by the police — In some cases a person with guilty knowledge also absconds — It is the facts and circumstances of the case which decide whether abscondence is due to any guilty knowledge or to anv intention to avoid harassment by the police The State Vs. Lain Miah and another 7 BLD (AD) 211.

 

 

Section 9 — Identification of accused — The accused was not recognised during the commission of the dacoity and no T I Parade was held — Recognition of the accused in the thana hajat at the instance of the OC is of no value Mahidur alias Mahidul Islam and ohters Vs. The State. Ref. 3 BLD (HCD) 162.

 

 

Section 9 — Value of T.I. Parade — The evidence of identification held at the stage of investigation can be used only to corroborate the substantive evidence given by the witnesses in the court — The value of identification in a T.I. Parade depends on the effectiveness of precau­tions taken against the identifying witness having any opportunity of seeing the accused to be identified in the parade. Hajrat All and others Vs. The State 5 BLD (HCD) 151.Ref. AIR 1972 (SCD) 283; AIR 1973 (SC)2190 AIR 1974 (SC) 791.

 

Section 9 — Evidence of identification of the accused — Evidence on identification per see is a weak type of evidence and it is not to be readily believed — Conviction may be based on the identification evidence alone if it is established beyond doubt that the witness correctly recognized the accused and that there was sufficient light to facilitate such recognition — It will be unsafe to base conviction on identification evidence alone unless such evidence is corrobo-rated by circumstances which may indicate that the accused took part in the commission of the offence Tafazzal Haque and another Vs. The State 6 BLD (HCD) 418

 

Section 9 — Value of T.I. Parade — In the absence of the Magistrate the defence obviously could not cross-examine him with regard to the proceedings of the T.I. Parade and as such the value of the T.I Parade is almost reduced to nil — T.I. Parade was held after the witness had seen the accused — So the identification of the accused in the T.I. Parade is of no consequence. Shahidullah and another Vs. The State 7 BLD (AD) 27.

 

Section 24 — Confessional statement not legally proved and not marked exhibits _The Magistrate recording the con­fessional statements simply stated in his evidence that he observed all the formalities and said nothing beyond that __He did not say that the statements were recorded according to the statements of the accused or that they were read over to the accused or that they signed them — In the absence of such proof the confessions could not be admitted in evidence nor could they be referred to by the Judge Mahidur alias Mahidul Islam and others Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 162.

 

Sections 24-30 — Confession — It is well-settled that as against the maker himself his confession, whether judicial or extra-judicial and whether retracted or not retracted, can validly form the sole basis of his conviction if the court is satisfied and believes that it was true and voluntary and it was not obtained by inducement, coercion or torture — It is also well settled that in the absence of any supporting evidence the evidence of a co-accused cannot be the basis of the conviction of another accused Ahdur Rashid and others Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 206.

 

Section 24 — Oral confession — It's veracity — When a confession does not at all indicate any injury referred to in the post-mortem report being committed while murdering the victim and nothing being said in the alleged oral confession as to where, when and in what manner the murder was committed, such a confession cannot be believed without independent corroboration. Sudhir and others Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 292.

 

Sections 24-30 — Retracted confession—Even a retracted confession if believed to be true and voluntary may form the sole basis of conviction of its maker but as against the co-accused the evidentiary value of a retracted confession is practically nil. Amir Hossain Hawlader Vs. The State 4 BLD (AD) 193.Ref. 12 DLR (SC) 156; PLD 1960 (SC) 313; PLD 1969 (SC) 89; PLD 1974 (SC) 65; 76 IA147.

 

Section 24 — Confessional statement—Partly inculpatory and partly ex­culpatory — The Court can consider the inculpatory portion of the confessional statement and exclude the exculpatory portion of the confessional statement.A confession, whether retracted or not, can form the basis of conviction of its maker if it is found true and voluntary The State Vs. Masudur Rahman 4 BLD (HCD) 228.

 

 

Section 24 — Confession — Con­fession means admission of certain facts which constitute an offence committed by the maker thereof and it should be directly on the point admitting facts — It must either admit in terms of the offence or at any rate substantially all facts which constitute the offence.

 

 

Duty of the recording Magistrate —The Magistrate recording the confessional statement should endeavour to place the confessing accused at ease, dispel all or any lurking fear, inducement and hope from the mind of the accused to enable him to make of his own volition an absolutely free and voluntary statement according to the best dictates of his own inner conscience — Before recording a confessional statement the Magistrate must assure himself and satisfy his own judicial conscience about it and his satisfaction must flow out of the answers given by the accused to the questions put to him by the Magistrate Abdul Wahah and another Vs. The State 6 BLD (HCD) 390.

 

Section 24 — Extra Judicial Confession __The extra-judicial confession made before the dafadar, who gave the accused some beating is not admissible in evidence Dipok Kumar Sarkar Vs. The State 8 BLD (AD) 109.

 

Section 24 — Confession of co-accused — It cannot be used against other co-accused Yusuf Ali and others Vs. The State 8 BLD ( HCD) 361.

 

Section 24 — Extra-judicial confession __By its very nature it is a very weak type of evidence and as such it is unsafe to base a conviction on an extra-judicial confession — The value of such a confession depends on the verasity of witnesses to whom it was made and it requires    material  corroboration by evidence of unimpeachable character. The State and others Vs.    Badsha Molla.9BLD (HCP) 257. Ref. 6 DLR 246.

 

Section  24 — Confessional statement __Conviction can be based solely on the confession of its maker if it is found true and voluntary, although the rule of prudence may require some sort of corroboration — It is not necessary that each and every circumstance regarding the maker's complicity must be corroborated _It is enough if the general trend of confession is substantiated — The Court has to examine the confession in the light of the materials on record and the broad probabilities of the case.Once a confession is found to be ture and voluntary conviction can be based solely on it even if it is retracted. Hajrat Ali and another Vs. The State 10 BLD (HCD) 38.Ref. 12 DLR (SC) 156; 16 DLR (SC) 598; 19 DLR 818; 31 DLR 3 16, 32 DLR 227; 1 BCR 105; SCR 1979 Vol. 3, Page 417.

 

Section 24-30 — Confessional State­ment — Partly inculpatory and partly exculpatory — When a confession is found to be voluntary and partly exculpatory and partly inculpatory, the Court may reject the exculpatory portion and accept the inculpatory portion thereof __Even if subsequently the confession is retracted, the Court can rely on such a confession and the inculpatory part of such a  confessional statement may be used against the other co-accused jointly tried for the same offence. Ahul Kashem and another Vs.  The State 10 BLD (HCD) 309 Ref. 7 BLD (AD) 212; 39 DLR (AD) I 17.

 

Section 25 — Retracted confession — When the retracted confession is found to be true and voluntary and not obtained by threat, coercion and inducement the same can be the basis for conviction The State Vs. Abu Bakkar and ohters 3 BLD (HCD) 240Ref. 31 DLR 3 12.
