Sections 25, 26 and 27 — Admissibility in evidence — Any statement made to a police officer is inadmissible in evidence under Section 162 Cr.P.C. and any confession made to a police officer is inadmissible under Sections 25 and 26 of the Evidence Act — But section 27 of the Evidence Act is an exception to those three sections — When any fact is deposed to as discovered in consequence of any information received from any accused during police custody, so much of such information, whether it amounts to a confession or not as it relates distinctly to the fact thereby discovered is admissible in evidence — In the instant case the first part of the statement that the accused "had killed Haji Yeasin Ali and five others" in admissible though the second part of the statement that they buried the dead bodies in the tarmaric field is admissible — This is so admissible in view of the fact that the truth of this statement made to the police has been sanctified and guaranteed by the discovery of the dead bodies from the place pointed out by the accused — Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898) S 162 Mohammad Siddiqur Rahman and others Vs. The State 7 BLD  (AD) 93.

 

 

Sections 25 and 26 — The validity of a confessional statement how far affected by the presence of a dafadar — When part of the confessional statement is made before the arrival of the dafadar and the remaining part of the confessional statement is made after his arrival the earlier part of the statement will not be affected since it was made when the accused was not in police custody When a confessional statement is voluntary and true and it agrees with the established facts of the case it can be safely accepted.

 

Language of the confessional Statem­ent — Confessional statement should be recorded in the words of the prisoner — But it is not correct to say that a confession not recorded exactly in the prisoner's own words is inadmissible in evidence Nowsher AH Sarder and others Vs. The State 7 BLD (AD ) 324.

 

 

Sections 25 and 27 — Confession made to a police officer — Section 25 of the Evidence Act excludes from evidence a confession made by an accused to a police officer under any circumstances but Section 27 provides an exception to the prohibition imposed by Section 25 to the extent that any information even by way of confession made in police custody, which relates distinctly to the fact discovered, is admissible in evidence against the accused Bashar AH and others Vs. The State 12 BLD (HCD) 225.

 

Section 27 — Admissibility of information furnished by accused — The information given by the accused that he concealed his wife's dead body in the latrine-well while being in the custody of the police is admissible in evidence as this information was followed by the recovery of the deadbody therefrom Dipok Kumar Sarkar Vs. The State .8 BLD (AD) 109

 

Section 27 — Statement of accused before police when admissible in evidence- Such statement as far as it leads to the discovery of the dead body or other incriminating materials is a relevant fact for finding out the clue to the crime and hence admissible in evidence Hazrat AH and another Vs. The State 10 BLD (HCD) 38.Ref. 32 DLR 227; 7 BLD (AD) 93.

 

Section 30 — Confession of a co-accused — The confession of a co-accused though not a substantive evidence against the other accused, the court may take such confession into consideration to lend assurance to other evidence for the purpose of conviction of other accused Moharak Hossain Vs. The State 1 BLD (HCD) 286.Ref. 27 DLR (AD) 29; 12 DLR (SC) 156 and 217; 11 DLR (SC) 38 and 81.

 

Section 30 — Extra-judicial confession _It may be taken into consideration along with other evidence — Since other evidence is meagre and it lacks independent corroboration, the confession of the co-accused even accepted as true cannot be the basis of conviction of the accused appellant Mil. Mohiiruk Hossain Vs. The State 3 BLD (AD) 329.

 

 

Section 30 — Conviction on the confession of a co-accused — Conviction of an accused solely based on the confession of a co-accused is not valid in law Abdur Rashid and others Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 206.

 

 

Section 30 — Conviction of an accused on the confession of a co-accused — conviction of an accused based on the confession of a co-accused cannot be sustained unless there are other evidences on which the conviction can be based. Safar All and others Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 325.

 

 

Section 30 — Retracted confession — The confession made by an co-accused even if retracted can form the sole basis of conviction of its maker if the confession is found to be true and voluntary.

 

Confession of a co-accused — Under certain circumstances the confession of a co-accused can be taken into considera­tion against other accused persons as well __But the confession of one accused cannot be used to corroborate the confession of another accused for the purpose of convicting the other accused who have not confessed Abdul Malik and others Vs. The State 5 BLD (HCD) 67.Ref. 16 DLR (SC) 598; 12 DLR (SC) 157 and 217; 29 DLR (AD) 271; 21 DLR (SC) 61; AIR 1956 (SC) 9; ILR 38 (Cal) 559; AIR 1937(Bomb) 31; 76 IA 147; ILR 54 (Mad) 75; 27 DLR (AD) 29; 60 IC 786 (Lahore). 10 DLR (Dhaka) 155.

 

 

Sections 30 and 3 — Value of the confession of a co-accused - - It is much weaker than the evidence of an approver—It is an established rule of evidence as well as a rule of prudence that the confessional statement of a co-accused shall not be used as the sole basis of conviction in the absence of independent corroborative evidence Mil Entran All and others Vs. The State 5 BLD (HCD) 95.Ref. 4 BLD (AD) 191.

 

 

Sections 30 and 3 — Confession of co-accused — The confession of a co-accused is not evidence against another co—accused whose guilt is under consideration Retracted confession — A confession found to be true and voluntary may be the sole basis of conviction even if retracted but as a matter of prudence some corroboration is asked for Abdul Jalil and others Vs. The State 5  BLD (HCD) 137Ref. 25 DLR 41; 27 DLR (AD) 29; 29 DLR (SC) 271, 12 DLR (SC) 156; AIR 1976 (SC) 1167, 76 IA 147; 1952 SCR 526.

 

 

1287

EVIDENCE ACT, 1872 (ACT 1 OF 1872) (Part-2)

Citation: 6 BLD (HCD) 436Ref. 16 DLR (SC) 598; 1 1 DLR (WP) 58, 4 DLR 311, 7 BLD (AD) 212.Ref. AIR 1969 (SC) 422; 27 DLR (AD) 29, 7 BLD (AD) 248. Ref. PLD 197.1 (SC) 469; PLD 1959 (SC) 377; PLD 1962 (SC) 320; PLD 1963 (SC) 157, 7 BLD (HCD) 351Ref. 12 DLR (SC) 157,

Case Year: 1872

Subject: Law of Evidence

Delivery Date: 2018-08-27

 

EVIDENCE ACT, 1872 (ACT 1 OF 1872)

 

 

Section 30 — Confession — Once a confession is found to be true and voluntary, the maker of the confession may be convicted solely on the basis of his confession, even if it is retracted

 

Confessional statement partly exculpa­tory and  partly  inculpatory The inculpatory part of the statement can be accepted and acted upon when there is corroborating evidence in support of the inculpatory part.

 

Retracted confession of a co-accused- Value of a retracted confession of an accused against a co-accused is prac-ticially nil Ali Asgar and another Vs. The State 6 BLD (HCD) 436Ref. 16 DLR (SC) 598; 1 1 DLR (WP) 58, 4 DLR 3 1 1

 

Section 30 — Confession of a co — accused — It cannot be made the foundation of the conviction if there is no other reliable evidence tending to prove the guilt of the accused — Such a confession can be used only in support of other evidence for corroboration The State Vs. Lalu Miah and another 7 BLD (AD) 212.Ref. AIR 1969 (SC) 422; 27 DLR (AD) 29.

 

Section 30 — Ex-culpatory confession __When the maker of a confession does not involve himself in the commission of the alleged offence, it is no confession at all — It is at best a statement against the other accused — In such a case the prosecution should examine the confessor as a witness instead of making him an accused in the case — If is the direct oral evidence does not qualify to be trustworthy, the alleged confession can be of no avail for sustaining conviction. Ibrahim Mollah and others Vs. The State 7 BLD (AD) 248. Ref. PLD 197.1 (SC) 469; PLD 1959 (SC) 377; PLD 1962 (SC) 320; PLD 1963 (SC) 157.

 

Section 30 — Retracted confession — If a confession is found to be true and voluntary, it can form for the sole basis of conviction, even if subsequently retracted Bhaguhan Chandra Chakma Vs. The State 7 BLD (HCD) 351Ref. 12 DLR (SC) 157, 29 DLR (AD) 271; 36 DLR 275; AIR 1957 (SC) 637 5 BLD (HCD) 137

 

Section 30 — Value of retracted confession A  judicial confession, whether retracted or not, can validly form the basis of conviction of the maker of confession but as a matter of prudence and caution, which has become virtually a rule of law, the Court does not generally consider it safe to base a conviction on a retracted confession without corrobora­tion in material particulars. Hahihur Rah m a alias Hahih Vs. The State 8 BLD (HCD) 210. Ref. 5 BLD (HCD) 9; AIR 1936 (PC) 253.

 

Section 30 — Value of a confession of a co-accused — A confession made by a person affecting himself and some other persons being jointly tried may be taken into consideration against the co-accused Section 30 — Confession of a co-accused — Such a confession can not form the basis of conviction of other accused persons but it can lend assurance to other evidence on record — The confession of a co-accused cannot lend any additional assurance to the substantive evidence liabor Ali Moilah and others Vs. The State 11 BLD (AD) 256.

 

Section 30 — Confession of a co-accused — Section 30 of the Evidence Act does not make a confession "evidence" within the meaning of section 3 of the Evidence Act — The confession of a co-accused can never be treated as a substantive evidence — In a proper case the Court may take such a confession into consideration along with other evidence Hannan alias A. Hannan Vs. The State 12 BLD (HCD) 147.Ref. AIR 1952 (SC) 159. PLD 1960 Lahore 3 1; 37 DLR (AD) 139.

 

Section 32(2) — Ordinary course of business — The phrase occurring in section 32 (2) of the Evidence Act does not aply to any particular transaction of an exceptional kind but it applies to business or employment in which the declaring was ordinarily or habitually engaged  .V. M Quamruzzaman Vs. The State 1 BLD (HCD) 107 Ref. 13 CWN 71.

 

Section 32 — Dying declaration — If believed, a dying declaration can form the basis of conviction Tuku Miah Vs. The State 1 BLD (HCD) 193

 

Section 32 — Dying declaration — The name of accused Amjad Hossain has not been mentioned in the dying declaration although his name appears in the FIR. — Since his conviction has been based on the dying declaration in which he has not been implicated, his conviction cannot be maintained. Amjad Hossain and others Vs. The State 5 BLD (AD) 63.

 

Section 32 Omission in the FIR - Minute details about the occurrence are not usually found in the FIR. — Mere omission of some details in the FIR. such as the story of dying declaration does not render such a declaration un-acceptable, if otherwise believed Majihur Rahman and others Vs. The State 5 BLD (HCD) 110.Ref. PLD 1978 (Lahore) 1285; PLD 1977 (SC) 529; PLD 1971 (Lahore) 883; AIR 1960 (Raj) 24; 31 DLR (AD) 101.

 

 

Section 32 — Dying declaration — The expectation of imminent death is not a requirement for treating a dying declara­tion as a valid dying declaration Nurjahan Begum Vs. The State 8 BLD (HCD) 389.

 

Section 32 — Dying declaration — it's credibility — Where a dying declaration is the sole basis of conviction, utmost care must be taken by the Court in considering the surrounding circumstances and compare them with the statement in the dying declaration for safe dispensation of justice — It is imperative to determine whether the dying deceleration is true and genuine, particularly in view of the state of affairs now prevailing in our society Abdul Majul Vs. The State 8 BLD (HCD) 459.

 

Section 32 — Dying declaration — It may be recorded by any person who is available near about — It may be written or verbal and it may also be indicated by signs and gestures in answer to questions, if the person making it is not in a position to speak — It is not necessary that it should be recorded by the Magistrate Sanctity of dying declaration — Although law attaches a particular sanctity to such a statement and it is admissible as substantive evidence, the Court must take care to see that the statement is really genuine Dying declaration — It's utility as evidence and as an F I R — When an injured person lodges an FIR about his injuries at a time when there was no apprehension of his death therefrom but subsequently he succumbs to his injuries, his statement serves both the purposes of dying declaration and FIR Nurjahan Begum Vs. The State 10 BLD (AD) 61.

 

Section 32 — Dying declaration — When the alleged dying declaration, which is the only piece of evidence ag accused is not free from reasonab such a dvmg declaration cannol basis of conviction — Genuinene: dying declaration must be consr the light of the circumstances of and the evidence on record Sk. S Rahman alias Shamsun Vs. State. 10 BLD (AD) 251.

 

Section 32 -Dying declaiat hearsay evidence — The statemer deceased shortly before his murder circumstances of the transaction eventually resulted in his death is ac in evidence. Ahul Kashem and ana The State 10 BLD (HCD) 309.

 

Section 33 - Confessional st of an approver - The Magistra recorded the confessional statetni examined in the Court in the case two other accused -- The Mag statement recorded in the earli< cannot be taken into consideratioi latter case as the accused in the case was a witness and as such he occasion to cross-examine the Ma — So, the Magistrate's evidence previous case cannot be considers present case and the confi statement of the previous case can used against him in the instan Augur Vs. The State 9 BLD (HCD) 485 Ref. AIR 1959 (SC) 13; AIF (Lahore) 15; AIR 1920 (Lahore) 37 [969 (Lahore) 1071; AIR 1935 ( 799; AIR 1937 (Lahore) 551; All (All) 43; AIR 1929 (Nag) 189.

 

Sections 45 and 157 — Corroborative evidence — The Doctor did not state in his evidence that there was anv fracture of bone in the hand of the victim His evidence before the Court is a substantive evidence* while his medical certificate is only a corroborative evidence — The corroborative evidence cannot be con­sidered without the substantive evidence Mil Hadiuzzatnan alius Abilul Hadi a nil others Vs. The State 6 BLD (AD) 191.

 

Section 60 -Hearsay evidence Generally speaking the statement or declarations of persons not called as witnesses but repeated bv a third person are excluded from evidence as hear say — But when it is proposed to establish by evidence nor the truth of the statement but the fact that if was made, there can be no objection in receiving the same in evidence S. M. Quamruzzainan Vs. The State 1 BLD (HCD) 107.Ref. AIR 1942 (Car) 214; 97 IC 785.

 

Section 60 — Hearsay evidence — It is hearsay and inadmissible when the object of the evidence is to establish the truth of the statement but it is not hearsay and is admissible when it is proposed to establish not the truth of the statement but the fact that it was made Shaflulla alias Kala Miah Vs. The State 5 BLD (HCD) 129.

 

Section 64 — Admissibility of news­paper report — Probative value of such report — Although a newspaper report is. admissible in evidence without formal proof yet the paper ipso facto is no proof of its contents — The newspaper report cannot be treated as proof of the facts stated therein Nurul Islam and others Vs. The State 7 BLD (HCD) 193Ref. AIR 1925 (Lahore) 299, AIR 1961 (Punjab) 215; AIR 1951 (SC) 1376.

 

Sections 64 and 65 — Best evidence - The requirement of law is that the best evidence should always be given — Primary evidence is the best evidence which affords the greatest amount of certainty of facts in question — Unless it is shown that the production of the best evidence or the primary evidence is out of a party's power, no other proof of fact is generally admitted — The oral testimony as to proof of shortage of stamp and stationary is inadmissible in evidence when the documentary evidence to prove the same was available and purposely withheld Sk. Abdul Majid Vs. The State 7 BLD (HCD) 413.

 

Section 80 — Examination of the Magistrate recording confession — When the confession has been recorded in accordance with law by observing all the formalities prescribed by law it becomes admissible in evidence under Section 80 of the Evidence Act without calling the Magistrate who recorded it — The two requirements for admitting such a con­fession into evidence are that it was taken in accordance with law and that the identity of the accused has been satisfactorily proved. Mil Emran AH and others Vs. The State 5 BLD (HCD) 95.Ref. 33 DLR 320; 3 DLR (Dhaka) 383; 12 DLR (Dhaka) 615, AIR 1929 (Cal) 617; AIR 1936 (PC) 253; AIR 1952 (SC) 159

 

Section 101 — Burden of proof— The prosecution must prove every link in the chain of evidence — Where the vital link in the chain of evidence is broken the accused cannot be convicted Mil Nasir alias Nasir Vs. The State 9 BLD (HCD) 502.

 

Section 105 — Burden of proving the exception — The mere fact that the victim survived for two weeks on account of treatment does not bring the case to one under the exception to Section 300 of the Penal Code - In the absence of anv material on record to bring the case within the exception it cannot be held that the offence is of culpable homicide not amounting to murder. Mil. Abdul Majid SarkarVs. The State 8 BLD (AD) 71.

 

Section 105 — Burden of proving the exceptions — The onus to establish special plea like the plea of the right of private defence of life and property or a plea of alibi is upon the accused and the Court shall presume the absence of any circumstances which bring their action within the exceptions of the offence charged with — In the absence of any material on record a Court can not be called upon to accept such a plea — In the instant case it was the duty of the defence to file as exhibit the petition of complaint of the counter case or at least the accused should have submitted it as part of their statement before the Court. Tayeh Ali and others Vs. The State 9 BLD (AD) 110.

 

Section 106 — Special Knowledge — Onus of proof— If the maid servant had died in any other circumstances other than by kicking, it was within the special knowledge of accused Mokles Mridha on whom lav the onus to prove the circumstances leading to the murder of victim — He was the master of the maid servant and it is in his house that she suddenly died although she got no ailment prior to her death and the accused hurriedly burried her — The conduct of the accused is highly incriminating. Abdul Hakim Vs. Mokles Mridha and others 6 BLD (AD) 174.

 

Section 106 — Special Knowledge — Section 100 of the Evidence Act is attracted only in exceptional cases where a relevant fact is pre-eminently within the knowledge of the accused — In such cases the accused is to prove a fact which is essentially within his knowledge — Of course, the burden of the accused is lighter than that of the prosecution, because the Court is to consider his plea only after, and not before, the prosecution leads evidence for sustaining a conviction. The State Vs. Mofazzal Hossain Pramanik 11BLD (AD) 302. Ref. AIR I960 (Madras) 218; AIR 1972 (SC) 608; AIR 1929 (PC) 1 10; AIR 1965 (SC) 97.

 

Section 106 — Conduct of the accused — The conduct of the accused cannot be accepted as the basis of conviction but it can only lend support to other evidence, oral or documentary, besides the conduct of the accused The State Vs. Badarddin 12BLD (HCD) 345.Ref. 42 DLR 440; 33 DLR 274; 9 DLR (WP) 1, 24 DLR 164.

 

Sections 114 and 133 — Uncorrobo­rated testimony of victim girl — The Court may treat her to be unworthy of credit unless she is corroborated in material particulars — In case the Court decides to accept her uncorroborated testimony he should state reasons for doing so Abdul Quililus anil another Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 1.Ref. 11 DLR 249; 12 DLR (SC) 165; I9DLR 259; 14 DLR 821; 10 DLR 532; 2(1916) KB 658.

 

Section 114 — Adverse presumption — When there is dependable oral evidence to prove the place of occurrence, the failure of the I O to seize blood stained earth from the scene will not shift the place of occurrence Mofazzel Hossain alias Mil. Mofazzel Hossian anil another Vs. The State 7 BLD (HCD) 406.

 

Section 114(g) — Non examination of the Investigating Officer — The defense having not drawn the attention of any of the witnesses as to any contradiction between his deposition in the Court and his statement before the police, the non -examination of the I O caused no prejudice to the defense Bhaguhan Chandra Clwkma Vs. The State 7 BLD  (HCD) 351.

 

Section 114(g) — Duty of the prosecution to call all material witnesses to prove its case — If all the witnesses are not called without sufficient reasons being shown, the Court may draw adverse inference against the prosecution — Non-production of witnesses named in the FIR and charge sheet weakens the prosecution case and the Court should reasonably draw an adverse presumption against the prosecution Abdul liahar alias Abu I liahar and others Vs. The State 5 BLD (HCD) 4

 

Section 114(g) —Non-examination of material witnesses — Non-examination of important and impartial witnesses without sufficient explanation gives rise to an adverse presumption against the prosecu­tion Failure to seize the blood stained earth from the place of occurrence and the wearing apparels of the deceased raise an adverse presumption against the prosecu­tion case and renders the same unaccep­table Moinullah and another Vs. The State 12 BLD (HCD) 100.Ref. 5 BLD 84.

 

Section 114(g) — Withholding of material witnesses raises adverse presump­tion against the prosecution Lalu alias Lai Miah Vs. The State 11 BLD (HCD) 1Ref. 5 BLD 84; 8 BLD 100.

 

Section 114(g) - Withholding of material witnesses — If the prosecution withholds material witnesses with oblique motives adverse presumption must be drawn against the prosecution, Gaziur Rahman Vs. The State 11 BLD (HCD) 11.

 

Section 118 — Competencey of witnesses Relationship by itself is no ground for discarding the evidence of the witnesses - - Enmity cuts both ways and it cannot be a ground for disbelieving an eye witness when the evidence appears to be true and reliable  Mahitullah Pk. and others Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 277 Ref. 6 DLR (Dhaka) 647.  10 DLR (Dhaka) 61; 19 DLR (SC) 241.

 

Section 118 — Child witness— Though a witness is of tender age he may be able to give intelligent answers to the questions put to him and he may figure as a natural and truthful witness — When the trial Judge having the advantage of seeing the demeanors of a child witness on dock finds him a natural and normal witness, his evidence can be relied upon Ahul Kashem and another Vs. The State 10 BLD (HCD) 309.Ref. 25 DLR (Dhaka) 41; PLD 1978 (SC) (AJ & K) 102.

 

Section 134 — Solitary testimony — On careful examination of the solitary evidence of a single witness if the Court finds the evidence reliable and free from all taints and suspicion, it can act upon it and base conviction thereon Shahidullah and another Vs. The State 7BLD (AD) 27.Ref. PLD 1957 (SC) (Ind) 525.

 

Section 134 — A Judge may convict an accused solely on the basis of the unimpeachable evidence of the police officer who made the search and seizure disbelieving the seizure list witnesses Nurul Islam Vs. The State 8 BLD (HCD) 106.

 

Section 134 — Evidence of a single witness — The conviction can be based on the evidence of a single witness of unimpeachable quality, Gaziur Rahman Vs. The State 11 BLD (HCD) 11.

 

Section 134 - - Conviction on the basis of a single witness — It is the quality and not the quantity that matters most — Ever on the basis of the evidence of a single witness conviction can be maintained provided the witnesses are found to be wholly and fully reliable. Md. loynal Ahedin Vs. The State 11 BLD (HCD) 70 Ref. 4 BCR (AD) I 14; 29 DLR (SC) 21 I; 7 BLD (AD) 27; 8 BLD (HCD) 106.

 

Section 134 — Conviction on the evidence of single witness — Conviction of an accused can be based even upon the evidence of a single witness if the Court finds him above reproach or suspicion and wholly reliable Ashrafuddin Vs. The State 11 BLD (HCD) 435.Ref. 1957 PLD (SC) (Ind) 525. 5 DLR (PC)64.

 

Section 134 — Solitary witness — A conviction can be based on the evidence of a solitary eye-witness if his evidence is found to be full, complete and self-contained Abdul Hai Sikder and another Vs. The State 12 BLD (AD) 1.

 

Section   134 — No particular number of witnesses is necessary to prove a case It is not the quantity but the quality of the witnesses which deserves considera tion. Shafiuddin and other Vs. Minhajuddin Chowdhury and another 12 BLD (BCD) 301 Ref. 29 DLR (SC) 211; 7 BLD (AD) 27; 8 BLD (HCD) 106; 11 BLD (HCD) 11 and 70.

 

Section 135 — Order of production and examination of witnesses — The Public Prosecutor's privilege and discretion to determine the order in which the witnesses will be produced and examined is subject to the limitations of Section 135 of the Evidence Act Md. Abdul Wahab alias Abdul Wahah Vs. The State 10 BLD (AD) 280.

 

Sections 145, 155 and 157 — Judicial statement of a witness — It cannot be treated as substantive evidence — Such a statement can only be used for corrobora­ting or contradicting the maker of the statement Khasru alias Khorshed Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 318.Ref. 33 DLR 320; 50 CWN (PC) 353; AIR 1942 (Cal)36.

 

Section 145 — Evidence of the witness in the Committing Court — The evidence of a witness in the Committing Court can be accepted by the Court only when the witness is examined in the Sessions Court and his attention is drawn to his statements in the Committing Court, which are contrary to his present statements — Mere production and tendering of witness is not sufficient for the purpose Hafizullah and others Vs. The State 5 BLD (HCD) 185Ref. 15 DLR (Dhaka ) 5 17.

 

Section 145 — When a witness was examined by the Investigating Officer and he recorded the statement under Section 161 Cr.P.C. the Investigating Officer is to be examined to get what statements were made by the witness before him — Unless the Investigating Officer is examined it cannot be said that a hostile witness initially supported the prosecution case but subsequently resiled from it Abdul Wahah and another Vs. The State 6 BLD (HCD) 390

 

Section 145 — Statements before police — Such statements can never be used as substantive evidence either in favour of or against the accused and no order of conviction can be based on such statements Md. Nasir alias Nasir Vs. The State 9 BLD (HCD) 502.

 

Section 145 — Confronting a witness — No witness can be contradicted without first drawing his attention to his previous statement under Section 145 of the Evidence Act. The State Vs. Md. Hani/ Sheikh and others 11 BLD (AD) 77

 

Section 145 — First Information Report — It may be used to corroborate its maker under Section 157 of the Code of Criminal Procedure or to contradict him under Section 145 of the Evidence Act Fulu Mohammad and others Vs. The State 12 BLD (HCD) 357.

  

Section 146 — The fact of relationship is no ground to discard the testimony of witnesses in a case unless there are internal   marks  of falsehood   in their evidence. Majihar Rahman anil others Vs. The State 5 BLD (HCD) 110 Ref. 21 DLR 575; 24 DLR 217.

 

Section 154 — Hostile witness — Merely because the party calling a witness declares him hostile it cannot be inferred that he is not telling the truth or that he has been gained over bv the opposite party — On the basis of the evidence oh record the Court has to arrive at its own conclusion regarding the value to be attached to his evidence Yitnus AH and others Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 121.Ref. 15 DLR 517; 2 DLR 114: AIR 1931 (Cal)(FB)40l.

 

Section 154 — Evidentiary value of a hostile witness — A witness even if declared hostile can be relied upon by the Court if considering his entire evidence the Court is satisfied about his credibility Mil. Shah Alum anil others Vs. The State 5 BLD (AD) 198Ref. 3 BLD (HCD) 121 II DLR 316; AIR 1931 (Cal)401 (FB).

 

Section 154 — Hostile witness — The mere fact that the truth has been revealed and it has gone against the party calling him does not render his evidence unreliable wholly or in part — A witness is not necessarily hostile if he reveals the truth — The whole of his evidence so far as it affects both the parties, favorably or unfavorably, must be considered and the Court is at liberty to make assessment of the entire evidence - - If corroboration from other sources is available to the evidence of a hostile witness, there is no reason why his evidence should be rejected if it fits in with the attending circumstances and it may be accepted and considered along with other evidence Sitlt/it/ue Munshi Vs. The State 12 BLD (AD) 591.Ref. 5 BLD (AD) 198, 13 DLR 414; 7 DLR 395. PLD 1971 (SC) 713.

 

Section 155 Credibility of a witness A Court fnay take into consideration a pan of the evidence of a witness which gels support from other evidence and the attending facts and circumstances of the case - The entire evidence of a witness should noi be excluded from considera­tion simply on the ground that the witness made contradictory statements Nurul Islam anil others Vs. The State 7 BLD (HCD) 193Ref.  29 DLR (AD) 221; 27 DLR 671.DLR 247. X DLR (FC) 69.

 

Section 156 Circumstantial corrobo-ration Effect of — The fact ofrecovery of money almost of the sameamount soon after the victim was robbed of lends circumstantial corroboration tothe evidence of identification of the accused by the victim Shahitlullah anila nother Iv. The State 7 BLD (AD) 27.

 

Section  157 — Statement of the victim The statement of a victim girl soon after the commission of the offence is legally admissible as corroboration — Its value and weight is. however, a different matter Abdul Quddus and another Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 10.

 

1288

G.D. ENTRY

Citation: 8 BLD (AD) 93

Subject: G.D. ENTRY

Delivery Date: 2018-07-30

G.D. ENTRY

 

G.D. Entry — Value of G.D. Entry — A timely G.D. Entry strengthens the alle­gations made in the complaint and its absence may create doubt about it. Md Shamsuddin alias Lambu and others Vs. The State and others 8 BLD (AD) 93

1289

GENERAL CLAUSES ACT, 1897

Citation: 3 BLD (HCD) 308 Ref. 20 DLR (SC) 315; 21 DLR (SC) 123, 6 BLD (HCD) 34.Ref. 30 DLR 49,

Case Year: 1897

Subject: GENERAL CLAUSES

Delivery Date: 2018-08-27

GENERAL CLAUSES ACT(X OF 1897)

 

Repeal of Section 250(B) Cr.P.C. - Whether it affected the right of the accused to be discharged -— A privilege of an accused to obtain an order of discharge has been taken away by the repeal and as such the repeal would not affect the operation of the omitted provisions — The repealed provision is not a procedural one and it shall not affect the right of the accused or the power of the Magistrate to discharge accused persons — General Clauses Act (X of 1897) S 6(C) Didarul Alain and others Vs. The State and others. 3 BLD (HCD) 308 Ref. 20 DLR (SC) 315; 21 DLR (SC) 123.

 

Repeal of an enactment Us effect in a pending legal proceeding - In a pending proceeding the accused acquires a vested right to be tried under the law existing at the time when cognizance is taken — Even repeal of the law does not affect this right in the absence of a clear provision — The proceeding shall be continued as if the repealing Ordinance has not been made — General Clauses Act (X of 1897) S 6. The State Vs. Mokhul Hossain 6 BLD (HCD) 34.Ref. 30 DLR 49.

 

Words in the singular include the plural and vice versa — Section 13(2) of the General Clauses Act provides that in all enactments unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context, words in the singular shall include the plural and the vice versa and as such the expression "an enquiry" in Section 202 Cr.P.C. includes more than one enquiry to ascertain the truth or falsehood of the complaint — Code of Criminal Procedure (Y of r«W) S 202 — General Clauses Act (X of 1897) S 13(2) Sarwar Kama! and others Vs. The State and others 7 BLD (HCD) 129Ref. 34 DLR 424; 35 DLR 176; 36 DLR (AD) 58; 19 DLR (SC) 426; 13 DLR 9.

1290

Industrial Relations Ordinance, 1969

Citation: 11 MLR (2006) (HC) 386, 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 21, 13 MLR (2008) (HO) 275, 12 MLR (2007) (HC) 401, 11 MLR (2006) (HC) 220,

Case Year: 1969

Subject: Industrial Relations

Delivery Date: 2018-03-18

Industrial Relations

Ordinance, 1969

 

Section 18— Not applicable to dispute regarding cancellation of membership of the workers union—

Dispute relating to cancellation of the membership of the petitioner of the workers union does not fall within the purview of section 18 of the Industrial Relations Ordinance, 1969 and as such the suit in the civil court is held to be quite maintainable. Nasiniddin Ahmed Vs. G.M. Shahabuddin and others 11 MLR (2006) (HC) 386.

 

Section 34— Labour Court has the jurisdiction to decide the dispute relating to establishment of workers welfare fund—

Companies Profit (Workers) Participation Act, 1968—

Section 3— Management of Industrial undertaking is under the legal obligation of establishing the workers welfare fund—

Hotel and Restaurant being an industrial undertaking the management thereof is required under section 3 of the Companies Profit (Workers). Participation Act, 1968 to establish the workers welfare fund and implement the scheme thereunder. Labour court has the jurisdiction to decide the dispute relating to the implementation of the scheme under section 34 of the Industrial Relations Ordinance, 1969. Hotel Agrabad Ltd. Chitlagong represented by its Managing DircctorVs. Chairman First Labour Court, Chittagong and others 13 MLR (2008) (AD) 21.

 

Section 34— Provides for enforcement of rights created or guaranteed by or under any law—

Exparte order— While passing exparte order labour court is required to see that atleast minimum amount of evidence is brought on record in support of the claim of the complainant—

It is well settled that the provisions of "section 34 of the Industrial Relations Ordinance, 1969 can be invoked for enforcement of certain rights already created or guaranteed under any law. But the complainant is not entitled under this section to seek for creation or introduction of any right. Labour court is mandatorily required to see that atleast some evidence in support of the claim of the complainant are brought on record before passing exparte order. In the instant case the learned judges of the High Court Division having found these two essential conditions not fulfilled made the rule absolute declaring the impugned judgment and order passed without any lawful authority and of no legal effect. Sylhet Pulp and Paper Mills Ltd. respresented by its Managing Director Vs. Chairman, Second Labour Court, Chittagong and others 13 MLR (2008) (HO) 275.

 

Section 34— Employee of BADC is not worker within the meaning of Shops and Establishments and as such Labour Court has no jurisdiction to entertain any dispute relating to employee of BADC—

Suspension of an employee for long time without drawing up proceedings is held to be illegal and the period of suspension is declared to be on duty with the entitlement of all the arrear pays and allowances admissible under rules. Transfer of an employee during suspension is held to be illegal. Labour Court has no jurisdiction to decide dispute of employees of BADC and as such its judgment and order are declared illegal and of no legal effect. Bangladesh Agricultural Development Corporation Vs. Chairman 2nd Labour Court and others 12 MLR (2007) (HC) 401.

 

 

Section 47-B— Protection against transfer of worker for trade union activities.

Section 47-B of the Industrial Relations Ordinance, 1965 provides protection of a worker against transfer on ground of trade union activities. When the writ petitioner was singled out and was transferred on ground of union activities, and the High Court Division stayed the operation of the transfer order, and the respondent in violation of the stay order terminated his service which the learned judges held to be malafide and declared both the transfer order and the termination order as illegal and passed without any lawful authority. It is further held that the alternative remedy in the labour court being not efficacious the writ petition is quite maintainable. Faniquc Hasan Vs. Titas Gas Transmission and Distribution Company Ltd. and others 11 MLR (2006) (HC) 220.

1291

LAW REFORMS ORDINANCE , 1978

Citation: 1 BLD (HCD) 52, 3 BLD (HCD) 277Ref. 19DLR(SC)241, 6BLD (AD) 337Ref. 19 DLR (SC) 242; AIR 1958 (All) 439; AIR 1933 (Cal) 551; AIR 1944 (FC) 1; AIR 1920 (Mad) 337 (FB); AIR 1950 (All) 369, 1 BLD (HCD) 52, 3 BLD (HCD) 277 Ref. 19 DLR (SC) 241, 6 BLD (AD) 3

Case Year: 1878

Subject: LAW REFORMS

Delivery Date: 2018-08-27

LAW REFORMS ORDINANCE (XLIX OF 1978)

 

Section 4 (I) –Case traiable by thesession jadge __The Session Judges hold an enquiry' under Section 202(2A) Cr.P.C after issuance of process after the Law reforms Ordinance. 1978 came into force — Under the present law the Magistrate is now to send the case to the Court of Sessions under Section 205C of the Code of Criminal Procedure Abdul Bari Vs. The State 1 BLD (HCD) 52.

 

Section 4 — Trial without the aid of the assessors — The case record was sent to the Court of Sessions on 15 6.77 — The Law reforms Ordinance came into force on 6.1.79 and trial started with the framing of formal charge on 16.3.81 — Trial held without the aid of assessors is not bad in law Mahitullah Pk. and others Vs. The State 3 BLD (HCD) 277Ref. 19DLR(SC)241.

 

Section 4 — It is true that with the taking of cognizance by the Sessions Judge a legal proceeding becomes pending but it will be too wide a proposition to say that with the taking of cognizance the trial itself becomes pending — In the instant case since all the accused appeared before the Court on 16.3.81 and the case was taken up for hearing that marks the beginning of the pendency of the trial — The High Court Division was justified in holding that there was no illegality in the trial without the aid of assessors Mahitullah Sk. alias Mohitulalh and others Vs. The State 6BLD (AD) 337Ref. 19 DLR (SC) 242; AIR 1958 (All) 439; AIR 1933 (Cal) 551; AIR 1944 (FC) 1; AIR 1920 (Mad) 337 (FB); AIR 1950 (All) 369.

 

Case triable by the Court of Sessi

 

— Magistrate cannot hold an enq under Section 202(2A) after issuanc process Since no enquiry under chapter X Cr.P C was pending on the date the reforms  Ordinance   came   into  Section 4( I) of that Ordinance ha application in the case _In a case where process has all been issued, the object of an en under sub-section (2A) of 202, under the old law or be it law. unde law amended by the Ordinance, has achieved and there is no scope to further enquiry under Sub-section notwithstanding the proviso added t session Magistrat 'es only duty now is to c with the provision of new Section Cr.P.C. and then send the case Court of Sessions under new « 205C and to do all that he is requ under that Section — Code of C Procedure (V of 1898) Ss 202(2Aj and 200C — Law reforms Ord 1978 S 4(1) Abdul Bari Vs. Th 1 BLD (HCD) 52.

 

Trial without the aid of asses Case records were sent to the C Sessions on   15 5.77 — Law Ordinance came into force on 1.6 trial started with the framing of charge on 16. 3. 81 — Trial wit aid of assessors is not illegal reforms Ordinance (XLIX of 19 Mahitullah Pk and others V State 3 BLD (HCD) 277 Ref. 19 DLR (SC) 241.

 

Sessions Trial — When it becomes pending — It will be too wide a proposition to say that with the taking of cognizance the trial of a case becomes pending — In the instant case all the accused appeared and the case was taken up for hearing on 16.3.81 — This date makes the beginning of the pendency of the trial — If the case was not taken out of the trial list on 15 8.1978, there would have been no difficulty in holding that the trial was to be held under the old law but since the case went out of the trial list and all the accused appeared and the date was fixed for trial on 16 3.1981. the trial actually started on that date — Law reforms Ordinance (XLIX of 1978) S 4 Mohitullah Sk. alias Mohitullah and others Vs. The State 6 BLD (AD) 337.Ref. 19 DLR (SC) 242; AIR 1958 (All) 439, AIR 1933 (Cal) 551; AIR 1944 (FC) 1; AIR 1920 (Mad) 337 (FB) and AIR 1950 (All) 369.

1292

TEST IDENTIFICATION PARADE (T.I PARADE)

Citation: 5 BLD (HCD) 151, 7BLD(AD)27, 8 BLD (HCD) 396 Ref. AIR 1925 (All) 223, 9 BLD (HCD) 461, 9 BLD (HCD) 485.

Subject: TEST IDENTIFICATION PARADE (T.I PARADE)

Delivery Date: 2018-08-12

TEST IDENTIFICATION PARADE (T.I PARADE)

T.L Parade — Its value — Law is that the evidence of identification held at the stage of investigation can be used only to corroborate the substantive evidence giv­ing by the witnesses before the court — The value of identification in a T.I. parade depends on the effectiveness of precau­tions taken against the identifying witness having an opportunity of seeing the per­sons to be identified before the parade — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 9. Hazrat Ali and others Vs. The State 5 BLD (HCD) 151.

 

T.I. Parade — Value of — In the ab­sence of the Magistrate who held the T.I Parade, the defence would not cross-examine him in respect of the proceedings of the T.I. Parade and this greatly reduces the value of the T.I. Parade.

 

T.I. Parade was held after the witness had seen the accused in the police sta­tion —In the circumstances the T.I. Parade is a matter of no consequence and the prosecution derives no benefit out of it — Evidence Act (1 of 1872) S 9. Shahidullah and another Vs. The State 7BLD(AD)27.

 

Identification of accused — The way to establish identification — One way to establish identification when a witness at the trial is no longer able to recognize the accused, although he identified the ac­cused in the T.I. Parade is by putting the witnesses’ statement before the Commit­ting Magistrate under Section 288 Cr.P.C. and the other method is to elicit from him at the trial a statement that he identified certain persons at the jail and that the per­sons whom he identified there were the persons whom he had seen taking part in the dacoity — If the witness is prepared to swear this, then it is often to the court to establish by other evidnce the identity of the accused. For this purpose the best evidence will be that of the Magistrate who conducted the T.I. Parade — Evidence Act (I of 1872) S 9. Rattan Kha alias Rattan and others Vs. The State 8 BLD (HCD) 396 Ref. AIR 1925 (All) 223.

                 

Test Identification — Question of its veracity — When the witness failed to divulge the name of the accused and the factum of its identification even after one year of the date of occurrence, no reliance can be placed on his identification in the T.I. Parade — Evidence Act (I of 1872) S 9. Abdul Mannan Miah alias Mannan Gain Vs. The State 9 BLD (HCD) 461.

 

When identification of the accused becomes unreliable — The accused was produced in the court on various occa­sions before holding of the T.I Parade and it was possible for the witnesses to see him in the Court — The Magistrate who conducted the T.I. Parade has not been examined and there is no material to find that the parade was conducted after observing the legal formalities — The identification of the accused is therefore found to be unreliable. Angur Vs. The State 9 BLD (HCD) 485.
